DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-128. - Oath to be taken by officers. 
Every officer of the village shall, before entering upon his duties, take the oath of his office, as prescribed by the statutes. 
(Code 1940, § 10.007; Code 1964, § 02-3) 
State Law reference— Oath of municipal officers generally, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25; oath of municipal officers in managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-9.  
Sec. 2-129. - Bonds for officers and employees generally. 
All bonds for village officers shall be for the period of their appointment and, in the case of an employee, it shall be for one year, and shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance of such person's duty and the payment of all monies received by him according to all laws of the state and ordinances of the village. Premiums for all such bonds shall be paid by the village. 
(Code 1940, § 10.015; Code 1964, § 02-4) 
State Law reference— Bond, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30; officer oath and bond in managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25.  
Sec. 2-130. - Officers to surrender books and records upon termination of office. 
Every officer of the village, upon the termination of his term of office for any cause whatsoever, shall deliver to his successor all books and records which may be the property of the village. If no successor is appointed within one week after the termination of such term of office, such property shall be delivered either to the village clerk or the village manager. 
(Code 1940, § 10.010; Code 1964, § 02-6) 
State Law reference— Duty to successor, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-35.  
Sec. 2-131. - Officials' names and images on signage prohibited. 
The name or image of any elected or appointed village official shall not be permitted to appear on the exterior of any village building, the exterior of any village structure, the exterior of any village motor vehicle, or any exterior village sign. 
(Ord. No. 2007-20, 3-12-2007)  
Sec. 2-132. - Travel, meal and lodging expense reimbursement. 
Consistent with the Local Governmental Travel Expense Control Act (P.A. 99-0604) the village allows and will reimburse Village officers and employees for reasonable authorized travel expenses, including meal and lodging expenses, incurred by them in the performance of their duties. This section regulates the reimbursement of all travel, meal, and lodging expenses of officers and employees of the village. 
(1)  Applicability. This section applies to every officer and employee of the village including, but not limited to, all full-time, part-time and temporary employees of the village and all elected officials of the village and appointed board, commission or committee members of the village. 
(2)  Definitions. 
Corporate authorities means the president and the trustees of the village. 
Entertainment includes, but is not limited to, shows, amusements, theaters, circuses, sporting events, or any other place of public or private entertainment or amusement, unless ancillary to the purpose of the program or event. 
Travel means any expenditure directly incident to official travel by employees and officers of the village involving reimbursement to travelers or direct payment to private agencies providing transportation or related services. 
Village means the Village of Brookfield, Illinois. 
(3)  Official business for which expense reimbursement is permitted. 
a.  Village officers and employees are permitted to be reimbursed for the travel, meal and lodging expenses in the following instances: 
1.  Official business travel — Travel that takes the village officer or employee outside of the village relating to official business of the village that is designed to further development, legislation, governance and administration of the village. 
2.  Training and professional/educational travel — Travel that takes the village officer or employee outside of the village related to the attendance at seminars, conferences, workshops, conventions and the like designed to further training, education and professional development of village officers or employees, directly related to their duties. 
3.  Official business meals — Meals eaten within or outside of the village during which the village officer or employee discusses official business of the village that is designed to further development, legislation, governance and administration of the village. 
b.  Commuting to a location within the village and to and from an officer's or employee's normal place of business does not constitute a reimbursable travel expense. 
(4)  Travel, meal and lodging expense authorization. Prior to incurring a travel, meal or lodging expense for which reimbursement is sought, village officers and employees are required to complete the travel authorization form set forth in subsection (8) below. Travel, meal or lodging expenses by employees (except for department heads) must be authorized in advance by the department head and the village manager. Travel, meal or lodging expenses by department heads must be authorized in advance by the village manager. Travel, meal or lodging expenses by village officers (except for the corporate authorities) must be authorized in advance by the village manager. Travel, meal or lodging expenses by the corporate authorities must be authorized in advance by the corporate authorities by a roll call vote at an open meeting of the corporate authorities. 
(5)  Travel, meal and lodging expense reimbursement approval. Within ten days after the return from travel, or in the absence of travel within ten days after incurring the expense, the village officer or employee must complete a travel expense reimbursement form set forth in subsection (9) below supported by the required documentation and submit the form to the village manager. Any travel reimbursement submitted after ten days must include an explanation of the delay. Only delays caused by reasonable circumstances will be approved for reimbursement. Travel, meal and lodging expenses of village officers (except for the corporate authorities) and employees that do not exceed the maximum allowable reimbursement amounts established in this section 2-132 may be approved by the village manager. In the case of emergency or other extraordinary circumstances, travel, meal and lodging expenses that exceed the maximum allowable reimbursement amounts established by this section 2-132 may be approved. All travel, meal and lodging expenses of the corporate authorities and travel, meal and lodging expenses of village officers or employees that exceed the maximum allowable reimbursement amounts established in this section 2-132 shall be approved by the corporate authorities by a roll call vote at an open meeting of the corporate authorities. 
(6)  General travel expense requirements and permitted rates of reimbursement. 
a.  General requirements. 
1.  Village officers and employees are required to utilize all reasonable forms of technology, including, but not limited to, internet, teleconferencing and webinars, to lessen travel expenses incurred. 
2.  The village shall reimburse allowable, authorized travel expenses for official business identified under section 2-132(3) and incurred in the performance of village duties, conditioned on the financial ability of the village and within the budgetary constraints established by the corporate authorities. 
3.  Village officials and employees shall exercise good judgment and proper regard for public funds when incurring travel expenses and when representing the village, by only authorizing the minimum number of staff necessary when travel is required. Personal items and other non-business/non-professional related expenses are not reimbursable. Personnel policies apply when conducting village business, regardless of location. 
4.  In order to minimize the village's total cost per trip, village officers and employees are encouraged to maximize the use of reduced-fare promotions. While travelers are not normally permitted to leave early or stay longer than designated business requires at village expense, they are encouraged to take advantage of reduced fares whenever possible. This may mean leaving in advance, or possibly staying longer. The total cost savings should take into account lost productivity if normal working time is missed. This lengthened stay may be permissible when it can be documented that the net effect is a lower total cost for a trip. This cost saving statement shall be entered on the travel authorization form. 
5.  Persons receiving reimbursement for all incurred expenses shall not receive reimbursement for the same expense from any other public or private source. Officers or employees who sign claims for reimbursement of expenses or who request payment of charges that have been incurred on a credit card or by any other means shall certify that they are the individuals that incurred the expense and that the village is the only entity that will receive a claim for reimbursement of the specific expense. 
b.  Transportation expenses. 
1.  Mode of transportation. Usual local and long distance modes of transportation to destinations authorized for travel in the course of Village business include automobiles, airlines, railroads, buses, taxicabs, ride share services and limousines. In all cases, travel should be by the most economical mode of transportation available, considering travel time and work requirements. 
2.  Routing of travel. Travel shall be by the most direct route. Travel by other routes is allowed when required by the individual's official duties, safety considerations and unusual circumstances. Expenses due to deviations for convenience shall be borne by the officer or employee. Explanations of unusual circumstances shall be reflected in the comment section of the travel expense reimbursement form. Higher cost travel interruptions for individual convenience are not reimbursable. 
3.  Commercial transportation. Individuals will be reimbursed for actual and necessary costs of transportation by airline, railroad or other common carrier following these guidelines: 
(i)  Commercial common carriers. Use of common carriers such as airlines, trains and buses will be reimbursed at actual cost, not to exceed coach fare. Upgrades to higher fares and first class travel will only be considered in emergencies and must be preapproved by the village board and supported by a written statement detailing the circumstances that created the extraordinary expenditure. In all cases, a traveler shall attempt to secure the lowest fare available given scheduling requirements. 
(ii)  Taxicab and ride sharing service fares. Taxicab and ride-sharing service (such as Uber, Lyft, etc.) fares are reimbursable at the actual cost of the fare. Receipts for fares are required for reimbursement. If free van, bus or shuttle service is available and convenient, they are recommended for use in lieu of taxicabs or ride sharing services. 
(iii)  Limousine. Use of a limousine service is reimbursable when there is an economic cost benefit compared to the use of alternative transportation, including parking costs, and must be approved by the village manager in advance. Limousine services will not be reimbursed where it can be demonstrated that use of other transportation can be more cost effective. 
(iv)  Vehicle rentals. A rental vehicle is not to be used as a personal convenience. The rental of an automobile while on travel status is allowed, if circumstances require. The most economical vehicle available that is suitable for the village's business shall be obtained. The collision damage waiver and personal accident insurance on rented vehicles are not reimbursable. Vehicle rentals must be identified on the travel authorization form and preapproved by the village manager. Failure to receive preapproval may result in non-reimbursement. Rental vehicle reimbursement is limited to: 
(a)  A situation that occurs where the traveler's final geographic destination is remote to the transportation terminal and there is no other cost effective conveyance from the common carrier terminal. 
(b)  A situation where there are three or more village travelers and it is cost effective to rent a vehicle in lieu of the total actual round trip cost of the taxi, limousine, etc., for each traveler. 
(c)  A situation where timely flight connections can only be made by utilizing a short-term car rental. 
(v)  Private conveyance. The use of a privately owned means of transportation for village business is permitted when such use is necessary or desirable due to a lack of other convenient means of transportation, or is otherwise advantageous to the village. 
4.  Personal automobiles. Use of personal automobiles for travel will be reimbursed for miles driven at the rate established by the Internal Revenue Service ("IRS") Standard Mileage Rate for Business in effect at the time of travel. The IRS mileage rate is intended to cover the following expenses: gasoline, normal wear and tear on the vehicle, insurance, and any vehicle damage. In the case of a vehicle accident, the employee's insurance policy will be considered to be the primary insurance coverage. 
(i)  Mileage reimbursement for personal automobile use is limited to travel outside of the village. The official or employee is required to document the mileage by providing a printout from a reliable map source (i.e., MapQuest, Google Earth, Yahoo Maps, etc.) and must attach the printout to the travel expense reimbursement form. 
(ii)  When two or more employees travel in one vehicle, reimbursement will be made to only one employee. The names of all travelers shall be indicated on the travel expense reimbursement form. 
(iii)  Where a personal automobile is used, the mileage allowance is not to exceed the related cost of coach airfare. Reimbursement shall be limited to the lower of coach air fare or actual miles driven times the prevailing IRS Standard Mileage Rate. 
(iv)  Employees using personal automobiles for travel on Village business must have insurance coverage in an amount not less than that required by Section 10-101(b) of the Illinois Vehicle Code [625 ILCS 5/10-101(b)]. The Village Manager shall require employees to file a statement certifying that they are duly licensed and carry at least the minimum insurance coverage. 
5.  Village vehicles. Village vehicles may be used for local travel. Village vehicles should not be used for out-of-state trips where the final destination is more than 100 miles outside of the village, unless it is shown to be the cheaper transportation alternative. Gasoline required for the continued use of a village vehicle where the village's gas pump cannot be used is reimbursable at the actual cost of the expense with receipts required. 
6.  Incidental auto expenses. Certain costs associated with the use of personal or village vehicles are reimbursable. The cost of automobile parking fees, bridge, road and tunnel tolls shall be allowed at the actual cost. The fee for parking a vehicle at a common carrier terminal, or other parking area, while the traveler is away shall be allowed only to the extent that the fees, plus the allowable mileage reimbursement to and from the terminal area, does not exceed the estimated cost for use of a limousine or taxicab to and from the terminal. Receipts or a printout of an I-PASS account showing time and date are acceptable for reimbursement of tolls paid. 
7.  Reimbursement for transportation in excess of established rates. Reimbursement for transportation in excess of the rates established in this section 2-132(6)b. must be authorized in advance and approved for reimbursement by the corporate authorities by a roll call vote at an open meeting of the corporate authorities. 
c.  Lodging expenses. 
1.  It is the responsibility of each village officer and employee to request the lowest available lodging rate at the time of making reservations. However, a person who due to a handicap may require special lodging consideration may be reimbursed for the actual cost of the least costly lodging that is substantially accessible. Special seminar, conference or government rates shall be sought. 
2.  Lodging reimbursement shall be at actual cost consistent with facilities available and proximity to the location of a conference, seminar or business meeting. Where multiple occupancy involving a spouse and/or other family members has occurred, the village officer or employee may only claim the actual and necessary cost of his or her single occupancy at a single rate. If no single rate exists, the lowest double rate shall be reimbursed. 
3.  Lodging provided by a friend, relative or non-invoicing organization is not reimbursable. 
4.  The number of nights for which an employee may obtain reimbursement will be limited to the number necessary to conduct village business, unless the officer of employee is utilizing a reduced-fare promotion in accordance with section 2-132(6)a.4. of this policy. For those conferences or meetings that begin in the morning, arrival the night before reimbursable. For conferences or meetings that end after 5:00 p.m., lodging expenses for that night will also be reimbursed. Employees are encouraged to return home on the final day of the conference whenever possible. 
5.  Longer stays where lodging is reimbursable are permitted if they result in a significant savings in travel costs, and must be preapproved by the village manager. (See section 2-132(6)a.4.). The employee requesting the reimbursement must document the net savings if longer stays are requested, including the lodging expense and meals. Lost work time should also be taken into account when calculating the cost savings. 
6.  It is not considered prudent to use public funds for overnight lodging within a 75-mile radius of the village; therefore, it is not normally reimbursed. Exceptions to this policy would be: 
(i)  If documented business meetings extend past 8:00 p.m. and then resume again at 8:00 a.m. the next morning. Business meetings, in this instance, do not include dinners, receptions or social functions sponsored for attendees during the evening hours. Employees may attend these functions, at their own expense, and if they choose to remain away from home overnight, lodging expenses will not be reimbursed. Prior approval of the corporate authorities must be obtained for any planned overnight stay within the 75-mile radius. Failure to gain prior approval may result in non-reimbursement. 
(ii)  If weather conditions make a return trip unsafe, then an overnight stay may be reimbursable. 
7.  For each day of an overnight stay, one personal telephone call of reasonable duration will be reimbursed on a lodging bill, telephone credit card or separate cell phone bill. Necessary business calls will be reimbursable. 
8.  Personal items such as movie rentals, clothes cleaning, etc., are not reimbursable. 
9.  Reimbursement for lodging in excess of two times the per diem rates published by the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA) Domestic Per Diem Rates (effective October 1 of each year) (see www.gsa.gov/perdiem), exclusive of taxes and fees, must be authorized in advance and approved for reimbursement by the corporate authorities by a roll call vote at an open meeting of the corporate authorities. 
d.  Meal expenses. Expenses for breakfast, lunch and dinner amounts will be reimbursed in accordance with the meals and incidental expenses (M&IE) breakdown established by the GSA. (See www.gsa.gov.) Reimbursement for expenses for meals shall not exceed the per diem amounts set forth in the published U.S. General Services Administration (GSA) Domestic Per Diem Rates (effective October 1 of each year). (See www.gsa.gov/perdiem.) The meals and incidental expense (M&IE) rate will be paid based on the destination location of authorized travel. 
1.  Breakfast is reimbursable when an officer or employee is traveling and leaves the village or his or her personal residence (if reporting directly to the destination) at or before 6:00 a.m. 
2.  Lunch is reimbursable when an officer or employee is traveling and leaves the village or his or her personal residence (if reporting directly to the destination) at or before 12:00 noon. 
3.  Dinner is reimbursable when an officer or employee is traveling and arrives back at the village offices or his or her personal residence (if reporting directly from destination) at or after 7:00 p.m. For employees commencing travel after close of business, but before 6:30 p.m., dinner reimbursement may be allowed. 
4.  Reimbursement for meals in excess of the per diem rates published by the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA) Domestic Per Diem Rates (effective October 1 of each year) (see www.gsa.gov/perdiem) must be authorized in advance and approved for reimbursement by the corporate authorities by a roll call vote at an open meeting of the corporate authorities. 
e.  Special expenses. 
1.  Registration fees and materials related to professional/educational activities. 
(i)  Actual registration fee expenditure and reimbursement is allowed for authorized attendance of professional/educational activities, with prior approval by the village manager. Advance registration should be used where the amount of the registration fee increases as the date of the event approaches. 
(ii)  Books and related materials such as conference tapes are reimbursable costs. The items purchased shall become the property of the village. 
2.  Service tips. Tips for services provided during travel not associated with meals (or requested elsewhere) shall be included for reimbursement on the travel expense reimbursement form. An officer or employee may request reimbursement up to 20 percent for documented tips and up to $5.00 for undocumented tips. 
3.  Village business meetings. The cost of village business related to special expenses incurred while hosting a meeting shall be reimbursable, when authorized by the village manager in advance and if reasonable, well-documented and budgeted. 
(i)  All special expenses shall be itemized and fully documented to include the actual village business transacted and the individuals and their affiliation. The actual cost of meals for other persons incurred in connection with official village business shall be allowed. 
(ii)  To be eligible for meal reimbursement of a guest, village business must have been discussed during the meal or immediately preceding or following the meal. 
(iii)  Two or more village employees dining together and discussing business will not constitute a reimbursable business meal. 
(iv)  Actual receipts are required to document reimbursements. 
(7)  Non-reimbursable expenses. The following expenses are non-reimbursable: 
a.  Alcoholic beverages; 
b.  Coat check; 
c.  Entertainment; 
d.  Late check-out and room guarantee charges; 
e.  Meals for other individuals, including other village employees or officers, except as provided in section 2-132(6)e.3.(ii); 
f.  Parking tickets or other traffic tickets; 
g.  Tips incurred beyond those specifically authorized in this section 2-132; and 
h.  Travel, meals, lodging or other expenses not authorized and approved for reimbursement according to this section 2-132. 
(8)  Travel authorization form. 
a.  Village officers and employees shall use the following travel authorization form to request that travel, meal or lodging be authorized for reimbursement:

1.  an estimate of the cost of travel, meals, or lodging; 
2.  the name of the individual who is requesting the travel, meal, or lodging expense; 
3.  the job title or office of the individual who is requesting the travel, meal, or lodging expense; and 
4.  the date or dates and nature of the official business in which the travel, meal, or lodging expense will be expended. 
(9)  Travel expense reimbursement form.

b.  The travel expense reimbursement form shall at a minimum contain the following information: 
1.  a receipt of the cost of travel, meals, or lodging; 
2.  the name of the individual who incurred the travel, meal, or lodging expense; 
3.  the job title or office of the individual who incurred the travel, meal, or lodging expense; and 
4.  the date or dates and nature of the official business in which the travel, meal, or lodging expense was expended. 
c.  Copies (or originals, if available) of receipts must be submitted as documentation in order for expenses to be reimbursable. In all cases, the detailed lodging bill and actual transportation ticket are required. Cash tips are to be included on the specific reimbursement line on the travel expense report and must be in compliance with section of this policy. 
d.  All receipts must show method of payment and that the services were paid for in full. For non-cash payments, receipt must show the name of the payee. 
(10)  Disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act. All documents and information submitted under this section are public records subject to disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act. 
(11)  Violations. Any village officer or employee who violates a provision of this section, fails to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who submits a false travel authorization form, travel expense reimbursement form or any false or altered document in support of a travel authorization form or a travel expense reimbursement form shall be subject to one or more of the following: 
a.  denial of reimbursement for the expense incurred: 
b.  for Village employees, disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment; and/or 
c.  a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $750.00 for each offense. 
(12)  Supersedes prior policies. This travel expense reimbursement policy of the village supersedes any prior policy or past practice of the village with respect to reimbursement of travel expenses. 
(Ord. No. 2017-12 , § 2, 3-13-2017)  
Secs. 2-133—2-160. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - VILLAGE MANAGER 
 
Sec. 2-161. - Appointment; qualifications. 
There is hereby established the office of village manager. The village manager shall be appointed for an indefinite term by the president and board of trustees, voting jointly. He shall be appointed without regard to his political beliefs and need not be a resident of the village when appointed. 
(Code 1964, §§ 02-30—02-32; Ord. of 1-14-1952, § 1) 
State Law reference— Municipal manager appointment, powers and duties, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-7.  
Sec. 2-162. - Powers and duties. 
The village manager shall be the administrative head of the government of the village and he shall be responsible for the efficient administration of all departments of the village. The powers and duties of the village manager shall be: 
(1)  To enforce the laws and ordinances within the village. 
(2)  To appoint and remove or suspend all directors of departments and the heads of divisions thereof. No appointments shall be made upon any basis other than that of merit and fitness. 
(3)  To exercise control of all departments of the village and divisions thereof. 
(4)  To attend all meetings of the board of trustees with the right to take part in the discussion, but with no right to vote. 
(5)  To recommend to the board of trustees for adoption such measures as he may deem necessary or expedient. 
(6)  To see that all terms and conditions imposed in favor of the village or its inhabitants in any contract or public utility franchise are faithfully kept and performed. 
(7)  To make or authorize to make in the ordinary course of business, all purchases of materials and supplies necessary for the village as provided for in the annual appropriation ordinance; provided that, on all purchases of more than $20,000.00, he shall first solicit bids, except in an emergency, and in all cases he shall comply with the statutory provisions as to the solicitation of bids. 
(8)  To have and exercise the power, authority and duties of any director of a department or division thereof prescribed by this Code or any amendment thereof, during the time when the office of any such director shall be vacant or no person shall have been appointed thereto. 
(9)  To act as agent for the local liquor control commissioner in all matters pertaining to the administration of the licensing and control of the sale of alcoholic liquors within the village and the administration of the statutes of the state and the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the village pertaining thereto. 
(10)  To issue all licenses and permits not otherwise provided for by state law. 
(11)  To appoint administrative assistants. 
(12)  To fix the compensation of all appointive officers and employees not otherwise provided for. 
(13)  To prescribe rules and regulations for the conduct of the various departments of the village and divisions thereunder. 
(14)  To authorize, by permit, the temporary closure of any street, sidewalk, alley or other public way or public place within the village for the conduct of any exhibition, block party, carnival, festival or other special event of limited duration. 
(15)  To issue all lawful licenses and permits not otherwise provided for by state law or by this Code. 
(16)  To perform such other duties as may be prescribed by state law or by this Code or any other ordinance or resolution of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1964, § 02-33; Ord. of 1-14-1952, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1974-45, § 1, 12-9-1974; Ord. No. 1978-20, § A, 6-26-1978; Ord. No. 1978-31, § A, 8-14-1978; Ord. No. 98-10, 2-09-1998; Ord. No. 2001-34, 7-23-2001; Ord. No. 2003-21, 6-23-2003; Ord. No. 2006-59, § 1, 7-10-2006; Ord. No. 2007-37, § 1, 4-23-2007). 
State Law reference— Municipal manager appointment, powers and duties, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-7.  
Sec. 2-163. - Compensation. 
The compensation of the village manager shall be as determined by the president and board of trustees, but shall, in no case, exceed the amount provided in the annual appropriation ordinance of the village in any fiscal year. 
(Code 1964, § 02-34; Ord. of 1-14-1952, § 7)  
Sec. 2-164. - Acting manager. 
In the case of the absence or disability of the village manager, the assistant village manager or another qualified administrative officer of the village, as designated by the president and board of trustees, shall perform the duties of the village manager during such absence or disability. 
(Code 1964, § 02-35; Ord. of 1-14-1952, § 1; Ord. of 6-12-1967, § 1)  
Sec. 2-165. - Removal from office. 
The village manager may at any time be removed from office by a majority vote of the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1964, § 02-36; Ord. of 1-14-1952, § 1)  
Secs. 2-166—2-183. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - ASSISTANT VILLAGE MANAGER 
 
Sec. 2-184. - Appointment; term. 
There is hereby established the office of assistant village manager. The assistant village manager shall be appointed by the village manager. The assistant village manager shall be appointed for an indefinite term. 
(Code 1964, § 02-30; Ord. of 6-12-1967, § 2)  
Sec. 2-185. - General duties. 
The assistant village manager shall act in the place of the village manager during his absence or disability and shall exercise the powers and duties of the village manager during such absence or disability. He shall further perform such duties as shall be prescribed by the village manager or any ordinance or resolution of the board of trustees. The assistant village manager shall also be responsible for the oversight of information technology (IT) projects and shall serve as the village's liaison with the village's IT provider. The assistant village manager shall also have oversight responsibilities for the village's website, social media outlets and cable television stations. 
(Code 1964, § 02-30; Ord. of 6-12-1967, § 2; Ord. No. 2019-11 , § 2, 2-11-2019)

DIVISION 4. - VILLAGE ATTORNEY[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Appointment officers in all municipalities, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-5. 
 
Sec. 2-209. - Appointment as officer or independent contractor. 
There is hereby established the position of village attorney. The village attorney shall be appointed by the president and the appointment shall be confirmed by the board of trustees. The village attorney may serve as an officer or as an independent contractor. 
(Code 1940, §§ 14.001, 14.002; Code 1964, § 02-42; Ord. of 1-14-1952, § 10; Ord. No. 1981-18, 4-27-1981; Ord. No. 1989-14, 5-8-1989)  
Sec. 2-210. - Term of office. 
The village attorney shall hold office until his successor shall be appointed and qualified. 
(Code 1940, § 14.003; Code 1964, § 02-43; Ord. of 5-8-1961, § 1; Ord. No. 1981-18, 4-27-1981)  
Sec. 2-211. - Duties. 
(a)  The village attorney shall be responsible for all legal matters pertaining to the village unless otherwise provided in this section. The village attorney shall: 
(1)  Give necessary attention to all suits and proceedings in every court of record and before other regulatory bodies in which the village may be a party or directly interested. 
(2)  Appear as the attorney on behalf of any officer of the village in any suit, prosecution or other judicial proceeding brought by or against such officer in his official capacity and, as the case may be, prosecute or defend to the termination thereof. 
(3)  Render legal opinions when requested by the president or board of trustees on all questions concerning village interests. 
(4)  Act on behalf of the village in those matters involving condemnation procedures, easements and vacations of properties for municipal purposes. 
(5)  Act on behalf of the village in those matters pertaining to local improvements to be paid for by special taxation. 
(6)  Perform such duties or special service which the president and the board of trustees may require. 
(b)  Nothing in this Code shall be construed as prohibiting the board of trustees from employing special counsel to represent the village for such purposes or at such compensation as the board of trustees may from time to time determine. 
(Code 1940, § 14.004; Code 1964, § 02-44; Ord. of 1-14-1952, § 10; Ord. No. 1978-5, § 1, 3-27-1978; Ord. No. 1981-18, 4-27-1981; Ord. No. 1989-14, 5-8-1989)  
Sec. 2-212. - Attendance at meetings; reports. 
(a)  The village attorney shall attend those meetings of the board of trustees as so directed by the president and board of trustees, and of official boards, commissions and committees of the village on occasion and as may be directed from time to time by the president and board of trustees. 
(b)  On or before its first meeting in April of each year, he shall make a report in writing to the board of trustees of all suits, proceedings or actions prosecuted or defended by him during the preceding year, with the names of the parties thereto, the titles of the courts or other bodies where same are pending, of their progress and final disposition, and such other information concerning the legal interests of the village as may be required by the president or board of trustees. 
(c)  The village attorney shall make such other reports on pending matters or other matters of legal concern as the president and board of trustees from time to time require. 
(Code 1964, § 02-45; Ord. No. 1989-14, 5-8-1989)  
Sec. 2-213. - Compensation. 
(a)  The village attorney shall be paid an hourly rate, salary or retainer as shall be fixed from time to time by the board of trustees and in addition thereto, such compensation as the village board may authorize or subsequently approve from time to time necessarily spent in the preparation and trial of all proceedings in all courts of record and before other regulatory bodies in which the village may be party or directly interested. 
(b)  The village attorney, while acting as the attorney for the board of local improvements, shall receive compensation as shall be fixed separately from time to time by the board of trustees; however, such compensation shall be paid for from warrants and vouchers of the special assessment and not from monies of the general fund. However, if the proposed improvement shall be abandoned before or after the awarding of any contract, he shall receive no compensation for work done in connection with such proceeding, unless so authorized by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1940, § 14.005; Code 1964, § 02-46; Ord. of 5-8-1961; Ord. No. 1978-5, § 2, 3-27-1978; Ord. No. 1981-18, 4-27-1981; Ord. No. 1989-14, 5-8-1989)  
Secs. 2-214—2-234. - Reserved.

DIVISION 6. - VILLAGE CLERK 
 
Sec. 2-270. - Election; term of office. 
There shall be elected a village clerk as provided by state law. The clerk shall serve for a four-year term as provided by statute. 
(Code 1940, § 9.001; Code 1964, § 02-51) 
State Law reference— Election or appointment of clerk generally, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-25-90; municipal clerk and treasurer in managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-12.  
Sec. 2-271. - Bond. 
The village clerk shall furnish a bond for the faithful performance of his duties as such clerk in the penal sum of $1,000.00, either with a reputable bonding house or with two sureties, who shall attach their names to the affidavit showing their respective qualifications to serve as sureties, and to be approved by the village board. 
(Code 1940, § 9.007; Code 1964, § 02-52) 
State Law reference— Bond, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-30; bond of officers in managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-9.  
Sec. 2-272. - General duties. 
The village clerk shall be ex officio clerk of the board of trustees and, in addition to the duties required to be performed by the clerk of the board as set forth in the state statutes, it shall be his duty to: 
(1)  Keep his office at the village hall during such hours as may be prescribed by the village board; 
(2)  Make copies of all ordinances, resolutions and other papers duly filed in his office, and transcripts from the journal and other records and files of his office, certified by him under the corporate seal, to be furnished to any of the trustees or officers of the village without the payment of any fee therefor, and to be furnished to all other persons upon the payment of the fee therefor prescribed by the village board; and 
(3)  Perform such other duties and functions as may be prescribed by the village board. 
(Code 1940, §§ 9.002, 9.003; Code 1964, § 02-53) 
State Law reference— Duties of municipal clerk generally, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90 et seq.  
Sec. 2-273. - Docketing and filing official documents. 
It shall be the duty of the village clerk to docket and file in regular order all official documents coming into his custody and control as such officer, filing the same in such manner that they can be referred to at all times. 
(Code 1940, § 9.004; Code 1964, § 02-54)  
Sec. 2-274. - Compensation. 
The compensation of the clerk of the village shall be $3,600.00 annually, payable $300.00 monthly. The salary of the village clerk shall be increased ten percent every four years beginning with the full term of office, effective immediately following the general election of April 20, 1993. 
(Code 1940, § 9.006; Code 1964, § 02-55; Ord. of 2-28-1949, § 1; Ord. of 1-26-1953, § 1; Ord. of 2-24-1964, § 1; Ord. No. 1973-03, § 1(b), 4-16-1973; Ord. No. 93-3, 2-8-1993)

No money shall be paid by the treasurer otherwise than upon such warrants so drawn, except as otherwise provided in this Code. 
(Code 1940, § 11.007; Code 1964, § 02-68; Ord. of 5-17-1948, § 1)  
Sec. 2-336. - Books and accounts.

(Code 1940, § 11.009; Code 1964, § 02-69)  
Sec. 2-337. - Reports.

(Code 1940, § 11.010; Code 1964, § 02-70)

ARTICLE V. - DEPARTMENTS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference— Departments and officers in managerial form of government, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-8. 
 
Sec. 2-391. - Established. 
The executive and administrative powers and duties of the village shall be distributed and exercised through the following departments: 
(1)  Administration department. 
(2)  Finance department. 
(3)  Department of public works and services. 
(4)  Fire department. 
(5)  Police department. 
(Code 1964, § 02-85; Ord. of 1-14-1952, § 3)  
Sec. 2-392. - Department heads. 
The supervision of the village departments shall be under the direction of the department directors appointed by the village manager. 
(Code 1964, § 02-86; Ord. of 1-14-1952, § 3)  
Sec. 2-393. - Duties, qualifications and compensation of department and division heads. 
The duties, qualifications and compensation of the directors of the various village departments and the heads of divisions thereunder shall be as determined by ordinance and by the regulations provided in this Code and by state law. 
(Code 1964, § 02-90; Ord. of 1-14-1952, § 8)  
Sec. 2-394. - Department of administration. 
The department of administration, under the direction of the assistant village manager, shall include all of the administrative functions of the village exclusive of those assigned to other departments, and shall contain the following divisions: 
(1)  Division of general services, which shall include all matters pertaining to office administration, personnel administration and clerical services. 
(2)  Division of inspection under the chief building inspector, which shall include all matters pertaining to the inspection of the construction and alteration of buildings, and all matters pertaining to electrical installations and repairs and plumbing installations and repairs. 
(3)  Division of health, which shall include the health officer and the sanitarian and all matters pertaining to health and sanitation. 
(4)  Division of engineering, which shall include all matters pertaining to engineering work. 
(5)  Division of building and zoning, which shall include under the supervisor of building and zoning all matters pertaining to the enforcement of the dwelling code, subdivision control and zoning. 
(Code 1964, § 02-87; Ord. of 1-14-1952, § 4; Ord. No. 2019-11 , § 3, 2-11-2019)  
Sec. 2-395. - Department of finance. 
The finance department, under the direction of the finance director, shall include matters pertaining to finance and shall contain the following divisions: 
(1)  Division of accounts under the finance officer, which shall include all matters pertaining to the finances of the village except those delegated to the village treasurer. 
(2)  Division of treasury under the village treasurer, which shall include those matters pertaining to the custody and authorized disbursement of village funds. 
(Code 1964, § 02-87; Ord. of 1-14-1952, § 4)  
Sec. 2-396. - Department of public works and services. 
The department of public works and services, under the director of public works and services, shall include matters pertaining to public works and services, and shall contain the following divisions: 
(1)  Division of water, which shall include all matters pertaining to the water supply and sewage systems of the village. 
(2)  Division of streets, which shall include all matters pertaining to the public streets and alleys. 
(3)  Division of equipment maintenance, which shall include the operation of the village garage. 
(4)  Division of recreation, which shall include all matters relating to village recreation and leisure facilities and activities. 
(Code 1964, § 02-88; Ord. of 1-14-1952, § 5)  
Sec. 2-397. - Department of fire. 
The department of fire, under the fire chief, shall include all matters pertaining to fire protection in the village. 
(Ord. No. 2019-11 , § 4, 2-11-2019) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2019-11 , § 4, adopted Feb. 11, 2019, amended § 2-397 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 2-397 pertained to department of public safety, and derived from Code 1964, § 02-89; and an ordinance adopted Jan. 14, 1952, § 6.  
Sec. 2-398. - Department of police. 
The department of police, under the police chief, shall include all matters pertaining to police protection in the village. 
(Ord. No. 2019-11 , § 5, 2-11-2019)  
Secs. 2-399—2-422. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - PROCEDURE 
 
Sec. 2-440. - Generally. 
Provided that the rules are not inconsistent with this Code, other village ordinances or state law, proceedings of the board shall be conducted under the most recent edition of Robert's Rules of Order. 
(Ord. No. 2010-90, § 2(02-22), 12-13-2010)  
Sec. 2-441. - Applicability. 
The rules herein provided shall also apply to meetings of the standing committees and special committees of the village board. 
(Ord. No. 2010-90, § 2(02-22(6)), 12-13-2010)  
Sec. 2-442. - Rules of procedure. 
(a)  Any person who seeks to address committees, boards, commissions, and other similar bodies of the village, at the time designated in the agenda of the meeting or otherwise allotted by the chairperson or presiding officer for public comments and questions, shall be permitted to speak, only upon recognition by the chairperson or presiding officer, and such person shall adhere to the requirements of this division. 
(1)  Prior to addressing the boards, commissions and committees of the village, each person desiring to speak shall state his name and address for the record, at the beginning of such address. 
(2)  Each person shall be granted no more than three minutes per meeting in order to address the boards, commissions and committees hereinabove provided, unless such time is extended by the chairperson or presiding officer, giving consideration to the probable number of persons desiring to speak, and the duration or projected duration of the meeting. 
(3)  Questions and/or comments shall be limited to the business of the board, commission or committee meeting during which a person speaks. Comments supporting or opposing a nominated person's candidacy for elective office shall not be permitted. 
(4)  Comments shall be directed to the chairperson or presiding officer, unless the chairperson or presiding officer permits the individual to address a member of the boards, commissions and committees, or other village officials or employees present. 
(5)  The following behavior is prohibited during a public meeting of the boards, commissions and committees hereinabove provided: 
a.  Conducting in violation of any village ordinance, state or federal law, or any rule or regulation implementing state or federal law; 
b.  Interruption of speakers; name calling; boisterous remarks; 
c.  Offensive use of abusive, obscene, profane, slanderous or threatening language or gestures; 
d.  Acting or behaving in such an unreasonable manner so as to alarm or disturb another and to provoke a breach of the peace; and 
e.  Any other act designed to intimidate, threaten or harm persons, or damage or destroy property. 
(6)  Members of the public shall not engage in audible conversation which prohibits individuals from hearing and/or participating in a public meeting, or disrupts the conduct of business by the boards, commissions and committees. 
(7)  Members of the public may enter and leave the meeting room at any time, provided such entrance or exit is made quietly and in an orderly fashion. 
(8)  Battery-operated recording equipment is permitted at public meetings, provided the operation thereof is silent, and provided that such recording is confined to the area of the meeting room designated by the boards, commissions and committees for such recording. 
(9)  The chairperson or presiding officer at each public meeting of the boards, commissions and committees of the village shall be responsible for the enforcement of the provisions of rules of procedure and shall be empowered to reprimand and cause the removal of any and all persons violating the provisions of this division. The removal of an offender from a public meeting shall proceed as follows: 
a.  The chairperson or presiding officer shall twice give the offender notice that he is violating certain terms of this section and might be removed from the public meeting. 
b.  If the offender continues to violate any of the provisions of this section after receiving the above notice, the chairperson or presiding officer shall order a police officer to remove the offender from the meeting room. If the offender continues the disturbance outside the meeting room, such that the orderly conduct of business by the boards, commissions and committees is disrupted, the offender shall be removed from the building in which such public meeting is held. 
c.  The offender has no right to appeal from an order of the chairperson or presiding officer requiring the removal of the offender from the meeting room or from the building in which such public meeting is held. 
d.  Any order of the chairperson or presiding officer of a meeting relating to the enforcement of the provisions of this section may be appealed by a member of the boards, commissions and committees present at the meeting. Any ruling by the chairperson or presiding officer may be overruled by a majority of the members of the boards, commissions and committees present at the public meeting. 
e.  The offender removed from the meeting room or from the building in which such public meeting is held shall be criminally charged for any violations of applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 2010-90, § 2(02-7(2)(A)—(D), (F)), 12-13-2010)  
Secs. 2-443—2-471. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - ADVISORY COMMITTEES  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 2-472. - Policy. 
It is the policy of the village to establish a procedure for creating advisory committees. An advisory committee shall be created by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees whenever, in the opinion of the president and the board of trustees, the village will benefit from an advisory committee. 
(Code 1964, § 02-300; Ord. No. 99-55, 12-13-1999)  
Sec. 2-473. - Scope. 
The provisions of this division shall apply to all advisory committees of all kinds appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, except as follows: 
(1)  If a conflicting provision appears in a state statute or in a village ordinance relating to a particular committee, the specific statute or ordinance shall apply rather than this division. 
(2)  The provisions of this division shall not apply to the boards and commissions created by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1964, § 02-301; Ord. No. 99-55, 12-13-1999)  
Sec. 2-474. - Procedure. 
Unless otherwise provided in the ordinance creating the advisory committee, or in a later ordinance pertaining to the advisory committee, in this Code, or by state law, the following provisions shall apply to each advisory committee: 
(1)  Advisory responsibility. The committee shall have responsibility to provide advice only, and the board of trustees shall not be bound by any recommendation or advice received from the committee. 
(2)  Appointment and terms. Advisory committees shall consist of at least three members, to be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. Members shall serve for terms designated by the president at the time of appointment or if no term is designated at the time of appointment members of the committee shall serve for three-year staggered terms, so that approximately one-third of the membership shall be subject to reappointment each year. The first appointed members shall establish terms of one, two and three years by lot so that they will be serving for staggered terms. If members are serving for terms other than staggered terms in any committee at the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived, members presently in office shall complete their terms and the members appointed at the completion of the existing terms shall be appointed for staggered terms. Any vacancy occurring shall be filled for the remainder of the term in the same manner as original appointments. The terms will run from the date of appointment or if the committee is created by ordinance, by the passage of the ordinance creating the committee. 
(3)  Chairperson. Unless a chairperson is appointed by the president, the committee shall select one of its members as chair and one of its members as secretary. 
(4)  Reports. The committee shall report in writing at least annually to the board of trustees. The committee shall provide such additional reports as from time to time may be necessary to fulfill the functions of the committee. 
(5)  Meetings. Meetings shall be held by advisory committees as often as may be necessary to accomplish its objectives. The advisory committee may fix the date and time of its meetings by a majority vote of the committee. Special meetings may be called at any time by the chairperson or by any two members of a committee upon notice to each member of the committee. Meetings shall be open to the public, and a notice of the meeting, with the agenda, shall be posted and filed in the same manner as notices of the meetings of the board of trustees. Minutes of all committee meetings shall be taken. 
(6)  Unexcused absences. If any member of any advisory committee misses three or more consecutive meetings without an excuse approved by a majority of the members of the advisory committee, the advisory committee shall declare that member's position vacant and shall notify the president and the board of trustees that there is a vacancy to be filled. The member shall be notified. 
(7)  Vacancies. Vacancies shall be filled for the remainder of the term in the same manner that original appointments are made. 
(8)  Expenses. Members of the advisory committee shall receive no pay for their services, and shall receive no compensation for their time expended nor time lost from work. Members of the committee may be reimbursed for actual expenditures, subject to receiving previous authorization from the village manager for each such expenditure. 
(Code 1964, § 02-302; Ord. No. 99-55, 12-13-1999)  
Sec. 2-475. - Review and reconsideration. 
At least once each year the board of trustees shall review the effectiveness of each advisory committee, and shall determine whether such committee shall be continued as it is, abolished, or continued in a changed form. The committee's annual report may contain recommendations in this regard. 
(Code 1964, § 02-303; Ord. No. 99-55, 12-13-1999)  
Sec. 2-476. - Attendance by audio or video conference. 
(a)  If any member of a village committee, including an advisory committee, is prevented from physically attending a regular or special committee meeting because of a personal illness or disability, employment purposes, the business of the village, or family or other emergency, and provided that a quorum of the committee is physically present at the meeting, the committee may, by a majority vote, allow the member or members who are prevented from physically attending the meeting to participate and vote by audio or video conference. 
(b)  The member who is prevented from physically attending a committee meeting must notify the secretary of the committee in advance of the meeting of the reason why the member is prevented from physically attending the meeting, unless advance notice is impractical. When the secretary of the committee has received the required notice from any member who is prevented from physically attending the meeting, the secretary of the committee shall, at the commencement of the meeting, announce to the committee the receipt of the notice, the identity of the member who notified the secretary of the committee, and the reason why the member is prevented from physically attending the meeting as set forth in the notice. 
(c)  Provided that a quorum of the committee is physically present at the meeting, the presiding officer at the meeting shall thereupon call for a vote on the question of permitting the member who are prevented from physically attending the meeting to participate and vote by audio or video conference. The vote to permit any member to participate in a closed meeting by audio or video conference shall be made in the open portion of the meeting. 
(d)  The minutes of the meeting shall identify those members participating in the meeting by audio or video conference. 
(Ord. No. 2006-79, 10-23-2006)  
Secs. 2-477—2-505. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Beautification Commission[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2016-25, § 3, adopted May 9, 2016, repealed the former Subdiv. II, §§ 2-506—2-512, and enacted a new subdivision as set out herein. The former Subdiv. II pertained to Beautification Committee. See Code Comparative Table for a detailed history of derivation. 
 
Sec. 2-506. - Creation. 
The village has created an advisory committee to be designated as the beautification commission. 
( Ord. No. 2016-25, § 3, 5-9-2016)  
Sec. 2-507. - Membership; compensation; qualifications; chairperson. 
The beautification commission shall be comprised of seven members, appointed by the president with the consent of the village board of trustees, and shall serve without compensation. Membership of the beautification commission may include nonresidents, provided that not less than six members of the beautification commission shall be residents or persons who own property located within village corporate limits. The village president shall appoint a chairperson from among the appointees. 
( Ord. No. 2016-25, § 3 , 5-9-2016)  
Sec. 2-508. - Term; vacancies. 
Initially, three members shall be appointed for terms of one year; two members for terms of two years; and two members for terms of three years. All vacancies to the beautification commission shall be appointed for the unexpired term in the same manner as the original appointments. The successor to each initial member shall be appointed or reappointed for a term of three years. 
( Ord. No. 2016-25, § 3 , 5-9-2016)  
Sec. 2-509. - Compensation; expenses. 
No member or officer of the beautification commission shall be entitled to compensation for service on the beautification commission, provided, however, that members may be reimbursed for actual expenditures, provided that they have received prior authorization from the village manager for each such expenditure. 
( Ord. No. 2016-25, § 3 , 5-9-2016)  
Sec. 2-510. - Duties. 
The beautification commission shall make findings of fact and advisory recommendations to the village president and board of trustees at least four times annually. Such findings and recommendations shall include, but are not limited to, identifying activities to promote community beautification and aesthetic improvements in public spaces, nominating awards to business and homeowners to recognize private beautification efforts, organizing volunteer cleanups and plantings, providing advisory recommendations regarding streetscaping programs to the village staff, and performing such other duties as are appropriate. 
( Ord. No. 2016-25, § 3 , 5-9-2016)  
Sec. 2-511. - Regular meetings of the beautification commission. 
The beautification commission shall regularly meet on the second Tuesday of each month at the hour of 6:00 p.m., in the Edward Barcal Hall in the Municipal Building, 8820 Brookfield Avenue, Brookfield, Illinois, or at such other location within the village as the beautification commission may by notice thereof provide. 
( Ord. No. 2016-25, § 3 , 5-9-2016)  
Sec. 2-512. - Meetings; notice. 
(a)  Special meetings of the beautification commission may be called by the chairperson or any two commission members of the beautification commission. Meetings of the beautification commission may be rescheduled or reconvened by the chairperson. 
(b)  Written notice stating the place, date, and hour of the special, rescheduled or reconvened meeting, including the agenda for the meeting, shall be delivered not less than 48 hours before the time of the meeting, either personally or by mail, by or at the direction of the chairperson, or in the case of a special meeting called by the commission members, by or at the direction of the commission members calling the meeting, to each commission member and to any news medium that has given the village an address or telephone number within the village at which such notice may be given. 
(c)  If mailed, such notice shall be deemed to be delivered when deposited with the United States Postal Service, addressed to the commission member or news medium at the address as it appears on the records of the village, with postage thereon prepaid. 
(d)  When a meeting is reconvened to another time within 24 hours, notice need not be given to the commission members or news medium of the reconvened meeting if the time and place thereof are announced at the meeting at which the adjournment is taken. In addition to notice to the commission members and news medium, public notice of any special meeting, any rescheduled regular meeting or of any reconvened meeting, shall be given at least 48 hours before such meeting, which notice shall also include the agenda for the special, rescheduled, or reconvened meeting. 
(e)  The requirement of public notice of reconvened meetings does not apply to any case where the meeting was open to the public and it is to be reconvened within 24 hours, or an announcement of the time and place of the reconvened meeting was made at the original meeting and there is no change in the agenda. 
(f)  Public notice of regular and special meetings of the beautification commission shall be given by posting a copy of the notice not less than 48 hours before the time of the meeting at the municipal building and, if the meeting is to be held at a location other than the municipal building, at the building in which the meeting is to be held and posted on the village website. 
( Ord. No. 2016-25, § 3 , 5-9-2016)  
Secs. 2-513—2-532. - Reserved.  
Subdivision III. - Fair Housing Advisory Committee 
 
Sec. 2-533. - Creation. 
There shall be and is hereby created an advisory committee to be designated as the fair housing advisory committee. 
(Ord. No. 2007-54, exh. A(02-700), 5-29-2007)  
Sec. 2-534. - Members. 
The fair housing advisory committee shall be comprised of all current members of the planning, zoning, and economic development committee as created by this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2007-54, exh. A(02-701), 5-29-2007)  
Sec. 2-535. - Term. 
Each member of the fair housing advisory committee shall be appointed for the same term as appointed to the planning, zoning, and economic development committee. 
(Ord. No. 2007-54, exh. A(02-702), 5-29-2007)  
Sec. 2-536. - Compensation; expense reimbursements. 
No member of the fair housing advisory committee shall be entitled to compensation for service on the fair housing advisory committee; provided, however that members may be reimbursed for actual expenditures, provided that they have received prior authorization from the village manager for each such expenditure. 
(Ord. No. 2007-54, exh. A(02-703), 5-29-2007)  
Sec. 2-537. - Powers and duties. 
It is the policy of the village to encourage and develop the best possible living conditions for the present and future residents of the village to attain and maintain a stable and well balanced community. The fair housing advisory committee shall propose policies and programs to the board of trustees as well as assist all persons, regardless of age, race, color, creed, or income, to have equal opportunity to secure safe and adequate housing within the city, in the following capacity: 
(1)  Encourage the maintenance of existing sound housing and rehabilitation of deteriorating housing. 
(2)  Encourage the development of a variety of housing types in accordance with the 2020 master plan. 
(3)  Assist in the identification and development of educational materials related to housing. 
(4)  Study and consider such other matters as may be referred to it from time to time by the board of trustees. 
(5)  Receive, investigate and process, as hereinafter set forth, complaints alleging violations of the village fair housing regulations. 
(6)  Make recommendations to the board of trustees upon its findings and make a report to the city council of its findings of fact and recommendations. 
(7)  Keep a separate file of every complaint filed, and keep an accurate record of all its proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 2007-54, exh. A(02-704), 5-29-2007)  
Sec. 2-538. - Meetings. 
The fair housing advisory committee shall meet as necessary to fulfill the duties and responsibilities set forth in this division. 
(Ord. No. 2007-54, exh. A(02-705), 5-29-2007)  
Secs. 2-539—2-569. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - PLANNING, ZONING AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMITTEE 
 
Sec. 2-570. - Creation. 
There shall be and is hereby created an advisory committee to be designated as the planning, zoning and economic development committee. 
(Ord. No. 2007-08, § 2(02-600))  
Sec. 2-571. - Membership. 
The planning, zoning and economic development committee shall be comprised of three members of the village board of trustees, appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, and shall serve without compensation. The village president shall appoint a chairperson from among the appointees. 
(Ord. No. 2007-08, § 2(02-601))  
Sec. 2-572. - Term. 
Initially, one member shall be appointed for a term of one year; one member for a term of two years; and one member for a term of three years. All vacancies to the planning, zoning and economic development committee shall be appointed for the unexpired term in the same manner as the original appointments. The successor to each initial member shall be appointed or reappointed for a term of three years. 
(Ord. No. 2007-08, § 2(02-602))  
Sec. 2-573. - Compensation of members and officers. 
No member or officer of the planning, zoning and economic development committee shall be entitled to compensation for service on the planning, zoning and economic development committee; provided, however that members may be reimbursed for actual expenditures, provided that they have received prior authorization from the village manager for each such expenditure. 
(Ord. No. 2007-08, § 2(02-603))  
Sec. 2-574. - Duties. 
(a)  The planning, zoning and economic development committee shall make findings of fact and recommendations to the village president and board of trustees as requested. Such findings and recommendations shall include, but are not limited to, the ongoing implementation of the village 2020 master plan, the ongoing planning activities of village staff, the review of the village's zoning ordinance and the advancement of the economic development goals and activities of the village to ensure broader policy initiatives are consistent with the goals of the village. 
(b)  The planning, zoning and economic development committee shall report in writing at least annually to the board of trustees. The planning, zoning and economic development committee shall provide such additional reports as from time to time may be necessary to fulfill the functions of the planning, zoning and economic development committee. 
(Ord. No. 2007-08, § 2(02-604))  
Sec. 2-575. - Meetings. 
(a)  The planning, zoning and economic development committee shall meet at such times and dates as are necessary to accomplish its duties. The planning, zoning and economic development committee may fix the date and time of its meetings by a majority vote of the committee. At the beginning of each calendar or fiscal year, a schedule of the dates, times and places of all regular meetings for the year shall be prepared, made available to the public and posted on the village's website. 
(b)  Meetings shall be open to the public, and a notice of the meeting, with the agenda, shall be posted and filed in the same manner as notices of meetings of the board of trustees. Minutes of the planning, zoning and economic development committee meetings shall be taken. The meetings shall be held in the Edward Barcall Hall in the Municipal Building, 8820 Brookfield Avenue, Brookfield, Illinois, or at such other location within the village as the planning, zoning and economic development committee may by notice thereof provide. 
(Ord. No. 2007-08, § 2(02-605))  
Sec. 2-576. - Special, rescheduled and reconvened meetings. 
(a)  Special meetings of the planning, zoning and economic development committee may be called by the chairperson or any two committee members of the planning, zoning and economic development committee. Meetings of the planning, zoning and economic development committee may be rescheduled or reconvened by the chairperson. 
(b)  Written notice stating the place, date, and hour of the special, rescheduled or reconvened meeting, including the agenda for the meeting, shall be delivered not less than 48 hours before the time of the meeting, either personally or by mail, by or at the direction of the chairperson, or in the case of a special meeting called by the commissioners, by or at the direction of the commissioners calling the meeting, to each conservation commissioner and to any news medium that has given the village an address or telephone number within the village at which such notice may be given. If mailed, such notice shall be deemed to be delivered when deposited with the United States Postal Service, addressed to the conservation commissioner or news medium at the address as it appears on the records of the village, with postage thereon prepaid. 
(c)  When a meeting is adjourned and reconvened to another time within 24 hours, notice need not be given to the commissioners or news medium of the reconvened meeting if the time and place thereof are announced at the meeting at which the adjournment is taken. In addition to notice to the commissioners and news medium, public notice of any special meeting, any rescheduled regular meeting or of any reconvened meeting, shall be given at least 48 hours before such meeting, which notice shall also include the agenda for the special, rescheduled, or reconvened meeting. 
(d)  The requirement of public notice of reconvened meetings does not apply to any case where the meeting was open to the public and it is to be reconvened within 24 hours or an announcement of the time and place of the reconvened meeting was made at the original meeting and there is no change in the agenda. 
(e)  Public notice shall be given by posting a copy of the notice not less than 48 hours before the time of the meeting at the municipal building and, if the meeting is to be held at a location other than the municipal building, at the building in which the meeting is to be held and posted on the village website. 
(Ord. No. 2007-08, § 2(02-606))  
Sec. 2-577. - Attendance by audio or video conference. 
If any member of the planning, zoning and economic development committee is prevented from physically attending a regular or special planning, zoning and economic development committee meeting because of: 
(1)  Personal illness or disability; 
(2)  Employment purposes or the business of the village; or 
(3)  Family or other emergency; 
and provided that a quorum of the planning, zoning and economic development committee is physically present at the meeting, the planning, zoning and economic development committee may, by a majority vote, allow the member who is prevented from physically attending the meeting to participate and vote by audio or video conference, provided that the member who is prevented from physically attending a planning, zoning and economic development committee meeting notifies the secretary of the planning, zoning and economic development committee in advance of the meeting of the reason why the member is prevented from physically attending the planning, zoning and economic development committee meeting, unless advance notice is impractical. When the secretary of the planning, zoning and economic development committee has received the required notice from any member who is prevented from physically attending the meeting, the secretary of the planning, zoning and economic development committee shall, at the commencement of the meeting, announce to the planning, zoning and economic development committee the receipt of the notice, the identity of the member who notified the secretary of the planning, zoning and economic development committee, and the reason why the member is prevented from physically attending the meeting as set forth in the notice. Provided that a quorum of the planning, zoning and economic development committee is physically present at the meeting, the presiding officer at the meeting shall thereupon call for a vote on the question of permitting the member who is prevented from physically attending the meeting to participate and vote by audio or video conference. The vote to permit any member to participate in a closed meeting by audio or video conference shall be made in the open portion of the meeting. The minutes of the meeting shall identify those members participating in the meeting by audio or video conference. 
(Ord. No. 2007-08, § 2(02-607))  
Secs. 2-578—2-602. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - PUBLIC SAFETY COMMITTEE 
 
Sec. 2-603. - Composition; appointment of members. 
The village has created a public safety committee that consists of five members. Three members shall be members of the community appointed by the president subject to the confirmation by the village board. The remaining two members shall be the police chief and the fire chief whose powers shall be gained by the holding of their respective offices. Each committee member shall have the right to vote on each subject matter brought for discussion. 
(Code 1964, §§ 02-190, 02-191; Ord. No. 89-26, 6-26-1989)  
Sec. 2-604. - Terms of members, vacancies. 
The terms of the committee community members shall be for three years with staggered terms. All vacancies occurring to the appointed members shall be filled in the same manner as original appointments. The terms of the police chief and the fire chief shall be indefinite as remain with their respective offices. 
(Code 1964, § 02-192; Ord. No. 89-26, 6-26-1989)  
Sec. 2-605. - Election of officers. 
The village president shall appoint a chairperson of the committee, the committee shall elect a secretary and such other officers of the committee as may, in their judgment, be necessary. 
(Code 1964, § 02-193; Ord. No. 89-26, 6-26-1989)  
Sec. 2-606. - Compensation of members and officers. 
No members or officers of the committee shall receive compensation based solely for serving as a member or officer of the committee. 
(Code 1964, § 02-194; Ord. No. 89-26, 6-26-1989)  
Sec. 2-607. - Obtaining technical advice or service. 
If the public safety committee deems it advisable to secure technical advice or service, it may do so upon authority from the village board and appropriation by the board thereafter. 
(Code 1964, § 02-196; Ord. No. 1989-26, 6-26-1989)  
Sec. 2-608. - Records to be kept. 
The public safety committee shall keep written records of its proceedings which shall be open to inspection by the board of trustees at all times. 
(Code 1964, § 02-197; Ord. No. 1989-26, 6-26-1989)  
Secs. 2-609—2-634. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - OTHER BOARDS, COMMISSIONS, AGENCIES AND AUTHORITIES 
 
Sec. 2-635. - Records. 
(a)  Every board and commission created by the board of trustees shall keep a true and accurate record of all its proceedings. A copy of this record, certified to by the clerk of the board or commission or by two members thereof, shall be filed with the village clerk and shall become a part of the records of the village. 
(b)  All tape recordings made by the village board and village commissions of their meetings are for assistance in transcribing minutes and are not the official record of the village. Minutes prepared from these tapes will be approved by a majority vote of the board or commission and are the official village records. Recording tapes may be disposed of by the village after the minutes have been approved by the board or commission. 
(Code 1940, § 10.014; Code 1964, § 02-8; Ord. No. 90-6, 1-22-1990)  
Sec. 2-636. - Attendance by audio or video conference. 
(a)  If any member of any village board, commission, authority, agency or other public body, (including those addressed in this chapter and in all other chapters of this Code or other ordinances of the village) is prevented from physically attending a regular or special meeting because of a personal illness or disability, employment purposes, the business of the village, or family or other emergency, and provided that a quorum of the body is physically present at the meeting, the body may, by a majority vote, allow the member or members who are prevented from physically attending the meeting to participate and vote by audio or video conference. 
(b)  The member who is prevented from physically attending a public body meeting must notify the secretary of the body in advance of the meeting of the reason why the member is prevented from physically attending the meeting, unless advance notice is impractical. When the secretary of the body has received the required notice from any member who is prevented from physically attending the meeting, the secretary of the body shall, at the commencement of the meeting, announce to the body the receipt of the notice, the identity of the member who notified the secretary of the body, and the reason why the member is prevented from physically attending the meeting as set forth in the notice. 
(c)  Provided that a quorum of the body is physically present at the meeting, the presiding officer at the meeting shall thereupon call for a vote on the question of permitting the member who are prevented from physically attending the meeting to participate and vote by audio or video conference. The vote to permit any member to participate in a closed meeting by audio or video conference shall be made in the open portion of the meeting. 
(d)  The minutes of the meeting shall identify those members participating in the meeting by audio or video conference. 
(Ord. No. 2006-79, 10-23-2006)  
Secs. 2-637—2-660. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 2-661. - Established. 
The board of fire and police commissioners of the village is hereby established. 
(Code 1940, § 17.001; Code 1964, § 02-96) 
State Law reference— Board of fire and police commissioners, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq.  
Sec. 2-662. - Composition; appointment of members. 
The village has created the board of fire and police commissioners that consists of three members who shall be appointed by the president, by and with the consent of the board of trustees; provided, however, that no appointment shall be made by any president within 30 days before the expiration of his term of office. 
(Code 1940, § 17.002; Code 1964, § 02-97) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1.  
Sec. 2-663. - Qualifications; oath. 
The members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall possess the qualifications required of other officers of the village, shall take the oath or affirmation of office, and shall be subject to removal from office as such other officers. No person holding an office under a municipality shall be a member of the board, and the acceptance of such office by any such member shall be deemed and held as a resignation of his office by such member. No person shall be appointed a member of the board of fire and police commissioners who has been convicted of a felony under the laws of this state or comparable laws of any other state or the United States.
