State Law reference— Local Government Air Rights Act, 50 ILCS 25/0.01 et seq.; Building Code Violation Notice Posting Act, 50 ILCS 810/0.01 et seq.; Contractor Unified License and Permit Bond Act, 50 ILCS; 830/1 et seq.; Building Authority Act, 20 ILCS 3110/0.01 et seq.; Building Code Violation Notice Posting Act, 50 ILCS 810/0.01 et seq.; procedure regarding municipal removal of abandoned buildings, 735 ILCS 5/2-206; municipal authority over building and construction generally, 65 ILCS 11-13-1 et seq.; municipal authority with regard to construction of buildings and fire escapes, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-4; municipal authority with regard to grading and drainage of lots, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-8; authority to regulate artificial basins of water used for swimming or wading, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-9; municipal authority to regulate demolition, repair, enclosure, or remediation of buildings and other structures, 65 ILCS 5/11-31-1 et seq.; building code violations, 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 12-1. - Compliance required. 
No person shall construct, erect, enlarge, remodel, alter, raise, lower, move, wreck or repair any building or structure, or any portion thereof, in the village in violation of the provisions of this chapter or any other ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1940, § 39.018; Code 1964, § 06-21; Ord. No. 1977-5, § 1, 2-28-1977)  
Sec. 12-2. - Liberal construction. 
This chapter shall at all times be construed so as to afford the greatest protection for health and safety against fire, construction and unsanitary conditions to the occupants of every building, adjacent property owner and the public. 
(Code 1940, § 39.206; Code 1964, § 06-23; Ord. No. 1977-5, § 1, 2-28-1977)  
Sec. 12-3. - Penalty for violation of chapter; continuing violations. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order or regulation made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of specification or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder, shall, for each and every such violation or noncompliance, for which a penalty is not specifically provided, be punished as provided in section 1-12 of this Code. 
(b)  The imposition of one penalty for any violation of this chapter shall not excuse the violation, or permit it to continue, and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time. When not otherwise specified, each ten days that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions, as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1940, § 39.208; Code 1964, § 06-24; Ord. No. 1977-5, § 1, 2-28-1977)  
Sec. 12-4. - Fire limits established. 
The fire limits of the village are hereby declared to be the boundaries of all areas included within business districts, and light manufacturing districts, as defined by village zoning provisions, and all property classified within any such business district or light manufacturing district is hereby declared to be within the fire limits. 
(Code 1940, § 39.137; Code 1964, § 06-3; Ord. of 10-27-1958, § 1)  
Secs. 12-5—12-26. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 12-27. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Building inspector means any full-time or part-time state, county or village employee whose duties include the inspection or examination of structures or property in the village to determine if zoning or other code violations exist. 
Hearing officer means a village employee or an officer or agent of the village appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the village board of trustees other than a building inspector or law enforcement officer, whose duty it shall be to: 
(1)  Preside at an administrative hearing called to determine whether or not a code violation exists. 
(2)  Hear testimony and accept evidence from an inspector, the building owner and all interested parties relevant to the existence of a code violation. 
(3)  Preserve and authenticate the transcript and record of the hearing and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing. 
(4)  Issue and sign a written finding, decision and order stating whether a code violation exists. 
Property owner means the legal or beneficial owner of premises. 
(Code 1964, § 36-10; Ord. No. 99-36, 10-11-1999)  
Secs. 12-28—12-57. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - INSPECTIONS 
 
Sec. 12-58. - Right of entry to enforce chapter. 
The chief building inspector or his assistants are empowered to enter any building or premises, whether complete or in the process of erection or alteration, for the purpose of determining whether the same has been or is being constructed and maintained in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and other ordinances of the village, and it shall be unlawful for any person to exclude them from any such building or premises. All inspectors or assistants shall have the proper credentials and are required to show the same on request. 
(Code 1940, § 39.009; Code 1964, § 06-22; Ord. of 9-26-1955, § 1; Ord. No. 1977-5, § 1, 2-28-1977)  
Sec. 12-59. - Inspection of new buildings. 
The chief building inspector shall inspect or cause to be inspected all new buildings or structures prior to their occupancy or use to determine conformity with all codes and ordinances of the village. No new building or structure may be used or occupied without having been so inspected and found in conformity. 
(Code 1940, § 39.004; Code 1964, § 06-19; Ord. of 9-26-1955, § 1; Ord. No. 1977-5, § 1, 2-28-1977; Ord. No. 92-20, 5-11-1992; Ord. No. 92-28, 7-27-1992; Ord. No. 93-38, 7-26-1993; Ord. No. 95-11, 5-22-1995; Ord. No. 2001-53, 11-12-2001; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006; Ord. No. 2010-52, § 06-19(a), 7-26-2010)  
Sec. 12-60. - Inspection of existing buildings. 
(a)  The chief building inspector shall inspect or cause to be inspected all existing commercial and industrial buildings and structures and all multifamily residential buildings with four or more dwelling units for compliance with the following items prior to their sale or other transfer or change of ownership; such inspection to be made no more than two months prior to the date of any sale or transfer: 
(1)  Proper and legal use and/or uses conforming to those regulations for the zoning district in which the building and/or structure is situated; 
(2)  Any illegal construction work not done under village permit, which has resulted in improper structural additions or alterations; 
(3)  Failure to install and maintain fire safety devices as required by state law; 
(4)  Compliance with the requirements of the village's adopted property maintenance code; and 
(5)  Compliance with the village's adopted electrical and plumbing codes. 
(b)  Not more than two months prior to the date of any sale or other transfer of ownership of an existing residential dwelling, except for multifamily residential buildings with four or more dwelling units, the existing residential dwelling shall be inspected by a home inspector holding a valid home inspector license issued by the Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation pursuant to the Home Inspector License Act in compliance with the Standards of Practice contained in Subpart C of Part 1410 of Chapter VIII of Title 68 of the Illinois Administrative Code (68 Ill. Admin. Code, Chpt. VIII, Part 1410, Subpart C), with also the Standards of Practice promulgated by the American Society of Home Inspectors (www.ashi.org), the Standards of Practice promulgated by the National Association of Home Inspectors, Inc. (www.nahi.org) or the Standards of Practice promulgated by the International Association of Certified Home Inspectors, Inc. (www.nachi.org). 
(c)  A resale certificate of compliance containing the following information and substantially in the following form: 
Resale Certificate of Compliance 
Date: _______, 20___ 
( Date of Certificate ) 
I hereby certify to the Village of Brookfield that: 
A. I hold a valid home inspector's license issued by the Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation; 
B. On _______, 20___, I inspected the residential dwelling located at 
( Date of Inspection ) 
___________ Brookfield, Illinois. 
C. Admin. Code, Chpt. (Code 1940, § 39.004; Code 1964, § 06-19; Ord. of 9-26-1955, § 1; Ord. No. 1977-5, § 1, 2-28-1977; Ord. No. 92-20, 5-11-1992; Ord. No. 92-28, 7-27-1992; Ord. No. 93-38, 7-26-1993; Ord. No. 95-11, 5-22-1995; Ord. No. 2001-53, 11-12-2001; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006; Ord. No. 2010-52, § 06-19(b), 7-26-2010; Ord. No. 2015-59, § 2 , 9-14-2015; Ord. No. 2015-70, § 2 , 11-9-2015)  
Sec. 12-61. - Inspection of rental dwelling units. 
The chief building inspector shall inspect or cause to be inspected all multifamily residential buildings with four or more dwelling units for compliance with the list of requirements set forth in section 12-60 on a biennial basis. 
(Code 1940, § 39.004; Code 1964, § 06-19; Ord. of 9-26-1955, § 1; Ord. No. 1977-5, § 1, 2-28-1977; Ord. No. 92-20, 5-11-1992; Ord. No. 92-28, 7-27-1992; Ord. No. 93-38, 7-26-1993; Ord. No. 95-11, 5-22-1995; Ord. No. 2001-53, 11-12-2001; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006; Ord. No. 2010-52, § 06-19(c), 7-26-2010; Ord. No. 2015-59, § 3 , 9-14-2015)  
Sec. 12-62. - Certificates of inspection; resale certificate of compliance. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to sell, change or transfer ownership of any commercial or industrial building or structure or any multifamily residential buildings with four or more dwelling units, or for anyone to rent, lease, or license any rental dwelling units or non-owner occupied properties in a multifamily residential building with four or more dwelling units in the village without first obtaining a certificate of inspection. 
(b)  No license of any kind shall be allowed to be issued to permit any commercial or industrial business occupation where a certificate of inspection has not been issued. 
(c)  A certificate of inspection shall be issued only if the commercial or industrial building or structure meets all requirements of this village's building and zoning codes. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to sell, change or transfer ownership of any residential dwelling, except multifamily residential buildings with four or more dwelling units, in the village without first filing a resale certificate of compliance conforming to the requirements of section 12-60(c) with the chief building inspector. 
( Ord. No. 2015-59, § 4 , 9-14-2015) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2015-59, § 4 , adopted Sept. 14, 2015, amended § 12-62 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 12-62 pertained to certificates of inspection, and derived from Code 1940, § 39.004; Code 1964, § 06-19; an ordinance adopted Sept. 26, 1955, § 1; Ord. No. 1977-5, § 1, adopted Feb. 28, 1977; Ord. No. 92-20, adopted May 11, 1992; Ord. No. 92-28, adopted July 27, 1992; Ord. No. 93-38, adopted July 26, 1993; Ord. No. 95-11, adopted May 22, 1995; Ord. No. 2001-53, adopted Nov. 12, 2001; Ord. No. 2006-64, adopted Sept. 11, 2006; and Ord. No. 2010-52, § 06-19(c), adopted July 26, 2010.  
Sec. 12-63. - Inspection of unsafe buildings. 
The chief building inspector shall inspect or cause to be inspected all existing buildings or structure as requested by the village manager where reasonable information exists that a building or structure is in an unsafe condition so as to endanger life or safety of the occupants or general public. Under such circumstances, the chief building inspector shall notify, in writing, the owner, agent or occupant, and to put into effect such precautionary measures as may be necessary or advisable in order to place such building or structure in a safe condition. 
(Code 1940, § 39.004; Code 1964, § 06-19; Ord. of 9-26-1955, § 1; Ord. No. 1977-5, § 1, 2-28-1977; Ord. No. 92-20, 5-11-1992; Ord. No. 92-28, 7-27-1992; Ord. No. 93-38, 7-26-1993; Ord. No. 95-11, 5-22-1995; Ord. No. 2001-53, 11-12-2001; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006; Ord. No. 2010-52, § 06-19(d), 7-26-2010)  
Sec. 12-64. - Notice of intent to sell or transfer real property. 
Every person, corporation, trust or other individual or entity who shall intend to sell real property on which there exists any commercial or industrial building, structure or use or any multifamily residential building with four or more dwelling units shall notify the village that said real property is to be sold or ownership is to be transferred within 60 days prior to the closing, completion or effective date of such transaction. 
(Code 1940, § 39.004; Code 1964, § 06-19; Ord. of 9-26-1955, § 1; Ord. No. 1977-5, § 1, 2-28-1977; Ord. No. 92-20, 5-11-1992; Ord. No. 92-28, 7-27-1992; Ord. No. 93-38, 7-26-1993; Ord. No. 95-11, 5-22-1995; Ord. No. 2001-53, 11-12-2001; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006; Ord. No. 2010-52, § 06-19(e), 7-26-2010; Ord. No. 2015-59, § 5 , 9-14-2015)  
Sec. 12-65. - Fees. 
Fees for inspection required under this division shall be as provided in the village fee schedule. The inspection fees shall be for the initial inspection and one reinspection. Should the property require an additional reinspection, the applicable initial inspection fee may again be charged for each additional inspection. 
(Code 1940, § 39.004; Code 1964, § 06-19; Ord. of 9-26-1955, § 1; Ord. No. 1977-5, § 1, 2-28-1977; Ord. No. 92-20, 5-11-1992; Ord. No. 92-28, 7-27-1992; Ord. No. 93-38, 7-26-1993; Ord. No. 95-11, 5-22-1995; Ord. No. 2001-53, 11-12-2001; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006)  
Sec. 12-66. - Stopping construction, alteration or repair of buildings. 
The chief building inspector shall have the power, and it shall be his duty, to stop the construction of any building which is in violation of this chapter or other ordinances of the village, or the alteration or repair of any building which, in his judgment, is unsafe for the uses set forth in the application for the permit to do such work. 
(Code 1940, § 39.005; Code 1964, § 06-20; Ord. of 9-26-1955, § 1; Ord. No. 1977-5, § 1, 2-28-1977)  
Sec. 12-67. - Penalties. 
Any person violating the terms and conditions of this division shall be subject to a penalty not exceeding $500.00. Each day that a violation exists shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense and shall be subject to the penalty provisions of this clause. 
(Code 1940, § 39.004; Code 1964, § 06-19; Ord. of 9-26-1955, § 1; Ord. No. 1977-5, § 1, 2-28-1977; Ord. No. 92-20, 5-11-1992; Ord. No. 92-28, 7-27-1992; Ord. No. 93-38, 7-26-1993; Ord. No. 95-11, 5-22-1995; Ord. No. 2001-53, 11-12-2001; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006)  
Secs. 12-68—12-92. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PERMITS AND FEES 
 
Sec. 12-93. - Required; exceptions. 
(a)  General . Before proceeding with topographic grading or excavating for or the erection, enlargement, alteration, repair, moving or removal of any building or structure in the village, a permit for such work shall first be obtained by the owner or agent from the building inspector; and it shall be unlawful to proceed unless such permit shall first have been obtained, provided, however, that ordinary repairs to buildings, when such repairs will not exceed $500.00, may be made without notice to any village officer or the building inspector, and no permit is required therefor if such repair does not contemplate or involve the changing, cutting, or removal of any external or division wall, the removal of any beam or support, the closing or removal of any stairs, exit, scuttle, skylight or fire escape, the placing or removal of any soil or drainage pipe, the installation of electric wires or electric apparatus, or the increase of the fire risk of any building, structure or premises. The fee for permits for excavating for or the erection, enlargement, alteration, repair, moving or removal of any building or structure in the village shall be as set forth in the village fee schedule. 
(b)  Elevators . Before proceeding with the erection, construction, alteration, addition, repair or removal of any elevator, dumbwaiter, escalator or moving walk, a permit for the same shall first be obtained by the owner or his agent from the building inspector, which permit shall issue upon satisfactory evidence of compliance with this article. The applicant, whether he is the owner or the contractor, by the signing of the building permit application, certifies the correctness of the application. 
(1)  Occupancy is prohibited until inspection is completed and installation approved. Occupancy of the building or structure within which the erection, construction, alteration, addition, repair or removal has been made prior to inspection of the same and the issuance of an occupancy permit shall subject the occupant, contractor and owner of the subject property to violation of the building code. 
(2)  For any and all existing elevators, dumbwaiters, escalators and moving walks, inspections shall be required to be made semiannually. If the inspection reveals the requirement of maintenance or repair, such elevator, dumbwaiter, escalator or moving walk shall be shut down immediately until such maintenance or repair has been performed in accordance with the orders of the building inspector for the village. 
(3)  The fee for permits for the erection, construction, alteration, addition, repair or removal of any elevator, dumbwaiter, escalator or moving walk in the village shall be as set forth in the village fee schedule. 
(4)  The fee for semiannual inspections of any elevator, dumbwaiter, escalator or moving walk in the village shall be as set forth in the village fee schedule. 
(Code 1940, §§ 39.010, 39.011; Code 1964, § 06-29; Ord. of 9-26-1955, § 1; Ord. No. 1979-74, 10-22-1979; Ord. No. 1983-21, 10-10-1983; Ord. No. 2018-54 , § 2, 6-25-2018)  
Sec. 12-94. - Special provisions relative to house moving permits. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, a permit to move any building shall be issued only to a licensed house mover. Such a permit shall state specifically all the conditions thereto and shall prescribe the route to be taken in moving the building and the time limit for such moving. 
(b)  No permit for moving any building shall be issued until there is filed with the chief building inspector a consent in writing, signed by the owners or their authorized agents, of a majority of the frontage upon the side of the street where such building is proposed to be moved, nearest intersecting streets. 
(c)  On each and every night while a building being moved under a permit from the village remains on any street or alley, from dusk until sunrise, the permit holder shall place or cause to be placed, at each corner or such building, a red light. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for the holder of a permit to move a building to permit or suffer such building to be or remain in any of the public grounds of the village for any time longer than specified in the permit. 
(Code 1940, §§ 39.125—39.129; Code 1964, § 06-37)  
Sec. 12-95. - Permits in flood base areas. 
(a)  Building permits are required for all proposed construction, substantial improvements, or other development, including the placement of mobile homes, within floodplain areas having special flood hazards. Such permits shall ensure that all other necessary permits have been received from those governmental agencies from which approval is required by federal or state law. The building permit applications will be reviewed to ensure that any proposed construction is: 
(1)  Designed and anchored to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement of the structure. 
(2)  Constructed with materials and utility equipment resistant to flood damage, and constructed by methods and practices that minimize flood damage. 
(b)  At the time of issuing a building permit, the following information will be noted and recorded by the village: 
(1)  Elevation of the lowest floor (including basement). 
(2)  Where the elevation of the lowest floor is below grade on one or more sides, the elevation of the floor immediately above. 
(3)  Where a structure has been floodproofed, the elevation to which the structure was floodproofed. 
(Code 1964, § 06-38; Ord. No. 1979-79, 11-12-1979; Ord. No. 1980-33, 10-27-1980; Ord. No. 1987-18, 9-28-1987)  
Sec. 12-96. - Prerequisites to issuance for shopping centers on state aid routes. 
No permit will be issued for the construction of shopping centers situated on or adjacent to state aid routes within the corporate limits of the village, before the county superintendent of highways has been notified of the application for such permit and given pertinent information relating thereto. A copy of this section, duly certified by the clerk of the village, shall be filed in the office of the county superintendent of highways. 
(Code 1964, § 06-32; Ord. of 1-14-1957, §§ 1, 2)  
Sec. 12-97. - Application. 
Every applicant for a building permit shall file with the chief building inspector a written application, under oath, on a form furnished by the village, with a plat of survey made by a certified surveyor, and show thereon the location of the proposed structure on the property. Also, such applicant shall file plans showing all general dimensions of structural members and supports and sizes of doors and windows and the purpose for which the building is used, the estimated cost of the proposed building, the name of the owner or his agent, and the name of the contractor. 
(Code 1940, § 39.012; Code 1964, § 06-30; Ord. of 9-26-1955, § 1)  
Sec. 12-98. - Scale and approval of plans filed by applicant. 
(a)  Every applicant for a permit required by this article shall file with the application three sets of plans drawn to scale, which scale must be noted on the plans and shall not be less than one-eighth inch to one foot, except in case of the application for a permit for erection of sheds or private garages containing 250 square feet or less and 12 feet and under the height, or ordinary alterations and repairs. The foundation, basement, plan, upper floors, elevations, roof plan and all other plans for the construction of any building or structure shall be examined by the chief building inspector and approved by him before the permit shall be issued; each sheet of approved plans should be stamped by the chief building inspector. 
(b)  The chief building inspector shall pass on all questions relating to the strength or durability of buildings or structures as provided by law. 
(Code 1940, §§ 39.007, 39.014; Code 1964, § 06-31; Ord. of 9-26-1955, § 1)  
Sec. 12-99. - Denial; appeal. 
(a)  No permit shall be issued for the construction, improvement, alteration or enlargement of any building which does not meet the architectural and other requirements of this chapter or any other provisions of this Code, including codes adopted by reference. 
(b)  In the event a permit is denied to any applicant by reason of this section, the applicant shall have the right to appeal from such denial to the village planning and zoning commission within such time as shall be prescribed by the planning and zoning commission by general rules. 
(c)  The applicant shall file with the planning and zoning commission a notice of appeal, specifying the grounds thereof. The village manager or his designee or other officer designated by the president and board of trustees, if any, shall forthwith transmit to the planning and zoning commission all papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. At the time of the filing of the notice of appeal, the applicant shall pay to the village manager or his designee a filing fee in the amount provided in the village fee schedule for each such notice of appeal. 
(d)  Upon such appeal having been perfected as aforesaid, and after such reasonable notice to the applicant and to owners and occupants of existing buildings in the vicinity of the proposed building, structure, alteration or enlargement, as the planning and zoning commission shall, by general rules, prescribe, a public hearing shall be held by the planning and zoning commission to review the action of the official denying the permit, at which hearing evidence shall be taken and received. 
(e)  After receiving and considering such evidence, if the planning and zoning commission shall determine that the proposed building or the proposed improvement, alteration or enlargement will detrimentally affect values of adjoining and neighboring properties, it shall affirm the denial of the permit. 
(f)  If the planning and zoning commission shall determine that the erection or construction of the proposed building or the improvement, alteration or enlargement will not detrimentally affect values of adjoining and neighboring properties, it shall direct the chief building inspector to issue a permit. 
(g)  The planning and zoning commission may, from time to time, adopt such rules and regulations as may be deemed necessary to carry into effect the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1964, § 06-33; Ord. of 3-21-1949, § 1; Ord. of 10-12-1953, § 1; Ord. No. 2013-69, § 10, 12-16-2013)  
Sec. 12-100. - Deposit required prior to construction operations. 
(a)  No person shall perform any work for which a building permit is required if the cost of such work is $1,000.00 or more, without first making a cash deposit with the village manager or his designee of $200.00 for residential construction and $500.00 for commercial construction. Such sum shall be increased an appropriate amount if, in the opinion of the chief building inspector, the stated amount would not be sufficient to construct or repair damages to sidewalks, pavements, trees and any other village property which are already damaged or obviously will be damaged in the course of construction. Such sum shall be paid in addition to the cost of a building permit. 
(b)  The deposit made pursuant to this section shall be refunded to the permittee upon return of the cash deposit receipt when certificates of occupancy have been issued and when compliance with this chapter and other village ordinances are complete, less deductions for damages to sidewalks, trees, pavement and any other village property. 
(c)  Any deposit not redeemed within two years after completion of the work shall be forfeited to the village. 
(Code 1940, §§ 36.013, 36.014; Code 1964, § 06-5; Ord. of 12-13-1965, § 1)  
Sec. 12-101. - Construction permit and inspection fees. 
(a)  Before obtaining a permit required by this article, every applicant shall pay the fees as provided in this section. 
(b)  Unless otherwise provided in subsections (c) through (j) of this section, the fee to be charged for a permit to construct, erect, enlarge, alter or repair any building or addition or part thereof shall be a percentage, as set forth in the village fee schedule, of the total cost of construction. For the purpose of determining the fees, the estimated cost shall be determined by the building inspector as provided in this subsection. 
(1)  The chief building inspector may accept an estimated cost furnished by the applicant for the permit, or he may require a certificate from a licensed architect or licensed professional engineer having experience in construction cost estimates; or an affidavit from the owner or his agent of the total cost of the proposed work; or he may make such estimate as chief building inspector and may rely on a recognized construction cost database such as RSMeans to verfiy or estimate materials, labor and equipment costs. 
(2)  The chief building inspector shall not require both an affidavit and the certificate mentioned herein. 
(c)  In the event the village enlists the assistance of an independent contractor to review plans or do inspections on such work, the fee to be charged for such a permit shall be the percentage set forth in the village fee schedule of the total cost of construction plus payment of the entire fee charged to the village by said independent contractor. 
(d)  The fee for cement and asphalt flatwork, including, but not limited to, sidewalks, driveways, patios, and other such slabs and curbs and parkway openings, shall be the percentage set forth in the village fee schedule of the cost of construction. 
(e)  The fee for building plan reviews shall be as set forth in the village fee schedule. 
(f)  The fee for a permit for the following construction activities shall be as set forth in the village fee schedule: 
(1)  Detached garage on a lot that contains an existing residential building; 
(2)  New accessory structure including, but not limited to, a shed, carport or gazebo on a lot that contains an existing residential building; 
(3)  Replacement of an existing roof on an existing single-family or multi-family residential structure; 
(4)  Replacement of siding or stucco or applying siding or stucco to an existing building; 
(5)  Replacement of gutters, soffit or fascia or installing gutters, soffit or fascia to an existing building; 
(6)  Replacement of windows or doors or installing windows or doors to an existing building; 
(7)  Replacement of insulation or installing insulation to an existing building; 
(8)  Installation, repair or replacement of waterproofing or basement sealing to an existing building; 
(9)  Repair, replacement of masonry or tuck pointing to an existing building; 
(10)  Installation, repair or replacement of a heating, ventilation or air conditioning system to an existing building; 
(11)  Installation, repair or replacement of a deck to an existing building; 
(12)  Installation, repair or replacement of landscaping features, including, but not limited to, a fountain or fire pit; 
(13)  Installation, repair or replacement of a garage door to an existing building; 
(14)  Installation, repair or replacement of railings in or to an existing building; 
(15)  Installation, repair or replacement of plumbing in or to an existing building; 
(16)  Installation, repair or replacement of a fire sprinkler system in or to an existing building; and 
(17)  The demolition or removal of an unground storage tank. 
(g)  The fee for permits for removing structures or any portion thereof shall be as set forth in the village fee schedule. 
(h)  The fee for permits for the construction of signs, fences, swimming pools and sheds shall be as set forth in the village fee schedule. 
(i)  The fee for electrical, heating, ventilation and air conditioning work permits shall be as set forth in the village fee schedule. 
(j)  The fee to remove a stop work order and resume work authorized by a permit shall be as set forth in the village fee schedule. 
(Code 1940, §§ 39.015, 39.126; Code 1964, § 06-34; Ord. of 3-9-1959, § 1; Ord. of 6-25-1962, § 1; Ord. of 12-14-1964, § 1; Ord. of 1-10-1966, § 3; Ord. No. 1968-39, § 2, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1970-3, § 1, 4-13-1970; Ord. No. 1974-04, § 1, 5-13-1974; Ord. No. 1975-2, § 2, 1-27-1975; Ord. No. 1978-4, § 2, 3-13-1978; Ord. No. 1979-9, § A, 3-12-1979; Ord. No. 1981-9, 3-9-1981; Ord. No. 1983-24, 10-24-1983; Ord. No. 1985-11, 3-11-1985; Ord. No. 1985-24, 5-13-1985; Ord. No. 98-22, 5-11-1998; Ord. No. 2001-40, 7-23-2001; Ord. No. 2005-03, 2-14-2005; Ord. No. 2005-06, 2-28-2005; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006; Ord. No. 2018-54 , § 3, 6-25-2018)  
Sec. 12-102. - Waiver of permit fees for certain charitable organizations. 
(a)  An eligible charitable organization may apply to the board of trustees for a waiver, not to exceed $750.00, of all or a portion of a building permit fee required under this chapter. The application for a waiver of the permit fee shall be in writing, signed by the applicant, or if the applicant is a corporation, by its duly authorized officer, or if the applicant is a partnership, by one or more duly authorized partners, on a dated form provided by the village. The application shall disclose the following information concerning the applicant and the fee waiver: 
(1)  The name of the applicant; 
(2)  The address of the applicant; 
(3)  The telephone number of the applicant; 
(4)  The fees, or portion thereof, requested to be waived; 
(5)  Documentation from the Internal Revenue Service that the eligible charitable organization is exempt from taxation by an applicable section of the Internal Revenue Code; and 
(6)  Such further information or documentation as may be required to verify any of the foregoing information. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, the term "eligible charitable organization" means: 
(1)  Corporations exclusively holding title to property on behalf of an exempt organization under and which have been granted an exemption from taxation under Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(2) by the Internal Revenue Service; 
(2)  Religious, charitable, scientific, literary and educational organizations, organizations for testing public safety, organizations that foster national or international amateur sports competition, organizations that are operated to prevent cruelty to children or animals and which have been granted an exemption from taxation under Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(3) by the Internal Revenue Service; 
(3)  Nonprofit civic organizations operated exclusively for social welfare and local employees' associations whose net earnings are used solely for charitable, educational or recreational purposes and which have been granted an exemption from taxation under Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(4) by the Internal Revenue Service; 
(4)  Labor, agricultural or horticultural organizations which have been granted an exemption from taxation under Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(5) by the Internal Revenue Service; 
(5)  Chambers of commerce, business leagues, real estate boards, boards of trade or professional football leagues not organized for profit or private benefit and which have been granted an exemption from taxation under Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(6) by the Internal Revenue Service; 
(6)  Social clubs organized for pleasure, recreation and other nonprofitable purposes and fraternal beneficiary societies which have been granted an exemption from taxation under Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(7) by the Internal Revenue Service; 
(7)  Fraternal beneficiary societies, orders or associations operating under the lodge system providing life, sick, accident or other benefits to members and their dependents and which have been granted an exemption from taxation under Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(8) by the Internal Revenue Service; 
(8)  Voluntary employees' beneficiary associations providing benefit payments to members and their dependents and which have been granted an exemption from taxation under Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(9) by the Internal Revenue Service; 
(9)  Domestic fraternal societies operating under the lodge system not providing benefits but whose net earnings are devoted exclusively to religious, charitable, scientific, literary or educational organizations and which have been granted an exemption from taxation under Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(10) by the Internal Revenue Service; 
(10)  Local teachers' retirement fund associations which have been granted an exemption from taxation under Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(11) by the Internal Revenue Service; 
(11)  Local benevolent life insurance associations, mutual ditch or irrigation companies, mutual or cooperative telephone companies which have been granted an exemption from taxation under Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(12) by the Internal Revenue Service; 
(12)  Nonprofit cemetery companies and burial corporations which have been granted an exemption from taxation under Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(13) by the Internal Revenue Service; 
(13)  Nonprofit credit unions, cooperative banks or mutual savings banks which have been granted an exemption from taxation under Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(14) by the Internal Revenue Service; and 
(14)  Domestic veterans organizations which have been granted an exemption from taxation under Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(19) by the Internal Revenue Service. 
(c)  The board of trustees shall promptly review each properly completed application and shall grant a waiver of the requested permit fees, provided that the applicant has complied with the requirements of this section and is determined to be a eligible charitable organization. 
(Ord. No. 2007-02, 1-8-2007)  
Sec. 12-103. - Water and sewer connections; fees. 
(a)  The labor charge for water and sewer connections shall be as set forth in the village fee schedule which shall include a labor charge. The standard labor charge for special construction services provided to users of the sewer and water system of the village shall be equal to the amount provided in the village fee schedule. 
(b)  The standard labor charge shall include the services of one person and all equipment or tools required for the project. General plan review by the water and sewer department is included in the scope of service. 
(c)  The fee for water and sewer connections and inspections shall be as set forth in the village fee schedule. 
(d)  Service connections shall be completed under the authority of a permit with direct supervision of the water department. The connection shall be performed by a licensed and bonded plumber. All procedures, tools and materials used shall be approved by the water department. 
(e)  The fee for service connection inspection shall be based upon the standard labor charge provided in the village fee schedule. The estimated labor requirements for the inspection services are included in the village fee schedule. If it becomes necessary for the water department to make the service connection to the public water main, the estimated labor charges as provided in the village fee schedule for such connections shall apply. 
(f)  Materials used shall be charged at cost, in addition to the labor cost. The sewer and water department shall utilize these schedules for calculating charges. All schedule values are subject to adjustment to account for unusual circumstances. 
(g)  During construction projects, when a section of village water main must be shut down to allow for the interconnection with a new water main, assistance provided to the contractor by the water department for the execution of the shut-down shall be reimbursed at the standard labor charge provided in the village fee schedule. 
(Code 1940, §§ 39.015, 39.126; Code 1964, § 06-34; Ord. of 3-9-1959, § 1; Ord. of 6-25-1962, § 1; Ord. of 12-14-1964, § 1; Ord. of 1-10-1966, § 3; Ord. No. 1968-39, § 2, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1970-3, § 1, 4-13-1970; Ord. No. 1974-04, § 1, 5-13-1974; Ord. No. 1975-2, § 2, 1-27-1975; Ord. No. 1978-4, § 2, 3-13-1978; Ord. No. 1979-9, § A, 3-12-1979; Ord. No. 1981-9, 3-9-1981; Ord. No. 1983-24, 10-24-1983; Ord. No. 1985-11, 3-11-1985; Ord. No. 1985-24, 5-13-1985; Ord. No. 98-22, 5-11-1998; Ord. No. 2001-40, 7-23-2001; Ord. No. 2005-03, 2-14-2005; Ord. No. 2005-06, 2-28-2005; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006; Ord. No. 2018-54 , § 4, 6-25-2018)  
Sec. 12-104. - Water meter installation; fees. 
(a)  The installation of a new water meter shall be made by the water department personnel. The building owner or customer shall provide the proper installation of piping, fittings, and accessories in the general location, and to the dimensions specified by the water department, for the installation of the new meter. All preparatory work shall be approved by the water department. 
(b)  The water department shall provide the water meter for the customer at cost, plus an installation cost computed with the standard labor charge per employee. Any additional materials or fittings not provided by the customer, but required to complete the installation, shall be supplied at cost to the customer. 
(c)  The water department shall maintain a schedule of current material costs for estimating installation costs. The labor charge specified for the meter installation provided in the village fee schedule is subject to adjustment by the water department to compensate for unusual installation conditions. 
(Code 1940, §§ 39.015, 39.126; Code 1964, § 06-34; Ord. of 3-9-1959, § 1; Ord. of 6-25-1962, § 1; Ord. of 12-14-1964, § 1; Ord. of 1-10-1966, § 3; Ord. No. 1968-39, § 2, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1970-3, § 1, 4-13-1970; Ord. No. 1974-04, § 1, 5-13-1974; Ord. No. 1975-2, § 2, 1-27-1975; Ord. No. 1978-4, § 2, 3-13-1978; Ord. No. 1979-9, § A, 3-12-1979; Ord. No. 1981-9, 3-9-1981; Ord. No. 1983-24, 10-24-1983; Ord. No. 1985-11, 3-11-1985; Ord. No. 1985-24, 5-13-1985; Ord. No. 98-22, 5-11-1998; Ord. No. 2001-40, 7-23-2001; Ord. No. 2005-03, 2-14-2005; Ord. No. 2005-06, 2-28-2005; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006).  
Sec. 12-105. - Construction water use; fees. 
The water department will provide a water meter for measuring actual water use during construction of improvements. The standard village rates shall apply to all metered volumes. Use of hydrant meter shall require a nonrefundable deposit in the amount provided in the village fee schedule. Where the use of water meter is not practical, the water department shall apply the fees provided in the village fee schedule. 
(Code 1940, §§ 39.015, 39.126; Code 1964, § 06-34; Ord. of 3-9-1959, § 1; Ord. of 6-25-1962, § 1; Ord. of 12-14-1964, § 1; Ord. of 1-10-1966, § 3; Ord. No. 1968-39, § 2, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1970-3, § 1, 4-13-1970; Ord. No. 1974-04, § 1, 5-13-1974; Ord. No. 1975-2, § 2, 1-27-1975; Ord. No. 1978-4, § 2, 3-13-1978; Ord. No. 1979-9, § A, 3-12-1979; Ord. No. 1981-9, 3-9-1981; Ord. No. 1983-24, 10-24-1983; Ord. No. 1985-11, 3-11-1985; Ord. No. 1985-24, 5-13-1985; Ord. No. 98-22, 5-11-1998; Ord. No. 2001-40, 7-23-2001; Ord. No. 2005-03, 2-14-2005; Ord. No. 2005-06, 2-28-2005; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006).  
Sec. 12-106. - Restoration of paved areas; inspection; fees. 
(a)  The restoration of the pavement, sidewalks, and parkway areas disturbed during sewer or water construction shall be completed to the satisfaction of the village manager or his designee. 
(b)  A cash restoration bond in the amount of 50 percent of the value of the sewer or water work shall be held by the village for a period of 12 months to ensure satisfactory repairs have been made. 
(c)  The water and sewer department shall inspect the restoration work and advise the contractor of any deficiencies. A labor charge of one man-hour shall be assessed for this purpose at the standard charge rate. 
(Code 1940, §§ 39.015, 39.126; Code 1964, § 06-34; Ord. of 3-9-1959, § 1; Ord. of 6-25-1962, § 1; Ord. of 12-14-1964, § 1; Ord. of 1-10-66, § 3; Ord. No. 1968-39, § 2, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1970-3, § 1, 4-13-1970; Ord. No. 1974-04, § 1, 5-13-1974; Ord. No. 1975-2, § 2, 1-27-1975; Ord. No. 1978-4, § 2, 3-13-1978; Ord. No. 1979-9, § A, 3-12-1979; Ord. No. 1981-9, 3-9-1981; Ord. No. 1983-24, 10-24-1983; Ord. No. 1985-11, 3-11-1985; Ord. No. 1985-24, 5-13-1985; Ord. No. 98-22, 5-11-1998; Ord. No. 2001-40, 7-23-2001; Ord. No. 2005-03, 2-14-2005; Ord. No. 2005-06, 2-28-2005; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006).  
Sec. 12-107. - Fees for small wireless right-of-way applications. 
(a)  Any person filing an application under section 46-448(b) of this Code shall pay an application fee of $650.00 for an application to collocate a single small wireless facility on an existing utility pole or wireless support structure, and $350.00 for each small wireless facility addressed in a consolidated application to collocate more than one small wireless facility on existing utility poles or wireless support structures. 
(b)  Any person filing an application under section 46-448(b) of this Code shall pay an application fee of $1,000.00 for each small wireless facility addressed in an application that includes the installation of a new utility pole for such collocation. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any contrary provision of state law or local ordinance, applications filed pursuant to section 46-448(b) of this Code shall be accompanied by the required application fee. Application fees shall be non-refundable. 
(Ord. No. 2018-62 , § 3, 7-23-2018)
