Sec. 12-403. - Compliance required. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator or occupant of a premises, building or accessory structure to fail, refuse or neglect to maintain such premises, or building, or accessory structure in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1964, § 06-51; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Secs. 12-404—12-419. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
 
Sec. 12-420. - Inspections and right of entry. 
(a)  Inspections authorized. The enforcement officer is hereby authorized to conduct inspections of buildings, accessory structures and the premises on which they are located to enforce the provisions of this Code in response to complaints or whenever the enforcement officer shall deem such inspections necessary; provided, however, that such inspections must be made at reasonable times and upon reasonable notice to, and with the consent of, the owner or operator or occupant, except when an emergency requires immediate action. 
(b)  Inspection upon warrant. Whenever the enforcement officer, after presentation of proper credentials and request for authorization to inspect, is refused access to any building, accessory structure or premises, or part thereof, the enforcement officer is authorized to petition any judge for the issuance of a search warrant authorizing the inspection of such building on the premises thereof for the purpose of making such inspections as shall be necessary to the enforcement of the provisions of this Code. 
(c)  Owner's right of entry. Every occupant of a building or premises, or portion thereof, shall give the owner thereof, or its agent or employees, access to any part of such building or its premises for the purposes of making an inspection, repair or alteration as necessary to effect compliance with the provisions of this Code or with any lawful order issued pursuant to the provisions of this Code. Entry pursuant to this subsection shall be made only at reasonable times and after reasonable notice to the occupant unless an emergency requires immediate action. 
(Code 1964, § 06-57; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Sec. 12-421. - Notice of violations. 
(a)  Notice required. Whenever, in the opinion of the enforcement officer, after inspection of a building, premises or accessory structure, violation of any provision of this Code is found to exist, the enforcement officer shall comply with the procedure for settling and compromising ordinance violations and index of minimum fines. 
(b)  Method of service. Notice shall be given either by personal service or by compliance with the procedure for settling and compromising ordinance violations and index or minimum fines. 
(c)  Required content. Such notice may contain an outline of remedial actions which if taken will affect such compliance. 
(Code 1964, § 06-58; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Sec. 12-422. - Effect of noncompliance. 
If any alleged violation for which notice has been given in conformity with this Code is not corrected or eliminated within the time specified in such notice, then the responsible owner, operator and/or occupant shall be subject to the index of minimum fines prescribed by the procedure for settling and compromising ordinances, violations and index of minimum fees. 
(Code 1964, § 06-59; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Sec. 12-423. - Records. 
The chief building inspector shall maintain a record of the following: 
(1)  Each and every complaint received by or referred to the chief building inspector of any alleged violation of this Code; 
(2)  Any investigations undertaken or directed by the chief building inspector and any and all reports or other documents related to such investigation; and 
(3)  Any and all warrants and notices related to the enforcement of the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1964, § 06-50; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Sec. 12-424. - Imposing of penalty; no bar to legal action. 
The imposition of any fine pursuant to the procedure for settling and compromising ordinance violations and index of minimum fines shall not preclude the village from instituting an appropriate action or proceeding in a court of proper jurisdiction to prevent any unlawful repair or maintenance; to restrain, correct or abate a violation; to prevent the occupancy of a building; or to require compliance with the provisions of this Code or other applicable laws, ordinances, orders and determinations of the enforcement officer. 
(Code 1964, § 06-60; Ord. No. 0-44, 10-8-1990)  
Secs. 12-425—12-443. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - STANDARDS AND REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 12-444. - Responsibilities of owners and operators. 
Every owner or operator of a building, accessory structure or premises shall: 
(1)  Compliance with duties. Comply with all of the duties, standards and responsibilities imposed by this Code. No owner or operator shall let, lease, license or otherwise permit any other person to occupy any premises unless such premises complies with all of the duties, standards, and responsibilities imposed by this Code and is otherwise fit for human use and occupancy. 
(2)  Shared area facilities. Maintain in a clean and safe condition the shared area of a building or premises on which it is located, and maintain and repair any equipment, fixtures or facilities which said owner or operator supplies or is otherwise required to provide under this Code. 
(3)  Extermination. Prevent infestation of any premises and exterminate any insects, rodents or other pests in, on or about any premises. 
(4)  Garbage and rubbish disposal. Supply and maintain facilities for the collection, storage and disposal of trash, garbage and rubbish as required by this Code. 
(5)  Accumulation of debris and storage of goods. Prevent the existence of any accumulation of rubbish, garbage, boxes, lumber, fire wood, scrap metal or any other material or substance which may cause or contribute to any infestation, fire hazard, threat to public welfare or safety, an unclean or unsanitary condition, litter or other conditions of deterioration. 
(Code 1964, § 06-53; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Sec. 12-445. - Responsibility of occupants. 
Every occupant of a premises or building shall: 
(1)  Maintenance. Maintain in a safe and sanitary condition that part of a building or premises which such occupant controls, including, but not limited to, any share of common areas and facilities. 
(2)  Garbage and rubbish disposal. Dispose of all garbage, trash and rubbish in a clean and sanitary manner by placing it in approved storage or disposal facilities, which are safe and sanitary. 
(3)  Accumulation of debris and storage of goods. Prevent the existence of or any accumulation of rubbish, garbage, boxes, lumber, firewood, scrap metal or any other material or substance which may cause or contribute to an infestation, fire hazard, threat to public welfare or safety, an unclean or unsanitary condition, litter or other condition of deterioration. 
(Code 1964, § 06-54; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Sec. 12-446. - Transfer of responsibility. 
An owner and an operator shall not be relieved of the requirements imposed by this Code by forming a contract with another person to discharge the requirements imposed by this Code. 
(Code 1964, § 06-56; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Sec. 12-447. - Number of occupants permitted. 
The number of persons occupying a dwelling unit shall not exceed 1.5 times the number of habitable rooms contained in such dwelling unit. In the calculation of the number of persons occupying a dwelling unit, children under one year of age shall not be included, and children under the age of 12 years shall be counted as one-half person. 
(Code 1964, § 06-45; Ord. of 11-24-1958, § 1)  
Sec. 12-448. - Basic equipment and facilities required. 
No person shall occupy as owner-occupant or let to another for occupancy any dwelling or dwelling unit, for the purpose of living, sleeping, cooking or eating therein, which does not comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Every dwelling unit shall contain a kitchen sink in good working condition and properly connected to the water system and sewer system. 
(2)  Every dwelling unit (except as otherwise permitted in this section) shall contain a room which affords privacy to a person, within such room and which is equipped with a flush water closet and a lavatory basin in good working condition and properly connected to water and sewer systems. 
(3)  Every dwelling unit (except as otherwise permitted in this section) shall contain, within a room which affords privacy to a person within such room, a bathtub or shower in good working condition and properly connected to water and sewer systems. 
(4)  The occupants of not more than two dwelling units may share a single flush water closet, a single lavatory basin, and a single bathtub or shower within a room which affords privacy to a person within such room if: 
a.  Neither of the two dwelling units contain more than two rooms, provided that for the purpose of this subsection, a kitchenette or an efficiency kitchen with not more than 60 square feet of floor area shall not be counted as a room; 
b.  The habitable area of each of such dwelling units shall equal not more than 400 square feet of floor area; and 
c.  Such water closet, lavatory basin, and bathtub or shower shall be in good working condition and properly connected to water and sewer systems. 
(5)  Every kitchen sink, lavatory basin, and bathtub or shower required under the provision of this section shall be properly connected with both hot and cold water lines. 
(6)  Every dwelling unit shall be supplied with adequate rubbish storage facilities in accordance with the provisions of this Code regarding solid waste. 
(7)  Every dwelling unit shall have adequate garbage disposal facilities or garbage storage containers in accordance with the provisions of this Code regarding solid waste. 
(8)  Every dwelling shall have supplied water-heating facilities which are properly installed, are maintained in safe and good working condition, are properly connected with the hot water lines required under this section, and are capable of heating water to such a temperature as to permit an adequate amount of water to be drawn at every required kitchen sink, lavatory basin, bathtub or shower at a temperature of not less than 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Such supplied water-heating facilities shall be capable of meeting the requirements of this section when the dwelling or dwelling unit heating facilities required under the provisions of this article are not in operation. 
(9)  Every dwelling unit shall have a minimum of two safe unobstructed means of egress leading to safe and open space at ground level, unless of fire-resistive construction whereby one means of egress is sufficient. 
(Code 1964, § 06-46; Ord. of 11-24-1958, § 1)  
Sec. 12-449. - Rat control requirements. 
(a)  Public nuisance. All rats are a nuisance to health and are otherwise injurious to the public health and welfare and are hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(b)  Extermination. It shall be unlawful for the owners of, and persons interested in private property, to permit the ingress of rats to their property. The failure to prevent the ingress of rats to their property and of rat extermination therein, shall constitute a violation of this section. 
(c)  Extermination by village. When the owners of, and persons interested in private property, fail to prevent ingress of rats to their property and of rat extermination therein, as provided in this section, the village manager or his designee shall cause such rat extermination, and any reasonable expense incurred by the village in so doing, shall be charged against the owner so failing, which may be recovered in an appropriate action in law instituted by the village attorney. 
(d)  Lien. In addition to all other remedies provided by law, the village shall have a lien on the real estate on which rats are a nuisance, for the reasonable cost of exterminating the rats. Such lien shall be superior to all other liens and encumbrances, except tax liens. Within 60 days after such cost and expense is incurred, the village manager, in the name and on behalf of the village, shall file notice of lien in the office of the county recorder of deeds. This notice of lien shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: 
(1)  A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof. 
(2)  The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service. 
(3)  The dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the village. 
Such lien shall not be valid as to any purchaser whose rights in and to the real estate have arisen subsequent to the extermination of such rats and prior to the filing of such notice, or as to any mortgagee, judgment creditor or other lien or whose rights in and to the real estate have arisen prior to the filing of such notice. 
(e)  Release of lien. Upon payment of the cost and expense by the owner of, or persons interested in the property, after such notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the village and the release may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. 
(Code 1964, § 06-47; Ord. of 2-14-1966)  
Sec. 12-450. - Light, ventilation and heating requirements. 
No person shall occupy as owner-occupant or let to another for occupancy any dwelling or dwelling unit, for the purpose of living therein, which does not comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Every habitable room shall have at least one window or skylight facing directly to the outdoors. The minimum total window area, measured between stops, for every habitable room shall be ten percent of the floor area of such room. Whenever walls or other portions of a structure face a window of any such room and such light-obstruction structures are located less than three feet from the window and extend to a level above that of a ceiling of the rooms, such a window shall not be included as contributing to the required minimum total window area. Whenever the only window in a room is a skylight-type window in the top of such room, the total window area of such skylight shall equal at least 15 percent of the total floor area of such room. 
(2)  Every habitable room shall have at least one window or skylight which can easily be opened or such other device as will adequately ventilate the room. The total of openable window area in every habitable room shall be equal to at least 45 percent of the minimum window area size or minimum skylight window size required in this section, except where there is supplied some other device affording adequate ventilation and approved by the officers of the village. 
(3)  Every bathroom and water closet compartment shall comply with the light and ventilation requirements for habitable rooms contained in this section, except that no window or skylight shall be required in adequately ventilated bathrooms and water closet compartments equipped with a ventilation system which is kept in continuous operation and approved by the officers of the village. 
(4)  Every habitable room of such dwellings shall contain at least two separate floor or wall type electric convenience outlets, or one such convenience outlet and one supplied ceiling-type electric light fixture; and every water closet compartment, bathroom, laundry room, furnace room and public hall shall contain at least one supplied ceiling or wall type electric light fixture. Every such outlet and fixture shall be properly installed and shall be connected to the source of electric power in a safe manner. 
(5)  Every dwelling shall have heating facilities which are properly installed, are maintained in safe and good working condition, and are capable of safely and adequately heating all habitable rooms, bathrooms, and water closet compartments in every dwelling unit located therein during the period from October 1 to May 31 to a temperature of at least 68 degrees Fahrenheit between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. of each day and maintain a temperature of not less than 60 degrees during other hours. The temperature shall be measured at a point three feet above the floor and three feet from exterior walls. Exception: When the exterior temperature falls below zero degrees Fahrenheit and the heating system is operating at its full capacity, a minimum room temperature of 60 degrees Fahrenheit shall be maintained at all times. 
(6)  Every public hall and stairway in every multiple dwelling containing five or more dwelling units shall be adequately lighted at all time. Every public hall and stairway in structures devoted solely to dwelling occupancy and containing not more than four dwelling units may be supplied with conveniently located light switches, controlling an adequate lighting system which may be turned on when needed, instead of full-time lighting. 
(7)  During that portion of each year from May 1 through October 31 for protection against mosquitoes, flies, and other insects, every door opening directly from a dwelling unit to outdoor space shall have supplied screens and a self-closing device; and every window or other device with openings to outdoor space, used or intended to be used for ventilation, shall likewise be supplied with screens. 
(8)  Every basement or cellar window used or intended for ventilation and every other opening to a basement which might provide an entry for rodents, shall be supplied with a screen or such other device as will effectively prevent their entrance. 
(Code 1964, § 06-48; Ord. of 11-24-1958, § 1; Ord. No. 1975-2, § 3, 1-27-1975; Ord. No. 1981-9, 3-9-1981; Ord. No. 1988-40, 11-28-1988)  
Sec. 12-451. - Space, room arrangement and similar requirements. 
No person shall occupy or let to another for occupancy any dwelling or dwelling unit, for the purpose of living therein, which does not comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Every dwelling unit must contain at least 150 square feet of floor space for the first occupant thereof and 100 square feet of floor space for each additional occupant thereof, such floor area not to include verandas, porches, terraces, balconies and basements; provided, however, that at least one habitable room in each dwelling unit shall have no less than 150 square feet of floor space. In addition to the other requirements of this section applicable to all dwelling units, every apartment shall contain a total of at least 400 square feet of floor space. 
(2)  Every sleeping room used for single occupancy must contain at least 70 square feet of floor space and, if used for multiple occupancy, it shall contain at least 50 square feet of floor space for each occupant, provided that children under one year shall not be considered persons for such computation. 
(3)  No dwelling or dwelling unit containing two or more sleeping rooms shall have such room arrangements that access to a bathroom or water closet compartment intended for use by occupants of more than one sleeping room can be had only by going through another sleeping room; nor shall room arrangements be such that access to a sleeping room can be had only by going through another sleeping room or a bathroom or water closet compartment. Where a bathroom or water closet entry is through a kitchen, there must be a second bathroom, which does not open into a kitchen. 
(4)  At least one-half of the floor area of every habitable room shall have a ceiling height of at least seven feet, six inches, and the floor area of that part of any room where the ceiling height is less than five feet shall not be considered as part of the floor area of the room for the purpose of determining the maximum permissible occupancy thereof. 
(5)  No cellar space shall be used as a habitable room or dwelling unit. 
(6)  No basement space shall be used as a habitable room or dwelling unit unless: 
a.  The floor and walls are impervious to leakage of underground and surface runoff water and are insulated against dampness; 
b.  The total of window area in each room is equal to at least the minimum window area sizes as required in section 12-450(1); 
c.  Such required minimum window area is located entirely above the grade of the ground adjoining such window area; and 
d.  The total of openable window area in each room is equal to at least the minimum as required under this division, except where there is supplied some other device affording adequate ventilation and approved by the officers of the village. 
(Code 1964, § 06-49; Ord. of 11-24-1958, § 1)  
Sec. 12-452. - Maintenance standards. 
(a)  Generally. All buildings and premises and each part thereof shall be maintained in good repair, and each part of a building or premises shall perform the function for which such part was designed or intended to be used. 
(b)  Accessory structures. All garages, pools, tool sheds and all other accessory structures shall be maintained in good repair and shall be kept free from any infestation. Fences and roadside mailboxes shall be maintained in good repair and in the same condition required for other exterior surfaces. 
(c)  Driveways, walkways and parking areas. Concrete, asphalt, brick or other driveways, parking areas and walkways shall be maintained free from loose or broken materials, or cracks which are safety hazards. Such driveways, walkways and parking areas shall be repaired as necessary to avoid safety hazards and shall be maintained in forms designed to prevent the spread of gravel or debris to public ways, easements and adjoining private property. 
(d)  Exterior surfaces. All exterior surfaces of any building or accessory structure shall be reasonably capable of withstanding the effects of the elements and decay. Any exterior surface, which is deteriorated, decayed, disintegrated or which has lost its reasonable capability to withstand the effects of the elements shall be repaired. Such repair is intended to bring the exterior surface material back to its original weather resistant properties and condition of original installation. Illustrative corrective remedies would include restaining of originally stained surfaces; repainting of surfaces having been painted and displaying peeling, chipping or flaking; tuckpointing of masonry or stone exteriors; and renovation of stucco or cement finishes. This section is not intended to prohibit replacement of an original material with that of another. 
(e)  Fixtures, utilities and equipment. Fixtures, utilities and equipment, including, but not limited to, chimneys, heating, air conditioning, refrigeration, and ventilation equipment and fixtures, that are part of or used in or on a building and the real estate upon which such building is located shall be maintained in good repair and working order so that they function safely and effectively without threat to health and safety. 
(f)  Foundations, exterior walls and roofs. Every foundation, exterior wall and roof of every building shall be substantially weather-tight; shall not harbor any infestation; shall be kept in sound condition and good repair; shall be kept free of holes or breaks, and loose or rotting boards, timbers, bricks, stones and other structural material; and shall be safe for the intended use and load. 
(g)  Gutters, downspouts and sump pumps. All gutters and downspouts shall be maintained free of debris which might prevent their proper function and shall not be allowed to discharge in a manner which might create unnecessary erosion. All gutters and downspouts shall be securely fastened to the building of which they serve. No sump pump shall discharge across any public right-of-way causing a hazard or other unsafe condition. All painted gutter and downspout surfaces shall be maintained like exterior surfaces. 
(h)  Ingress and egress. The means of ingress to and egress from any building, including, but not limited to, hallways, corridors, stairs, gangways and porches, shall be maintained in good repair and free from obstructions. 
(i)  Plumbing. Every plumbing fixture and all water and waste pipes shall be properly installed, properly maintained and in sanitary working condition. 
(j)  Protective railings. Any handrails, guardrails or other types of protective railings required to be constructed or installed under any provision of this Code or which have otherwise been constructed and installed shall be maintained in good repair. All painted surfaces on handrails, guardrails and other protective railings shall be maintained like exterior surfaces. 
(k)  Infestation. Every building, accessory structure and premises shall be free from any infestation. 
(l)  Stairways and porches. Every inside and outside stairway, and every porch and appurtenance thereto, shall be maintained in a good repair, shall be capable of supporting the loads which normal use may cause to be placed thereon, and shall be maintained like any other exterior surface. 
(m)  Vegetation. No lot or easement within the village shall have uncontrolled growths of vegetation in violation of this Code. 
(n)  Windows, exterior doors, and awnings. Every window, storm exterior door, screens, basement or cellar door and hatchway shall be substantially weather-tight, wind-tight and watertight; shall be capable of being easily opened unless designed to be fixed; shall be kept in good repair, and shall be maintained like any other exterior surface. Awnings shall be kept in good repair and maintained like any other exterior surface. 
(o)  Electrical. Every electrical fixture, service panel, or other electrical connection to the overhead service shall be maintained in good and safe working condition. 
(p)  Outdoor storage. The storage of materials, supplies, commodities or property, other than vehicles in good running condition, currently licensed by the state and the village, except where such goods or items are wholly located within a building or structure, shall not be permitted; whereas, the on-site storage of building material for a reasonable time in connection with the construction of any lawfully permitted building or structure anywhere in the village shall not be considered a violation of this Code. Further, the storage of firewood shall be maintained as follows: All firewood must be neatly stacked in a rack or area raised off the ground a minimum distance of six inches. Stacks of cut firewood shall not exceed five feet in height. The total length of the firewood stack shall not exceed 20 feet. Storage shall be arranged and located in the rear yard area only, and in a manner that does not constitute a hazard or nuisance. 
(q)  Public easements and rights-of-way. No brush, tree or other growth shall be permitted to obstruct, restrict or encroach any public sidewalk, alley, public drive, or public right-of-way or obstruct any field of vision. 
(Code 1964, § 06-52; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Secs. 12-453—12-472. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - MOTELS, HOTELS AND ROOMING HOUSES 
 
Sec. 12-473. - Compliance required. 
No person shall operate a hotel, motel or rooming house, or shall occupy or let to another for occupancy any rooming unit in any hotel, motel or rooming house, except in compliance with the provisions of every section of this article, except sections 12-448 and 12-452. 
(Code 1964, § 06-55(a); Ord. of 11-24-1958, § 1; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Sec. 12-474. - Permit and initial inspection. 
(a)  No person shall operate a hotel, motel, or rooming house within the village, until he has made application for a permit to do so, to the village, and paid the annual inspection fees in the amount provided in the village fee schedule and has been inspected by officers of the village and has been found to meet all requirements of this article and all health, fire prevention and other ordinances pertaining to hotels, motels and rooming house, and the laws of the state. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the designated village officers to inspect each hotel, motel or rooming house within a reasonable time after being notified by the village clerk that the applicant has applied for a permit to operate a hotel, motel or rooming house and has paid the annual inspection fee. 
(c)  The officers of the village shall refuse the applicant the permit to operate a hotel, motel or rooming house until he has complied with all ordinances of the village pertaining to health and fire prevention and all laws of the state in regard to hotels, motels and rooming houses. 
(Code 1964, § 06-55(b); Ord. of 11-24-1958, § 1; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Sec. 12-475. - Certificate as to condition of premises. 
No person shall operate a hotel, motel or rooming house until he has received a certificate from the officers of the village as to the condition of the premises. Such certificate shall be displayed in a conspicuous place within the hotel, motel or rooming house. 
(Code 1964, § 06-55(c); Ord. of 11-24-1958, § 1; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Sec. 12-476. - Periodic inspections. 
Every hotel, motel and rooming house operated and maintained in the village shall be inspected by officers of the village semi-annually, or more often, if deemed necessary by the village. The inspections shall be made to ascertain that the operator of such hotel, motel or rooming house has and does conform to all requirements of this article, all other health and fire prevention ordinances of the village and all laws of the state regarding hotels, motels and rooming houses. 
(Code 1964, § 06-55(d); Ord. of 11-24-1958, § 1; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Sec. 12-477. - Inspection fees. 
(a)  Hotels and motels. It shall be the duty of every person maintaining or operating a hotel or motel to pay to the village clerk an annual inspection fee in the amount provided in the village fee schedule for each unit used for the accommodation of guests, lodgers or roomers in such hotel or motel. For the purpose of this section, the term "units" means the space rented to or occupied by the same tenant. 
(b)  Rooming houses. It shall be the duty of every person maintaining or operating a rooming house to pay the village clerk an annual inspection fee and the additional sum for every roomer over five in any such rooming house in the amounts provided in the village fee schedule. 
(Code 1964, § 06-55(e—f); Ord. of 11-24-1958, § 1; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Sec. 12-478. - Toilet facilities. 
(a)  At least one flush water closet, lavatory basin and bathtub or shower, properly connected to the water and sewer system, and in good working condition, shall be supplied for each eight persons or fractions thereof residing within a hotel, motel, or rooming house, including members of the operator's family whenever they share the use of such facilities; provided that, in a hotel, motel or rooming house where rooms are let to males, flush urinals may be substituted for not more than one-half the required number of water closets. 
(b)  All such facilities shall be so located within the buildings as to be reasonably accessible from a common hall or passageway to all persons sharing such facilities, within a room which affords privacy to a person within such room. 
(c)  Every lavatory basin and bathtub or shower shall be supplied with hot water at all times. 
(d)  No such facilities shall be located in a cellar. 
(Code 1964, § 06-55(g); Ord. of 11-24-1958, § 1; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Sec. 12-479. - Space and egress requirements. 
Every room occupied for sleeping purposes by one person in a hotel, motel or rooming house shall contain at least 70 square feet of floor space, and every room occupied for sleeping purposes by more than one person shall contain at least 50 square feet of floor space for each occupant thereof. Every rooming unit shall have safe, unobstructed means of egress leading to a safe and open space at ground level, as required by the laws of the state and the ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1964, § 06-55(h); Ord. of 11-24-1958, § 1; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Sec. 12-480. - Change and maintenance of linens. 
The operator of every hotel, motel, or rooming house shall change supplied bed linen and towels therein at least once each week, and prior to the letting of any room to any occupant. The operator shall be responsible for the maintenance of all supplied bedding in a clean and sanitary manner. 
(Code 1964, § 06-55(i); Ord. of 11-24-1958, § 1; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Sec. 12-481. - Premises maintenance. 
The operator of every hotel, motel, or rooming house shall be responsible for the sanitary maintenance of all walls, floors and ceiling, and the maintenance and sanitary condition in every part of the hotel, motel or rooming house. He shall be further responsible for the sanitary maintenance of the entire premises where the entire structure of building is leased or occupied by the operator. 
(Code 1964, § 06-55(j); Ord. of 11-24-1958, § 1; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Sec. 12-482. - Notice to correct defects; closing defective premises. 
(a)  Whenever upon inspection of any hotel, motel or rooming house, the officers of the village find that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of any of the provisions of this article or other health or fire prevention ordinances of the village or the laws of the state regarding hotels, motels or rooming houses, the officers of the village shall give notice in writing to the operator of such hotel, motel or rooming house that, unless conditions or practices are corrected within a reasonable time of not less than ten days, the operator's right to operate a hotel, motel or rooming house will be suspended. 
(b)  At the end of such period of time, the inspector shall reinspect such hotel, motel or rooming house, and if he finds that such conditions or practices have not been corrected, he shall give notice in writing to the operator that the hotel, motel or rooming house is closed. 
(c)  Upon receipt of such notice, the operator of such hotel, motel or rooming house shall immediately cease operating the same, and no person shall occupy, for sleeping of living purposes, any rooming unit thereof therein. 
(Code 1964, § 06-55(k); Ord. of 11-24-1958, § 1; Ord. No. 90-44, 10-8-1990)  
Secs. 12-483—12-502. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL PROPERTY MAINTENANCE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Unsafe buildings, 65 ILCS 5/11-31-1 et seq.; removal of deteriorated or damaged building in fire limits, 65 ILCS 5/11-8-3; promotion of health, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-5. 
 
Sec. 12-503. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to provide guidelines appropriate for maintaining and enhancing the visual appearance of the village's commercial and industrial districts. Proper building and site maintenance contributes to an attractive shopping and business environment, preserves property values and promotes public health safety and welfare. 
(Code 1964, § 32-1; Ord. No. 1987-21, 9-28-1987)  
Sec. 12-504. - Objectives. 
The objectives of this article are to: 
(1)  Enhance community appearance through the participation of business, industry, civic groups and local government officials. 
(2)  Encourage maintenance of all commercially and industrially owned property. 
(3)  Foster community interest with the intent of developing a positive community image. 
(4)  Create an attractive business environment. 
(Code 1964, § 32-2; Ord. No. 1987-21, 9-28-1987)  
Sec. 12-505. - Jurisdiction. 
The provisions of this article shall apply to all commercial and industrial property located within the commercial, light manufacturing, and all other zoning classifications where commercial or industrial property exists. 
(Code 1964, § 32-3; Ord. No. 1987-21, 9-28-1987)  
Sec. 12-506. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Appearance means the outward aspect visible to the public. 
Appurtenances means the visible, functional objects accessory to and part of the exterior of a building. 
Landscape means plant materials, topography and other natural physical elements combined in relation to one another and to manmade structures. 
Lot means a parcel of land with a front yard abutting a public street, and occupied or to be occupied by one whole building and any accessory buildings or uses authorized in connection therewith, including such open spaces as are arranged or designed to be used in connection with such building. 
Plant materials means trees, shrubs, vines, ground covers, grass, perennials, annuals and bulbs. 
Street hardware means manmade objects other than buildings which are part of the streetscape. Examples of street hardware are: lamp posts, utility poles, traffic lights, traffic signs, benches, litter containers, planting containers, fire hydrants and other items which the village has jurisdiction over. 
(Code 1964, § 32-4; Ord. No. 1987-21, 9-28-1987)  
Sec. 12-507. - Property maintenance standards. 
(a)  Buildings and appurtenances. The exterior portion of buildings and exterior appurtenances, including signs, shall be kept clean and painted or repaired as necessary to present a neat appearance. The exterior portion of buildings and exterior appurtenances which are deteriorated, worn or damaged shall be repaired or replaced. 
(b)  Lots. Vacant lots shall be kept clear of refuse, debris and hazardous material and shall have the vegetation cut to conform with all applicable provisions of this Code. Landscaped materials, other than plantings, which have been damaged or have deteriorated shall be repaired or replaced. Plantings shall be maintained to reflect a healthy appearance. Plant materials which have deteriorated or died shall be replaced. 
(c)  Parking areas. Parking areas shall be kept in good repair, properly marked and clear of debris and hazardous material. 
(d)  Open public access area. 
(1)  Authorized benches located on public right-of-way shall conform to the provisions outlined in this Code. 
(2)  Refuse containers of an aesthetically suitable design shall be placed in locations which promote their use. The village encourages business owners to participate in the purchase of refuse containers for use on public right-of-way. However, in the interest of coordinating container design, the village reserves the right to approve the design. 
(3)  Parkway plantings shall be maintained by the adjacent property owner or tenant in order to maintain the overall appearance of the area. 
(4)  Sidewalks, curbs and gutters and other public improvements in the public right-of-way shall be repaired and maintained as necessary. 
(5)  Street hardware shall be maintained and replaced if necessary. 
(Code 1964, § 32-5; Ord. No. 1987-21, 9-28-1987)  
Sec. 12-508. - Incentives and awards. 
The village, in cooperation with the village chamber of commerce, will recognize businesses that exhibit outstanding achievements in the area of property maintenance and appearance. 
(Code 1964, § 32-6; Ord. No. 1987-21, 9-28-87)  
Secs. 12-509—12-539. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - DANGEROUS BUILDINGS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Unsafe buildings, 65 ILCS 5/11-31-1 et seq.; removal of deteriorated or damaged building in fire limits, 65 ILCS 5/11-8-3; promotion of health, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-5. 
 
Sec. 12-540. - Dangerous building defined. 
The term "dangerous building," as used in this article, is hereby defined to mean and include any building, shed, fence, or other manmade structure which is dangerous to the public health because of its condition, and which may cause or aid in the spread of disease or injury to the health of the occupants of it or of neighboring structures; any building, shed, fence, or other manmade structure which, because of faulty construction, age, lack of proper repair or any other cause, is especially liable to fire, and constitutes or creates a fire hazard; any building, shed, fence, or other manmade structure which, by reason of faulty construction, age, lack of proper repair or any other cause, is liable to cause injury or damage by collapsing or by a collapse or fall or any part of such structure; and any building, shed, fence, or other manmade structure which, because of its condition or because of lack of doors or windows, is available to and frequented by malefactors or disorderly persons who are not lawful occupants of such structures. 
(Code 1940, § 38.001; Code 1964, § 06-62)  
Sec. 12-541. - Declared to be nuisances. 
Any dangerous building in the village is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(Code 1940, § 38.002; Code 1964, § 06-63)  
Sec. 12-542. - Existence and occupancy prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or permit the existence of any dangerous building owned by him in the village, and it shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant or person in custody of any dangerous building to permit the same to remain in a dangerous condition, or to occupy such building or permit it to be occupied while it is or remains in a dangerous condition. 
(Code 1940, § 38.003; Code 1964, § 06-64)  
Sec. 12-543. - Correction of defects or removal generally. 
(a)  Whenever the building inspector, fire chief, health inspector, or any other officer or employee of the village, shall be of the opinion that any building or structure in the village is a dangerous building, he shall file a written statement to this effect with the village manager. The manager shall thereupon cause written notice to be served upon the owner thereof, and upon the occupant thereof, if any, by registered mail or by personal service. 
(b)  Such notice shall state that the building has been declared to be in a dangerous condition, and that such dangerous condition must be removed or remedied by repairing or altering the building or by demolishing it, and that the condition must be remedied at once. The form of the notice shall be as determined from time to time by the village board. 
(c)  If the person receiving such notice has not complied therewith or taken an appeal from the determination of the officer or employee finding that a dangerous building exists within 15 days from the time when such notice is served upon such person by personal service or by registered mail, the village may proceed to have the condition remedied or the building demolished in accord with state law. 
(Code 1940, § 38.004; Code 1964, § 06-65)  
Sec. 12-544. - Removal of damaged buildings within fire limits. 
(a)  Any building or structure within the fire limits of the village damaged by fire, decay, or other cause to the extent of 50 percent of its value, shall be torn down and removed. 
(b)  Upon written notice by the building inspector, health inspector, fire chief, or any other village employee filed with the village manager, the manager shall notify the president of the receipt of such notice. The president shall then appoint three persons to determine whether or not such building or structure has been damaged to the extent of 50 percent of its value. 
(c)  A copy of the notice filed by the village officer, together with a notice of the appointment of this board of three persons to determine the damage, shall be served upon the owner of the premises by personal service or by registered mail to his last known address. 
(d)  The form of the notice shall be as determined from time to time by the village board. 
(e)  If the board of three members determines that the building in question has been damaged to the extent of 50 percent of its value, it shall be the duty of the owner to tear down or remove the building within 20 days after the finding of the board, and it shall be unlawful to occupy or permit such building to be occupied after such finding. 
(Code 1940, § 38.005; Code 1964, § 06-66)  
Secs. 12-545—12-566. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XI. - CONTRACTOR REGULATION  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 12-567. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Bituminous paving contractor means any person, individual proprietorship, partnership, or corporation engaged in the business of any construction or repairs using materials consisting of any mixture of, or stone cemented with, asphalt, bitumen, blacktop, macadam, mineral pitch, tars, or other petroleum products, and commonly referred to as asphalt or bituminous concrete. 
Boiler contractor means any person engaged in the business of selling, installing, repairing or replacing steam, vapor or hot water boilers. 
Building contractor means any person who undertakes to, or offers to undertake or purports to have the capacity to undertake or submits a bid or does himself or by or through others, construct, alter, repair, add to, subtract from, improve, move, wreck or demolish the whole or any part of a building structure within the corporate limits of the village, or the appurtenances thereto, for which a permit is required by this chapter. The term "building contractor" includes subcontractor and specialty contractor and any person doing business as a subcontractor shall be construed as engaged in the business of a "building contractor" for the purposes of this article. 
Catchbasin or sewer cleaner means any person who engages in the business of cleaning catchbasins or sewers or of collecting or transporting the contents of catchbasins or sewers or kindred refuse by wagon, cart or otherwise. 
Drain layer means any person engaged in the business of laying drains, sewers, tile or other sanitary systems within the village. 
Excavator means any person who, with horses and teams, electrically equipped apparatus, or steam shovels or other mechanical devices, or by day labor, excavates, removes or carries away dirt, rock, cinders, building material, sand, debris, or other substance or material in order to construct the foundation of any house, residence, store or other private or public building or structure requiring a foundation to be constructed below the level of the street, or any sewer, vault or other like work requiring the removal of dirt, rock, sand, debris or other substance. 
Mason contractor means any person engaging in the business commonly known as mason contracting. 
Roofer means any person engaged in the business of roofing, repairing, recoating, altering or changing roofs of buildings or other structures, whether under construction or otherwise, within the village, with tile, slate, sheet metal, mastic and gravel roofing, ready roofing, over-shingles, asphalt and asphalt shingle roofing, felt composition roofing or any other king of prepared roofing. 
Sheet metal worker means any person conducting a business or doing work commonly known as sheet metal work, including hot air furnace installation or repair, metal ceiling or gutter work, or any kind of sheet metal work, in or about any building in the village. 
Sidewalk contractor means any person engaged in the business of constructing or repairing sidewalks in any public street or place in the village. 
(Code 1940, §§ 25.123, 25.154, 25.165, 25.175, 25.201, 25.360, 25.373; Ord. of 12-27-1948, § 1; Ord. of 5-14-1962, §§ 1, 7; Ord. No. 1972-24, § 1, 7-24-1972)  
Secs. 12-568—12-597. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 
 
Sec. 12-598. - Required; exceptions. 
No person shall engage in the village in any business, trade, occupation or calling for which a license fee is prescribed herein without first obtaining a license to do so; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not be construed to require a license of a plumbing contractor or building contractor and, provided further, that any person licensed as a general contractor shall not be required to obtain any other license for the performance of any building specialty. 
(Code 1940, §§ 25.154, 25.175, 25.202, 25.360, 25.373, 39.125; Ord. of 12-27-1948, § 1; Ord. of 5-14-1962, §§ 1, 2, 6)  
Sec. 12-599. - Application. 
An application for a license under this division shall be made to the chief building inspector on forms to be provided by his office. The applicant shall state his qualifications and competency to engage in the business of a building contractor or in a building trade specialty or specialties. 
(Code 1940, §§ 25.124, 25.155, 25.176, 25.361, 25.374; Ord. of 5-14-1962, § 3)  
Sec. 12-600. - Fee. 
(a)  The annual fee for a license under this division shall be payable in advance at the office of the chief building inspector and shall be in the amount provided in the fee schedule. 
(b)  Where more than one person is employed in the establishment, an additional annual license fee in the amount provided in the village fee schedule shall be paid for each additional person over one so employed, except for employees working one day per week only. The number of employees shall be determined by the largest number employed at any previous time in the preceding year. For the first year, the fee and license shall be for the number of employees stated in the application. 
(c)  Licensed plumbers or licensed sewer builders who clean catchbasins or sewers as an incident to the repair of such catchbasins or sewers shall be exempt from payment of a fee under this section. 
(Code 1940, §§ 25.125, 25.156, 25.166, 25.177, 25.203, 25.360, 25.375, 39.125; Code 1964, § 06-63; Ord. of 12-27-1948, § 1; Ord. of 5-14-1962, §§ 1, 6; Ord. of 12-3-1962, § 1; Ord. No. 1972-24, § 2, 7-24-1972; Ord. No. 1975-2, § 4, 1-27-1975; Ord. No. 1992-19, 5-11-1992; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006)  
Sec. 12-601. - Issuance. 
Licenses required by this division shall be issued by the chief building inspector if he is satisfied that the applicant is competent to engage in the business or trade for which the license is sought and upon payment of the required fee. 
(Code 1940, §§ 25.124, 25.165, 25.176, 25.203, 25.361, 25.374; Code 1964, § 06-73; Ord. of 12-27-1948, § 1; Ord. of 5-14-1962, § 1)  
Sec. 12-602. - Duration; renewal. 
Licenses issued under this division shall be valid and have force for the year issued, and may be renewed upon expiration by payment in advance of the annual fee prescribed herein. 
(Code 1964, § 06-74; Ord. of 5-14-1962, § 4)  
Sec. 12-603. - Not transferable. 
No license issued under this division shall be transferable. 
(Code 1964, § 06-75; Ord. of 5-14-1962, § 5)  
Sec. 12-604. - Bond requirements. 
(a)  All building contractors, except those performing only glazing, painting and decorating, tuck pointing and cleaning, or tile, marble and mosaic work, shall, before performing any work in the village, provide the building department with a license and permit bond in the sum equal to the total cost of the proposed project, but such bond shall be for an amount of not less than $2,500.00 nor need be for an amount of more than $10,000.00. 
(b)  The purpose of the bond is to ensure that the contractor faithfully observes all of the provisions of the building codes, zoning code and all other codes and regulations of the village and that the contractor will correct any and all work improperly done to bring it into compliance with the applicable village codes and regulations. 
(c)  The sureties used shall be approved by the village manager. Such bonds shall be conditioned to save and hold harmless the village, its officials, and employees from all accidents and damages that may happen and also shall accrue to and be useable by the village for such purposes as, but not limited to, the repair, replacement or bringing back into condition of any street, curb, sidewalk, tree or other damages of items located within the public right-of-way, whether such damage or injury shall be inflicted by the principal or his agents, employees or workmen, as well as to guarantee compliance with the conditions of any license or permit issued to him by the village. 
(Code 1940, § 25.360; Code 1964, § 06-76; Ord. of 12-27-1948, § 1; Ord. of 5-14-1962, § 1; Ord. No. 92-42, 11-23-1992)  
Sec. 12-605. - Insurance requirements. 
No building permit for any construction in the village shall be issued until the contractors and each subcontractor who apply for the building permit or who have contracted to do the scheduled construction certify that the following insurance coverage's are in effect and provide the evidence of such coverage in the form of a certificate of insurance. Notice of cancellation of any insurance policy shall be given to the village clerk no less than 30 days before such cancellation is effective. The coverages required are: 
(1)  Comprehensive automobile liability in the amount of $500,000.00 bodily injury per person, $1,000,000.00 bodily injury per accident, $500,000.00 property damage each occurrence, and $1,000,000.00 bodily injury and property damage combined each occurrence. 
(2)  Worker's compensation in the statutory limits with the employer's liability in the sum of $500,000.00 bodily injury per person. 
(3)  Comprehensive general liability in the sum of $1,000,000.00 bodily injury each occurrence, $1,000,000.00 bodily injury aggregate, $500,000.00 property damages per occurrence, and $1,000,000.00 property damage aggregate. 
The village shall be named in the policy as an additional insured. 
(Code 1940, § 25.360; Code 1964, § 06-76; Ord. of 12-27-1948, § 1; Ord. of 5-14-1962, § 1; Ord. No. 92-42, 11-23-1992; Ord. No. 2004-48, 12-20-2004)  
Sec. 12-606. - Duty to secure building permits. 
It shall be the absolute duty and irrevocable responsibility of the building contractor to secure the appropriate and necessary building permits required under this chapter before undertaking to construct, alter, repair, add to, subtract from, improve, move, wreck or demolish any building or structure. 
(Code 1964, § 06-79; Ord. of 5-14-1962, § 8)  
Secs. 12-607—12-630. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR REGISTRATION 
 
Sec. 12-631. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of an electrical contractor, without being registered with the village as an electrical contractor; provided, however, that if such person is already registered for the current year in another city or village within the state, such electrical contractor shall not be required to be registered or to pay a registration fee for such year in this village. The village will require that a contractor's license be purchased to work in the village. 
(Code 1964, § 10-6; Ord. No. 97-66, 11-24-1997)  
Sec. 12-632. - Penalties for violation. 
Any person who shall engage in the business of electrical contractor without having a certificate of registration and a current village contractor's license herein provided for shall be fined not less than $5.00 nor more than $50.00 for each offense, and a separate and distinct offense shall be regarded as committed every day on which such person continues to operate contrary to the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1964, § 10-6; Ord. No. 97-66, 11-24-1997)  
Sec. 12-633. - Application. 
Any person desiring to engage in the business of electrical contractor shall apply for a village contractor's license to the electrical inspection division. 
(Code 1940, § 41.012; Code 1964, § 10-7; Ord. No. 97-66, 11-24-1997)  
Sec. 12-634. - Bonds required; electrical contractors. 
(a)  All electrical contractors, before performing any work in the village, shall provide the electrical inspection division with a license, a certificate of registration, and permit bond in the sum equal to the total cost of the proposed project; but such bond shall be not less than the amount of $10,000.00, to ensure that the contractor faithfully observes all of the provisions of the building codes, zoning code and all other codes and regulations of the village and that the contractor will correct any and all work improperly done to bring it into compliance with the applicable village codes and regulations. The sureties shall be approved by the village manager. 
(b)  Such bonds shall be conditioned to save and hold harmless the village, its officials, and employees from all accidents and damages that may happen arising from any negligence or unskillfulness in either the execution or the performance of his work, done under or by virtue of his certification of registration and further conditioned that he will pay all fines that may be imposed on him for a violation of any ordinance in force during the term of his registration. 
(Code 1940, § 41.012; Code 1964, § 10-8; Ord. No. 92-42, 11-23-1992; Ord. No. 97-66, 11-24-1997)  
Sec. 12-635. - Fee. 
The annual fee for an electrical contractor shall be in the amount provided in the village fee schedule by the applicant to the electrical inspection division, in advance, upon filing the request. 
(Code 1940, § 41. 013; Code 1964, § 10-9; Ord. No. 97-66, 11-24-1997)  
Sec. 12-636. - Issuance and duration of certificate. 
Upon receipt of the application and filing of the bond and payment of the fee required by this division, the electrical inspection division shall license the applicant as an electrical contractor, and shall issue to the applicant a contractor license which will authorize the applicant to engage in such business for the year in which it is issued. Such license shall expire on the December 31 of the year in which it is issued. 
(Code 1940, §§ 41.012, 41-013; Code 1964, § 10-10; Ord. No. 97-66, 11-24-1997)  
Sec. 12-637. - Record to be kept. 
The electrical inspection division shall keep a suitable record of all registrations and licenses issued under this division. 
(Code 1940, § 41 012; Code 1964, § 10-11; Ord. No. 97-66, 11-24-1997)  
Chapter 14 - BUSINESS LICENSING AND REGULATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— For provisions regarding business related taxes, see Chapter 62. 
State Law reference— Regulation of businesses and professions, 225 ILCS 2/1 et seq.; authority of village over certain businesses, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1 et seq.; authority of village to fix the amount, terms and manner of issuing and revoking licenses, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-1; Business Opportunity Sales Law, 815 ILCS 602/5-1 et seq.; Large Business Development Act, 30 ILCS 750/10-1 et seq.; criminally operated businesses, 720 ILCS 5/3-1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter and in the village fee schedule, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Advertiser, outdoor, means any person who engages in or carries on the business of outdoor advertising by means of billposting, or by distributing, tacking, pasting, mailing or otherwise fastening handbills, signs, posters or advertisements of any kind, or by erecting, constructing or maintaining painted bulletin boards or signs, or by maintaining or operating any other outdoor advertising means or devices. 
Advertising, handbill distributor, means any person who distributes any handbills, sale bills or any printed advertisement of any bankrupt, reduction or other special sale of any goods or merchandise to be held in the future. For business licensing purposes, the term "advertising" and "hand bill distributor" do not include by any local church or benevolent or fraternal order regarding bakery sales, rummage sales, or entertainments to be held for benevolent or charitable purposes. 
Automatic dry cleaning machine includes and means any device or apparatus for the cleaning of clothes or fabrics, and designed to be used or operated by anyone but the owner or an employee of the owner thereof, which machine or device makes use of or contains perchlorethylene or any other chemical solvent or substance which may cause harm to human beings by reason of inhalation or contact. 
Automobile dealer means any person who manages, conducts or carries on or operates a business of selling, buying or exchanging new, used or secondhand automobiles, trucks or any similar self-propelled vehicles or parts thereof, in any building, structure, premises, lot or other place in the village. 
Automobile parts and accessories dealer means any person who engages in the business of selling, at wholesale or retail, any new or secondhand motor vehicle tires, supplies, parts and accessories, whether purchased or exchanged, or kept for sale or exchange. 
Automobile repair shop means any barn, stable, building or structure within the village in which work or service is performed on any automobile, motor vehicle or other self-propelled vehicle, such work consisting of the replacing of or adding to or repairing parts of such vehicles, including frames, wheels, bodies, tops or any other parts, or the painting or refinishing of such vehicles. 
Bakery means any place used for any process of mixing, compounding or baking, for sale or for purposes of a restaurant, bakery or hotel, any bread, biscuits, pretzels, crackers, buns, rolls, macaroni, cake, pies or any food product of which flour or meal is a principal ingredient. Licensed restaurants in which any of the foregoing food products are mixed and baked for consumption in such restaurant only, on or in ordinary restaurant kitchen stoves or ranges, and kitchens or rooms in dwellings where any such food products are mixed and baked in an ordinary kitchen stove or range shall not be considered bakeries. 
Barber means one who cuts or trims hair and is one who holds a certificate of registration as a licensed barber under state statute. 
Barbershop means a place where licensed barbers pursue their calling. 
Beauty culture means one or any combination of the following practices: When done for cosmetic or beautifying purposes and not for the purpose of the treatment of disease or muscular disorder, the application of cosmetics to the human body by massaging, exercising, cleansing, beautifying or by means of devices, apparatus or appliances, arranging, dressing, marcelling, curling, waving, cleansing, singeing, bleaching, coloring, dyeing, tinting, or otherwise treating by any means, the hair of any person, but shall not include hair cutting unless the one practicing beauty culture shall have obtained the certificate provided for beauty culture and a certificate of registration as a barber in the state. 
Beauty shop means any place where beauty culture is practiced as above defined and as prescribed under state statute. 
Bicycle shop means a shop, store or other place of business where bicycles are sold at retail or where bicycle accessories are sold or where bicycles are repaired or rented. 
Bowling alley or pin and ball alley includes bowling alleys, pin and ball alleys, box ball alleys, skee-ball alleys, ping-pong tables, and all alleys or tables of similar character. 
Canvasser means any person who solicits or takes orders or subscriptions, at retail, for the future delivery of any magazines, books, newspapers, goods, wares or merchandise. 
Cartage vehicle means any automobile, truck, wagon or similar vehicle which is kept, used, operated, or employed for the purpose of transporting or conveying bundles, parcels, books, furniture, baggage, goods, wares, merchandise or other property, within or upon the streets or alleys of the village for hire or reward. The term "cartage vehicles" shall not include wagons, trucks, or other vehicles kept by merchants for the free delivery of goods sold by them, nor to the owners or drivers of vehicles used in hauling or transporting brick, sand, lime, mortar, stone, coal, coke, wood, hay and straw, or to any vehicle employed for public improvement of the village, or vehicles employed in connection with the excavating of structures, provided such vehicles are not used for other purposes for hire, or to vehicles used by a coal dealer who has secured a license under this chapter. 
Chiropodist means one who practices chiropody and one who has been duly licensed to practice the profession of chiropody by the department of registration and education under state law. 
Cleaner and dyer branch store means a business for receiving and delivering clothes for any purpose defined herein as the business of a dry cleaner or spotter, provided that none of the actual work on such clothes is done at such cleaner and dyer branch store. 
Dancing schools, required to be licensed under this chapter, includes any building, room or enclosure where instruction in the art of dancing or dancing lessons are given and where a charge or fee for such instruction or lesson is made, paid or received. 
Drug and variety store means any building, store, place or establishment where prescriptions for drugs or medicine are filled or compounded, or where medical preparations or remedies for human consumption containing more than one-half of one percent of alcohol or potent or dangerous drugs are sold at retail or are manufactured for sale at retail, or where medicines, drugs, chemicals, therapeutic preparations, druggist sundries, invalid and infant foods, physicians supplies, proprietary medicines, toilet articles, candy, ice cream, jewelry, greeting cards, toys, school supplies, household supplies, cosmetics, gifts, novelties, magazines, and any other items for general use in the home are sold, offered for sale, or kept with the intention of selling at retail. Licenses for drug and variety stores do not include licensure for the sale of cigarettes or the operation of vending machines. 
Dry cleaner or spotter means every person keeping or using more than two quarts of gasoline, naphtha, benzene or other volatile oils or chemicals for the purpose of cleaning or renovating any clothing or article of wearing apparel or any fabric of any kind for profit or reward. 
Dry goods store means any building, room, place or premises in the village operated, maintained or conducted for the sale or offering for sale of any dry goods, woolen, silk, cotton, or other fabrics, notions, fancy goods, wearing apparel, haberdashery, hats, caps, millinery, or any cloth goods. The term "dry goods stores" does not include secondhand clothing stores. 
Factory and workshop mean any building, room, enclosure, premises, place, or establishment in the village where any merchandise, goods, wares, commodities, or products are manufactured, made, finished, printed, engraved, worked on, altered, repaired, polished, cleaned, renovated, or assorted, in whole or in part, for sale or for wages or compensation. Such terms shall not include, however, places or establishments specifically defined and required to be licensed by other provisions of this Code. 
Feed store means any place operated as a feed store or place where such grain as corn, barley, oats, wheat and hay are kept or offered for sale. 
Filling station means any room, building, place, lot, yard, plant, or premises where a container, tank, either portable or stationary and containing either carbon bisulphide, gasoline, naphtha, benzole, hydrocarbon (gas drips) liquefied petroleum gas, acetone, kerosene, turpentine or other inflammable liquids having a flash point below 185 degrees Fahrenheit, are kept or located for the purpose of selling, offering for sale, or distributing any such liquids from such containers, or tanks; provided, however, that the provisions of this chapter shall not apply to inflammable liquids when such liquids are used for medical purposes. 
Food delivery vehicle means any vehicle, including wagons, motor vehicles and vehicles propelled by human power, used for the storage or carrying of any meats, poultry, fish, butter, cheese, lard, vegetables, bread or bakery products, or any other provisions intended for human consumption, including beverages and milk, for the purpose of delivering any such food stuffs or beverages to any place in the village for use and consumption or for resale in the village for such purpose. 
Food establishment means any building, room, stand, enclosure, place of selling, offering for sale, or keeping with the intention of selling or distributing, any article of food, confection, condiment, or drink used or intended for human consumption or any such article used for, mixed with, or entering into the consumption of, or intended for use as an ingredient in any such food. The term "food establishment" shall also be held to include any place used, operated or maintained for the preparation, manufacture, packing, bottling or canning of foods, confection, condiment or drink sold in the establishment where such articles are manufactured or prepared. 
Garage means any barn, stable, building or other place in the village where automobiles or similar self-propelled vehicles are kept or left for hire or reward to any person, whether such vehicle is hired out or let, with or without an operator for the same, or where such vehicles are kept ready for use and rent is paid to the keeper thereof for such keeping. The term "garage" shall not apply, however, to any garage used for housing the vehicles of the owner of such garage, and which vehicles are not used or let for hire or reward, or to any garage in which not more than one vehicle is kept for hire or reward. 
Garage sale includes "garage sale," "patio sale," "basement sale," "back yard sale," "rummage sale," or any similar type of sale of common household items, which is held on residential premises to which the general public is invited. 
Hardware store means any place operated or conducted for the sale at retail of any hardware, tinware, aluminum-ware, enamel-ware, cutlery, tools, implements, apparatus, machinery, plumbing, or engineers', janitors', blacksmiths', contractors', or electrical supplies, or gas, plumbing or electrical fixtures or other articles or wares, largely of metals, or kerosene, or rifles, shot guns and loaded shot shells or cartridges. 
Ice dealer means any person who engages in the business, either wholesale or retail, of manufacturing, dealing in, distributing or selling ice. 
Insurance broker means any person engaged for others in negotiating contracts for insurance of any kind or nature, either directly or through any insurance agent, or with any insurance company other than an insurance company of which such person is an employee. 
Itinerant merchant means any nonresident carrying on a merchandising business in the village but who does not rent a store, loft, warehouse, yard, office space, or showroom by the year or hold a year's lease on the same. 
Jeweler means any person whose principal business or occupation, or an essential or incidental part of whose business or occupation, is that of manufacturing, buying, selling, or otherwise trading or dealing in or with jewelry, watches, clocks, silverware, diamonds, semiprecious stones, cut glass, ivory goods, pens, umbrellas, jewelers' supplies and materials, dental supplies and accessories, optical goods, lenses, optical or watch making tools or machinery or surgical instruments, or who operates, manages or carries on the business of jewelry repairing, altering or manufacturing, or carries on the business of dental laboratories, smelting, concentrating or refining gold, silver, platinum or other precious metals. 
Junk dealer and secondhand dealer mean and include any person who operates, maintains or keeps any place where any secondhand furniture, junk, clothing, jewelry, rags, old metal or miscellaneous articles of personal property are purchased or sold, or engages in the business of collecting rags, old bottles, old metal or miscellaneous articles of personal property of any sort, with wagons, carts, trucks or otherwise, or keeps a junk shop or yard or assists in the conduct of any such business as a helper. 
Laundry means any place, building, structure, room, establishment, or portion thereof, which is used for the purpose of washing, drying, starching or ironing shirts, dresses, underwear, collars, cuffs, or other wearing apparel, table, bed or other household linens, towels, curtains, draperies, or other washable fabrics, such works being done for the general public. 
Laundry, self-service, means any establishment in which coin-operated facilities are available for washing clothes or for drying clothes, or both, and which is open and available to the general public for use. 
Laundry vehicles means any wagon, automobile or other vehicle used for the purpose of collecting and delivering laundry within the village. 
Manicurist parlour means any place wherein the business of caring for and treating the hands, especially the fingernails, is conducted. 
Material storage yard means any material storage yard or place where stone, gravel, sand, cement, hollow tile, sewer pipe or other building material is kept for sale or stored. 
Mechanical musical device means any automatic or coin-controlled or coin-operated music box, juke box, radio or any similar device, or any combination thereof, from which music or other entertainment may be obtained by the deposit or payment of money or other token. 
Milk dealer means any person who sells or offers for sale, disposes of, exchanges or delivers or, with the intent so to do, has in his possession, care, custody or control any milk or milk products for human food. 
Paint store means any place operated or conducted for sale at retail of paints, dry colors, wallpaper, varnishes, calcimine, white or red lead, raw or boiled linseed oil, turpentine, dryer, benzene, naphtha, painters' tools, supplies and equipment. 
Peddler means and includes every person who shall sell or offer for sale, barter or exchange any goods, wares, merchandise, coal, coke, charcoal, wood, oil, fish, fruits, vegetables or country produce, traveling from place to place on, along or upon the streets, alleys or sidewalks of the village, or who shall sell and deliver any such items from any wagon, pushcart, automobile or other vehicle going from place to place, or who shall go about from place to place selling and delivering any such items. 
Pet shop means any building, room, enclosure, premises or place where birds, dogs or other similar animals used as household pets are sold or where food supplies and equipment for such birds, dogs or similar animals and other similar articles are manufactured, made, altered, repaired, sold or offered for sale or given away. 
Photographer, for the purpose of this chapter, means any person operating, managing or maintaining a photographic studio, a postcard studio, tintype or ferrotype studio, a bromide enlarging plant, a finishing or developing plant, or a portrait-copying house, or carrying on the business of photography, including commercial, portrait and home portrait photography, or the business of a lantern slide maker, or of an itinerant or transient photographer, or the business of photography for any purpose whatsoever, except that such term shall not apply to photographing for or developing of motion picture films. 
Real estate broker means any person who, for another, in consideration of a commission or brokerage, or on the basis of compensation in proportion to the amount of the transaction, shall make it his vocation or business, in part or in whole, to sell, buy, exchange, lease, or negotiate the sale, purchase, exchange or leasing of any real property or interest therein, or who, for another, in consideration of the commission, brokerage, or on the basis of compensation in proportion to the amount of money involved, engages in the renting or management of real property, or acts through the medium of another licensed broker for any of the purposes aforesaid. 
Regulated employer means any individual, partnership, association, corporation, limited liability company, business trust, or any person or group of persons that gainfully employs at least one employee with a regulated place of business in the village. 
Regulated place of business means any of the following businesses and activities located within the village: 
Arborist or tree expert which means for purposes of this definition any person who, for profit, diagnoses the condition of shade or ornamental trees and shrubs and recommends or supervises the treatment of any such trees, or in any manner treats any such trees, by feeding or fertilizing, or by pruning, trimming, bracing, treating cavities or other methods; 
Ambulances; 
Athletic contests and exhibitions carried on for gain; 
Auctioneers; 
Bagatelle tables; 
Bankers; 
Bed and breakfast establishments and operators; 
Billiard tables; 
Bowling alleys; 
Brokers except real estate and insurance brokers; 
Cabmen;

Dealers in dismantled or wrecked vehicles or parts thereof;

Draymen;

Food and beverage dealers including: 
Alcoholic liquor dealers — Retail; 
Bakeries;

Mills, mill races and feeders; 
Mobile home parks; 
Money changers, but not currency exchanges;

Omnibus drivers; 
Parking garages, lots and ramps; 
Pawnbrokers; 
Peddlers; 
Pet shops; 
Pigeonhole tables; 
Pin ball; 
Places for amusement; 
Places for eating; 
Pool tables; 
Porters; 
Public accommodation businesses that permit the consumption of alcoholic liquor on the business premises and that are not licensed under the Liquor Control Act of 1934. For purposes of this definition, "public accommodation" means a refreshment, entertainment, or recreation facility of any kind, whether licensed or not, whose goods, services, facilities, privileges, or advantages are extended, offered, sold, or otherwise made available to the public; 
Public scales; 
Rag dealers; 
Runners for cabs, busses, railroads, ships, hotels, public houses, and other similar businesses; 
Sanitariums; 
Scavengers and garbage collectors; 
Second-hand article dealers; 
Shows; 
Steam boiler operator; 
Sales on streets, sidewalks, public property and municipal property; 
Theatricals and other exhibitions; 
Ticket sellers for theatricals, shows, amusements, athletic events and other exhibitions at a place other than the theatre or location where the theatricals, shows, amusements, athletic events and other exhibitions are given or exhibited; 
Transient vendors of merchandise; 
Undertaking establishments. 
Regulated place of business shall exclude any business not listed in the above definition of regulated place of business and the following businesses and activities located within the village: 
Architectural practice; 
Athletic trainers; 
Attorneys at law; 
Barbers and cosmetologists; 
Business and vocational schools;
