Restaurant means any establishment or premises where any article of food or drink for human consumption is kept for sale, sold or served to the general public for consumption on the premises or on the sidewalk or public way contiguous to the premises. 
Sawdust dealer means any person who sells or offers for sale sawdust, shavings or chipped products of wood or timber of any kind. 
Scavenger means anyone performing residential or nonresidential solid waste collection activities as specified in chapter 44 (Solid Waste). 
Shoe store means any building, room, place or premises operated, maintained, or conducted primarily for the sale, or offering or keeping for sale, of any shoes, boots, slippers, sandals, or other footwear for men, women or children. 
Veterinary hospital shall have the same meaning ascribed to it be section 10-240. 
Wholesale produce establishment means any wholesale food establishment located in the village, or any truck, wagon or vehicle operating from such establishment, which sells, offers for sale or delivers, at wholesale, any produce used or intended for human consumption. 
(Code 1940, §§ 25.068, 25.073, 25.078, 25.079, 25.087, 25.096, 25.109, 25.113, 25.129, 25.134, 25.142, 25.168, 25.169, 25.179, 25.185, 25.196, 25.205, 25.209, 25.218, 25.231, 25.237, 25.251, 25.259, 25.264, 25.270, 25.277, 25.283, 25.289, 25.308, 25.316, 25.328, 25.333, 25.339, 25.346, 25.351, 25.364, 25.369, 25.378, 25.402, 25.428; Code 1964, § 07-1; Ord. of 2-9-1948; Ord. of 1-22-1962; Ord. of 11-12-1962(1); Ord. of 11-12-1962(2); Ord. of 12-3-1962; Ord. No. 1975-28, § 1, 10-27-1975; Ord. No. 1976-31, § 1, 11-22-1976; Ord. No. 1994-22, 4-25-1994; Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994; Ord. No. 2017-38 , § 2, 6-26-2017; Ord. No. 2017-39 , § 2, 6-26-2017)  
Secs. 14-2—14-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES AND OCCUPATION TAXES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Regulation of businesses and professions, 225 ILCS 2/1 et seq.; authority of village over certain businesses, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1 et seq.; authority of village to fix the amount, terms and manner of issuing and revoking licenses, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-1 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 14-21. - Required; exceptions. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage, within the village, in any business, trade, occupation or calling for which a license is required without first obtaining a license to do so. 
(Code 1964, § 07-14)  
Sec. 14-22. - Applicant to obtain required permit, license or certificate from state. 
In case any applicant for a village license is required, by state law, to obtain any permit, license or certificate from any department or agency of the state, no license shall be issued by the village unless satisfactory evidence is offered that such state permit, license or certificate has been obtained. 
(Code 1964, § 07-17)  
Sec. 14-23. - Not to issue to delinquent debtors. 
No village license shall be issued to any person indebted to the village and more than 30 days delinquent in the payment of such indebtedness at the time of filing application for the license. 
(Code 1940, § 25.007; Code 1964, § 07-23)  
Sec. 14-24. - Separate license for each place of business; auto repair shop exception. 
(a)  Unless otherwise specifically provided, no village license shall authorize the licensee to operate or conduct more than one establishment or place of business and an additional license shall be required for each additional place of business. 
(b)  In case an automobile repair shop is managed, conducted, operated or carried on in the same building, structure, premises, enclosure or other place in which a business licensed under this section is managed, conducted, operated or carried on, by one and the same person, such person shall not be required to obtain a separate license for such repair shop. 
(Code 1940, § 25.012; Code 1964, § 07-16)  
Sec. 14-25. - Application. 
Application for a license required by this article shall be in writing and filed in the office of the village manager on a form provided for that purpose. Such application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The date of the application; 
(2)  The name of the applicant, and, if a partnership, the names of all partners, and, if a corporation, the names of the principal officers thereof; 
(3)  The residence address of the applicant and of all partners, if the applicant is a partnership; 
(4)  The address of the place at which the business, trade or occupation is proposed to be conducted; and 
(5)  Such other information required by ordinance as may be necessary to determine the fee for such license and to determine that the applicant and his place of business have complied with all applicable provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1940, §§ 25.002, 25.004; Code 1964, § 07-15)  
Sec. 14-26. - Investigation prior to issuance. 
(a)  Upon the filing of an application for a license under this article, the village manager shall cause an investigation to be made of the applicant and his proposed place of business, including all machines and vehicles proposed to be used in such business, for the purpose of determining whether all applicable requirements of this Code and of the state law have been met. 
(b)  Such investigation shall be made by the appropriate village officers and employees, and no license shall be issued until such investigation has been made and a report received from the investigating officer or employee stating that all requirements of this Code and of the state law have been fulfilled. 
(c)  The fee for an inspection of the premises for which a license under this article is applied shall be in the amount provided in the village fee schedule. 
(Code 1964, § 07-21; Ord. No. 2018-54 , § 6, 6-25-2018)  
Sec. 14-27. - Issuance or refusal. 
(a)  When the applicant for a license required by this article is of good moral character and reputation and has complied with all conditions prerequisite to the issuance of the license, whether imposed by this article or by state statute, including the payment of the proper fee therefor, such license shall be issued by the village manager. 
(b)  Any license applied for under this article or any other village ordinance may be refused if it appears that the applicant is not a proper person to engage in the activity for which the license is sought, or if he has not complied with all applicable provisions of this Code and the state law, or if it appears that the premises at which such activity is to be carried on are unfit or do not conform to the applicable provisions of this Code and the state law. In the event of such refusal, the applicant shall have the right to appeal to the village board. 
(Code 1940, §§ 25.001, 25.002; Code 1964, § 07-26)  
Sec. 14-28. - Display of license. 
Unless otherwise specifically provided, every licensee shall post, in the place of business licensed, or on any vending machine licensed, his license certificate in such a place as to be plainly in the view of persons who may enter such place. If the licensee has no regular place of business, he shall carry such license certificate upon his person, whenever engaged in his licensed business or occupation. 
(Code 1940, § 25.009; Code 1964, § 07-27; Ord. of 2-9-1948, § 1)  
Sec. 14-29. - Unauthorized exhibition or display. 
It shall be unlawful for any person who is not the licensee or his duly authorized agent to exhibit or display in his place of business or on his person any certificate or other evidence of a license issued by the village. 
(Code 1940, § 27.023; Code 1964, § 07-29)  
Sec. 14-30. - Alteration, destruction or mutilation of license. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to alter, destroy or mutilate any license certificate or other evidence of a license issued by the village. 
(Code 1940, § 25.009; Code 1964, § 07-28)  
Sec. 14-31. - Transfer. 
Except as otherwise specifically provided, no license issued by the village shall be transferable. 
(Code 1940, § 25.005; Code 1964, § 07-31)  
Sec. 14-32. - Duration. 
All licenses issued by the village shall be dated as of January 1 of the year of issuance and shall expire December 31 of such year, unless otherwise specifically provided. 
(Code 1940, § 25.003; Code 1964, § 07-32)  
Sec. 14-33. - Responsibility of licensee as owner of vehicle used in business. 
Any person to whom a license is granted to keep and use a cartage vehicle or to keep and use any vehicle in his business shall be considered the owner thereof and responsible for all articles entrusted to, and for the conduct of, the driver thereof, and liable, together with the driver thereof, to all forfeitures, penalties, and punishments imposed for the violation of the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1940, § 25.143; Code 1964, § 07-34)  
Secs. 14-34—14-54. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BONDS 
 
Sec. 14-55. - Automobile, junk and secondhand dealers; auctioneers. 
(a)  No license shall be issued for any of the following businesses, trades or occupations unless the applicant has first filed in the office of the village manager a bond meeting the requirements of this section: 
(1)  Automobile dealers. 
(2)  Auctioneers. 
(3)  Junk and secondhand dealers. 
(b)  Such bond shall be in the principle sum of $1,000.00, shall have as surety thereon a surety company authorized to do business in this state or two sureties approved by the village president, and shall be conditioned that the principal and his agents and employees shall observe all provisions of the state law and of this Code and other ordinances of the village relating to the conduct of such business, trade or occupation. 
(Code 1940, §§ 25.061, 25.080, 25.271, 25.353; Code 1964, § 07-18; Ord. of 12-27-1948, § 1; Ord. of 12-3-1962, § 1; Ord. of 12-14-1964, § 1)  
Sec. 14-56. - Christmas trees sales. 
(a)  No license shall be issued authorizing the sale of Christmas trees unless the applicant deposits in the office of the village manager a cash bond in the amount of $25.00 for each location at which trees are to be sold. 
(b)  Such cash bond shall be for the purpose of indemnifying the village against having such premises left in an unclean condition and such cash bond shall be refunded upon surrender of the receipt thereof, within five days after discontinuance or termination of the business, together with evidence that all such trees, branches and parts thereof have been removed from the premises. 
(Code 1964, § 07-19; Ord. of 11-12-1962, §§ 2, 4)  
Secs. 14-57—14-85. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - FEES 
 
Sec. 14-86. - Licenses required; fees. 
(a)  Persons engaged, within the village, in the following businesses, trades, occupations or callings shall apply for, obtain and maintain a business license. The fee payable by the applicant for the applicable business license shall be as listed in the village's fee schedule. 
(1)  Advertising. 
a.  Outdoor advertisers. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(a) of the village fee schedule. 
b.  Handbill distributor. 
1.  If the applicant has his principal place of business in the village and has a village business license, the fee shall be as follows: 
i.  Per day: The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(1) b.1.i. of the village fee schedule. 
ii.  Per year: The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(1)b.1.ii. of the village fee schedule. 
2.  If the applicant's place of business is not in the village, or if the applicant does not have a village business license, the fee shall be as follows: 
i.  Per day: The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(1)b.2.i. of the village fee schedule. 
ii.  Per year: The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(1)b.2.ii. of the village fee schedule. 
3.  Nothing in this paragraph b. shall be construed to apply to any local church or benevolent or fraternal order advertising bakery sales, rummage sales, or entertainments to be held for benevolent or charitable purposes. 
c.  Advertising benches. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(1)c. of the village fee schedule. 
(2)  Alcoholic liquor dealers. See chapter 6 of this Code. 
(3)  Auctioneers of real or personal property. (Bond required). 
a.  Per year: The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(3)a. of the village fee schedule. 
b.  Per day: The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(3)b. of the village fee schedule. 
(4)  Automatic vending machines. Each applicant for a license to operate or maintain any automatic vending machine for the sale of merchandise or to sell any merchandise by means of any such machine shall pay an annual license fee for each such machine, which fee shall be based upon the amount of the deposit required to operate such machine, and which fee shall be in accord with the following schedule: 
a.  Amount of deposit. 
1.  $0.20 or less. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(4)a.1.of the village fee schedule. 
2.  $0.30. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(4)a.2. of the village fee schedule. 
3.  $0.31 to $0.50. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(4)a.3. of the village fee schedule. 
4.  More than $0.50. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(4)a.4. of the village fee schedule. 
(5)  Automobile dealers. If an automobile repair shop is managed, conducted, operated or carried on in the same building, structure, premises, enclosure or other place in which a business licensed under this subsection is managed, conducted, operated or carried on, by one and the same person, such person shall not be required to take out a separate license for such repair shop. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(5) of the village fee schedule. 
(6)  Automobile parts and accessories dealers. This subsection shall not apply to any person licensed to operate a garage or repair shop. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(6) of the village fee schedule. 
(7)  Automobile repair shops. No fee shall be required under this subsection from any person holding a license for another business, which license, by the express provisions of this section, includes the right to operate an automobile repair shop. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(7) of the village fee schedule. 
(8)  Bakeries. The annual license fee shall entitle the licensed premises to be inspected without additional charge for up to three times per calendar year. The cost of inspections in excess of three in any calendar year shall be billed to, and payable by, the license holder at the time of the inspection. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(8) of the village fee schedule. 
(9)  Barbershops, beauty shops, massage parlors, manicurist parlors and chiropodist. 
a.  One person employed or engaged in licensed establishment. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(9)a. of the village fee schedule. 
b.  More than one person so employed or engaged. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(9)b. of the village fee schedule. 
(10)  Bicycle shops. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(10) of the village fee schedule. 
(11)  Bowling alleys or pin and ball alleys. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(11) of the village fee schedule. The license fee shall be in addition to any license fee for other businesses conducted, such as cigarette and soft drink sales, etc. 
(12)  Canvassers. 
a.  If the applicant has his principal place of business in the village and has a village business license, the license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(12)a. of the village fee schedule. 
b.  If the applicant's place of business is not in the village, or if the applicant does not have a village business license, the license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(12)b. of the village fee schedule. 
c.  No fee shall be required under this subsection from any person, resident or nonresident who sells or offers for sale or solicits orders for the sale of articles when the proceeds of such sale are to be devoted to charitable or religious purposes, provided any such person shall procure from the police division a permit to engage in such work before being permitted to do so. 
d.  All canvassers shall be issued a badge by the police division, which badge shall be worn on the canvasser in plain sight. 
e.  A deposit shall be required for each badge, which deposit shall be returned upon surrender of the badge to the police division. The deposit shall be as set forth in section 14-86(12)e. of the village fee schedule. 
f.  The fee required by this subsection is in addition to any other business license fee required by this Code. 
(13)  Cartage vehicles. 
a.  If the applicant has his principal place of business in the village, the license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(13)a. of the village fee schedule. 
b.  If the applicant's principal place of business is not in the village, the license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(13)b. of the village fee schedule. 
c.  The fee required by this subsection is in addition to the regular vehicle license required by section 54-325 of this Code. 
d.  The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to wagons, trucks, or other vehicles kept by merchants for the free delivery of goods sold by them, nor to the owners or drivers of vehicles used in hauling or transporting brick, sand, lime, mortar, stone, coal, coke, wood, hay and straw, or to any vehicle employed for public improvement of the village, or vehicles employed in connection with the excavating of structures, provided such vehicles are not used for other purposes for hire, or to vehicles used by a coal dealer who has secured a license under subsection (16). 
(14)  Christmas tree sales (bond required). 
a.  For each location to sell, store or offer to sell any pine, balsam, spruce, fir or other trees, or any branches or parts thereof, which have been cut for use as Christmas trees or for ornamental or decorative purposes, the license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(14)a. of the village fee schedule. 
b.  If the applicant is a charitable, fraternal, religious or educational institution, the license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(14)b. of the village fee schedule. 
(15)  Cigarette dealers. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(15) of the village fee schedule. 
(16)  Coal dealers. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(16) of the village fee schedule. 
(17)  Contractors and related trades. See article XI of chapter 12 of this Code. 
(18)  Dancing schools. This subsection shall apply to any building, room or enclosure where instruction in the art of dancing or dancing lessons are given and where a charge or fee for such instruction or lesson is made, paid or received. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(18) of the village fee schedule. 
(19)  Drug and variety store. The license fee paid under this subsection shall not include a license for the sale of cigarettes or the operation of vending machines. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(19) of the village fee schedule. 
(20)  Dry cleaners or spotters and automatic dry cleaning machines. 
a.  The license fee for dry cleaners or spotters shall be as follows: 
1.  General dry cleaners or spotters business license. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(20)a.1. of the village fee schedule. 
2.  Each cleaner and dyers branch store. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(20)a.2. of the village fee schedule. 
3.  Any vehicle used in collecting or delivering articles cleaned or dyed for such establishments having their principal office in the village. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(20)1.3. of the village fee schedule. The license fee is in addition to the vehicle license required under section 54-325 of this Code. 
4.  Any vehicle used in collecting or delivering articles cleaned or dyed for such establishments not having their principal office in the village. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(20)a.3. of the village fee schedule. The license fee is in addition to the vehicle license required under section 54-325 of this Code. 
b.  The license fee for persons engaging in the business of maintaining any automatic dry cleaning machine for use by the public upon payment of a fee shall be as follows: 
1.  One to five machines: Any vehicle used in collecting or delivering articles cleaned or dyed for such establishments having their principal office in the village. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(20)b.1. of the village fee schedule. 
2.  More than five machines; per machine The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(20)b.2. of the village fee schedule. 
(21)  Dry goods stores. A license under this subsection shall not include any secondhand clothing stores. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(21) of the village fee schedule. 
(22)  Factories and workshops not otherwise specified. 
a.  With not more than three persons employed or engaged in such establishment, the license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(22)a. of the village fee schedule. 
b.  With more than three persons so employed or engaged, the license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(22)b. of the village fee schedule. 
(23)  Feed stores. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(23) of the village fee schedule. 
(24)  Filling stations. 
a.  The license fee for filling stations shall be as follows: 
1.  For containers or tanks in one and the same premises from which liquids sold at such station are drawn directly upon the making of sales of such liquids to purchasers at the station, the license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(24)a.1. of the village fee schedule. 
2.  For each portable wheel tank, the license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(24)a.2. of the village fee schedule. 
3.  For each station having a total capacity of tanks or containers not exceeding 5,000 gallons, the license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(24)a.3. of the village fee schedule. 
4.  For each station having a total capacity of tanks or containers of more than 5,000 gallons and not exceeding 10,000 gallons, the license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(24)a.4. of the village fee schedule. 
5.  For each station having a total capacity of tanks or containers of more than 10,000 gallons and not exceeding 15,000 gallons, the license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(24)a.5. of the village fee schedule. 
6.  For each station having a total capacity of more than 15,000 gallons, the license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(24)a.6. of the village fee schedule. 
7.  For any container having a total capacity of more than 15,000 gallons and which shall be used exclusively as an original storage container from which no liquid shall be drawn directly upon the making of sales of such liquid to purchasers at the filling station, the license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(24)a.7. of the village fee schedule. 
b.  License fees under this subsection shall be paid for total capacity of tanks or containers which shall be used at any time during the year to contain any of the liquids sold or stored at the station. 
c.  The license to keep, operate and maintain a filling station under the provisions of this subsection shall be deemed to include a license to conduct, maintain and operate an automobile repair shop in connection therewith without additional license or the payment of an additional fee. 
(25)  Firearms dealers. This subsection shall apply to any person who sells pistols, revolvers, guns and other small arms which are of such size or nature as to render them capable of being concealed upon the person. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-452 of the village fee schedule.

The cost of inspections in excess of three in any calendar year shall be billed to and payable by the license holder at the time of the inspection The license fee is in addition to the vehicle license required under section 54-325 of this Code.

(46)  Peddlers. This subsection shall apply only to places or establishments not specifically provided for by other provisions of this section. 
a.  Peddling without a vehicle. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(46)a. of the village fee schedule.

If a peddler desires an assistant or helper, he shall make an application for the same either at the time of making application for his license or at any time during which his license is in force; provided, however, that there shall be permitted but one helper or assistant to the operator or driver of any peddler's vehicle. No such helper or assistant shall be permitted to so assist or help unless the peddler's license authorizes such helper or assistant.

f.  No license shall be issued to any person authorizing the peddling at retail of any drugs or medicines of any description; and the peddling of drugs and medicines from door to door or the distributing of samples of pills, powders or other drugs or medicines from door to door within the corporate limits of the village is hereby forbidden.

e.  For multiple registration of license categories as herein stated above, the maximum license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(56)e. of the village fee schedule.

(60)  Taxicabs. See article II of chapter 60 of this Code. 
(61)  Theatricals, shows and amusements. All theatricals, shows and amusements offered, operated, presented or exhibited for gain, or for admission to which the public is required to pay a fee are hereby divided into four classes as follows and the license fee for each class shall be as herein prescribed: 
a.  Class 1 shall consist of all moving picture theaters. The license fee shall be: 
1.  For theaters seating not over 350: The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(61)a.1. of the village fee schedule. 
2.  For theaters seating over 350 persons: The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(61)a.2. of the village fee schedule. 
b.  Class 2 shall consist of dances, amateur theatrical entertainments, bazaars and other entertainments of like character in a hall, structure or building. The license fee shall be paid by the owner or operator of the hall, structure or building in which such amusement is offered and shall be as follows: 
1.  For places where the floor space occupied is not over 2,400 square feet: The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(61)b.1. of the village fee schedule. 
2.  For places where such floor space is over 2,400 square feet: The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(61)b.2. of the village fee schedule. 
c.  Class 3 shall consist of carnivals, exhibitions, amusement parks, picnic grounds and other outdoor amusements. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(61)c. of the village fee schedule. 
d.  Class 4 shall consist of any building or room, place or enclosure where food and drink is served to which the general public may be admitted, either with or without the payment or charge of any admission fee, where such food or drink is sold or offered for sale, and where the public may engage in or witness the performance of any theatrical entertainment, exhibition, show, amusement, dance or entertainment. The license fee shall be as follows: 
1.  If the floor space does not exceed 2,400 square feet and the seating capacity does not exceed 300 persons: The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(61)d.1. of the village fee schedule. 
2.  If floor space exceeds 2,400 square feet or the seating capacity exceeds 300 persons: The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(61)d.2. of the village fee schedule. 
e.  Where any entertainment embraces two or more of the classes specified in this subsection, such entertainment shall be classified and charged for as wholly belonging to that class for which the highest license fee is fixed. 
f.  In case the business of an ice cream parlor, a coffee house, or a retail beverage dealer is conducted, operated, managed or carried on in connection with the business of public entertainment for which a license is required by this subsection in the same premises and by the same person, only one license shall be required and that license shall be that which requires the payment of the highest license fee. 
g.  Where all of the proceeds of any game, exhibition, concert, or other entertainment for which a license is sought under this subsection inure exclusively to the use and benefit of charitable, religious or educational institutions or purposes, and where proof to such effect is furnished in a manner satisfactory to the village manager, the license fee prescribed by this subsection may be waived, and the required license issued without any charge therefor. 
(62)  Undertakers. 
a.  General undertakers license. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(62)a. of the village fee schedule. 
b.  Undertaker's assistant. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(62)b. of the village fee schedule. 
c.  Each removal of corpse or cadaver from the village by other than an undertaker licensed under this subsection. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(62)c. of the village fee schedule. 
(63)  Veterinary hospitals. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(63) of the village fee schedule. 
(64)  Wallpaper store. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(64) of the village fee schedule. A license under this subsection shall entitle the licensee to operate as a wallpaper, hardware or paint store. 
(65)  Wholesale produce establishments. The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(65) of the village fee schedule. The annual license fee shall entitle the licensed premises to be inspected without additional charge for up to three times per calendar year. The cost of inspections in excess of three in any calendar year shall be billed to and payable by the license holder at the time of the inspection. 
(66)  General business licenses. License to operate any business, trade, occupation or calling over which the village has been authorized to regulate under the applicable Illinois statutes and not otherwise provided for in this section or otherwise provided for in this Code, shall require a "general business license." The license fee shall be as set forth in section 14-86(66) of the village fee schedule. 
(b)  The license fee to be paid by persons engaged in any business, trade, occupation or calling within the village shall be as provided in the village fee schedule if the license fee is paid on or before January 31 of the year for which the same is being issued. 
(c)  If the license is purchased after January 31, the fee shall be increased by $5.00 or ten percent, whichever is the greater. This penalty shall be applicable only to those persons engaged in any business, trade, occupation or calling on or before January 1 of each year. 
(d)  License fees shall be paid in advance, and unless specifically provided to the contrary, shall be paid annually. 
(Ord. No. 2018-38 , § 3, 5-14-2018)  
Sec. 14-87. - Rules of construction relative to fee schedule. 
In interpretation of the village fee schedule as it relates to certain business fees, the following shall apply: 
(1)  Food establishment exclusions. Food establishments, when used as a license fee category, shall not apply to bakeries, restaurants, and other establishments making or preparing food which are specifically licensed under other provisions. 
(2)  Ice cream dealers distinguished from restaurants. Ice cream dealers, when used as a license fee category, do not include restaurants required to be licensed under this chapter, where ice cream, ices or beverages are sold and consumed in conjunction with the service of the restaurant's meals. 
(3)  Capacity of filling station tanks; license permits auto repair shop. License fees for filling stations are calculated based on the total capacity of tanks or containers that will be used at any time during the year for containment of any liquids sold or stored at the station. The license to keep, operate and maintain a filling station includes a license to conduct, maintain and operate an automobile repair shop in connection therewith without additional license or the payment of an additional fee. 
(4)  Insurance sales by real estate broker. Any person who shall negotiate or conduct, in any way, the business of soliciting or selling insurance, except life insurance, in conjunction with a licensed real estate brokerage business, shall be permitted to do so under and by authority of a real estate broker's license and shall not be required to pay an additional license fee.  
Sec. 14-88. - Proration of fee. 
Unless otherwise specifically provided, where application is made for a village license issue on an annual basis after July 1 of any calendar year, and the applicant gives satisfactory evidence that he has not engaged in the business, profession, or occupation so licensed prior to July 1 of such year, then and in the event, the fee for such license shall be two-thirds of the annual fee prescribed therefor; provided, however, that there will be no such proration of any annual license fee which is less than $5.00. 
(Code 1940, § 25.010; Code 1964, § 07-25; Ord. No. 1985-42, 11-11-1985; Ord. No. 1993-63, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 2005-71, 12-12-2005)  
Secs. 14-89—14-119. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION 
 
Sec. 14-120. - Summary order for cessation of business activities. 
(a)  When the conduct or operation of any business shall constitute a nuisance in fact or a clear and present danger to the public health, safety or general welfare, the village manager shall be authorized to summarily order, by the issuance of a written order, the cessation of business, the closing of the premises and the suspension of any license for a period not to exceed ten days. 
(b)  The written order shall state the reason for the cessation of business, the closing of the premises and the suspension of the license. Within eight days after the village manager has so acted, the village manager shall call a hearing for the purpose of determining whether or not the license should be suspended for an additional period of time or revoked. 
(Code 1964, § 07-35(a); Ord. No. 2005-54, 10-24-2005)  
Sec. 14-121. - Grounds for suspension and revocation. 
Licenses issued under the ordinances of the village, unless otherwise provided, may be suspended for up to 30 days or revoked by the village manager after notice and hearing as provided below for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for the license; 
(2)  Any fraud perpetrated upon a customer of the business by the licensee, its agents or employees; 
(3)  Any violation by the licensee, its agents or employees of ordinance provisions relating to the license, the subject matter of the license, or the premises occupied; 
(4)  Conviction of the licensee, its agents or employees of any felony or of a misdemeanor when such conviction indicates his inability to operate a safe, honest, or legitimate business operation within the village; 
(5)  Failure of the licensee to pay any fine or penalty owing to the village; 
(6)  Refusal to permit an inspection or sampling, or any interference with a duly authorized village officer or employee while in the performance of his duties in making such inspections, as provided in this Code; or 
(7)  Any other violation by the licensee of any village ordinances, resolutions, or regulations. 
(Code 1964, § 07-35(b); Ord. No. 2005-54, 10-24-2005)  
Sec. 14-122. - Other remedies available. 
Such suspension or revocation, if ordered, shall not preclude prosecution and imposition of any other penalties provided for the violation of other applicable ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1964, § 07-35(c); Ord. No. 2005-54, 10-24-2005)  
Sec. 14-123. - Hearing procedure. 
(a)  Notice of the hearing for suspension or revocation of a license shall be given in writing setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. 
(b)  Such notice shall be sent by certified mail (return receipt requested) to the licensee at his last known address at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. If the licensee is not found at its last known address, and upon inquiry cannot be found, a copy of the notice shall be posted upon the licensee's place of business, or, if the licensee has no known place of business, may be published in a newspaper of general circulation within the village. A copy of the notice shall be filed in the records of the village. 
(c)  At the hearing, the village attorney shall present the complaint and shall represent the village. The licensee shall be permitted counsel and shall have the right to submit evidence and cross-examine witnesses. A stenographic or electronically recorded record of the hearing shall be kept. 
(d)  The village manager shall preside at the hearing and shall render the decision within a reasonable time after the conclusion of the hearing, but not later than 30 days after such conclusion. The decision shall be in writing and shall summarize the evidence and state the reasons for the decision. 
(Code 1964, § 07-35(d); Ord. No. 2005-54, 10-24-2005)  
Sec. 14-124. - Costs. 
(a)  The village manager shall determine the costs incurred by the village for said hearing, including, but not limited to, court reporter fees, the costs of transcripts or records, attorneys' fees, the cost of preparing and mailing notices and orders, and all other miscellaneous expenses incurred by the village or such lesser sum as the village manager may allow. 
(b)  Any licensee whose license is suspended or revoked shall pay to the village the costs of the hearing as determined by the village manager within 30 days of notification of the costs by the village manager. Failure to pay said costs within 30 days of notification is a violation of this section and may be cause for license suspension or revocation, or the levy of a fine. 
(Code 1964, § 07-35(e); Ord. No. 2005-54, 10-24-2005)  
Sec. 14-125. - Issuance of new license after revocation. 
When any license shall have been revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted to the revoked licensee or any person acting for the revoked licensee for the conduct of the business described in such revoked license until one year after the cause for the revocation has been abated, unless the revocation order has been vacated. 
(Code 1964, § 07-35(f); Ord. No. 2005-54, 10-24-2005)  
Sec. 14-126. - Appeal. 
(a)  The decision of the village manager to suspend or revoke a license may be appealed, in writing, within 30 days to the village board. Upon appeal, the board shall review the transcript of the hearing, the evidence presented and the written decision of the village manager. It shall render its decision on the evidence and testimony presented at the hearing before the village manager. No oral testimony, new or additional evidence shall be presented to the village board at the appeal. 
(b)  The village board shall render a decision within a reasonable time following its review of the transcript of the hearing, the evidence presented and the written decision of the village manager, but not later than 30 days after such review. The village board may affirm or reverse the decision of the village manager or may remand the matter for further hearing. The decision shall be in writing and shall state the reasons for the decision. 
(c)  A decision of the village board affirming or reversing the decision of the village manager shall be a final administrative decision subject to review under 735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq. 
(Code 1964, § 07-35(g); Ord. No. 2005-54, 10-24-2005)  
Secs. 14-127—14-150. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - INSPECTIONS 
 
Sec. 14-151. - Inspections of licensed premises, vehicles and machines. 
(a)  The police, officers and employees of the inspection, health and fire divisions, and such other officers and employees of the village as may be authorized and directed by the village manager, shall have the right to enter any licensed place of business or any vehicle authorized to be used in such business, at all reasonable hours, for the purpose of inspecting the same and determining whether or not all applicable provisions of this Code and of the state law are being complied with. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the officers and employees of the health division to inspect and examine all merchandise being offered for sale by means of automatic vending machines for the purpose of ascertaining whether the laws of the state and the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the village in relation to sales from such vending machines are complied with and that such merchandise so offered for sale is kept fresh, clean and wholesome. It shall be the duty of all persons operating such vending machines, upon the demand of any such officer or employee, to furnish to him for his inspection samples of all such merchandise, which samples may be analyzed by or under the direction of the head of the health division, and a record of such analysis shall be made and kept in his office for the inspection of the public. 
(c)  The officers and employees of the health division shall also inspect all locations where automatic vending machines are placed in order to ascertain that the merchandise is free from contamination and in a wholesome condition. All owners of such machines shall, on the request, furnish keys for such machines so that the contents of the same may be inspected in company with a representative designated by the owner of the machine. 
(Code 1940, § 25.008; Code 1964, § 07-33; Ord. of 2-9-1948, § 1)  
Sec. 14-152. - Inspection fees for certain businesses. 
(a)  The annual license fee for the following listed businesses shall entitle the licensed premises to be inspected up to three times per calendar year without additional charge: 
(1)  Bakeries. 
(2)  Food delivery vehicles. 
(3)  Food establishments. 
(4)  Ice cream parlors. 
(5)  Soft drink dealers. 
(6)  Ice dealers and ice dealer vehicles. 
(7)  Milk dealers and milk dealer vehicles. 
(8)  Restaurants. 
(9)  Wholesale produce establishments. 
(b)  The cost of inspections in excess of three in any calendar year shall be billed to, and payable by, the license holder at the time of the inspection.  
Secs. 14-153—14-172. - Reserved.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 14-173. - Maintenance of business premises. 
The premises of every business licensed by the village shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and free of rodents and vermin, and all refuse, garbage and waste shall be removed there from at such intervals as will prevent any accumulations which should be detrimental to the health and comfort of employees and customers of such business. Such premises shall at all times be maintained in accord with all applicable provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1940, §§ 25.199, 25.241, 25.282, 25.381; Code 1964, § 07-11; Ord. No. 1982-2, 2-8-1982)  
Sec. 14-174. - Health of employees. 
No person shall work in any business establishment in the village in any capacity which brings him in contact with other employees or with the general public if he is infected or suffers with any communicable disease. No owner, manager or operator of any business shall permit any person to work therein in violation of this section. 
(Code 1940, §§ 25.199, 25.241, 25.282, 25.381, 25.432; Code 1964, § 07-12; Ord. No. 1982-2, 2-8-1982)  
Sec. 14-175. - Exit requirements for hardware, paint, dry goods and shoe stores. 
Every hardware store, paint store, dry goods store or shoe store shall have at least one exit at the front and back of such store. 
(Code 1940, §§ 25.199, 25.241, 25.381; Code 1964, § 07-2)  
Sec. 14-176. - Sanitary regulations for barber and beauty shops, massage parlors, etc. 
The owner, manager, operator and all employees of every barbershop, beauty shop, massage parlor, manicurist parlor and establishment where any chiropodist practices his profession shall conform strictly to the following regulations: 
(1)  No person shall be employed in any such place who is suffering from any communicable disease. 
(2)  All such places, together with the furniture, fixtures, tools, implements and linen, shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition at all times. 
(3)  Mugs, shaving brushes, scissors, combs and other tools and appliances of like nature that will admit of such treatment shall, after use on each person, be sterilized by immersion in boiling water or in alcohol of at least 60 percent strength. 
(4)  A separate clean towel or face cloth shall be used for each customer. 
(5)  The common use of powder puffs and sponges is prohibited. 
(6)  No alum or other astringent shall be used in stick form. If used at all, such astringent must be in powder form. 
(7)  All hair brushes, hair dusters and analogous articles shall be washed thoroughly at frequent intervals and kept scrupulously clean at all times. 
(8)  No barber shall permit any person to use the headrest of any barber chair under his control unless such headrest is covered with a towel that has been washed since last being used or with a clean new paper. 
(9)  No barber shall shave any person when the surface to be shaved is inflamed or broken out or contains pus, unless such person is provided with a cup and shaving brush for his individual use. 
(10)  Every employee shall cleanse his hands thoroughly immediately before serving each customer. 
(11)  Every barber shall, while serving customers, wear a washable apron or coat, which shall be kept clean. 
(12)  No person shall use a barbershop as a place in which to sleep, nor shall any proprietor or owner thereof permit such shop to be so used. 
(13)  Every barber or other person in charge of any barbershop shall furnish a plentiful supply of hot and cold water and shall use hot-water tanks for no other purpose than that of heating water. 
(14)  The owner or proprietor of every barbershop or beauty shop shall keep a copy of this section, which shall be furnished by the village manager, posted in such shop for the information and guidance of persons working or employed therein. 
(Code 1940, § 25.098; Code 1964, § 14-4)  
Sec. 14-177. - Canvasser badge required. 
All canvassers shall be issued a badge by the police division; which badge shall be worn on the canvasser in plain sight.  
Sec. 14-178. - Tattooing and body piercing establishments. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any business or occupation, shop or facility that engages in the practice of tattooing or body art, wherein any part of the human body is marked or figured by the insertion of pigment or dye under the skin or by the use of scarring, body piercing, or other mutilation of the human body for cosmetic purposes involving sharp instruments. 
(Code 1964, § 14-6; Ord. 93-11, 6-28-1993)  
Sec. 14-179. - Report of purchase and sale of used automobiles. 
(a)  All dealers in secondhand or used automobiles shall report to the police division of the department of public safety at least once each month the number of secondhand or used automobiles on hand and the number of used automobiles received and sold during the period from the last report given. 
(b)  Such report shall contain the motor and serial numbers of each such automobile, the name of the person from whom it was received, the name of the person to whom it was sold and such other information as the police chief may require. Blanks for the purpose of preparing such reports shall be furnished by the village. 
(Code 1940, § 25.084; Code 1964, § 18-13)  
Sec. 14-180. - Sick leave. 
(a)  It is the declared intent of the provisions of this section to conflict with Ordinance 16-4229 entitled An Ordinance Establishing Earned Sick Leave for Employees in Cook County enacted by the Cook County Board of Commissioners establishing an earned sick leave policy for all private employers in Cook County and thereby pursuant to Article VII. § 6(c) of the Illinois Constitution the provisions of this section shall prevail as to the Regulated Employers located within the village. 
(b)  As to all regulated employers in the village, employee eligibility for paid sick leave shall be in compliance with all statutes of the State of Illinois and/or all federal laws and regulations as such laws and regulations may exist from time to time, but shall not be required to be in compliance with Ordinance 16-4229 entitled An Ordinance Establishing Earned Sick Leave for Employees in Cook County enacted by the Cook County Board of Commissioners. 
(c)  No additional obligations with regard to the sick leave imposed by the Cook County Board of Commissioners now, or hereafter, shall apply to any regulated employer located within the village. 
(Ord. No. 2017-39 , § 3, 6-26-2017)  
Sec. 14-181. - Minimum wages. 
(a)  It is the declared intent of the provisions of this section to conflict with Ordinance 16-5768 entitled An Ordinance Creating a Minimum Wage in Cook County enacted by the Cook County Board of Commissioners establishing minimum wages to be paid by all private employers in Cook County and thereby pursuant to Article VII. § 6(c) of the Illinois Constitution, the provisions of this section shall prevail as to the regulated employers located within the village. 
(b)  As to all regulated employers in the village, employee minimum wages shall be in compliance with all statutes of the State of Illinois and/or all federal laws and regulations as such laws and regulations may exist from time to time, but shall not be required to be in compliance with Ordinance 16-5768 entitled An Ordinance Creating a Minimum Wage in Cook County enacted by the Cook County Board of Commissioners. 
(c)  No additional obligations with regard to the minimum wages imposed by the Cook County Board of Commissioners now, or hereafter, shall apply to any regulated employer located within the village. 
(Ord. No. 2017-38 , § 3, 6-26-2017)  
Secs. 14-182—14-196. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - AUCTIONEERS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Auction License Act, 225 ILCS 407/5-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 14-197. - Sales to be conducted by licensed auctioneer. 
All sales of real and personal property at public auction within the village, except such as are made under and by virtue of legal process, shall be made by a person who shall have first obtained a license for such purpose from the village. 
(Code 1940, § 25.060; Code 1964, § 07-41)  
Sec. 14-198. - Sale in public places prohibited. 
No goods, wares, merchandise, or any other thing whatsoever shall be sold or exposed for sale in any street, alley, or public place in the village at auction, but all auctions shall be held or conducted in a store, warehouse or other proper place, which shall be so arranged that none of the bidders or bystanders will be compelled or required to stand or remain on the street or sidewalk in front of such warehouse, store or other place in such manner as to obstruct free travel. 
(Code 1940, § 25.059; Code 1964, § 07-42)  
Sec. 14-199. - False representations as to articles offered for sale. 
Any auctioneer or person present when any article is offered for sale who shall knowingly, with intent to induce any person at auction to purchase the same or any part thereof, make any false representation or statement as to the ownership, character or quality of the article so offered for sale, or as to the property or circumstances of the owner or pretended owner of such article, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1940, § 25.006; Code 1964, § 07-43)  
Sec. 14-200. - Substitutions for articles purchased. 
Any auctioneer who shall exhibit and offer for sale at auction any article, and induce its purchase by any bidder, and who shall afterwards substitute any article in lieu of that offer to and purchased by the bidder, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1940, § 25.065; Code 1964, § 07-44)  
Sec. 14-201. - Fictitious bids. 
Any auctioneer or other person who shall procure any person to make a fictitious bid at any auction sale of real or personal property, or who shall conspire with any person to make a fictitious bid at any such auction sale, or who shall knowingly permit any person to make a fictitious bid at any such auction sale, or who shall himself fictitiously raise any bids at any such auction sale, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1940, § 25.067; Code 1964, § 07-45)  
Sec. 14-202. - Investigations by police. 
It shall be the duty of the village police to investigate all auctions and to observe and see that there are no violations of the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1940, § 25.064; Code 1964, § 07-46)  
Secs. 14-203—14-227. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - AUTO DRY CLEANING MACHINES 
 
Sec. 14-228. - Compliance with division and rules of state health department. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to install, operate or maintain any automatic dry cleaning machine, coin-operated or otherwise, except in compliance with the provisions of this division, or without complying with all of the provisions pertaining to the installation and operation of such machine contained in this division, or in violation of any laws, rules or regulations of the state department of public health relating thereto. 
(Code 1964, § 07-52; Ord. of 1-22-1962)  
Sec. 14-229. - Permit to install. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to install any automatic dry cleaning machine without first having secured a permit therefor from the chief building inspector. Application for such permit shall contain full information as to the mechanical equipment of such machine and provisions for ventilation for both machine and the room in which the machine will be located. The fee for such permit shall be $25.00 for each unit or machine. 
(Code 1964, § 07-53; Ord. of 1-22-1962)  
Sec. 14-230. - Construction and installation requirements. 
(a)  Each automatic dry cleaning machine shall be completely enclosed by a cabinet and shall be vented with intake at the top and the outlet at or near the bottom of such machine. Groups of machines may be entirely enclosed or supported on all open sides by an enclosure topped with a hood vented as provided for each individual machine. 
(b)  The exhaust system for such machines must maintain a minimum flow of 100 cubic feet per minute face velocity through the loading door whenever the door is open. The discharge stack for the machines and for the room in which the machines are located shall extend at least two feet above the level of any window which can be opened, located within 50 feet of the outlet of the stack, and shall be at least 50 feet away from fresh air intake leading to any premises. 
(c)  Automatic dry cleaning machines must be so constructed as to prevent the loading door from being opened during the normal cycle of operation. Each machine shall be equipped with a transparent door or port to allow visual examination of the status of the cleaning cycle. 
(d)  Any connection of such machine with the water supply system must be equipped with an air gap or vacuum breaker in the line upstream from the condenser, with no control valves down stream from such gap or breaker. Wastewater shall be discharged through an air gap. 
(e)  The room in which such machine is installed shall be ventilated so that there shall be a minimum flow of air per machine from the area to which the public is admitted of at least 500 cubic feet per minute in a room where there are no more than three machines installed; 400 cubic feet per minute where there are no more than eight machines installed; 375 cubic feet per minute where there are no more than 16 machines installed; and 360 cubic feet per minute where there are more than 17 machines installed. For this purpose, each cleaning cell shall be considered as one machine. 
(f)  Each machine must be so designed and constructed as to prevent the leakage of liquids, gas or vapors. 
(Code 1964, § 07-54; Ord. of 1-22-1962)  
Sec. 14-231. - Operating requirements. 
(a)  No automatic dry cleaning machine shall be operated unless all the equipment is properly installed and in good working condition. 
(b)  No establishment wherein automatic dry cleaning machines are located for the use of the public shall be open for business, and it shall be unlawful to admit the public or customers into the room where such machines are located, unless there is on duty in the establishment at all times a competent person in charge of the establishment, and in charge of the operation of such machines. 
(c)  There shall be signs posted in places of easy observation warning of all the dangers in the event leakage of liquids, gas or vapor occurs. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any residue containing solvent to flow into the sewer system of the village. 
(e)  Tightly covered metal containers may be used for temporary storage of such waste outside the building. Such containers shall bear labels indicating the contents and dangers involved in handling, and shall be locked if in an unenclosed place. 
(f)  At least one legible sign shall be maintained in a place available to customers giving the name, address and phone number of the owner of the establishment, and of the service department or agency responsible for the proper maintenance of the machines. 
(Code 1964, § 07-55; Ord. of 1-22-1962)  
Sec. 14-232. - Inspections to enforce article. 
It shall be the duty of the village manager to cause such inspections to be made as are necessary to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1964, § 07-56; Ord. of 1-22-1962)  
Secs. 14-233—14-257. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - FACTORIES AND WORKSHOPS 
 
Sec. 14-258. - General sanitary requirements. 
(a)  Every factory or workshop shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. All articles made, altered, repaired, or finished in such establishment shall be kept free from vermin and any matter of any infectious or contagious nature. 
(b)  No person suffering from any actively contagious or infectious disease shall be employed in any factory or workshop. 
(c)  All decomposed, fetid, or putrescent matter, and all refuse, waste, and sweepings of any factory or workshop shall be removed and disposed of at least once each day, and in such a manner as not to cause a nuisance. 
(d)  All cleaning shall be done, as far as possible, outside of working hours, but if done during working hours, it shall be done in such a manner as to avoid the unnecessary raising of dust or noxious odors. 
(Code 1940, § 25.432; Code 1964, § 07-62)  
Sec. 14-259. - Floors. 
In every factory or workshop in which any process is carried on which makes the floor wet, the floor shall be constructed and maintained with due regard to the health of the employees, and gratings or dry standing room shall be provided for, if practicable, at points where employees are regularly stationed, and adequate means shall be provided for drainage, and for preventing seepage or leakage to the floors below. 
(Code 1940, § 25.432; Code 1964, § 07-63)  
Sec. 14-260. - Ventilation, washing and toilet facilities. 
In all factories and workshops adequate ventilation, washing and toilet facilities shall be provided in accordance with the provisions of the laws of the state in reference thereto. 
(Code 1940, § 25.432; Code 1964, § 07-64)  
Sec. 14-261. - Heating requirements. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every person owning or controlling the heating plant, which furnishes heat to any factory or workshop, to maintain a temperature within such factory or workshop of not less than 68 degrees Fahrenheit, without such undue restriction of ventilation as to interfere with proper sanitary conditions therein. 
(b)  This requirement shall not apply to any factory or workshop where the business conducted therein is of such a nature that a higher or lower temperature than 68 degrees Fahrenheit is necessary or expedient for the work, or manufacturing processes of such business. In all such cases, when such higher or lower temperature is necessary or expedient, the moisture content of the air shall be increased where the temperature is maintained below 68 degrees Fahrenheit or decreased where the temperature is maintained above 68 degrees Fahrenheit in the proper amount to maintain a wet bulb temperature between 54 degrees and 58 degrees Fahrenheit, and in the case of special manufacturing processes where it is necessary or expedient to maintain a wet bulb temperature below or above the extremes herein set forth, the commissioner of buildings shall prescribe and enforce such reasonable precautions and safeguards as will meet the requirements of such special manufacturing processes without endangering the health of the occupants of such factory or workshop. 
(c)  In cases where the temperature to be maintained under this section is 68 degrees Fahrenheit, temperature readings shall be made by the chief building inspector by means of a standard Fahrenheit thermometer, in not less than two separate rooms in such factory or workshop or, if the premises consists of only one room, then in two opposite parts of the room as near the extremes as practicable, such thermometer to be placed at a point not less than four feet nor more than six feet away from any door or window leading to the outer air, and not more than four feet from the floor. In all other cases, such temperature shall be determined in such practical manner as the chief building inspector may determine. 
(Code 1964, § 07-65; Ord. of 12-19-1949, § 1)  
Sec. 14-262. - Outdoor storage. 
It shall be unlawful for any business to store any materials offered for sale to the general public outdoors unless prior approval is received from the village health department and manager's office. 
(Code 1964, § 07-66; Ord. No. 1974-14, § 1, 9-23-1974)  
Secs. 14-263—14-287. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - GARAGE SALES 
 
Sec. 14-288. - Number and duration limited; goods to be sold. 
Every owner or occupant of a dwelling unit may conduct not more than two garage sales in any one calendar year. Such sales shall extend over not more than three consecutive days, and shall be limited to household goods and furnishings which have been in use in the dwelling unit located on the premises on which such sales are conducted or which have been in use in more than one dwelling unit on the same block. No merchandise purchased for intentional sale or resale at a profit may be sold from a private residence. 
(Code 1964, § 07-136; Ord. No. 1977-21, § 1, 6-27-1977)  
Sec. 14-289. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2015-77, § 2 , adopted Dec. 14, 2015, repealed § 14-289, which pertained to permit required and derived from Code 1964, § 07-137; and Ord. No. 1977-21, § 1, adopted June 27, 1977.  
Sec. 14-290. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2015-77, § 3 , adopted Dec. 14, 2015, repealed § 14-290, which pertained to exemption for charitable, not-for-profit, and religious fundraising and derived from Code 1964, § 07-138; and Ord. No. 1977-21, § 1, adopted June 27, 1977.  
Sec. 14-291. - Signs and loudspeakers prohibited. 
No signs or advertisement indicating the address, location or direction of a garage sale shall be allowed upon any tree, shrub or pole located in any street, parkway or other public place; nor shall any sign be allowed on any property other than the property wherein the garage sale is to take place. No loudspeakers shall be used for promotional purposes during the conduct of any garage sale. 
(Code 1964, § 07-139; Ord. No. 1977-21, § 1, 6-27-1977)  
Sec. 14-292. - Front yard restriction. 
No household goods or furnishings shall be displayed or offered for sale in any portion of a front yard, from the front building line to the public right-of-way. 
(Code 1964, § 07-140; Ord. No. 1977-21, § 1, 6-27-1977)  
Sec. 14-293. - Public property. 
No household goods or furnishings shall be displayed or offered for sale on any public property or public right-of-way. 
(Code 1964, § 07-141; Ord. No. 1977-21, § 1, 6-27-1977)  
Sec. 14-294. - Time of sale. 
No garage, rummage or other like sale may commence before the hour of 9:00 a.m., nor extend beyond the hour of 6:00 p.m. 
(Code 1964, § 07-142; Ord. No. 1977-21, § 1, 6-27-1977)  
Sec. 14-295. - Violation and penalty. 
Any garage sale held in violation of any of the foregoing provisions of this division shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $25.00. 
(Code 1964, § 07-143; Ord. No. 1977-21, § 1, 6-27-1977)  
Secs. 14-296—14-323. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - PEDDLERS 
 
Sec. 14-324. - Exception for charitable and religious peddling; badge required. 
No license fee shall be required from any person, resident or nonresident who sells or offers for sale or solicits orders for the sale of articles when the proceeds of such sale are to be devoted to charitable or religious purposes, provided any such person shall procure from the police division a permit to engage in such work before being permitted to do so.  
Sec. 14-325. - Assistants and helpers. 
If a peddler desires an assistant or helper, he shall make an application for the same either at the time of making application for his license or at any time during which his license is in force; provided, however, that there shall be permitted but one helper or assistant to the operator or driver of any peddler's vehicle. No such helper or assistant shall be permitted to so assist or help unless the peddler's license authorizes such helper or assistant.  
Sec. 14-326. - Sales by growers. 
Upon the presentation of proof to the village manager by a farmer, fruit or vine grower or gardener of his intention to sell only the produce of his own farm, orchard, vineyard or garden, the village manager shall issue to such person, without charge, a license to peddle within the village, and no village officer shall collect or demand for himself or for the village any fee for any such license.  
Sec. 14-327. - Peddling of drugs and medicines prohibited. 
No license shall be issued to any person authorizing the peddling at retail of any drugs or medicines of any description and the peddling of drugs and medicines from door to door or the distributing of samples of pills, powders or other drugs or medicines from door to door within the corporate limits of the village is hereby forbidden.  
Secs. 14-328—14-357. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - SOLICITORS 
 
Sec. 14-358. - Findings and purpose. 
(a)  It is hereby determined that: 
(1)  Uninvited visits to private residential properties and privately owned businesses for the purposes of soliciting funds, goods, wares, merchandise or services by persons and organizations have been occurring and continue to occur within the village. 
(2)  Residents and business owners have complained that these activities are intrusive upon their privacy and disruptive to their daily activities. 
(3)  A variety of misrepresentations and other frauds are at times employed in such activities. 
(4)  Burglaries and attacks on persons in their homes have occurred by persons claiming to be solicitors. 
(5)  The village has a legitimate and substantial interest in promoting the public health, safety, and welfare of its residents by preventing fraudulent or criminal activities which may result from unregulated solicitation. 
(6)  Noncommercial speech is entitled to broader protection under the First Amendment to the United States Constitution than commercial speech, affording the village a greater ability to regulate commercial speech than noncommercial speech. 
(7)  An effective way to promote and protect persons' safety and privacy is by reasonably limiting the hours of solicitation and requiring solicitors to obtain permits in a content-neutral manner. Allowing individuals to determine their level of comfort with privacy and whether or not they want to receive solicitation will promote the village's interest in promoting public safety and protecting individuals' privacy, while respecting solicitors' interests in effective distribution of information. A reasonable accommodation of these competing interests can be achieved by adoption of this division, which regulates the time, place and manner of solicitations. 
(b)  Based on the findings described above, it is further found that there is a need for narrowly tailored reasonable time, place and manner restrictions regarding soliciting within the village so as to accomplish the following, to the extent reasonably possible: 
(1)  Provide for the safety of the public and property; 
(2)  Deter fraud and crime by determining the identity of solicitors by requiring solicitors to obtain a permit prior to soliciting within the village; 
(3)  Restrict the unreasonable interference with privacy by reasonably restricting the hours of solicitation activities; 
(4)  Prohibit the solicitation of occupants of property when the occupant has posted a sign prohibiting such activities; and 
(5)  Respect the solicitors' interests in effective distribution of information. 
(Ord. No. 2011-41, § 1(07-175), 7-25-2011)  
Sec. 14-359. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Applicant means any person or entity that has filed an application for a commercial or noncommercial solicitation permit as hereinafter provided. 
Charitable organization means: 
(1)  Any benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, or eleemosynary person, or one purporting to be such, which solicits and collects funds for charitable purposes and includes each local, county or area division of such charitable organization, provided such local, county or area division has authority and discretion to disburse funds or property otherwise than by transfer to any parent organization; 
(2)  A not-for-profit organization incorporated pursuant to 805 ILCS 110/0.01 and 805 ILCS 110/35; or 
(3)  Any other organization that has been granted tax-exempt status from the state or the Internal Revenue Service pursuant to Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
Charitable purpose means any charitable, benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, or eleemosynary purpose. 
Commercial solicitation means solicitation which is not conducted for any charitable purpose or political purpose, or on behalf of any charitable organization, as those terms are defined herein. 
Noncommercial solicitation means solicitation for a charitable purpose or political purpose, or on behalf of a charitable organization, as those terms are defined herein. 
Nonresidential premises means and includes all buildings, structures, and units in the village occupied for nonresidential purposes. 
Political purpose means any activity in support of bona fide candidates for public office, or any matter related to the election, nomination, or performance of public officials, or issues presented to the electorate at any election. 
Residence means and includes every separate living unit in the village occupied for residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of building or structure. 
Solicit means to engage in any acts of solicitation as defined herein. 
Solicitation. 
(1)  The term "solicitation" means the act of any person traveling by foot, vehicle or any other type of conveyance who goes from residence to residence, business to business, from place to place or in or along any highway, street or sidewalk within the village either: 
a.  Requesting, either directly or indirectly, money, credit, funds, contributions, personal property or anything of value; 
b.  Taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of any goods, wares, merchandise or services of any kind, or description for future delivery or for services to be performed in the future, in person or by the in person distribution of flyers and leaflets; and 
c.  Selling and making immediate delivery any goods, wares, merchandise or services of any kind or description, commonly referred to as peddling. 
(2)  The term "solicitation" shall not include the following so long as the person is not requesting, either directly or indirectly, money, credit, funds, contributions, personal property or anything of value: 
a.  A person communicating or otherwise conveying ideas, views or beliefs or otherwise disseminating oral or written information to a person willing to directly receive such information, provided that such information is of a political, religious or charitable nature; 
b.  A person seeking to influence the personal belief of the occupant of any residence or business in regard to any political or religious matter; 
c.  A person seeking to obtain, from an occupant of any residence or business, an indication of the occupant's belief in regard to any political or religious matter; 
d.  A person conducting a poll, survey or petition drive in regard to any political matter; and 
e.  A person carrying, conveying, delivering or transporting dairy products, newspapers or other goods to regular customers on established routes or to the premises of any person who had previously ordered such products or goods and is entitled to receive the same. 
(3)  The term "solicitation" shall also not include seeking or obtaining nominal contributions such as gifts, food, candy or contributions of money as is customarily and commonly known as "trick-or-treat" in the celebration of Halloween day. 
(Ord. No. 2011-41, § 1(07-176), 7-25-2011)  
Sec. 14-360. - Administration. 
(a)  The village clerk shall have the following powers and duties, which shall at all times be performed without consideration of the content or viewpoint of the information being distributed by a solicitor: 
(1)  To administer and rule upon the applications for, and the issuance, renewal, suspension, denial and revocation of permits as set forth in this division. 
(2)  To take such further actions as the village clerk shall deem necessary to carry out the purposes and intent of this division and to exercise such additional powers in furtherance thereof as are implied or incident to those powers and duties expressly set forth in this division. 
(b)  The powers and duties of the village clerk under this division may be exercised by any deputy village clerk appointed as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2011-41, § 1(07-177), 7-25-2011)  
Sec. 14-361. - Solicitation permits. 
(a)  Solicitation permit required. A commercial or noncommercial solicitation permit shall be required to solicit within the village. 
(b)  Solicitation without permit prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person not in possession of a current and valid commercial or noncommercial solicitation permit to solicit within the village at any time after the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived. 
(c)  Solicitation without permit displayed. It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit within the village at any time that a current and valid commercial or noncommercial solicitation permit is not displayed in plain view on the person who is soliciting after the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived. 
(d)  Solicitation in violation of permit prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any holder of a commercial or noncommercial solicitation permit to solicit except in the manner authorized by, and in compliance with, the provisions of this division. 
(e)  Assignment or transfer of permit prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any holder of a commercial or noncommercial solicitation permit to assign or transfer a commercial or noncommercial solicitation permit. 
(Ord. No. 2011-41, § 1(07-178), 7-25-2011)  
Sec. 14-362. - Solicitation restrictions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to go in or upon, ring the bell, knock on the door of or attempt to gain admission to any residence, dwelling, apartment or nonresidential premises which is posted with a sticker or sign bearing the words "No Trespassing," "No Peddlers," "No Solicitors" or any other similar notice indicating in any manner that the occupants of such residence or nonresidential premises desire not to be disturbed or to have their rights of privacy disturbed for the purpose of soliciting, unless such occupant has specifically requested or invited such solicitation. For convenience, the village manager may make available to village residents stickers or weatherproof cards bearing notice of the type herein described for posting on or near the main entrance door to any residence or nonresidential premises. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to go in or upon, ring the bell, knock on the door of, or attempt to gain admission to any residence, dwelling, apartment or nonresidential premises for the purpose of conducting solicitation at any time after 9:00 p.m. or before 8:00 a.m. on any day, unless such person has been requested or invited by the owner or adult occupant of the premises to be thereupon for such purposes. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person conducting solicitation at any residence or nonresidential premises to fail to leave and to fail to cease conducting solicitation at such residence or nonresidential premises immediately upon receiving, from any person present at such residence or nonresidential premises, a request to leave or cease conducting solicitation. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct solicitation in or on any sidewalk or other public property, way or place in a manner that completely or substantially impedes the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic in, on or around such sidewalk or public property, way or place. No person conducting solicitation shall have the exclusive right to any sidewalk or other public property, way or place, nor to establish a permanent stationary location for such solicitation. 
(e)  Notwithstanding the provisions of section 14-365, it shall be unlawful for any person to conduct solicitation of employment, business, or sales of any kind from the occupant of any vehicle traveling upon any street or highway when: 
(1)  The solicitation or collection causes the person performing the activity to enter onto the traveled portion of a street or highway; 
(2)  The solicitation or collection involves the person performing the activity to be located upon any median area which separates traffic lanes for vehicular travel in opposite directions; or 
(3)  The person performing the activity is located such that vehicles cannot move into a legal parking area to safely conduct the transaction. 
(f)  For purposes of this section, the term "traveled portion of the street or highway" shall mean that portion of the road normally used by moving motor vehicle traffic. 
(g)  A violation of this section is hereby defined to be a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 2011-41, §1(07-179), 7-25-2011)  
Sec. 14-363. - Frauds, misrepresentations, and cheating prohibited. 
No peddler, solicitor or canvasser shall commit any fraud, cheating or misrepresentation within the village.
