(2)  Conviction of the applicant, or, if the applicant is a firm, partnership, or association, of any of its members, or, if a corporation, of any of its officers or directors, or of the person designated to manage or supervise the home, of a felony or of two or more misdemeanors involving moral turpitude, as shown by a certified copy of the record of a court of convictions, or, in the case of the conviction of a misdemeanor by a court not of record, as shown by other evidence; or other satisfactory evidence that the moral character of the applicant, or manager, or supervisor of the home is not reputable. 
(3)  Personnel insufficient in number or unqualified by training or experience to properly care for the proposed number and type of residents. 
(4)  Financial inability to operate and conduct the home in accordance with the requirements of this chapter and the minimum standards, rules, and regulations promulgated hereunder. 
(Code 1964, § 19-12; Ord. of 5-14-1962, § 6)  
Sec. 28-30. - Inspection prerequisite to issuance. 
No license shall be issued for the operation of a nursing home, sheltered care home or home for the aged until an inspection shall first have been made by the building inspector, the fire chief, and the division of health, to determine that the minimum standards prescribed in this chapter have been met. 
(Code 1964, § 19-13; Ord. of 5-14-1962, § 8)  
Sec. 28-31. - Fees. 
There shall be no license fee for a home for the aged. The annual license fee for operating a nursing home or sheltered care home shall be based upon the number of residents for which maintenance, personal care, or nursing is to be provided, as provided in the village fee schedule. 
(Code 1964, § 19-14; Ord. of 5-14-1962, § 5)  
Sec. 28-32. - Renewal. 
An application for the annual renewal of a license issued under this article, accompanied by the annual renewal fee, shall be submitted to the village manager on blanks furnished by the village. No such license shall be renewed unless authorized by the village manager. 
(Code 1964, § 19-15; Ord. of 5-14-62, § 9)  
Sec. 28-33. - Relocation of home voids license. 
When a licensed nursing home, sheltered care home, or home for the aged is sold, leased, discontinued, or moved to a new location, the license shall immediately become void. 
(Code 1964, § 19-16; Ord. of 5-14-1962, § 10)  
Sec. 28-34. - Revocation. 
Any license issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Cruelty or indifference to the welfare of the residents. 
(2)  Misappropriation of the property of the residents. 
(3)  Conversion of the property of the resident without his consent. 
(4)  Violation of any provision of this chapter or of the minimum standards, rules, regulations or orders prescribed or adopted by this chapter. 
(5)  Any ground upon which an application for a license may be denied. 
(Code 1964, § 19-17; Ord. of 5-14-1962, § 10) 

Chapter 30 - HOTELS, MOTELS AND ROOMING HOUSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to regulate rooming houses and apartments, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-3; municipal authority to regulate public sleeping accommodations, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-5; Hotel Floor Plan Posting Act, 425 ILCS 50/0.01 et seq.; Innkeeper Protection Act, 740 ILCS 90-/1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 30-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Hotel means any building or part thereof, other than a motel, used or held out to the public as a place where sleeping accommodations are furnished for 20 or more persons for a period of one day or more. 
Motel means any establishment consisting of a group of attached or detached rooms, located on a single zoning lot or contiguous or adjoining zoning lots comprising one single plot of land, which is kept, used, maintained, advertised or held out to the public to be a place where units, with or without self-contained kitchen facilities, are offered for adequate pay to travelers and guests, whether transient, permanent or residential. These facilities may be described as motor hotels, highway hotels, motor courts, lodges, inns or other similar names denoting that accommodations are available primarily for transient guests. 
Rooming house means any building, apartment or portion of a building, other than a hotel or motel, in which more than four persons not related to the owner or occupant of such premises by blood or marriage are furnished sleeping accommodations for hire. 
(Code 1964, § 15-1; Ord. of 8-4-1958, § 1; Ord. of 2-22-1960, § 1; Ord. of 12-3-1962, § 1)  
Secs. 30-2—30-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - REGULATIONS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 30-21. - Conflicts with state law or rules. 
In the event any provision of this article conflicts with state law or state rules and regulations promulgated pursuant to law, state law shall prevail.  
Secs. 30-22—30-45. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - HOTELS AND ROOMING HOUSES 
 
Sec. 30-46. - Premises to be kept clean and sanitary. 
All premises used for hotel or rooming house purposes shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Code 1964, § 15-7; Ord. of 8-4-1958, § 1)  
Sec. 30-47. - Heating of premises. 
All premises used for hotel or rooming house purposes shall be kept heated between October 1 and May 1 to a temperature of not less than 68 degrees Fahrenheit between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m., and to a temperature of not less than 55 degrees Fahrenheit at all other hours. 
(Code 1964, § 15-8; Ord. of 8-4-1958, § 1)  
Sec. 30-48. - Exits. 
(a)  No building shall be used for a hotel unless it is furnished with the number of exits and fire escapes required by the building ordinances of the village for the construction of a new hotel. No premises shall be used for a rooming house unless there are at least two exits to the outdoors from such premises. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to block or permit the blocking of any exit from any premises used for a hotel or rooming house. 
(Code 1964, § 15-9; Ord. of 8-4-1958, § 1)  
Sec. 30-49. - Lighting of hotel premises. 
All portions of a hotel that are open for use by all guests or by the public shall be kept lighted at all times they are so open. 
(Code 1964, § 15-10; Ord. of 8-4-1958, § 1)  
Sec. 30-50. - Guest registration. 
Each hotel proprietor shall keep or cause to be kept a register of guests as required by state law, and each operator of a rooming house shall keep a list of all persons staying therein. Such registration or list shall be available for inspection by any village police officer at any time. 
(Code 1964, § 15-11; Ord. of 8-4-1958, § 1)  
Sec. 30-51. - Fugitives from justice not to be kept. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly permit any fugitive from justice to stay in any rooming house, hotel or motel. 
(Code 1964, § 15-12; Ord. of 8-4-1958, § 1)  
Sec. 30-52. - Inspections to enforce article. 
It shall be the duty of the director of building and planning to inspect or cause to be inspected every hotel or rooming house operated in the village as frequently as may be necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1964, § 15-13; Ord. of 8-4-1958, § 1)  
Secs. 30-53—30-77. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - MOTELS 
 
Sec. 30-78. - Compliance with building ordinances. 
All motels constructed or so remodeled as to create new or additional accommodations shall comply with all applicable provisions of chapter 12 and other building ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1964, § 15-19; Ord. of 2-22-1960, § 1)  
Sec. 30-79. - Minimum size for rooms. 
All motel units shall have at least 50 square feet of floor area for each adult person occupying such room and in no event shall any room have less than 100 square feet, exclusive of area required for toilet and exclusive of space provided for clothing racks or closet space. 
(Code 1964, § 15-20; Ord. of 2-22-1960, § 1)  
Sec. 30-80. - Window area of rental units. 
The window area of each motel rental unit shall be sufficient to furnish adequate natural light. Twenty-five percent of the required window area shall be capable of being opened unless some other adequate means of ventilation is provided. 
(Code 1964, § 15-21; Ord. of 2-22-1960, § 1)  
Sec. 30-81. - Water supply and sewerage disposal. 
An adequate supply of safe water shall be provided at every motel from a source which complies with the municipal requirements governing the supply of water. All sewage and all other or water carried wastes shall be discharged into a municipal sewer. 
(Code 1964, § 15-22; Ord. of 2-22-1960, § 1)  
Sec. 30-82. - Toilet facilities. 
Each motel rental unit shall be equipped with a private bathroom consisting of a toilet, lavatory, shower-stall and/or bath, all within a single enclosed area. The toilet room shall contain at least one window opening to the outside unless some other adequate means of ventilation is provided. 
(Code 1964, § 15-23; Ord. of 2-22-1960, § 1)  
Sec. 30-83. - Heating facilities. 
Each motel room, including the bathroom, shall have facilities to keep such room at a minimum temperature of 68 degrees Fahrenheit. All combustion type room heaters used at a motel shall be vented to the outside. If gas heaters are used, the same shall be approved by the American Gas Association or some other recognized testing laboratory that provides a follow up inspection service. All heaters must be equipped with an automatic shut-off which will operate at flame failure. 
(Code 1964, § 15-24; Ord. of 2-22-1960, § 1)  
Sec. 30-84. - Standards for mechanical equipment. 
All mechanical equipment installed or used in connection with a motel, including, but not limited to, electrical, water, and sewer supplies and heating facilities, shall be of such standard as to provide a reasonable degree of health and safeguards for the occupants of the motel. 
(Code 1964, § 15-25; Ord. of 2-22-1960, § 1)  
Sec. 30-85. - Off-street parking. 
The village zoning requirements of this Code with respect to off-street parking shall be fully met at every motel. 
(Code 1964, § 15-26; Ord. of 2-22-1960, § 1)  
Sec. 30-86. - Attendant or caretaker. 
Each motel establishment shall have at least one competent attendant or caretaker available at all times. It shall be his duty to receive and deliver telephone messages and mail and to maintain the premises, facilities and equipment in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition and free from rodents and vermin. 
(Code 1964, § 15-27; Ord. of 2-22-1960, § 1)  
Sec. 30-87. - Maintenance of premises and supplies, facilities, etc., generally. 
(a)  All floors in the bathroom of each motel unit shall be thoroughly washed and disinfected for each incoming guest. 
(b)  All areas of a motel shall be kept free from rubbish, litter and inflammable materials at all times, and no inflammable liquids or chemicals shall be kept on the premises unless the same are in approved types of containers. 
(c)  All sheets, towels and other linens furnished for a motel rental unit shall be clean and freshly laundered for each incoming guest. 
(d)  All drinking glasses furnished at a motel shall be washed and sterilized for each incoming guest. If paper cups are furnished in lieu thereof, such paper cups shall be in proper dispensers which do not require the handling of same by the guest. 
(e)  The entire establishment of a motel shall be operated in such a manner as to provide clean wholesome accommodations to the guests at all times. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, it shall be the duty of the operator of the establishment to keep the furniture, furnishings and equipment and the premises as a whole in a good state of repair and maintenance. 
(f)  In any motel rental unit where cooking facilities are provided, fly-proof metal containers shall be supplied for garbage and refuse; and it shall be the duty of the motel operator to promptly remove and dispose of such garbage and refuse each day. 
(g)  Any area or premises of a motel open to use by the public or by all persons staying in or being accommodated in the motel shall be kept adequately lighted at night time. 
(Code 1964, § 15-28; Ord. of 2-22-1960, § 1)  
Sec. 30-88. - Construction and maintenance of swimming pools. 
Artificial swimming pools used in connection with the recreation area of a motel shall be constructed and maintained in a manner which will not create any health or safety hazards. 
(Code 1964, § 15-29; Ord. of 2-22-1960, § 1)  
Sec. 30-89. - Guest registration generally. 
Each motel establishment shall keep a registration of all transient guests. This register shall contain the name, legal residence, make of car, car licenses, number and names of persons occupying the rooms, the number of the rooms assigned to the guest or guests and the date of arrival and departure. The register shall be available for inspection by law enforcement officers for a period of not less than three years. 
(Code 1964, § 15-30; Ord. of 2-22-1960, § 1)  
Sec. 30-90. - Office, lobby, or other registration area required. 
Each motel establishment shall maintain an office, lobby or other room or lighted drive-in area, which shall be available for the registration of guests. 
(Code 1964, § 15-31; Ord. of 2-22-1960, § 1)  
Sec. 30-91. - Number of occupants permitted per room. 
In no event shall more than four adult persons be accommodated in any one individual motel room. 
(Code 1964, § 15-32; Ord. of 2-22-1960, § 1)  
Sec. 30-92. - Fire extinguishers. 
For each 2,500 square feet of floor area on each floor of a motel, one, two and one-half gallon soda and acid approved type fire extinguishers shall be available, but in no event shall there be less than one fire extinguisher on each floor. In no event shall extinguishers be located so that a person would have to travel more than 100 feet from any part of the motel to the nearest extinguisher. 
(Code 1964, § 15-33; Ord. of 2-22-1960, § 1)  
Sec. 30-93. - Notices relative to rates and regulations to be posted in rooms. 
(a)  Printed notices shall be posted in each motel room giving the established rate for the room for one or more persons and it shall be unlawful to charge a rate in excess of such rate; provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall prohibit the motel from establishing other or different rates during seasonal periods and nothing herein contained shall prevent the proprietor from changing such published rates from time to time. 
(b)  Such notices shall also prescribe any reasonable rules and regulations of the establishment not in conflict with any provision of this Code or other ordinance of the village or any statute or regulation of the state. 
(Code 1964, § 15-34; Ord. of 2-22-1960, § 1)  
Secs. 30-94—30-114. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - HOTEL-MOTEL TAX 
 
Sec. 30-115. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Hotel means any building or buildings in which the public may, for a consideration, obtain living quarters, sleeping or housekeeping accommodations. The term "hotel" includes inns, motels, tourist homes or courts, lodging houses, rooming houses and apartment houses; provided, however, if the definition of "hotel" in the Hotel Operators' Occupation Tax Act is amended, this definition shall also be amended to comply with that definition. 
Hotel operator means any person operating a hotel. 
Occupy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession, of any room or rooms in a hotel for any purpose, or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room or rooms. 
Permanent resident means any person who occupied or has the right to occupy any room or rooms, regardless of whether or not it is the same room or rooms, in a hotel for at least 30 consecutive days. 
Rental payment or lease payment means any consideration received by a hotel operator for the right or privilege to occupy a room in a hotel within the village. 
Room means any room in a hotel within the village that a member of the public is charged for the right or privilege to occupy the room. 
(Ord. No. 2010-50, § 2(07-190), 7-12-2010)  
Sec. 30-116. - License required. 
No person shall operate a hotel without first obtaining a license from the village as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2010-50, § 2(07-191), 7-12-2010)  
Sec. 30-117. - Hotel use tax imposed. 
A tax is imposed upon the privilege of renting or leasing rooms in a hotel within the village in an amount equal to five percent of the rental or lease payment, excluding, however, any rental or lease payment by a permanent resident of the hotel or any payment made to any hotel that is subject to the tax imposed under 70 ILCS 210/13(c), part of the Metropolitan Pier and Exposition Authority Act, 70 ILCS 210/1 et seq. This tax is in addition to all other taxes imposed by law. 
(Ord. No. 2010-50, § 2(07-192), 7-12-2010)  
Sec. 30-118. - Tax collection. 
(a)  The tax shall be collected by any hotel operator, as trustee, from those persons making the rental or lease payment at the time that the payment is tendered to the hotel. A hotel operator may separately state such tax as an additional charge on any rental or lease payment statement. 
(b)  Every hotel operator shall, on or before the 15th day of each calendar month, file with the village treasurer a tax return, on a form provided by the village, signed and sworn to by the hotel operator or its authorized agent indicating the total rental and lease payments and the total tax collected thereon by the hotel operator during the preceding calendar month and any penalties and interest due. 
(c)  The tax so collected shall be due and payable on the 15th day of each month for the preceding calendar month. The tax shall be paid to and collected from the hotel operator by the village treasurer. A remittance for the amount of the tax imposed by this article shall accompany the tax return. 
(d)  The hotel operator shall keep complete and accurate records, books and accounts in detail of all rental or lease payments. Such records shall be kept and made available at the hotel or such other place in the village as may be designated in writing by the person liable for the collection of the tax. Such records shall be kept for a period of not less than two years. 
(e)  The village treasurer, either personally or through his authorized agent, shall have the right at all reasonable times to audit the books and records of any hotel operator for the purpose of determining the accurate collection of the tax. Every hotel operator shall be considered a trustee for the collection of the tax for the village. 
(f)  All taxes collected shall be held by such hotel operator as trustee for and on behalf of the village. The failure of the hotel operator to collect the tax shall not exclude or release the obligation to pay the tax. 
(Ord. No. 2010-50, § 2(07-193), 7-12-2010)  
Sec. 30-119. - License suspension or revocation. 
(a)  The village manager may suspend or revoke any license issued to a hotel operator for failure to comply with the provisions of this article. A revocation or suspension shall take place only after a hearing based upon previously presented written charges and with at least 14 days' prior written notice. At that hearing, the party charged may be represented by counsel, and any witnesses called shall be subject to cross examination. 
(b)  The village manager shall issue a written opinion, with findings of fact, within 14 days after the conclusion of the hearing. Any person aggrieved by any decision of the village manager to suspend or revoke any license issued to a hotel operator may appeal that decision to the board of trustees within 14 days of the issuance of the village manager's decision by delivering a written notice with the village manager setting forth the facts on which the person bases the appeal. 
(Ord. No. 2010-50, § 2(07-195), 7-12-2010)  
Sec. 30-120. - Expenditure of hotel use tax. 
The monies collected by the village under this article may be expended solely to promote tourism and conventions within the village or otherwise to attract nonresident overnight visitors to the village. No monies collected by the village under this article may be used to advertise for or otherwise promote new competition in the hotel business. 
(Ord. No. 2010-50, § 2(07-196), 7-12-2010)  
Sec. 30-121. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be subject to penalties as provided in section 50-365 or, if no penalty is provided in that section, then as provided in section 1-12. 
(Ord. No. 2010-50, § 2(07-194), 7-12-2010)  
Chapter 32 - HUMAN RELATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Illinois Human Rights Act, 775 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.; authority for municipal fair housing ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/11-11.1-1; Discrimination in Sale of Real Estate Act, 720 ILCS 590/0.01 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 32-1. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter, the words and phrases used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in the Fair Housing Act, 42 USC. 3601 et seq., and in the Illinois Human Rights Act at Article 1 (775 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.), Article 3 (775 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.), and Article 4 (775 ILCS 5/5-101 et seq.), unless this chapter contains a specific definition for a word or phrase or unless the context of the sentence in which the word or phrase is used shall indicate otherwise. Specific definitions for this chapter are as follows: 
Discriminate means to treat any person differently from others because of race, color, religion, sex, national origin, ancestry, age, marital status, familial status, physical or mental handicap or disability, military status, sexual orientation, or legal source of income. 
Handicap may be used interchangeably with the term "disability." The preferred term for purposes of this chapter and its enforcement shall be "disability." 
Unlawful discrimination means discrimination against a person because of his race, color, religion, sex, national origin, ancestry, age, marital status, familial status, physical or mental handicap or disability, military status, sexual orientation, or legal source of income. 
(Code 1964, § 38-3; Ord. No. 02-29, 6-10-2002; Ord. No. 2007-54, exh. B(38-2), 5-29-2007)  
Secs. 32-2—32-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - FAIR HOUSING[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Authority for municipal fair housing ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/11-11.1-1. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 32-21. - Policy. 
It is the policy of the village that all individuals shall have an equal opportunity to purchase, own, lease, and occupy housing within the village without being discriminated against based on race, color, religion, gender, age, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge status, source of income, gender identity or housing status. It is also the policy of the village that members of those protected classes shall have the right to be free from discriminatory practices when engaging in real estate transactions and seeking access to financial credit for real estate transactions. The village's fair housing regulations shall be consistent with the provisions of the Fair Housing Act (42 USC 3601 et seq., as amended) and the Illinois Human Rights Act. Both laws as used in this chapter shall be identified as the Fair Housing Act and the Illinois Human Rights Act without citation to the statutes unless a specific citation is necessary. 
(Code 1964, § 38-1; Ord. No. 02-29, 6-10-2002; Ord. No. 2007-54, exh. B(38-1), 5-29-2007; Ord. No. 2009-007, § 2(38-1), 2-9-2009)  
Sec. 32-22. - Prohibited acts generally. 
No person shall engage in unlawful discrimination in violation of any provision of this chapter; the Fair Housing Act, 42 USC 3601 et seq., and in the Illinois Human Rights Act at Article 3 (775 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.), and Article 4 (775 ILCS 5/5-101 et seq.),; the village building code, as amended, as it relates to accessibility; the Illinois Accessibility Code, 71 Ill. Admin. Code § 400 et seq.; or any other applicable law or ordinance. Any amendments to those laws made after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall be incorporated by reference into this section without formal action by the village. If any provisions of the laws and codes are in conflict or are otherwise inconsistent, then the more stringent or restrictive provision shall prevail and shall be enforced by the village. 
(Code 1964, § 38-5(A); Ord. No. 02-29, 6-10-2002; Ord. No. 2007-54, exh. B(38-3), 5-29-2007)  
Sec. 32-23. - Rental regulations. 
No owner or manager of property being made available for rent within the village shall: 
(1)  Refuse to let a person with a disability make a reasonable modification to his dwelling unit or common use areas at the sole expense of the person renting the property from the owner or manager, if the modification is necessary for that person to make the housing accessible. The owner or manager shall be required to permit the modification to be made only if the person making the modification agrees to restore the property to its original condition when that person vacates the property. 
(2)  Refuse to make reasonable accommodations in rules, policies, practices, or services if the accommodations are necessary for the person with a disability to use the housing. 
(Code 1964, § 38-5; Ord. No. 02-29, 6-10-2002; Ord. No. 2007-54, exh. B(38-4), 5-29-2007)  
Secs. 32-24—32-49. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PROCEDURE 
 
Sec. 32-50. - Complaints. 
Any person aggrieved by a violation of any provision of this chapter may file a written complaint with the fair housing advisory committee. A complaint shall be barred from consideration by the committee if it is not filed within 90 days of the alleged unlawful act that forms the basis of the complaint. The complaint shall state: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the complainant. 
(2)  The name and address of the person or persons against whom the complaint is made, if that information is known to the complainant. 
(3)  The facts upon which the alleged violation is based. 
(4)  The dates and places when and where the alleged acts were committed. 
(5)  Any other information or documents supporting the alleged violation. 
(Code 1964, § 38-8(A); Ord. No. 02-29, 6-10-2002; Ord. No. 2007-54, exh. B(38-5), 5-29-2007)  
Sec. 32-51. - Procedure for processing complaints. 
(a)  The written complaint shall be filed with the office of the village manager and forwarded to the fair housing advisory committee and the village's consulting attorney. The committee shall call a special meeting, to be held within ten business days from the date the complaint was received, to review the complaint. 
(b)  If the committee determines that the face of the complaint is not a violation of this chapter, the complaint may be dismissed by the committee. 
(c)  If the committee determines that the face of the complaint may state a violation of this chapter, the committee may request additional information from the complainant, notice the party in violation, and request a written response to the complaint from the person or entity ("respondent") against whom the complaint has been filed. The respondent shall have ten days from the date of the request for response to submit a written response. The committee shall be authorized to grant an extension of the period in which to respond. 
(d)  Based on the additional information requested, if any, and the response from the respondent, if provided, the committee may follow any of the following courses of action: 
(1)  Determine that no probable cause exists for the filing of the complaint, and the complaint should be dismissed. 
(2)  Determine that mediation of the dispute is possible without further action as authorized by this Code. The committee shall state its findings and requirements of the complainant and respondent, and authorize village staff to monitor for compliance with said requirements for 30 calendar days. Upon resolution within 30 calendar days, the complaint may be closed. In the event the issue is not resolved within 30 days, the committee may reconvene to follow another course of action. 
(3)  Make a recommendation to the board of trustees that the party in violation be assessed a fine of $1,000.00 and that the complaint is referred to the county human rights commission. 
(e)  The board of trustees shall: 
(1)  Review and concur with or modify the committee recommendation; 
(2)  Find that no probable cause exists for the filing of the complaint, and the complaint should be dismissed; or 
(3)  Find that the issue was resolved after committee level but before board of trustees review, assess a fine of $1,000.00, and close the complaint. 
(f)  Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as prohibiting the complainant from taking independent legal or administrative action against the respondent for any violation of this chapter or any other applicable law or ordinance. 
(Code 1964, § 38-7; Ord. No. 02-29, 6-10-2002; Ord. No. 2007-54, exh. B(38-6), 5-29-2007)  
Chapter 34 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Requirement that municipal police department comply with the Minor Identification and Protection Act, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-10; Illinois Police Training Act, 50 ILCS 705/1 et seq.; Peace Officer Firearm Training Act, 50 ILCS 710/0.01 et seq.; Law Enforcement Salary Grant Act, 50 ILCS 715/0.01 et seq.; Uniform Peace Officers' Disciplinary Act, 50 ILCS 725/1 et seq.; auxiliary police officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-20; part-time police officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-21; hours, wages, and working hours of police officers and firemen, 65 ILCS 5/10-3-1; board of police and fire commissioners, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 34-1. - Certain village officers designated as conservators of the peace. 
After receiving a certificate attesting to the successful completion of a training course administered by the state law enforcement training standards board, the president, members of the board of trustees, the chief building inspector and the fire chief, as well as every member of the police department, are hereby declared to be conservators of the peace with such powers to make arrests as are given to conservators of the peace by statute. 
(Code 1940, § 10.009; Code 1964, § 22-1; Ord. No. 1971-27, § 1, 12-13-1971; Ord. No. 2008-53, § 2(22-1), 7-14-2008) 
State Law reference— Role of certain officers as conservators of the peace, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-15-25.  
Sec. 34-2. - Bail processing fee. 
An administrative bail processing fee in the amount provided in the village fee schedule shall be assessed against any person arrested and charged with a violation of any bailable village ordinance or state or federal law. The bail processing fee shall be collected when the arrestee posts bail or bond. All bail processing fees collected shall be paid over to the village's general corporate fund. 
(Ord. No. 2011-69, § 1, 11-14-2011)  
Secs. 34-3—34-22. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 34-23—34-47. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - POLICE CHIEF AND DEPUTY POLICE CHIEF 
 
Sec. 34-48. - Police chief ex officio captain. 
The police chief shall be the ex officio captain of the police department of the village. 
(Code 1940, § 18.003; Code 1964, § 22-2; Ord. of 3-26-1962, § 1; Ord. No. 1971-27, § 1, 12-13-1971)  
Sec. 34-49. - General powers and duties of police chief. 
(a)  The police chief shall have general and special supervision of the police department and all of its properties, equipment, appliances and implements used in, about or appurtenant to the police department, and he shall be held responsible for the proper use thereof and of the proper efficiency and conduct of the members of the police department, all under the direct supervision of the village manager. 
(b)  The police chief shall make a monthly report to the village manager, describing the activities of the department. 
(c)  The police chief shall promulgate a set of rules and regulations for the guidance and government of the members of the department. 
(d)  The police chief shall enforce all ordinances and police regulations of the village and orders of the president and board of trustees, and all applicable state and federal law. 
(Code 1940, § 18.004; Code 1964, § 22-3; Ord. No. 1971-27, § 1, 12-13-1971)  
Sec. 34-50. - Deputy police chief. 
(a)  There is hereby established the position of deputy police chief. The deputy police chief shall be appointed by the police chief with the approval of the village manager. 
(b)  The rank of deputy police chief shall be an exempt rank immediately below that of police chief. The appointment shall be from any rank of sworn, full-time officers of the village's police department, provided such officer has at least five years of full-time service as a police officer within the village. 
(c)  The deputy police chief shall serve at the discretion of the police chief and may be removed by the police chief. If removed from the position of deputy police chief, the officer shall revert to the rank held immediately prior to appointment to the deputy police chief rank, regardless of whether a vacancy exists in that rank. 
(d)  A deputy police chief, having been appointed from any rank of sworn full-time officers of the village's police department, shall be permitted, regardless of rank, to take promotional exams and be promoted to a higher classified rank than he currently holds, without having to resign as deputy police chief. 
(e)  The deputy police chief shall perform those duties as required by the police chief. 
(f)  Should there be a vacancy in the office of police chief, the deputy police chief shall have the powers and shall perform the duties of police chief until such time as a new police chief is appointed and sworn into office. Should the police chief be incapacitated or otherwise unable to perform the duties of police chief, the deputy police chief shall have the powers and shall perform the duties of police chief until such time as the police chief is able to resume the performance of the duties of police chief. 
(g)  The compensation of the deputy police chief shall be set by the village manager. 
(Code 1964, § 22-4; Ord. No. 2006-47, 6-12-2006)  
Secs. 34-51—34-73. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - POLICE PERSONNEL 
 
Sec. 34-74. - General powers and duties of police officers. 
It shall be the duty of all police officers and patrolmen to aid and assist the police chief in the execution of his duties and they shall have the power and authority in the village to serve and execute warrants and other process for the apprehension and commitment of persons charged with any misdemeanor or held for examination on trial or taken in execution for the commission of any crime or misdemeanor or violation of any law or ordinance of the village. They shall perform such other duties as are now or hereafter may be required of them by the police chief, by ordinance or by rules and regulations of the police department. 
(Code 1940, § 18.006; Code 1964, § 22-5; Ord. No. 1971-27, § 1, 12-13-1971; Ord. No. 2006-47, 6-12-2006)  
Sec. 34-75. - Duties upon making arrests. 
One member of the police department shall at all times be at the police station and, whenever any person shall be arrested, it shall be the duty of the person making such arrest to cause the prisoner to be taken to the police station and the officer on duty there shall put down in the book to be kept for that purpose the name of the person arrested, his last and present residence, with street and number, the nature of the offense charged against him, the name of the complaining witness, together with the names of all witnesses on behalf of the village, and their last and present residence, with street and number, and take necessary legal measures to secure the attendance of such witnesses at time of trial. 
(Code 1940, § 18.009; Code 1964, § 22-6; Ord. No. 1971-27, § 1, 12-13-1971; Ord. No. 2006-47, 6-12-2006)  
Sec. 34-76. - Additional police protection for special events and unique circumstances. 
(a)  Any person may make application to the police chief for additional police protection for special events or other unique circumstances requiring increased security. 
(b)  After reviewing the application, the police chief shall then submit written recommendations to the village manager, both as to whether or not additional police services are required, and whether or not a charge should be made for supplying such additional police protection. 
(c)  If it is determined by the village manager that the additional police protection is required because of circumstances which are either unique or are solely for the benefit of the applicant, then the applicant shall be advised that there will be a charge for the additional police protection. The village manager shall inform the village board of his decision relative to the application for this service. 
(d)  If the applicant agrees to the payment of the charges, the police chief shall assign one or more men to said additional police protection, not to exceed 20 hours per week per man. The person, group, civic organization or other entity shall pay to the village the sum equal to the rate of two times the top patrolman's salary per man for each hour served of additional police protection. 
(e)  In the event the additional police protection results in the men serving hours in excess or their normal duty period, said officer or officers shall be paid by the village for the excess hours, less the usual deductions for payroll purposes. At no time will the officers accept wages for services directly from the applicant. 
(Code 1964, § 22-50; Ord. No. 1978-18, § A, 6-12-1978) 
State Law reference— Auxiliary police officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-20; part-time police officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-21.  
Secs. 34-77—34-92. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - PARKING DIVISION 
 
Sec. 34-93. - Parking division established. 
(a)  There is hereby established and created the parking division within the police department. Said division shall consist of such employees as the village manager may from time to time provide. 
(b)  The members of the parking division will be persons whose qualifications shall permit the performance of the duties hereinafter designated and in accordance with such requirements as may be established from time to time. 
(Code 1964, § 22-55; Ord. No. 1986-7, 1-27-1986)  
Sec. 34-94. - Parking enforcement officers; creation; appointment; powers; duties. 
(a)  There is hereby created the position of parking enforcement officers, an office of the police department. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the parking enforcement officers, under the supervision of the police chief, to maintain and regulate parking in the village, whether metered or unmetered, and to issue written parking violation notices whenever any vehicle is found to be unlawfully parked in any restricted district or in a municipal-operated parking facilities and those other assignments which may be ordered by the police chief which do not involve the power of arrest. 
(Code 1964, § 22-56; Ord. No. 1986-7, 1-27-1986)  
Sec. 34-95. - Limitations. 
The above shall not in any way be construed as granting or establishing in the parking enforcement officers the general powers or authority of a police officer, and the members of the parking division shall be strictly limited thereby to the exercise and performance of duties provided herein. 
(Code 1964, § 22-57; Ord. No. 1986-7, 1-27-1986)  
Secs. 34-96—34-111. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - AUXILIARY POLICE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Auxiliary police officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-20; part-time police officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-21. 
 
Sec. 34-112. - Appointment; qualifications. 
(a)  The village president is hereby authorized to appoint as many auxiliary police as deemed necessary, subject to the advice and consent of the board of trustees from among residents of the village or an owner or employee of a business located in the village for at least one year at the time they are accepted into membership with the village auxiliary police corps. 
(b)  All members must maintain residency or ownership of a business or remain employed by the business during training and the probationary period, after which time, with the approval of the captain of the corps and the police chief, they may be permitted to move from the village without jeopardizing their membership status with the village auxiliary police corps. Such members shall serve without pay. 
(c)  Prior to appointment, all proposed auxiliary police officer shall be fingerprinted and their fingerprints shall be checked with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Washington, D.C., for any possible criminal record. No person shall be appointed as an auxiliary police officer if that person has been convicted for a felony or other crime involving moral turpitude.

(a)  Such auxiliary police officers shall not be members of the regular police department of the village. Identification symbols worn by such auxiliary police officers shall be different and distinct from those worn by the regular police department and shall be selected and chosen by the police chief of the village. 
(b)  Auxiliary police officers shall, at all times during the performance of their duties, be subject to the direction and control of the police chief of the village.

(1)  To aid or direct traffic in the village. 
(2)  To aid in control of natural or manmade disasters. 
(3)  To aid in case of civil disorder as directed by the police chief. 
(Code 1964, § 22-37; Ord. No. 1968-38, § 2, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1971-27, §§ 2, 6, 12-13-1971; Ord. No. 2008-53, § 3(22-37), 7-14-2008)

ARTICLE III. - POLICE PENSION FUND[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Police pension fund in municipalities having a population of 500,000 or less, 40 ILCS 5-3-101 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 34-131. - Established; sources of money. 
There is hereby created a fund to be known as the police pension fund, and the following monies, derived from the following sources, shall be set apart for the police pension fund: 
(1)  Seven and one-half percent per month shall be deducted from the salary of each police officer. 
(2)  All monies that may have been accumulated by the village in conformity with the law and ordinances establishing the police pension fund. 
(3)  Any donations, gifts, or other transfers required by state law. 
(4)  All monies derived from the levy of an annual tax on all taxable property of the village as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1964, § 22-20; Ord. No. 1971-27, § 3, 12-13-1971) 
State Law reference— Financing, 40 ILCS 5/3-125.  
Sec. 34-132. - Taxation for fund; disposition of monies collected. 
(a)  There shall be levied annually, a tax upon all the taxable property of the village at the rate on the dollar which will produce an amount which, when added to the deductions from the salaries or wages of police, and receipts available from all other sources as hereinbefore referred to, will equal a sum sufficient to meet the annual requirements of the police pension fund. Said tax, when collected, shall be placed to the credit of the police pension fund heretofore created as provided by law. The annual requirements to be provided by such tax levy shall be equal to the reserve as required by state law. 
(b)  The tax shall be levied and collected in like manner with the general taxes of the village and shall be in addition to all of the taxes now or hereafter authorized to be levied upon all property within the village. 
(Code 1964, § 22-21; Ord. No. 1971-27, § 3, 12-13-1971) 
State Law reference— Financing, 40 ILCS 5/3-125.  
Secs. 34-133—34-162. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF TRUSTEES 
 
Sec. 34-163. - Established; membership. 
(a)  There is hereby created a board composed of five members, the majority of whom should be residents of the village. They shall be responsible for the administration of the pension fund and to designate the beneficiaries thereof. The board shall be known as "The Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund of Brookfield." 
(b)  Two members of the board shall be appointed by the village president for terms of two years each, of until such time as their successors are appointed and qualified. The third and fourth members of the board shall be elected from the regular police force by the active members thereof. The fifth member shall be elected by and from among the beneficiaries of the fund. 
(c)  The election provided for in this section for elected board members shall be held every two years on the third Monday in April at such places in the village and under the Australian ballot system, and such other regulations as shall be prescribed by the appointed members of the board. All members of the regular police force shall be entitled to vote only for the police force members of the board. All beneficiaries of legal age shall be entitled to vote only for the members chosen from among the beneficiaries. No person shall be entitled to cast more than one ballot at such election. 
(d)  The members shall be elected for a term of two years, beginning on the second Tuesday of the first May after such election. Upon the death, resignation or inability to act of any member of the board elected under this section, his successor shall be elected for the unexpired term at a special election to be called by the board and conducted in the same manner as the regular biennial election. 
(Code 1964, § 22-22; Ord. No. 1971-27, § 3, 12-13-1971) 
State Law reference— Municipal police pension board created, 40 ILCS 5/3-128.  
Sec. 34-164. - Governed by state law. 
The board of trustees shall be guided and governed by the provisions of 40 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq. 
(Code 1964, § 22-23; Ord. No. 1971-27, § 3, 12-13-1971)  
Sec. 34-165. - Board meetings; election of officers. 
The board shall hold regular quarterly meetings annually on the second Tuesday of July, October, January and April, and special meetings as called by the president. At the regular July meeting of the board, the board shall elect from its members a president, vice-president, secretary, and assistant secretary to serve for the period of one year, and until his respective successor is elected and qualified. 
(Code 1964, § 22-24; Ord. No. 1971-27, § 3, 12-13-1971) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 40 ILCS 5/3-130.  
Sec. 34-166. - Entitlement of benefits; retirement at 50 not compulsory. 
(a)  Any police officer who has creditable service of 20 years or more and has reached age 50 and who is no longer in the service as a police officer shall be entitled to a yearly pension equal to one-half of the salary attached to the rank he held on such police force for one year immediately prior to his retirement, payable from the police pension fund of the village, provided that the pension shall be increased by one percent of such salary for each additional year of service over 20 years to a maximum limit of 60 percent of such salary. 
(b)  Upon the death of a police officer entitled to a pension, the surviving spouse, or surviving minor children dependent because of physical or mental disability regardless of age or dependent because of age, or surviving dependent parent or parents shall be entitled to the pension to which the police officer was then entitled. 
(c)  Pensions provided for in this section shall not be paid to a widow, child or dependent parent after marriage or remarriage following the death of the police officer. 
(d)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to require the retirement at age 50 of any police officer capable of performing his duties. 
(Code 1964, § 22-25; Ord. No. 1971-27, § 3, 12-13-1971) 
State Law reference— Police officers over age 50, 40 ILCS 5/3-117.  
Secs. 34-167—34-185. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - LOST, ABANDONED AND STOLEN PROPERTY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Uniform Disposition of Unclaimed Property Act, 765 ILCS 1025/1 et seq.; funds or property held for owner by public authority, public officer or political subdivision, 765 ILCS 1025/8; property held by governments, 765 ILCS 1025/8.1. 
 
Sec. 34-186. - Custody. 
The police chief shall be the custodian of all property seized or taken by the police and of all lost, abandoned or stolen property within the village. As such custodian, he shall keep or cause to be kept, a record of all property which has been seized or otherwise taken possession of by the police force. 
(Code 1964, § 22-41; Ord. No. 1977-15, § 2, 5-23-1977)  
Sec. 34-187. - Regular sale procedure. 
(a)  The police chief shall make reasonable efforts to learn the identity of the owner of the property prior to sale. If such property shall not be claimed by the rightful owner thereof and possession surrendered to such owner within six months from the date of the final disposition of the court proceedings in connection with which such property was seized or otherwise taken possession of, or, in case there are no such court proceedings, then if such property shall not be claimed by the rightful owner thereof and possession surrendered to such owner within six months from the date of such seizure or taking by the police, the police chief shall publish or cause to be published, in a daily newspaper in the village, a description of such property together with the date of seizure or the taking possession thereof. Copies of said published notice shall also be posted in at least three public places where public notices are commonly posted. 
(b)  The notice shall state that if such property is not claimed by the rightful owner or owners thereof within ten days from the date of publication, the property will be sold at public auction at such place as the police chief may direct and in such manner as to expose to the inspection of bidders all property so offered for sale. 
(c)  No member of the police department, directly or indirectly, shall purchase or participate in the bidding for or purchase of such unclaimed property. 
(Code 1964, § 22-41; Ord. No. 1977-15, § 2, 5-23-1977)  
Sec. 34-188. - Emergency sale. 
If any property seized by or coming into the possession of the police force shall be of a perishable nature or of such a nature as to make it dangerous or inadvisable to retain possession thereof for six months, the police chief, upon certifying such fact to the board and setting forth his reasons why such property should not be retained for the period hereinabove fixed before selling the same, shall with the approval of the board, cause such property to be advertised forthwith in a daily newspaper of the village, and shall sell such property at public auction at any time after three days shall have elapsed from the seizure or taking possession thereof. 
(Code 1964, § 22-42; Ord. No. 1977-15, § 1, 5-23-1977)  
Sec. 34-189. - Disposition of sale proceeds. 
The proceeds of any sale or sales made pursuant to this article, after deducting the cost of storage, advertising, selling, and expenses incident to the handling or selling of such property, shall be deposited in the village treasury. 
(Code 1964, § 22-43; Ord. No. 1977-15, § 1, 5-23-1977)  
Sec. 34-190. - Exception; disposition of weapons. 
None of the provisions of this article shall apply to pistols, revolvers, derringers, bowie knives, dirks, slingshots, metallic knuckles, or other deadly weapons of like character. All such weapons, except those that the police chief shall deem to be of use to the department and shall retain for the use of the police department, shall, within six months after their receipt, be completely destroyed. 
(Code 1964, § 22-44; Ord. No. 1977-15, § 1, 5-23-1977)  
Secs. 34-191—34-218. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - ALARM SYSTEMS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— False alarms as disorderly conduct, 720 ILCS 5/26-1; alarm contractors, 225 ILCS 447/5-5 et seq.; tampering with a security, fire or life safety system, 720 ILCS 5/16-22. 
 
Sec. 34-219. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alarm coordinator means the police department records sergeant or any other person designated by the police chief. The alarm coordinator, under the direction of the fire or police chief, shall have responsibility and authority for enforcing the provisions of this article with respect to fire or medical alarm systems, intrusion, hold-up or other types of alarms not heretofore described. 
Alarm system means any assembly of equipment, mechanical or electrical, arranged to signal the occurrence of any illegal entry or other activity requiring urgent attention and to which police, fire or ambulance personnel are expected to respond. Individual devices such as smoke detectors which emit audible or visual signals and which are primarily designed to alert occupants of a premises of an impending fire or medical emergency shall not be considered as an alarm system and subject to the restriction set forth herein. 
Alarm user means the person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind in control of the premises or property where an alarm system is maintained. 
Automatic telephone alarm means a telephone device or telephone attachment which automatically relays a prerecorded message to report a robbery, burglary, fire or other emergency by means of a telephone line which terminates at any office or telephone registered to the village. 
Business means any individual, partnership, corporation or other entity involved in buying or selling any product or service for any fee or other consideration. The term "business," as herein defined, shall not include governmental units or religious organizations and not-for-profit corporations or not-for-profit service organizations registered as such with the state in accordance with the law. 
False alarms means any alarm system emitting a signal prompting a response by police, fire or ambulance personnel that was activated other than for an emergency situation, an unlawful act, a fire or medical problem. Severe weather, electrical outages, transmission line malfunctions, acts of God, malicious acts of persons not under the control of the alarm user or any other cause clearly beyond the control of the alarm user may be considered in determining if an alarm was false and whether or not any fee, fine, warning or punitive action should be directed to the alarm user as provided for by this article. 
Private alarm monitor agency or agency means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation or organization which contracts with an alarm user to receive and initiate action on alarm signals. 
(Code 1964, § 22-70; Ord. No. 1988-24, 6-27-1988)  
Sec. 34-220. - Registrations required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to lease, or own an alarm system, or be in control of any premises, including single-family and multifamily dwellings and business places wherein an alarm system is operated or maintained without first having obtained an alarm user registration from the village, except no registration shall be required for alarm systems contained in or on vehicles or for alarm users registered under an agency as provided herein. 
(Code 1964, § 22-71; Ord. No. 1988-24, 6-27-1988)  
Sec. 34-221. - User registration fee. 
(a)  The fee for an alarm user registration for business and residential alarms shall be in the amount provided in the village fee schedule. This fee is applicable to the original registration only. No fee is required for renewal registrations. 
(b)  Premises which utilize alarm system with multiple devices may be issued more than one alarm user registration if heat, smoke or other fire alerting devices are located in adjacent businesses or housing units which transmit signals into a shared control panel located on the combined premises, a single registration may be issued to the property owner or his agent or to a property owner association as long as such person or organization has legal control and accountability for the entire alarm system and information required under the application for registration is completed for each business entity in which a part of the alarm system is contained. 
(Code 1964, § 22-72; Ord. No. 1988-24, 6-27-1988)  
Sec. 34-222. - Application for registration. 
(a)  An application for an alarm user registration shall be filed with the village manager's office and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  Name and address of the premises where the alarm system is located. 
(3)  General description of the alarm system which classifies it as burglary, safe, hold-up, fire, medical or other and the presence of silent alarms and any audible or visual alerting signals on the premises. Any alarm system classified as other shall include a brief description as to category type. 
(4)  Any alarm system designed to transmit a signal to a monitoring service or central answering station shall include the name and telephone number of said service. 
(5)  A statement listing the name, address, and telephone number of at least one other person responsible for the premises where the alarm system is located and who should be contacted to deactivate the alarm system and respond to the premises. 
(6)  The name, address and telephone number of the person, firm, or corporation that installed the alarm system and of the person, firm or corporation responsible for any maintenance or repair of the alarm system. 
(b)  An agency may register any or all of its contracted alarm users with the village under its own name for a single fee in the amount provided in the village fee schedule, provided the agency: 
(1)  Completes a registration form as provided by the village manager. The registration form shall include the agency's name, address and telephone number as well as the agency's license number if registered under the Private Detective, Private Alarm, Private Security, Fingerprint Vendor, and Locksmith Act of 2004, 225 ILCS 447/5-5 et seq. 
(2)  Delivers once a month to the alarm coordinator a current alphabetized list of all alarm users registered under the agency's name. 
(3)  Promptly pays all fees and fines resulting from false alarms on the property or premises of an alarm user registered under the agency's name. 
(Code 1964, § 22-73; Ord. No. 1988-24, 6-27-1988; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006)  
Sec. 34-223. - Issuance of registration. 
Alarm user or agency registration within 15 days after a completed application is filed and after each application has been approved by the alarm coordinator. Following receipt and acceptance of an application, the village manager shall issue the applicant a registration number. Prior to the issuance of an alarm user registration, the alarm coordinator may cause an inspection of the alarm system if deemed necessary. 
(Code 1964, § 22-74; Ord. No. 1988-24, 6-27-1988)  
Sec. 34-224. - Term of registration. 
All registrations shall expire annually at the end of each calendar year. 
(Code 1964, § 22-75; Ord. No. 1988-24, 6-27-1988)  
Sec. 34-225. - Updating alarm user or agency registration application. 
No fee shall be charged for updating of user or agency registration applications, however it shall be unlawful for any registrant to fail or refuse to amend a registration application within ten days after any of the information required becomes outdated or inaccurate. Failure to comply with this section shall subject the alarm user or agency to a $50.00 fine, payable within 30 days of notification. 
(Code 1964, § 22-76; Ord. No. 1988-24, 6-27-1988)  
Sec. 34-226. - Alarm system deactivation requirements. 
It shall be unlawful for any alarm user to cause or permit an alarm system to sound in excess of 15 minutes without shutting off. The 15-minute period shall commence upon the arrival of responding police or fire personnel. Activation of an alarm for more than 15 minutes shall be declared a nuisance. 
(Code 1964, § 22-77; Ord. No. 1988-24, 6-27-1988)  
Sec. 34-227. - Alarm system tests. 
Tests of alarm systems may be made at reasonable times and for a reasonable duration, but only immediately after notifying the village police department. Any other tests may be deemed a false alarm. 
(Code 1964, § 22-78; Ord. No. 1988-24, 6-27-1988)  
Sec. 34-228. - Automatic telephone alarm requirements. 
(a)  No person shall install or cause to be installed or maintained any automatic telephone alarm connected to the city phone system except for medical alert alarms unless having first obtained permission from the alarm coordinator. Such permission shall include instructions as to what city telephones have been designated and will accept automatic telephone alarms. 
(b)  Any automatic telephone alarm, except those authorized by the alarm coordinator, shall be removed by the owner thereof within 90 days following the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. Automatic telephone alarms not so removed shall be subject to fine as provided herein. 
(Code 1964, § 22-79; Ord. No. 1988-24, 6-27-1988)  
Sec. 34-229. - False alarms. 
(a)  If the village police department responds to more than three false alarms within any 12-month period at the same premises, the alarm user or agency shall pay to the village, within 30 days after receiving notification of a false alarm, the amounts provided in the village fee schedule. 
(b)  If the village fire department responds to more than three false alarms in any 12-month period at the same premises, the alarm user or agency shall pay to the village for each and every false alarm in excess of the aforementioned three false alarms, within 30 days after receiving notification of same, the amount provided in the village fee schedule. 
(c)  The alarm coordinator shall notify, in writing, the alarm user or agency of each instance wherein a false alarm was recorded and in the case of the third recorded false alarm in any 12-month period shall further notify the registrant that additional false alarms will result in the imposition of charges as set forth herein. Each registrant shall have the opportunity, within ten calendar days after the receipt of such notice, to submit, in writing, a report to the alarm coordinator for the purpose of explaining the circumstances surrounding or the causes of any false alarms. 
(Code 1964, § 22-80; Ord. No. 1988-24, 6-27-1988; Ord. No. 2008-40, § 2(22-80), 4-28-2008)  
Sec. 34-230. - Alarm revocation. 
(a)  No alarm system will be allowed to transmit or in any other way connect to any alarm board or other receiving equipment located on village property or monitored by village employees unless said alarm system is registered in accordance with the provisions contained herein and said alarm system is working in a manner that is determined to be satisfactory by the alarm coordinator. 
(b)  In the event an alarm system is not registered as required by this article or is not working in a satisfactory manner as determined by the alarm coordinator or any fees payable to the village are 30 days overdue, said alarm system shall, at the direction of the alarm coordinator, be disconnected from direct monitoring at the village police department. 
(c)  If the fire or police department records indicate six or more false alarms within any 12-month period for any alarm system: 
(1)  The alarm coordinator shall notify the alarm user or agency of any such fact and direct that the user submit a report to the department within 15 days of receipt of said notice describing the actions to be taken to eliminate the cause of the false alarms. 
(2)  If the alarm user or agency submits a report as directed, the alarm coordinator shall determine whether or not the action to be taken will substantially reduce the likelihood of false alarms; if he determines that the action will substantially reduce the likelihood of false alarms, he shall notify the alarm user or agency that his registration will not be revoked, but that if more false alarms occur within any 12-month period, the user's registration may be revoked. 
(3)  If no report is submitted, or if the alarm coordinator determines that the action to be taken by the alarm user or agency will not substantially reduce the likelihood of false alarms, the alarm coordinator shall give notice to the user that the registration will be revoked if the user does not file within ten days a written request for a hearing. 
(4)  If a hearing is requested, written notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be served on the user by the alarm coordinator, at least ten days prior to the date set for the hearing, which date shall not be more than 21 days nor less than ten days after the filing of the request for the hearing. 
(5)  The hearing shall be before the alarm hearing board. The alarm user or agency shall have the right to present written and oral evidence regarding the alarm. If the hearing board determines that in fact six or more false alarms have occurred, and the alarm user or agency has failed to take action to substantially reduce the likelihood of false alarms, the hearing board shall issue written findings to that effect and an order revoking the alarm user's or agency's registration. 
(6)  An alarm user or agency whose registration has been revoked may apply for a revoked user's registration subject to the term thereof. The alarm coordinator may impose reasonable restrictions and conditions upon the alarm user or agency before issuing a revoked user's registration, which restrictions and conditions shall be written on the registration. 
(7)  The false alarm hearing board shall be made up of three residents of the village, of a majority age, appointed by the village president, to serve at his pleasure for an indefinite term. 
(Code 1964, § 22-81; Ord. No. 1988-24, 6-27-1988)  
Sec. 34-231. - Authority of false alarm hearing board. 
The false alarm hearing board is hereby authorized to recommend to the village board the following orders or sanctions: 
(1)  Deny the revocation request of the alarm coordinator; 
(2)  Enter an order revoking the alarm user registration; or 
(3)  Place the registrant on a period of probation for a designated period of time deemed appropriate. 
(Code 1964, § 22-82; Ord. No. 1988-24, 6-27-1988)  
Sec. 34-232. - Grace period for false alarms. 
Whenever a new alarm system is installed, the alarm user shall be given 30 days from the date of the installation before alarms from the premises shall be deemed to be false alarms. 
(Code 1964, § 22-83; Ord. No. 1988-24, 6-27-1988)  
Chapter 36 - OFFENSES AND NUISANCES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Criminal Code of 2012 720 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.; municipal powers as to police ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-1; municipal authority to conduct programs and coordinate activities for the prevention, reduction or control of juvenile delinquency, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-8; municipal authority to pass and enforce necessary police ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-1; municipal authority to suppress bawdy houses, disorderly houses, and houses of ill-fame, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-1; municipal authority to abate nuisances, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2; municipal powers as to police ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-1; Lewdness Public Nuisance Act, 740 ILCS 105.0.01 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 36-1. - Penalties. 
Unless a different penalty is specifically provided in this chapter or required by state law, penalties for violations of this chapter shall be as provided in section 1-12.  
Secs. 36-2—36-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PERSONS 
 
Sec. 36-21. - Assault. 
It shall be unlawful for a person to commit assault within the village. A person commits an assault when, without lawful authority, he engages in conduct which places another in reasonable apprehension of receiving a battery. 
(Code 1940, § 27.007; Code 1964, § 17-7; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1981-38, 9-28-1981) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, 720 ILCS 5/12-1.  
Secs. 36-22—36-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Damage and trespass to property, 720 ILCS 5/21-1 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 36-46. - Spitting on streets, sidewalks and other public places. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to expectorate in or on any street sidewalk, depot platform, or on the floor or wall of any public railway car, hall or other public building. 
(Code 1940, § 26.001(20); Code 1964, § 14-5)  
Sec. 36-47. - Criminal damage to property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Damage the property of another without his consent; 
(2)  Damage the property of another by means of fire or explosive; 
(3)  Start a fire on the land of another without his consent; 
(4)  Injure a domestic animal of another without his consent; 
(5)  Deposit on the land or in the building of another without his consent, any stink bomb or offensive smelling compound and thereby intend to interfere with the use by another of the land or building; 
(6)  Damage the property of another without his consent by defacing, deforming or otherwise damaging such property by the use of paint or any other similar substance; or 
(7)  Cut, injure, damage, tamper with or destroy or deface any fire hydrant or any fire hose or any fire engine or other public or private firefighting equipment or any apparatus pertaining to such equipment or intentionally open any fire hydrant without proper authorization. 
(b)  Any person violating this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00 or more than $750.00. 
(Code 1964, § 17-51; Ord. No. 1981-39, 9-28-1981) 
State Law reference— Similar property, 720 ILCS 5/21-1.  
Sec. 36-48. - Trespass. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation or other organization to commit a trespass within the village upon private property. A trespass shall be committed by any person, firm, corporation or other organization by entering upon the land or any part thereof of another after receiving, immediately prior to such entry, notice from the owner or occupant that such entry is forbidden. A trespass shall also be committed by any person, firm or corporation who shall remain upon the land of another after receiving notice from the owner or occupant to depart. A person, firm or corporation shall have received notice from this section: 
(1)  If he has been notified personally, either orally or in writing, to leave the premises; or 
(2)  If a printed or written notice forbidding such entry has been posted or exhibited at any entrance to such land or the forbidden part thereof. 
(Code 1964, § 17-31; Ord. No. 1979-8, § A, 3-12-1979; Ord. No. 1981-11, 03-23-1981) 
State Law reference— Criminal trespass to real property, 720 ILCS 5/21-3.  
Sec. 36-49. - Sod, gravel, sand, earth; removal without owner's consent. 
No person shall dig, cut or remove any sod, gravel, sand or earth from any premises not his own without the consent of the owner thereof. 
(Code 1940, § 27.019; Code 1964, § 17-23; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2)  
Sec. 36-50. - Littering. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, cause or allow to be thrown or dispose of in any manner any litter, garbage, cigarette butts, waste, rubbish, ashes, cans, bottles, paper, cartons, boxes, debris, glass or other discarded items on any public property or along or near any public sidewalk, way, parkway, road, street, alley, drive, gutter or on any public or private land adjoining any public road, except in an authorized litter receptacle maintained on public property for that purpose. 
(b)  The owner or person in control of any private premises shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter. The owner or person in control of any private premises shall maintain litter receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place or private premises. 
(Ord. No. 2008-93A, § 4(07-37), 12-8-2008; Ord. No. 2008-93B, § 5(07-37), 12-8-2008)  
Secs. 36-51—36-73. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DAMAGE TO VILLAGE PROPERTY 
 
Sec. 36-74. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Damage to village property means any harm or destruction to any village property, whether partial or total, regardless of the manner in which the damage occurred. 
Legal guardian means a person appointed guardian, or given custody, of a minor by a circuit court of the state, but does not include a person appointed guardian, or given custody, of a minor under the Juvenile Court Act of 1987, 705 ILCS 405/1-1 et seq. 
Minor means a person who was not yet 18 years of age at the time any offense was committed. 
Responsible party means the person who caused the damage, which shall be determined without consideration of contributing or intervening factors or actions of another. 
Village property means and includes all property owned by the village, including, but not limited to, traffic-control devices; street lights and street light poles; fire hydrants; median dividers and median strips, with or without vegetation, and median planters; parkways, with or without vegetation; sidewalks, streets and curbs; fences and gates; signs; municipal vehicles; municipal buildings and appurtenances thereto; and municipal equipment. 
(Ord. No. 2009-004, § 2(17-47A), 1-26-2009; Ord. No. 2012-39, § 2(17-47A), 6-11-2012; Ord. No. 2016-56 , § 2, 11-14-2016)  
Sec. 36-75. - Policy, purpose and intent. 
(a)  It shall be the policy of the village to seek all funds related to the repair or replacement of village property that results from damage to village property, including the village's deductible from its insurance carrier. In addition to recouping the actual costs of the damage to village property, the village shall add the administrative fees provided in this division. 
(b)  In all events where there is damage to village property and a department of public works and services employee is called out to the scene to assess damage, there shall be an accounting of time spent, and a charge assessed for such time as determined by the village's department of public works. 
(Ord. No. 2009-004, § 2(17-47C), 1-26-2009; Ord. No. 2012-39, § 2(17-47C), 6-11-2012)  
Sec. 36-76. - Damage to village property prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause damage to village property. 
(Ord. No. 2009-004, § 2(17-47B), 1-26-2009; Ord. No. 2012-39, § 2(17-47B), 6-11-2012)  
Sec. 36-77. - Responsible party's payment for repair or replacement. 
(a)  The responsible party shall reimburse the village for the cost to repair or replace any village property damaged by the responsible party, including any deductible under any applicable village insurance policy. In addition, the responsible party shall reimburse the village for all labor costs or time costs associated with responding to or investigating incidents of damage to village property. 
(b)  The village shall give written notice to the responsible party of the total cost, suitably itemized, to repair or replace the damaged village property. 
(c)  The responsible party shall remit payment in full to the village not later than 30 days after the notice. Payment shall be in the form of cash, insurance company check, certified check, cashier's check, insured check, money order or approved credit card. 
(d)  If payment is not received by the village within 30 days of the written notice to the responsible party, the village may use any lawful means to secure payment in full, including any attorney or collection agency to secure payment. In the event that the village undertakes an action to collect payment from the responsible party, the costs of collection shall be added to the total cost of repair or replacement and shall be charged to the responsible party. 
(e)  The cost to repair or replace damaged village property shall be in addition to any fine that may be imposed under any applicable ordinance prohibiting damage to village property. 
(Ord. No. 2009-004, § 2(17-47D), 1-26-2009; Ord. No. 2012-39, § 2(17-47D), 6-11-2012)  
Sec. 36-78. - Parental responsibility for damages. 
A parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor who resides with such parent or legal guardian is liable to the village for the cost to repair or replace any village property damaged by a responsible party who is a minor, and for reasonable attorney's fees in an amount that shall not exceed $15,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 2009-004, § 2(17-47E), 1-26-2009; Ord. No. 2012-39, § 2(17-47E), 6-11-2012) 
State Law reference— Criminal damage to property, 720 ILCS 5/21-1; criminal defacement of property, 720 ILCS 5/21-1.3.  
Secs. 36-79—36-99. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - GRAFFITI[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of municipalities to removal and recover costs of removal from owner, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-13. 
 
Sec. 36-100. - Defacing buildings generally. 
No person shall cut, injure, mark or deface any building not his own. Any person violating this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00 or more than $750.00. 
(Code 1940, § 27.016; Code 1964, § 17-42; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 3, 4) 
State Law reference— Criminal damage to property, 720 ILCS 5/21-1; criminal defacement of property, 720 ILCS 5/21-1.3.  
Sec. 36-101. - Types of prohibited depictions. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to inscribe, draw or otherwise place upon the surface of any structure or wall that is publicly or privately owned, any word, phrase, diagram, symbol, sketch, or letters wherein the contents thereof are visible to any member of the general public and contains references to sexual activity, diagrams relating to sexual activity or sexual organs, references to gangs or criminal activities, or groups which promote or are involved in criminal activity, swearing or fighting words, defamatory materials about any person, or references to personal relationships. 
(b)  The above list is not to be considered a limitation, but is merely illustrative of items known as graffiti. It shall be an affirmative defense to the alleged violation of the foregoing provision if such activity was undertaken with the prior written consent of the owner or persons in charge or control of the property, demonstrating that the owner or person in charge or control was aware of the content and method of the inscription to be placed on the structure or wall.
