(Code 1964, § 17-42.01(1); Ord. No. 93-29, 7-26-1993; Ord. No. 2001-35, 7-24-2001)  
Sec. 36-102. - Responsibility for removal. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the owner or person in charge or control of the structure or wall upon which any inscription or representation prohibited in this division to remove, eradicate or eliminate such inscription or representation within seven days from the date of the offense. 
(b)  In the event the owner or person in charge or control has failed to eliminate such graffiti, that person shall be notified via certified mail or personal notice that he has an additional 14 days to remove such graffiti. 
(c)  In the event that the owner, person in charge or control, can show to the village manager that there is a reasonable likelihood that the person responsible for placement of the graffiti will be required to make restitution or restore the premises to its previous condition, the owner may be given additional time, not to exceed 30 days, to meet the removal requirements without issuance of a citation. 
(Code 1964, § 17-42.01(1); Ord. No. 93-29, 7-26-1993; Ord. No. 2001-35, 7-24-2001) 
State Law reference— Authority of municipalities to removal and recover costs of removal from owner, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-13.  
Sec. 36-103. - Compensation and restitution. 
The owner of the property shall be entitled to restitution and compensation for the direct costs incurred in the repair or restoration of the property to its previous condition from any person found guilty of the offense listed in this division. The property owner shall submit receipts evidencing payments for the direct costs incurred in the removal of the graffiti and providing further that the court enters an order of restitution. 
(Code 1964, § 17-42.01(3); Ord. No. 93-29, 7-26-1993; Ord. No. 2001-35, 7-24-2001) 
State Law reference— Authority of municipalities to removal and recover costs of removal from owner, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-13.  
Sec. 36-104. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person violating this division shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00 or more than $750.00. 
(b)  Additionally, any court or adjudicator may, as a condition of probation, supervision, or conditional discharge, require that full and complete restitution be made to the owner of the property for expenses incurred in the removal of the graffiti or restoration of the structure or wall to its previous condition. 
(c)  In addition, the court or adjudicator may impose a penalty of mandatory community service of no less than ten hours nor more than 750 hours. 
(Code 1964, § 17-42.01(4); Ord. No. 93-29, 7-26-1993; Ord. No. 2001-35, 7-24-2001)  
Secs. 36-105—36-121. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC ORDER 
 
Sec. 36-122. - Disorderly conduct generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit disorderly conduct in the village. A person commits disorderly conduct when he knowingly: 
(1)  Does any act in such an unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb another and to provoke a breach of the peace; 
(2)  With intent to alarm another, makes a telephone call, whether or not conversation thereby ensues; 
(3)  Transmits in any manner to the fire department, a false alarm of fire, knowing at the time of such transmission that there was no reasonable ground for believing that such fire existed; 
(4)  Transmits in any manner to another a false alarm to the effect that a bomb or other explosive of any nature is concealed in any place and that its explosion would endanger human life, knowing at the time of such transmission that there was no reasonable ground for believing that such bomb or explosive was concealed in such place; 
(5)  Transmits in any manner to any police officer, public officer or public employee a report to the effect that an offense has been committed, knowing at the time of such transmission that there was no reasonable ground for believing that such an offense had been committed; 
(6)  Enters upon the property of another for a lewd or unlawful purpose and deliberately looks into a dwelling on the property through any window or other opening on it. For purposes of this subsection, the term "lewd purpose" shall be defined as intended for the sexual gratification or arousal of the accused; 
(7)  Does any act in a violent, tumultuous or alarming manner toward another such that it endangers the other person's health, limb or life; 
(8)  Acts in a violent, tumultuous or alarming manner toward another whereby public property or the private property of another is placed in danger of being damaged or destroyed; 
(9)  Endangers or interferes with the lawful pursuits of another by threats or acts of violence to that person; 
(10)  Causes, provokes or engages in any fight, brawl or riotous conduct so as to endanger the health or safety of another, or endanger the property of another; 
(11)  Utters "fighting words" directed at any other person resulting in that other person becoming alarmed. The term "fighting words" is defined as those words which by their very utterance inflict injury or tend to incite an immediate breach of the peace; or 
(12)  Congregates with one or more persons on any public place and in such a manner as to impede the free flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
(Code 1940, § 27.008; Code 1964, § 17-11; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1994-47, 11-28-1994) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 5/26-1.  
Sec. 36-123. - Fortunetelling, spiritualism, and related practices. 
(a)  Any person who shall obtain any money or property from another in the name of, or by means of, spirit medium-ship, palmistry, card reading, astrology, seership or like crafty science, or fortunetelling of any kind shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  It shall also be unlawful for any person to hold or give any public or private meeting, gathering, circle or seance of any kind in the name of spiritualism or of any other religious body, society or denomination, and therein practice or permit to be practiced fraud or deception of any kind. 
(Code 1940, § 27.021; Code 1964, § 17-13; Ord. of 11-9-1964, § 1; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2)  
Sec. 36-124. - Disturbing lawful assemblies. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any congregation or assembly met for worship or any other lawful purpose, by making noise or by rude and indecent behavior or profane language within the place of such assembly or so near the same as to disturb the order of the meeting. 
(Code 1940, § 27.003; Code 1964, § 17-43; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 3, 4; Ord. No. 2009-50, § 2, 9-28-2009) 
State Law reference— Disorderly conduct, 720 ILCS 5/26-1; Illinois Public Demonstrations Law, 430 ILCS 70/1 et seq.  
Sec. 36-125. - Disorderly acts of intoxicated persons. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subsection, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Intoxicated person means a person who is physically or mentally impaired to any material degree as a result of the presence of alcoholic liquor, drugs or other substances, or any combination thereof, in the person's body. Evidence of an intoxicated person shall include, but not be limited to, a combination of the following indicators: 
(1)  Odor of an alcoholic beverage on the person's breath. 
(2)  Odor or physical evidence of drugs or controlled substance about one's person. 
(3)  Bloodshot or glassy eyes. 
(4)  Dilated pupils. 
(5)  Unaware of one's presence or location. 
(6)  Stumbling, staggering, unsteady gait or needing assistance in standing or walking. 
(7)  Slurred speech. 
(8)  Portable breath test reading (P.B.T.) in excess of 0.08. 
(9)  Failure of a standardized field sobriety test. 
(10)  Chemical tests of blood, breath or urine for the purpose of determining the content of alcohol, other drugs or intoxicating compounds of any combination thereof in the person's blood. 
Public place means any building or place owned, operated, controlled or maintained by the village, including any public street, public sidewalk, alley, walkway or any other publicly owned, controlled, operated or maintained lands. 
(b)  A person commits the offense of disorderly act by an intoxicated person when he knowingly appears or remains in or upon any public place in the village in an intoxicated state and: 
(1)  Does any act in such an unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb another and to provoke a breach of the peace; 
(2)  Blocks, hinders or impedes pedestrian or vehicular traffic without just cause; 
(3)  Refuses to leave the immediate area upon lawful order of a person known to him or her to be a peace officer; 
(4)  Causes, provokes or engages in any fight, brawl or riotous conduct so as to endanger the health or safety of another, or endanger the property of another; 
(5)  Fails to obey a lawful order to disperse or cease and desist given by a person known to him to be a peace officer; 
(6)  Interferes with a peace officer conducting an investigation or otherwise interferes with a peace officer while in the performance of the officer's duties; 
(7)  Acts in a violent, tumultuous or alarming manner toward another whereby public property or the private property of another is placed in danger of being damaged or destroyed; or 
(8)  Does any act in a violent, tumultuous or alarming manner toward another such that it endangers the other person's health, limb or life. 
(Code 1940, § 27.006; Code 1964, § 17-44; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 3, 4; Ord. No. 2009-50, § 1, 9-28-2009)  
Sec. 36-126. - Loitering in public places. 
No person shall obstruct or encumber any street corner, railroad depot or platform or other public place in the village by lounging or loafing in or about the same after being requested to move on by any police officer. Any person violating this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00 or more than $750.00. 
(Code 1940, §§ 27.001, 27.018; Code 1964, § 17-45; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 3, 4) 
State Law reference— Loitering near parks and schools, 720 ILCS 5/11-9.4; unlawful assembly, 20 ILCS 1815/40.  
Sec. 36-127. - Stones or other objects; throwing unlawful. 
No person shall throw or cast any stone or other object upon or at any building, railroad car, tree or other public or private property or upon or at any person in any street, avenue, alley, lane, public place, or at enclosed or unenclosed ground in the village. Any person violating this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00 or more than $750.00. 
(Code 1940, § 27.017; Code 1964, § 17-48; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 3, 4) 
State Law reference— Disorderly conduct, 720 ILCS 5/26-1.  
Sec. 36-128. - Threats. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use any threatening language towards any other person tending to a breach of the peace. Any person violating this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00 or more than $750.00. 
(Code 1940, § 27.009; Code 1964, § 17-49; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 3, 4) 
State Law reference— Disorderly conduct, 720 ILCS 5/26-1.  
Sec. 36-129. - Unlawful assemblies. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to assemble, congregate or collect in bodies, crowds, groups of three or more for unlawful purposes, or for any purpose which causes a breach of the peace within the limits of the village. 
(b)  It shall further be unlawful for any person in a group of three or more to congregate, loiter, linger, stand together or near to each other on any sidewalk, street, alley, public parking lot, public park or public passageway or in front of, about or upon any stairway, doorway or window of any church theater, auditorium, school, hall or other public buildings so as to obstruct, block, impede or interfere with free passage of persons on or upon said public sidewalks, streets and way or as to obstruct, impede or interfere with free passage of persons entering or occupying any such public building or premises or any premises fronting upon any public sidewalk, street or way, when requested to immediately disperse and move by any police officer. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for two or more persons, acting together, to disturb the public peace by the use of force or violence without authority of law; or for two or more persons to assemble for the purpose of committing an unlawful act. 
(d)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be fined in an amount not less than $25.00 or more than $500.00. 
(Code 1964, § 17-36; Ord. No. 94-19, 3-28-1994) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 20 ILCS 1815/40.  
Sec. 36-130. - Impersonating or interfering with village officers or employees. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to impersonate, without lawful authority, any officer or employee of the village. It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to interfere with or hinder any officer or employee of the village while engaged in the duties of his office. 
(Code 1940, §§ 10.011, 10.012; Code 1964, § 17-16; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2) 
State Law reference— False personation of attorney, judicial or government officials, 720 ILCS 5/32-5.  
Sec. 36-131. - Trains; playing upon or about prohibited. 
No person shall play upon or about any railroad locomotive, engine, tender, car, or train of cars, or any platform or steps thereof, while the same or any or either of them are in motion. 
(Code 1940, § 27.014; Code 1964, § 17-28; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2)  
Secs. 36-132—36-160. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC DECENCY AND MORALS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 36-161. - Disorderly houses. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep a disorderly house within the village. A person keeps a disorderly house when he knowingly: 
(1)  Keeps or maintains any bawdy or disorderly house such that the health or safety of the community is endangered; 
(2)  Keeps or maintains any house or other place where any person is permitted or tolerated to make any loud or raucous noise; 
(3)  Permits or tolerates any minor to use dice, dominoes, cards, balls or other articles for the purpose of gambling; or 
(4)  Keeps or maintains any house or other place where any person under the age of 21 years is permitted to consume any alcoholic beverage. 
(b)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, it shall not be a violation of this section where the permitted consumption of alcohol by a person under the age of 21 is under the direct supervision and approval of the parents or guardians of such under age person in the privacy of the parents' or guardians' home, or is in the performance of a religious service or ceremony. 
(Code 1940, § 27. 026; Code 1964, § 17-12; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 95-2, 1-23-1995) 
State Law reference— Prostitution, 720 ILCS 5/11-14; municipal authority to suppress bawdy houses, disorderly houses, and houses of ill-fame, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-1.  
Sec. 36-162. - Houses of ill fame. 
No person shall keep or maintain, or be an inmate of or in any way be connected with, or in any way contribute to the support of any house of ill fame or assignation or other place where persons resort for the purpose of prostitution. Every person found in a house of ill fame or assignation shall be considered an "inmate" within the meaning of this section. 
(Code 1940, §§ 26.001(14), 27.015; Code 1964, § 17-15; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2) 
State Law reference— Prostitution, 720 ILCS 5/11-14; municipal authority to suppress bawdy houses, disorderly houses, and houses of ill-fame, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-1.  
Sec. 36-163. - Indecent exposure, dress or acts. 
If any person shall appear in a public place in a state of nudity, or in a dress not belonging to his sex or in an indecent or lewd dress, or perform any indecent, lewd or filthy act of behavior, or utter any lewd or indecent words, or make any obscene gesture, or perform any indecent, immoral or lewd play or representation, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1940, §§ 27.005, 27.009; Code 1964, § 17-17; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2) 
State Law reference— Public indecency, 720 ILCS 5/11-30.  
Sec. 36-164. - Public urination or defecation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to urinate or defecate upon any sidewalk, street, alley, public parking lot, park, playground or other public area or upon any private property in open view of the public outside of any designated sanitary facilities designed to be used for such purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2008-93A, § 5(17-38), 12-8-2008; Ord. No. 2008-93B, § 5(07-37), 12-8-2008)  
Secs. 36-165—36-181. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - OBSCENITY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of municipalities to prohibit obscene publications, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-1; public indecency, 720 ILCS 5/11-30. 
 
Sec. 36-182. - Prohibited conduct. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to commit obscenity within the village. A person commits obscenity when, with knowledge of the nature or content thereof, or recklessly failing to exercise reasonable inspection which would have disclosed the nature or content thereof, he: 
(1)  Sells, delivers or provides, or offers or agrees to sell, deliver or provide, any obscene writing, picture, record or other representation or embodiment of the obscene; 
(2)  Presents or directs an obscene play, dance or other performance or participates directly in that portion thereof which makes it obscene; 
(3)  Publishes, exhibits or otherwise makes available anything obscene; 
(4)  Performs an obscene act or otherwise presents an obscene exhibition of his body for gain; 
(5)  Creates, buys, procures or possesses obscene matter or material with intent to disseminate it in violation of this section, or of the penal laws or regulations of any other jurisdiction; or 
(6)  Advertises or otherwise promotes the sale of material represented or held out by him to be obscene, whether or not it is obscene. 
(b)  A thing is obscene if, considered as a whole, its predominant appeal is to prurient interest, that is, a shameful or morbid interest in nudity, sex, or excretion, and if it goes substantially beyond customary limits of candor or in description or representation of such matters. A thing is obscene even though the obscenity is latent, as in the case of undeveloped photographs. 
(c)  Obscenity shall be judged with reference to ordinary adults, except that it shall be judged with reference to children or other specially susceptible audiences if it appears from the character of the material or the circumstances of its dissemination to be specially designed for or directed to such an audience. 
(d)  Where circumstances of production, presentation, sale, dissemination, distribution, or publicity indicate that material is being commercially exploited for the sake of its prurient appeal, such evidence is probative with respect to the nature of the matter and can justify the conclusion that the matter is utterly without redeeming social importance. 
(Code 1940, § 27.010; Code 1964, § 17-19; Ord. of 11-28-1960, § 1; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1981-23, 6-8-1981)  
Sec. 36-183. - Evidence admissible at prosecution. 
In any prosecution for an offense under this division, evidence shall be admissible to show: 
(1)  The character of the audience for which the material was designed or to which it was directed. 
(2)  What the predominant appeal of the material would be for ordinary adults or a special audience, and what effect, if any, it would probably have on the behavior of such people. 
(3)  The artistic, literary, scientific, educational or other merits of the material, or absence thereof. 
(4)  The degree, if any, of public acceptance of the material in this state. 
(5)  Appeal to prurient interest, or absence thereof, in advertising or other promotion of the material. 
(6)  Purpose of the author, creator, publisher or disseminator. 
(Code 1940, § 27.010; Code 1964, § 17-19; Ord. of 11-28-1960, § 1; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1981-23, 6-8-1981)  
Secs. 36-184—36-204. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - GAMBLING[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Gaming generally, 230 ILCS 5/1 et seq.; gambling, 720 ILCS 5/28-1. 
 
Sec. 36-205. - Gambling prohibited. 
(a)  Except for video gaming terminals licensed by the state gaming board and the village, as defined in section 6-201 of this Code, it shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or to permit any gaming, gambling or other games of chance within any store or public place in the village or to conduct or to permit any person to play for money or any other article of value with cards, dice, checks, tickets or books which may be used for winning or losing money, or any other article or thing of value within any store or public place in the village. 
(b)  The establishment of an inter-track wagering location is prohibited within that area over which the village board possess zoning authority. Pursuant to state law, no state license may, therefore, be issued to conduct inter-track wagering within the zoning jurisdiction of the village. 
(Code 1940, § 27.033; Code 1964, § 17-14; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2; Ord. 1990-17, 3-12-1990; Ord. No. 2012-28, § 8(17-14), 4-23-2012) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, 720 ILCS 5/28-1.  
Sec. 36-206. - Pinball, bagatelle, pigeonhole. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or use in any place of public resort within the village, any tables or implements for any game of bagatelle or pigeonhole. 
(b)  The term, "bagatelle or pigeonhole," as used in this section, shall mean a game played with any number of balls or spheres upon a table or board having holes, pockets or cups into which such balls or spheres may drop or become lodged and having arches, pins, and springs, or any of them, to control, deflect, or impede the direction or speed of the balls or spheres put in motion by the player, and shall include the modern variety of bagatelle or pigeonhole commonly known as pin games. 
(c)  The term "place of public resort," as used in this section, shall mean any premises wherein any service or merchandise is offered for sale to the public or where tables or implements for playing the game of bagatelle or pigeonhole are kept for gain or profit, or any premises used as a clubhouse or clubrooms. 
(d)  It is hereby made the duty of every police officer to seize any table or implement kept or used in violation of this section and, upon conviction of the keeper thereof, such table or implement so seized shall be destroyed. 
(Code 1964, § 17-22; Ord. of 2-14-1966; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 97-12, 3-24-1997) 
State Law reference— Gambling, 720 ILCS 5/28-1.  
Sec. 36-207. - Off-track betting messenger services prohibited. 
No person or corporations located within the corporate limits of the village may solicit, for the purpose of taking wagers, or directions on how to make any specific wager at a legal horse racing track. All persons in the village are specifically prohibited from going to any horse racing track, and there placing a wager for the purpose of making a fee by acting as the messenger or agent of an absentee bettor. 
(Code 1964, § 17-30; Ord. No. 1976-26, § 1, 10-25-1976) 
State Law reference— Syndicated gambling (bookmaking), 720 ILCS 5/-28-1.1.  
Secs. 36-208—36-237. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - OFFENSES INVOLVING MINORS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 36-238. - Junk and secondhand dealer purchase or receipt from minors prohibited. 
No junk or secondhand dealer shall purchase or receive from minors, without the written consent of their parents or guardians, any article of property whatever. 
(Code 1940, § 25.273; Code 1964, § 17-18; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2) 
State Law reference— Unlawful for junk dealer, pawnbroker or secondhand dealer to purchase from minor, 720 ILCS 345/1.  
Secs. 36-239—36-269. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PAINTS AND MARKERS 
 
Sec. 36-270. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Marker means any implement or other device containing a nonwater soluble fluid and having a point, brush, applicator or other writing surface that is three-eighths of an inch or greater. 
Spray paint means any aerosol-propelled paint or any other method or device used or designated to expel or propel paint by means of compressed gas or pressurization. 
(Code 1964, § 17-52(a); Ord. No. 95-18, 5-22-1995)  
Sec. 36-271. - Possession prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to possess spray paint or markers within the passenger area of any motor vehicle within the village. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to a person under the age of 18 years in the company of a parent or legal guardian or a person under the age of 18 years discharging the duties of his employment, provided that the records required in this division are maintained as required. 
(Code 1964, §§ 17-52(b), (c); Ord. No. 95-18, 5-22-1995)  
Sec. 36-272. - Sale to minors prohibited; identification required. 
It shall be unlawful for any business, employee or agent of a business that offers spray paint or markers for sale at the retail level to sell, give or otherwise deliver spray paint or markers to any person under the age of 18 years unless said minor has first produced a form of pictured identification, such as, but not limited to, a driver's license or a state or school identification card. 
(Code 1964, § 17-52(d); Ord. No. 95-18, 5-22-1995)  
Sec. 36-273. - Records required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any business engaged in the retail sale of spray paint or markers to sell spray paint or markers to any person under the age of 18 years pursuant to any exception provided in this division, unless that business maintains a log book and records the following information in the log book for each retail sale of spray paint or markers to a person of the age of 18 years: 
(1)  The name and address of the person under the age of 18 years purchasing or otherwise receiving the spray paint or markers; 
(2)  The date of purchase; and 
(3)  The brand name, type, color and quantity of spray paint or markers sold or delivered to said minor. 
(b)  The log book shall be made available for inspection by the police chief or other officer acting at the direction of the police chief. 
(c)  Any person or business violating the provisions of this division shall be fined in an amount not less than $25.00 or more than $500.00 for each offense. 
(Code 1964, § 17-52(e—g); Ord. No. 95-18, 5-22-1995)  
Secs. 36-274—36-294. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - TOBACCO PRODUCTS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Display of Tobacco Products Act, 720 ILCS 677/1 et seq.; Prevention of Tobacco Use by Minors and Sale and Distribution of Tobacco Products Act, 720 ILCS 675/0.01 et seq. 
 
Sec. 36-295. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alternative nicotine product means a product or device not consisting of or containing tobacco that provides for the ingestion into the body of nicotine, whether by chewing, smoking, absorbing, dissolving, inhaling, snorting, sniffing, or by any other means and includes, but is not limited to, e-cigarettes. Alternative nicotine product excludes cigarettes, smokeless tobacco, or other tobacco products as these terms are defined in Section 1 of the Prevention of Tobacco Use by Minors and Sale and Distribution of Tobacco Products Act (720 ILCS 675/1 et seq.) and any product approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration as a non-tobacco product for sale as a tobacco cessation product, as a tobacco dependence product, or for other medical purposes, and is being marketed and sold solely for that approved purpose. 
E-cigarette means a device, usually battery-powered, that heats nicotine, releasing a nicotine vapor that can be inhaled by the user of the device. Not by way of limitation, the term "e-cigarette" includes e-cigar, e-cigarillo, e-pipe, e-hookah, or any other device that heats nicotine, releasing a nicotine vapor that can be inhaled by the user of the device. 
Tobacco products means any substance containing tobacco leaf, including, but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, chewing tobacco or dipping tobacco. 
Vending machine means any mechanical, electrical or electronic self-service device that, upon the insertion of money, tokens or other forms of payment, dispenses tobacco products. 
(Code 1940, § 25.158; Code 1964, § 17-27(A); Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 93-59, 11-22-1993; Ord. No. 2014-43, § 2 , 7-14-2014)  
Sec. 36-296. - Prohibited sales and deliveries. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, including any licensee or agent or employee of a licensee, to sell, offer for sale, give away or deliver any tobacco products or alternative nicotine products including, but not limited to, e-cigarettes to any person under the age of 18 years. 
(Code 1940, § 25.158; Code 1964, § 17-27(B); Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 93-59, 11-22-1993; Ord. No. 2014-43, § 3 , 7-14-2014) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, 720 ILCS 675/1.  
Sec. 36-297. - Signs required. 
(a)  Signs informing the public of the age restrictions provided herein shall be posted by every licensee at or near every display of tobacco products and on or upon every vending machine that offers tobacco products for sale. Each such sign shall be plainly visible and shall state: 
"THE SALE, OFFERING FOR SALE, GIVING OR DELIVERING OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS OR ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCTS INCLUDING E-CIGARETTES TO PERSONS UNDER 18 YEARS OF AGE IS PROHIBITED BY LAW." 
(b)  The text of such signs shall be in red letters on a white background; said letters to be at least two inches high. 
(Code 1940, § 25.158; Code 1964, § 17-27(C); Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 93-59, 11-22-1993; Ord. No. 2014-43, § 4 , 7-14-2014)  
Sec. 36-298. - Purchase by minors prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to purchase or acquire by other means tobacco products or alternative nicotine products including, but not limited to, e-cigarettes, or to misrepresent his or her identity or age, or to use any false or altered identification for the purpose of purchasing or otherwise securing tobacco products or alternative nicotine products including, but not limited to, e-cigarettes. 
(Code 1940, § 25.158; Code 1964, § 17-27(D); Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 93-59, 11-22-1993; Ord. No. 2014-43, § 5 , 7-14-2014)  
Sec. 36-299. - Possession by minors prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to possess any tobacco products or alternative nicotine products including, but not limited to, e-cigarettes. The possession of tobacco products or alternative nicotine products including, but not limited to, e-cigarettes by a person under the age of 18 years under the direct supervision of the parent or guardian of such person in the privacy of the parent's or guardian's home shall not be prohibited 
(Code 1940, § 25.158; Code 1964, § 17-27(E); Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 93-59, 11-22-1993; Ord. No. 2014-43, § 6 , 7-14-2014)  
Sec. 36-300. - Certain free distributions prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any person in the business of selling or otherwise distributing, promoting or advertising tobacco products or alternative nicotine products including, but not limited to, e-cigarettes, or any employee or agent of any such licensee or person, in the course of that licensee's or person's business, to distribute, give away or deliver tobacco products or alternative nicotine products including, but not limited to, e-cigarettes free of charge to any person on any right-of-way, park, playground or other property owned by the village, any school district, any park district or any public library within the village. 
(Code 1940, § 25.158; Code 1964, § 17-27(F); Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 93-59, 11-22-1993; Ord. No. 2014-43, § 7 , 7-14-2014)  
Sec. 36-301. - Responsibility for agents and employees. 
Every act or omission of whatsoever nature, constituting a violation of any of the provisions of this division by any officer, director, manager or other agent or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act of such licensee; and such licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if such act or omission had been done or omitted by the licensee personally. 
(Code 1940, § 25.158; Code 1964, § 17-27(G); Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 93-59, 11-22-1993)  
Sec. 36-302. - Administration and enforcement; penalties. 
(a)  The village president shall be charged with the administration of this division. The village president may suspend or revoke any license issued under the provisions of this division if he determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of this division. Each day on which a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation. 
(b)  In lieu of suspension or revocation of a license, the village president may instead levy a fine on the licensee. The fine imposed shall not exceed $500.00 for each violation. 
(c)  However, no such license shall be suspended or revoked and no licensee shall be fined except after a public hearing by the village president with a seven-day written notice of hearing to the licensee affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and defend against the charges contained in such notice. The seven-day notice provision shall begin the day following delivery by certified mail or by personal service of the notice. 
(d)  The village president shall, within seven days after such hearing, if he determines after such hearing that the license should be revoked or suspended, or that the licensee should be fined, state the reason for such determination in a written order and either the amount of the fine, the period of suspension or that the license has been revoked and serve a copy of such order within the seven days upon the licensee. 
(e)  Any licensee determined by the village president to have violated any of the provisions of this division shall pay to the village the costs of the hearing before the village president on such violation. The village president shall determine the costs incurred by the village for said hearing, including, but not limited to, court reporter's fees, the costs of transcripts or records, attorneys' fees, the cost of preparing and mailing notices and orders and all other miscellaneous expenses incurred by the village or such lesser sum as the village president may allow. 
(f)  The licensee shall pay said costs to the village within 30 days of notification of the costs by the village president. Failure to pay said costs within 30 days of notification is a violation of this division and may be cause for license suspension or revocation, or the levy of a fine. 
(Code 1940, § 25.158; Code 1964, § 17-27(H); Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 93-59, 11-22-1993)  
Sec. 36-303. - Reissuance of license after revocation. 
When any licensee shall have been revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted to the licensee for a period of six months thereafter for the conduct of the business of selling tobacco products as defined herein in the premises described in the revoked license. 
(Code 1940, § 25.158; Code 1964, § 17-27(I); Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 93-59, 11-22-1993)  
Secs. 36-304—36-324. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - CURFEW[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to establish curfew, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-5; improper supervision of minors, 720 ILCS 640/1. 
 
Sec. 36-325. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Curfew hours means 10:30 p.m. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday until 6:00 a.m. of the following day and 11:30 p.m. on any Friday or Saturday and until 6:00 a.m. of the following day. 
Emergency means an unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action. The term "emergency" includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, an automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. 
Establishment means any privately owned place of business operated for a profit to which the public is invited, including, but not limited to, any place of amusement or entertainment. 
Guardian means a person who, under court order, is the guardian of the person of a minor or a public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by a court. 
Minor means any person under 17 years of age. 
Operator means any individual, firm, association, partnership, or corporation operating, managing or conducting any establishment. The term "operator" includes the members or partners of an association or partnership and the officers of a corporation. 
Parent means a person who is a natural parent, adoptive parent, or step-parent of another person or at least 18 years of age and authorized by a parent or guardian to have the care and custody of a minor. 
Public place means any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access and includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways, and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transport facilities, and shops. 
Remain means to linger or stay or fail to leave premises when requested to do so by a police officer or the owner, operator, or other person in control of the premises. 
Serious bodily injury means bodily injury that creates a substantial risk of death or that causes death, serious permanent disfigurement, or protracted loss or impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ. 
(Code 1964, § 17-33(a); Ord. No. 94-18, 3-14-1994; Ord. No. 04-19, 3-22-2004)  
Sec. 36-326. - Prohibited conduct. 
(a)  A minor commits an offense if he is anywhere in public or on the premises of any establishment within the village or is the driver of or a passenger in a motor vehicle during curfew hours. 
(b)  A parent or guardian of a minor commits an offense if he knowingly permits, or by insufficient control allows, the minor to remain in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the village during curfew hours. 
(c)  The owner, operator, or any employee of an establishment commits an offense if he knowingly allows a minor to remain upon the premises of the establishment during curfew hours. 
(Code 1964, § 17-33(b); Ord. No. 94-18, 3-14-1994; Ord. No. 04-19, 3-22-2004; Ord. No. 2011-23, § 1, 3-28-2011) 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to establish curfew, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-5 improper supervision of minors, 720 ILCS 640/1.  
Sec. 36-327. - Defenses available to minors. 
It is a defense to prosecution under section 36-326(a) and (b) that the minor was: 
(1)  Accompanied by the minor's parent or guardian; 
(2)  On an errand at the direction of the minor's parent or guardian, without any detour or stop; 
(3)  In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel; 
(4)  Engaged in an employment activity, or going to or returning home from an employment activity, without any detour or stop; 
(5)  Involved in an emergency; 
(6)  On the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence or abutting the residence of a next door neighbor if the neighbor did not complain to the police department about the minor's presence; 
(7)  Attending an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the village, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor, or going to or returning home from, without any detour or stop, an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the village, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor; 
(8)  Exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the right of assembly; or 
(9)  Married or had been married or is an emancipated minor under the Emancipation of Minors Act, 750 ILCS 30/1 et seq. 
(Code 1964, § 17-33(c)(1); Ord. No. 94-18, 3-14-1994; Ord. No. 04-19, 3-22-2004)  
Sec. 36-328. - Defenses available to business personnel. 
It is a defense to prosecution under section 36-326(c) that the owner, operator, or employee of an establishment promptly notified the police department that a minor was present on the premises of the establishment during curfew hours and refused to leave. 
(Code 1964, § 17-33(c)(2); Ord. No. 94-18, 3-14-1994; Ord. No. 04-19, 3-22-2004)  
Sec. 36-329. - Enforcement. 
Before taking any enforcement action under this division, a police officer shall ask the apparent offender's age and reason for being in the public place. The officer shall not issue a citation or make an arrest under this division unless the officer reasonably believes that an offense has occurred and that, based on any response and other circumstances, no defense specifically provided for in this division is present. 
(Code 1964, § 17-33(d); Ord. No. 94-18, 3-14-1994; Ord. No. 04-19, 3-22-2004)  
Sec. 36-330. - Penalties. 
A person who violates a provision of this division is guilty of a separate offense for each day or part of a day during which the violation is committed, continued, or permitted. Each offense, upon conviction, is punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(Code 1964, § 17-33(e); Ord. No. 94-18, 3-14-1994; Ord. No. 04-19, 3-22-2004)  
Secs. 36-331—36-348. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - THEFT  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 36-349. - Burglars' tools; possession prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession a nippers of the description known as burglar's nippers, pick lock or skeleton key to be used with bits, jimmy or other burglars' instruments or tools, of whatsoever kind or description, unless it is shown that such possession is innocent or for a lawful purpose. 
(Code 1940, § 27.020; Code 1964, § 17-9; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2)  
Sec. 36-350. - Obtaining telephone service by fraud. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to insert, or to attempt to insert, into the coin box or money receptacle of any telephone any slug, button or other substance or to manipulate or operate or attempt to manipulate or operate in any manner whatever any telephone instrument or any mechanism or device connected or commonly used therewith, with the intent to obtain telephone service without paying therefor. 
(Code 1940, § 27.029; Code 1964, § 17-25; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2)  
Sec. 36-351. - Unauthorized taking of coins from coin box. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to insert or to attempt to insert into the coin box or money receptacle of any telephone any slug, button, wire, hook or other implements or substance with the intent to obtain from such coin box or money receptacle a legal tender. 
(Code 1940, § 27.030; Code 1964, § 17-26; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2)  
Secs. 36-352—36-375. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PROPERTY THEFT AND THEFT BY LESSEE 
 
Sec. 36-376. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Deception means to knowingly: 
(1)  Create or confirm another's impression which is false and which the offender does not believe to be true; 
(2)  Fail to correct a false impression which the offender has previously created or confirmed by silence, false pretense or otherwise; 
(3)  Prevent another from acquiring information pertinent to the disposition of the property involved; or 
(4)  Promise performance which the offender does not intend to perform or knows will not be performed. 
Failure to perform standing alone is not evidence that the offender did not intend to perform. 
Obtain means to bring about a transfer of interest or possession, whether to the offender or to another. 
Obtains control over property or exerts control cover property includes, but is not limited to, the taking, carrying away, or the sale, conveyance, or transfer of title to, or interest in, or possession of property. 
Owner means a person other than the offender, who has a possessory interest in the property involved, whether lawful or unlawful, and without whose consent the offender has no authority to exert control over property, or whose consent has lawfully been withdrawn. 
Permanently deprive means to defeat all recovery of the property by the owner, to deprive the owner permanently of the beneficial use of the property or to sell, give, pledge or otherwise transfer any interest in the property or subject it to the claim of a person other than the owner. 
Property means anything of value, including, but not limited to, money, commercial instruments, admission or transportation tickets, written instruments, membership or entitlement cards, written instruments, representing or embodying the rights concerning anything of value, labor or services, or otherwise of value to the owner. 
(Code 1964, § 17-35(B); Ord. No. 94-17, 3-14-1994)  
Sec. 36-377. - Prohibited conduct. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to commit theft within the village. A person commits the offense of property theft when he knowingly obtains or exerts unauthorized control over the property of the owner, or obtains by deception control over the property of the owner or obtains by threat control over the property of the owner with the intent to permanently deprive the owner of the use or benefit of the property. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to commit theft by lessee within the village. A person commits the offense of theft by lessee when he knowingly obtains or exerts unauthorized control over the property of the owner when a lessee or renter of the personal property of another fails to return it to the owner within 30 days after written demand to the lessee or renter from the owner for its return. Any said notice in writing given after the expiration of any written or oral leasing agreement, addressed and mailed, by registered mail, to the lessee or renter at the address given by the lessee or renter or shown on any lease or membership agreement shall constitute proper demand. 
(Code 1964, § 17-35(A); Ord. No. 94-17, 3-14-1994)  
Sec. 36-378. - Penalties. 
Any person violating the provisions of this division shall be fined an amount not less than $25.00 nor more than $500.00. 
(Code 1964, § 17-35(C); Ord. No. 94-17, 3-14-1994)  
Secs. 36-379—36-399. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - RETAIL THEFT[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference— Retail theft generally, 720 ILCS 5/16A-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 36-400. - Definitions. 
The words, terms and phrases defined in 720 ILCS 5/16A-2 shall be applicable to the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1964, § 17-34(C); Ord. No. 94-16, 3-14-1994)  
Sec. 36-401. - Prohibited conduct. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit the offense of retail theft in the village. A person commits the offense of retail theft when he knowingly: 
(1)  Takes possession of, carries away, transfer or causes to be carried away, or transferred, any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail mercantile establishment with the intention of retaining such merchandise or with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of such merchandise without paying the full retail value of such merchandise; 
(2)  Alters, transfers, or removes any label, price tag, marking, indicia of value or any other markings which aid in determining value affixed to any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale, in a retail mercantile establishment and attempts to purchase such merchandise personally or in consort with another at less than the full retail value with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise; 
(3)  Transfers any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale, in a retail mercantile establishment from the container in or on which such merchandise is displayed to any other container with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise; 
(4)  Underrings with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of the merchandise; or 
(5)  Removes a shopping cart from the premises of a retail mercantile establishment without the consent of the merchant given at the time of such removal with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of such cart. 
(Code 1964, § 17-34; Ord. No. 94-16, 3-14-1994) 
State Law reference— Offense of retail theft, 720 ILCS 5/16A-3; theft by emergency exit, 720 ILCS 5/16A-3.5.  
Sec. 36-402. - Presumption. 
If any person conceals upon his person or among his belongings, unpurchased merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail mercantile establishment, and removes that merchandise beyond the last known station for receiving payments for that merchandise in that retail mercantile establishment, such person shall be presumed to have possessed, carried away or transferred such merchandise with the intention of retaining it or with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of such merchandise without paying the full retail value of such merchandise. 
(Code 1964, § 17-34; Ord. No. 94-16, 3-14-1994) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, 720 ILCS 5/16A-4.  
Secs. 36-403—36-432. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - WEAPONS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference— Unlawful use of weapons, 720 ILCS 5/24-1. 
 
Sec. 36-433. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Air rifle means and includes any air gun, air pistol, spring gun, spring pistol, B-B gun, paint ball gun, paint ball pistol, pellet gun or any implement that is not a firearm which impels a breakable paint ball containing washable or unwashable marking colors, or a pellet constructed of hard plastic, steel, lead or other hard materials with a force that reasonably is expected to cause bodily harm. 
Firearm means any device, by whatever name known, which is designed to expel projectiles by the action of an explosion, expansion of gas or escape of gas; excluding, however: 
(1)  Any pneumatic gun, spring gun, paint ball gun or B-B gun which either expels a single globular projectile not exceeding 0.18 inch in diameter and which has a maximum muzzle velocity of less than 700 feet per second or breakable paint balls containing washable marking colors; 
(2)  Any device used exclusively for signaling' or safety and required or recommended by the United States Coast Guard or the interstate commerce commission; 
(3)  Any device used exclusively for the firing of stud cartridges, explosive rivets or similar industrial ammunition; and 
(4)  An antique firearm (other than a machine-gun) which, although designed as a weapon, the department of state police finds by reason of the date of its manufacture, value, design, and other characteristics is primarily a collector's item and is not likely to be used as a weapon. 
(Code 1940, § 27.040; Code 1964, § 29-1; Ord. No. 2009-003, § 2(29-1), 1-12-2009) 
State Law reference— Similar definitions, 430 ILCS 65/1.1.  
Sec. 36-434. - Discharge of projectiles prohibited. 
No person shall fire, discharge, set off or use within the limits of the village any firearm, air rifle, bean shooter, slingshot or any other instrument or machine from which a missile is discharged or hurled; provided, however, that, this section shall not be construed to prohibit the discharge of a firearm by any officer of the law in the performance of his duty or by any citizen on his current dwelling-place property in accord with the justifiable use of force in defense statutes, codified at 720 ILCS 5/7-1, 2. 
(Ord. No. 2009-003, § 2(4.01), 1-12-2009)  
Sec. 36-435. - Carrying concealed weapons prohibited. 
No person within the village shall carry a concealed weapon in violation of the provisions of 720 ILCS 5/24-1. 
(Code 1940, § 27.044; Code 1964, § 29-4; Ord. of 12-27-1954, § 1) 
State Law reference— Unlawful use of weapons, 720 ILCS 5/24-2.  
Sec. 36-436. - Right to keep firearms in home or place of business. 
The provisions of this article shall not be construed to deprive any citizen of the right to keep in his home or place of business any firearm reasonably necessary for the protection thereof, provided that such keeping is in compliance with state law. 
(Code 1940, § 27.045; Code 1964, § 29-5)  
Sec. 36-437. - Possession of air rifle by certain minors. 
It is unlawful for any person under 18 years of age to carry any air rifle on the public streets, roads, highways or public lands within the village, unless such person under 18 years of age carries such air rifle unloaded within a case fully enclosing the air rifle. 
(Ord. No. 2009-003, § 2(4.02), 1-12-2009)  
Sec. 36-438. - Defacing identification marks on firearms. 
No person shall change, alter, remove or obliterate the name of the maker, model, manufacturer's number, or other mark of identification on any firearm. Possession of any firearm upon which any such mark shall have been changed, altered, removed or obliterated shall be prima facie evidence that the possessor has changed, altered, removed or obliterated the same. 
(Code 1940, § 27.043; Code 1964, § 29-3) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, 720 ILCS 5/24-5.  
Sec. 36-439. - Confiscation of weapons. 
Any deadly weapon or firearm duly adjudged by any court of competent jurisdiction to have been worn or carried by any person in violation of any provision of this article, shall be forfeited to the village and shall be so adjudged as part of the judgment and penalty for any violation wherein a deadly weapon or firearm shall have been discovered and taken. 
(Code 1940, § 27.046; Code 1964, § 29-6) 
State Law reference— Confiscation and disposition of weapons, 720 ILCS 5/24-6.  
Sec. 36-440. - Certain firearm sales prohibited. 
(a)  Sale of firearms within 0.25 miles of the grounds of a school or public park is prohibited and each violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. For purposes of this article, a school shall be defined as any public or private elementary or secondary school, public or private college or university. 
(b)  The prohibition in this section shall not apply to otherwise lawful sales of firearms, in compliance with applicable village, state and federal law, by a firearms dealer licensed pursuant to village ordinance at the licensed place of business or a private citizen on his private property. 
(Code 1964, § 29-7.01(H); Ord. No. 94-56, 12-12-1994; Ord. No. 95-41, 9-25-1995; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006)  
Secs. 36-441—36-463. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES[10] 
Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference— Tobacco Accessories and Smoking Herbs Control Act, 720 ILCS 685/1 et seq.; Controlled Substances Act, 720 ILCS 570/100 et seq.; Controlled Substance and Cannabis Nuisance Act, 740 ILCS 40/0.01 et seq.; Drug Paraphernalia Control Act, 720 ILCS 600/1 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 36-464—36-494. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DRUG PARAPHERNALIA[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
State Law reference— Tobacco Accessories and Smoking Herbs Control Act, 720 ILCS 685/1 et seq.; authority for municipal ordinances regulating drug paraphernalia, 720 ILCS 6000/7. 
 
Sec. 36-495. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Close proximity means within 2,500 feet on a straight line commencing at the property lines nearest to each other. 
Controlled substance means any drug or controlled substance as defined under any state or federal law. 
Instrument means a device or contrivance used, designed for use, or intended for use in ingesting, inhaling, injecting, smoking, administering or preparing cannabis, marijuana, cocaine, phencyclidine, opium or any derivative thereof, or any other controlled substance into one's body without a doctor's prescription, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic, or ceramic marijuana (cannabis sativa) or hashish pipes which have an inside diameter of less than five-eighths inches with or without screens, permanent screens, hashish heads, or punctured metal bowls. 
(2)  Water pipes designed for use or intended for use with marijuana, hashish, hashish oil, or cocaine. 
(3)  Carburetion tubes and devices. 
(4)  Smoking and carburetion masks. 
(5)  Roach clips. 
(6)  Separation gins designed for use or intended for use in cleaning marijuana. 
(7)  Cocaine spoons and vials. 
(8)  Chamber, carburetor, electric and air driven pipes. 
(9)  Chillums. 
(10)  Bongs. 
(11)  Ice pipes or chillers. 
Minor means any person who has not attained 18 years of age at the time of the infraction. 
Premises open to minors means any establishment which sells its wares or merchandise to minors or which permits minors to enter into its place of business. 
Place of display means any museum, library, school or other similar public place upon which business is not transacted for a profit. 
School means any public or private elementary, junior high school, or high school. 
(Code 1964, § 17-32(b); Ord. No. 1980-4, 2-25-1980) 
State Law reference— Similar definitions, 720 ILCS 600/2.  
Sec. 36-496. - Possession, display and sale prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to have, possess, sell, offer to sell, display, dispense or give away any device or contrivance adapted for the use of smoking, injecting, inhaling, ingesting or otherwise introducing any controlled substance, including marijuana, into one's body, which said device or contrivance defined herein as an instrument has been or could be used for the purpose of smoking, inhaling, ingesting, injecting or otherwise introducing a controlled substance, including marijuana, into one's body without a doctor's prescription. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to sell or display any instruments as defined in this division in or upon any premises that is a premises open to minors or is in close proximity to any public or private school, day care center, nursery, church, synagogue or other place of worship, park, or any facility holding a liquor license; unless such premises is a place of display. 
(Code 1964, § 17-32(a); Ord. No. 1980-4, 2-25-1980) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 600/3.5.  
Sec. 36-497. - Exceptions. 
This division shall not apply to manufacturers, wholesalers of medical supplies, nor to licensed medical technicians, nurses, hospitals, research teaching institutions, medical doctors, embalmers, or pharmacists in the lawful normal course of business and those under the care of a physician suffering from diabetes, asthma or other medical condition requiring self-injection. 
(Code 1964, § 17-32(e); Ord. No. 1980-4, 2-25-1980)  
Sec. 36-498. - Penalties. 
(a)  In addition to all other penalties provided in this Code for violation of this division, any person convicted of a violation of this division shall be subject to the revocation of the business license issued to the owner or operator of such premises. 
(b)  A violation of this division is hereby defined and declared to be a public nuisance and shall be subject to abatement as provided by law. 
(Code 1964, § 17-32(c), (d); Ord. No. 1980-4, 2-25-1980)  
Secs. 36-499—36-519. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - CANNABIS[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
State Law reference— Cannabis Control Act, 720 ILCS 550/1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 36-520. - Cannabis defined. 
The term "cannabis," as used in this division, includes marijuana, hashish and other substances which are identified as including any parts of the plant Cannabis Sativa, whether growing or not; the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any part of such plant; and any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of such plant, its seeds, or resin, including tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and all other cannabinol derivatives, including its naturally occurring or synthetically produced ingredients, whether produced directly or indirectly by extraction, or independently by means of chemical synthesis or by a combination of extraction and chemical synthesis, but shall not include the mature stalks of such plant, fiber produced from such stalks, oil or cake made from the seeds of such plant, any other compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of such mature stalks (except the resin extracted therefrom), fiber, oil, cake, or the sterilized seed of such plant which is incapable of germination. 
(Code 1964, § 17-32.01(A); Ord. No. 94-15, 3-14-1994; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, 720 ILCS 550/3.  
Sec. 36-521. - Possession prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to possess any quantity of any substance containing cannabis as defined in this division except that the effect of this section shall be limited to persons knowingly possessing less than 30 grams of any substance containing cannabis. 
(Code 1964, § 17-32.01(B); Ord. No. 94-15, 3-14-1994; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, 720 ILCS 550/4.  
Sec. 36-522. - Penalties. 
Any person found guilty of any violation of the provisions of this division shall be fined not less than $25.00 or more than $500.00 for each offense. 
(Code 1964, § 17-32.01(C); Ord. No. 94-15, 3-14-1994; Ord. No. 2006-64, 9-11-2006)  
Secs. 36-523—36-552. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - HANDBILLS, SIGNS, POSTERS AND SIMILAR NOTICES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 36-553. - Posting on public property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to paste, post or fasten any handbill, poster, advertisement or notice of any kind whatsoever, or cause the same to be done, on any curbstone, flagstone or any other portion or part of any sidewalk or street, or upon any tree or street light post, telephone or electric light pole, hydrant, bridge or pier, or upon any structure within the limits of any street of the village, except such notices as may be required by the laws of the state or the ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1940, § 25.311; Code 1964, § 17-1; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2)  
Sec. 36-554. - Posting on private property generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to paste, nail or otherwise fasten any handbill, sign, poster, advertisement or notice of any kind, or cause the same to be done, upon any private wall, window, tree, gate, fence, advertising board, or sign, or upon any other private structure or building, unless such person is the owner, agent or lessee of such private property or unless he has the consent of such owner. 
(Code 1940, § 25.311; Code 1964, § 17-2; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2)  
Sec. 36-555. - Posting on private structures abutting street or constructed on street line. 
No advertising board or sign shall be attached to the side of any private structure or building abutting the street in such manner that any portion of such board or sign projects into the street, and no person shall paste, post or fasten any handbill, poster, advertisement or notice of any kind whatsoever, or any advertising board or sign, upon the side of any private structure or building which is constructed on the street line. 
(Code 1940, § 25.311; Code 1964, § 17-3; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2)  
Sec. 36-556. - Posting obscene or immoral advertisements. 
No person shall, within the village, post or cause to be posted, so that the same can be seen from the streets, alleys, or other public places of the village, any advertisement containing pictures or illustrations of an obscene or immoral character. 
(Code 1940, § 25.313; Code 1964, § 17-4; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2)  
Sec. 36-557. - Exception for legal notices. 
Nothing in this division shall be construed to apply to the posting of any legal notice by a public officer in the performance of his duty, in the manner and in the place prescribed by law. 
(Code 1940, § 25.314; Code 1964, § 17-6; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2)  
Secs. 36-558—36-577. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DISTRIBUTION 
 
Sec. 36-578. - Handbills, circulars, booklets and other printed material. 
No person shall distribute or cause to be distributed any handbills, circulars, booklets or sheets of written or printed matter advertising any commodity, article, merchandise, business or entertainment of any kind or nature except in the matter and in accordance with the following regulations: 
(1)  In the case of dwelling houses and apartment buildings, such matter shall be placed only at the rear entrances thereof; provided, however, that printed material delivered on paid subscription may be placed at the front entrances. 
(2)  Any printed matter so distributed shall be securely rolled, folded, tied or otherwise held in compact form and placed between the door knob and the door jamb, or other suitable place designated to prevent it from being scattered about. 
(3)  No distribution whatsoever of such printed matter shall be made in any dwelling houses or apartments which are obviously vacant or unoccupied. 
(4)  No printed matter shall be placed in or attached to any parked motor vehicle. 
(5)  This section shall not apply to the posting of any legal notice by a public officer in the performance of his duty, in the manner and in the place prescribed by law. 
(Code 1940, § 28.002; Code 1964, § 17-5; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2)  
Secs. 36-579—36-604. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XI. - FIREWORKS 
 
Sec. 36-605. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Consumer fireworks means those fireworks that must comply with the construction, chemical composition and labeling regulations of the United States Consumer Products Safety Commission, as set forth in 16 CFR parts 1500 and 1507, and classified as fireworks UN0336 or UN0337 by the United States Department of Transportation under 49 CFR 172.101. The term "consumer fireworks" shall not include snake and glow worm pellets; smoke devices; trick noisemakers known as "party poppers," "booby traps," "snappers," "trick matches," "cigarette loads," and "auto burglar alarms;" sparklers; toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns, or other devices in which paper or plastic caps containing 0.25 grains or less of explosive compound are used, provided they are so constructed that the hand cannot come in contact with the cap when in place for the explosion; and toy pistol paper or plastic caps that contain less than 0.20 grains of explosive mixture; the sale and use of which shall be permitted at all times. 
Consumer fireworks display means the detonation, ignition, or deflagration of consumer fireworks to produce a visual or audible effect. 
Display fireworks means 1.3G or special effects fireworks, as further defined in the Pyrotechnic Distributor and Operator Licensing Act, codified at 225 ILCS 227/1 et seq. 
Fire chief means the chief of the village's fire department or his duly authorized representative. 
Fire department means the village's fire department. 
Fireworks means and includes any explosive composition, or substance or combination of substances, or article prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect of a temporary exhibitional nature by explosion, combustion, deflagration or detonation, and shall include consumer fireworks and display fireworks, as herein defined, and also includes blank cartridges, toy cannons, in which explosives are used, the type of balloons which require fire underneath to propel the same, firecrackers, torpedoes, skyrockets, Roman candles, bombs, sparklers, or other fireworks of like construction and any fireworks containing any explosive compound, or any tablets or other device containing any explosive substance, or containing combustible substances producing visual effects; provided, however, that the term "fireworks" shall not include snake or glow worm pellets, smoke devices, trick noisemakers known as "party poppers," "booby traps," "snappers," "trick matches," "cigarette loads," and "auto burglar alarms," toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns, or other devices in which paper or plastic caps containing 0.25 grains or less of explosive compound are used, providing they are so constructed that the hand cannot come in contact with the cap when the place for the explosion, and toy pistol paper or plastic caps which contain less than 0.25 grains of explosive mixture, the sale and use of which shall be permitted at all times. 
Flame effects means the detonation, ignition, or deflagration of flammable gases, liquids, or special materials to produce a thermal, physical, visual, or audible effect before the public, invitees, or licensees, regardless of whether admission is charged, in accordance with National Fire Protection Association 160 Guidelines, and as may be further defined in the Pyrotechnic Distributor and Operator Licensing Act, codified at 225 ILCS 227/1 et seq. 
Permittee means and includes any person, firm or corporation or agent or employee of such person, firm or corporation who has been issued a permit for supervised displays of fireworks in the village under the terms of this article. 
Pyrotechnic display means the detonation, ignition, or deflagration of display fireworks or flame effects to produce visual or audible effects of an exhibitional nature before the public, invitees, or licensees, regardless of whether admission is charged, and as may be further defined in the Pyrotechnic Distributor and Operator Licensing Act, codified at 225 ILCS 227/1 et seq. 
Special effects fireworks means pyrotechnic devises used for special effects by professionals in the performing arts in conjunction with theatrical, musical, or other productions that are similar to consumer fireworks in chemical composition and construction, but are not intended for consumer use and are not labeled as such or identified as intended for indoor use. Special effects fireworks are classified as fireworks UN0431 or UN0432 by the United States Department of Transportation under 49 CRF 172.101. 
(Ord. No. 2009-002, § 2(17-70), 1-12-2009)  
Sec. 36-606. - Sale or discharge of fireworks and sparklers; permits. 
(a)  No person shall sell or use sparklers on public property within the village. 
(b)  Except as hereinafter provided, no person, firm, co-partnership or corporation shall knowingly possess, offer for sale, expose for sale, sell at retail, use or explode any fireworks; provided, however, that the fire chief may issue permits for supervised pyrotechnic displays of fireworks in the village to persons, including, but not limited to, fair associations, shopping centers, units of government and other civic organizations, or groups of individuals. 
(c)  Permits may be issued upon approval of an application submitted to the fire chief and after compliance with all code regulations contained herein, and the filing of a bond by the applicant as provided hereinafter. 
(d)  Every such pyrotechnic display shall be supervised by a licensed operator and of such composition, character and so located, discharged or fired so that, in the opinion of the fire chief, it shall not constitute a hazard to property or endanger any persons. 
(e)  Pursuant to such permit having been granted, possession, use and distribution of fireworks for such display shall be lawful for that purpose only; and no permit granted hereunder shall be transferable. 
(f)  The fire chief or his designee is authorized to confiscate, seize, take, remove or cause to be removed, at the expense of the owner, all stocks of fireworks or combustibles offered or exposed for sale, stored or held in violation of this article. 
(g)  No consumer fireworks display shall be permitted in the village, unless otherwise conducted as a part of a pyrotechnic display. 
(Ord. No. 2009-002, § 2(17-71), 1-12-2009)  
Sec. 36-607. - Application for pyrotechnic display. 
An application for a permit to operate a pyrotechnic display in conformance with the terms of this article shall be made in writing on forms provided by the fire chief of the village fire department. The application shall set forth: 
(1)  The name of the organization sponsoring the pyrotechnic display, together with the names, addresses and telephone numbers of the persons who will be on the site of and supervising the detonation of the pyrotechnic display. 
(2)  A certificate of general liability insurance or other evidence of financial responsibility in a form and amount approved by the village manager. 
(3)  The date and time of day at which the pyrotechnic display is to be held. 
(4)  The exact location proposed for the pyrotechnic display. 
(5)  A description setting forth the age, experience and physical characteristics of the persons who will detonate the fireworks. 
(6)  The number and kinds of fireworks to be discharged. 
(7)  The manner and place of storage of such fireworks prior to the pyrotechnic display. 
(8)  A diagram of the grounds on which the pyrotechnic display is to be held showing the point at which the fireworks are to be discharged, the location of all buildings, highways and other lines of communication, the lines behind which the audience will be restrained, and the location of all nearby trees, overhead wires or other overhead obstructions. 
(Ord. No. 2009-002, § 2(17-72), 1-12-2009)  
Sec. 36-608. - Conduct of pyrotechnic display. 
(a)  No permit shall be granted for any pyrotechnic display where the discharge, failure to fire, faulty firing or fallout of any fireworks or other objects would endanger persons, buildings, structures, forests or brush, nor in any case where the point at which the fireworks are to be fired is less than 200 feet from the nearest permanent building, public highway, railroad or other means of travel or 50 feet from the nearest aboveground telephone or telegraph line, tree or other overhead obstruction. 
(b)  All physical arrangements for firing and storage must be approved by the fire chief or his designee. 
(c)  Spectators at a pyrotechnic display shall be restrained behind lines or barriers as designated by the fire department, but in no case less than 200 feet from the point at which the fireworks are to be discharged. Only authorized persons and those in actual charge of the pyrotechnic display shall be allowed inside these lines or barriers during the unloading, preparation or firing of fireworks. 
(d)  All fireworks that fire a projectile shall be set up so that the projectile will go into the air as nearly as possible in a vertical direction. Furthermore, no firing tubes shall be utilized in rapid succession or in any other manner so as to cause overheating or instability of such tubes. 
(e)  No pyrotechnic display shall be held during any windstorm in which the wind reaches a velocity of more than 20 miles per hour. 
(f)  All firework articles and items at places of the pyrotechnic display shall be stored in a manner and in a place secure from fire, accidental discharge and theft, and in a manner approved by the fire chief. 
(g)  Fire protection and extinguishing equipment shall be provided as required by the fire chief or his designee. 
(h)  The permittee shall arrange for the detailing of a fire guard, consisting of one member of the fire department or such larger number of members as may be deemed necessary by the fire chief. 
(1)  The fire chief may require such fire guard to be at the site as soon as the fireworks are delivered to the site and such fire guard may be required to remain at such site by the said fire chief until after the conclusion of the pyrotechnic display and removal of all remaining fireworks or debris from the site. 
(2)  The expense for such fire guard shall be paid by the permittee. 
(i)  There shall be at all times no fewer than two licensed pyrotechnic operators of the pyrotechnic display constantly on duty during the discharge. 
(j)  Any fireworks that remain unfired after the pyrotechnic display is concluded shall be immediately disposed of or removed in a manner which is safe for the particular type of fireworks. 
(1)  The debris from the discharged fireworks shall be properly disposed of by the operator before leaving the premises. 
(2)  The operator, upon the conclusion of the display, shall make a complete and thorough search for any unfired fireworks or pieces which have failed to fire or function and shall dispose of them in a safe manner. 
(3)  Such search shall be instituted at the earliest possible time following the conclusion of the display, but in no event later than the first two hours of daylight which follow. 
(k)  Upon failure of a permittee to comply with any regulation contained in this section, the fire chief or the fire guard at the scene is hereby authorized to seize, take, remove or cause to be removed all or any stock of fireworks or combustibles or to terminate any display upon observing such violation. 
(Ord. No. 2009-002, § 2(17-73), 1-12-2009)  
Sec. 36-609. - Qualifications of operators. 
The person in actual charge of firing of the fireworks in a pyrotechnic display, as well as his assistant, shall be able bodied, at least 21 years of age, and shall be a lead pyrotechnic operator licensed by the office of the state fire marshal. 
(Ord. No. 2009-002, § 2(17-74), 1-12-2009)  
Sec. 36-610. - Use of signals or fuses. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the manufacture, storage or use of signals or fuses necessary for the safe operation of railroads, trucks, aircraft, or other instrumentalities of transportation. 
(Ord. No. 2009-002, § 2(17-75), 1-12-2009)  
Secs. 36-611—36-638. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XII. - NUISANCES[13] 
Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Editor's note— For nuisances related to alcohol beverage establishments, see Chapter 6. 
State Law reference— Municipal powers as to nuisances, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2; nuisances generally, 720 ILCS 5/47-25; municipal sanitation code violations, 65 ILCS 5/11-19.2-1 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 36-639. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Debris means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid waste, excluding body waste, consisting of both combustible and noncombustible materials, except garbage as defined in this section.
