Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
Nuisance means any condition or use of a premises which is detrimental to the property of others or which causes or tends to cause substantial diminution in the value of other property in the neighborhood in which such premises are located. This includes, but is not limited to, the keeping or depositing on the premises of any lumber, junk, trash, debris and abandoned, discarded or unused objects or equipment such as automobiles, furniture, stoves, refrigerators, freezers, cans, or containers. 
Owner means the owner, owners, tenants, lessees or occupants of any real property or the owner, owners or lessees of any personal property within the village. 
(Code 1964, § 14-30; Ord. No. 1979-27, § A, 6-11-1979)  
Sec. 36-640. - Unbarricaded building materials and mineral products prohibited; exception. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain or suffer or permit to be or remain on any premises owned or occupied by him, for a period of more than 24 consecutive hours, any pile, heap or mound of earth, soil, dirt, debris, sand, gravel, clay, rock, stone, lumber, cinders or any other building materials, coal, slag or similar material, or mineral products more than three feet high at any point thereof, without erecting, providing or maintaining a sufficient fence or barrier at least three feet high around such pile, heap or mound. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to any pile, heap or mound of the aforesaid materials or any of them erected or deposited by a building contractor in connection with the construction of a building by such contractor or any excavation in connection therewith, but such building contractor shall place and maintain signs on such piles, heaps or mounds so erected or deposited by him warning persons against trespassing or encroaching on the same, and such pile, heap or mound shall be removed not later than upon completion of the building then under construction or prior thereto on 24 hours' written notice from the chief building inspector, if, in the opinion of the inspector, such pile, heap or mound is dangerous to the safety of the public. 
(Ord. of 5-23-1949, § 1; Code 1964, § 17-8; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 1, 2)  
Sec. 36-641. - Nuisances on private property prohibited. 
(a)  Duty to maintain private property. No person owning, leasing, occupying or having charge of any premises shall maintain or keep any nuisance thereon, nor shall any such person keep or maintain such premises in a manner causing substantial diminution in the value of the other property in the neighborhood in which such premises are located. 
(b)  Exterior storage of junked and wrecked vehicles prohibited. No person in charge of or in control of premises, to which a village business license has been issued, whether as owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or otherwise, shall allow any partially dismantled, wrecked, junked, discarded or other motor vehicle, which cannot be driven under its own power, to remain on such property longer than 30 days, and no person shall leave any such vehicle on any property within the village for a longer time than 30 days. 
(c)  Abatement. The owner, owners, tenants, lessees or occupants of any lot within the corporate limits of this village upon which such storage is made, and also the owner, owners, or lessees of said personality involved in such storage, shall jointly and severally abate said nuisance by the prompt removal of said personality into completely enclosed buildings authorized to be used for such storage purposes, if within the corporate limits of the village, or otherwise to remove it to a location without said corporate limits. 
(Code 1964, § 07-36; Ord. No. 1979-28, § 1, 6-11-1979)  
Secs. 36-642—36-670. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - GARBAGE AND DEBRIS 
 
Sec. 36-671. - Unauthorized accumulation declared nuisance. 
The unauthorized accumulation of garbage and debris on any premises within the corporate limits is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is hereby prohibited. 
(Code 1964, § 14-31; Ord. No. 1979-27, § A, 6-11-1979)  
Sec. 36-672. - Failure to properly dispose of garbage and debris; notice. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit, create, cause or contribute to any unsightly, nauseous, unhealthful and dangerous condition by failing to properly dispose of garbage and debris. The failure to remove any existing accumulation of garbage and refuse after written notice from the village sanitarian shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(Code 1964, § 14-32; Ord. No. 1979-27, § A, 6-11-1979)  
Sec. 36-673. - Removal by village. 
(a)  When the owner or person in control of the premises refuses or neglects to remove such garbage and debris, after having received written notice from the village to do so, the village shall collect from such owner the reasonable cost of having the garbage and debris removed from the premises. 
(b)  This cost shall be a lien upon the real estate affected, superior to all subsequent liens and encumbrances, except tax liens, if, within 60 days after such cost and expense is incurred, the municipality, or person performing the service by authority of the municipality, in his own name, files notice of lien in the office of the recorded of deeds in the county in which such real estate is located or in the office of the registrar of titles of such county if the real estate affected is registered under the Torrens system. The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: 
(1)  A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof. 
(2)  The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred by the municipality. 
(3)  The dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the municipality. 
(c)  However, the lien of such municipality shall not be valid as to any purchaser whose rights in and to such real estate have arisen subsequent to removal of the garbage and debris and prior to the filing of such notice; and the lien of such municipality shall not be valid as to any mortgagee, judgment creditor or other lienor whose rights in and to such real estate arise prior to the filing of such notice. 
(d)  Upon payment of the cost and expense by the owner or persons interested in such property after notice of the lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the municipality or person in whose name the lien has been filed; and the release may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. 
(e)  The lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose as in the case of mortgages or mechanic's lien; however, the suit to foreclose this lien shall be commenced within two years after the date of filing the notice of lien. 
(Code 1964, § 14-33; Ord. No. 1979-27, § A, 6-11-1979)  
Secs. 36-674—36-704. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - NOISE 
 
Sec. 36-705. - Advertising and soliciting. 
No person shall make or cause, permit or allow to be made, upon a public street, or in such close proximity to a public street as to be distinctly and loudly audible upon such public street, any noise of any kind by crying, calling or shouting, or by means of any whistle, rattle, bell, gong, clapper, hammer, drum, horn, hand organ, mechanically operated piano, other musical instrument or similar mechanical device or wind instrument, for the purpose of advertising any goods, wares or merchandise, or of attracting attention or inviting the patronage of any person to any business whatsoever. 
(Code 1964, § 17-46(a); Ord. No. 2000-46, 7-24-2000)  
Sec. 36-706. - Transportation of building products and materials. 
All rails, pillars and columns of iron, steel or other metal which are being transported over and along the streets of the village upon carts, drays, cars or trucks, or in any other manner, shall be so loaded as to avoid causing loud noises or disturbing the peace and quiet of such streets. 
(Code 1964, § 17-46(b); Ord. No. 2000-46, 7-24-2000)  
Sec. 36-707. - Whistle of stationary steam plant. 
No person shall blow or cause to be blown, within the village, the steam whistle of any stationary steam plant as a signal commencing or suspending work, or for any other purpose. This section shall not be construed as forbidding the use of steam whistles as alarm signals in case of fire, collision or other imminent danger. 
(Code 1964, § 17-46(c); Ord. No. 2000-46, 7-24-2000)  
Sec. 36-708. - Musical instruments. 
(a)  No person shall use or perform upon any hand organ or other musical instrument, for pay or in expectation of payment, in any of the street or public places in the village before 9:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m. of any day or at any time on Sunday in any place whereby the peace and good order of society or of any private family shall be disturbed. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any band or music or organized musical society engaged in serenading, or civic or military parade. 
(Code 1964, § 17-46(d); Ord. No. 2000-46, 7-24-2000)  
Sec. 36-709. - Business operations generally. 
No person owning or in possession, charge or control of any building or premises shall use the same, or rent the same to be used for any business or employment, or for any purpose of pleasure or recreation, if such use shall, from its noise or its boisterous nature, disturb or destroy the peace of the neighborhood in which such building or premises is situated. 
(Code 1964, § 17-46(e); Ord. No. 2000-46, 7-24-2000)  
Sec. 36-710. - Foundries, machine shops, and factories. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to locate, build, construct or maintain a foundry, machine shop or factory wherein pneumatic hammers, pneumatic shovels or other apparatus the use of which is attended with loud or unusual noises are used within 200 feet of any residence. 
(Code 1964, § 17-46(f); Ord. No. 2000-46, 7-24-2000)  
Sec. 36-711. - Construction operations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or use any pile drivers, steam shovels, pneumatic hammers, pneumatic shovels, derricks, steam hoists, apparatus, the use of which is attended with loud or unusual noises, in any block in which more than half of the buildings on either side of the street are used exclusively for residence purposes. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, demolish, alter or repair any building or structure, to grade mechanically land or excavate any ditch, trench, hole, streets and highways with powered mechanical equipment between the hours of 12:00 a.m. (midnight) to 7:30 a.m. and from 7:00 p.m. to 11:59 p.m. on weekdays (other than legal holidays), between the hours of 12:00 a.m. (midnight) to 8:00 a.m. and from 6:00 p.m. to 11:59 p.m. on Saturdays (other than legal holidays) and between the hours of 12:00 a.m. (midnight) to 9:00 a.m. and from 6:00 p.m. to 11:59 p.m. on Sundays and legal holidays. Emergency work and work undertaken by local, state, or federal governmental entities are exempt from this provision. 
(c)  Upon written application to the village manager stating the applicant's name, the specific work to be done, the location of the work to be done and the time required to complete the work, the village manager may, in his/her discretion, issue written permission to undertake the construction, demolition, alteration or repair any building or structure, to grade mechanically land or excavate any ditch, trench, hole, streets and highways with powered mechanical equipment between the hours of 12:00 a.m. (midnight) to 7:30 a.m. and from 7:00 p.m. to 11:59 p.m. on weekdays (other than legal holidays), between the hours of 12:00 a.m. (midnight) to 8:00 a.m. and from 6:00 p.m. to 11:59 p.m. on Saturdays (other than legal holidays) and between the hours of 12:00 a.m. (midnight) to 9:00 a.m. and from 6:00 p.m. to 11:59 p.m. on Sundays and legal holidays if he/she determines that the public health and safety will not be detrimentally affected by the noise created by the work proposed to be performed. Permission granted under this subsection shall be for a period of no more than seven days and may be renewed for one period of no more than seven days. The village manager may, in his/her discretion, impose conditions and/or restrictions upon the permission granted. 
(Code 1940, §§ 26.001(29), (36), 27.012; Ord. of 6-13-1966, §§ 3, 4; Code 1964, § 17-46(g); Ord. No. 2000-46, 7-24-2000; Ord. No. 2015-01 , § 1, 1-12-2015)  
Sec. 36-712. - Designated railroad quiet zone. 
(a)  The Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railroad Line traversing the village between First Avenue on the east and Eberly Avenue on the west is hereby designated a quiet-zone. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, railroad employee or railroad train engineer to sound or otherwise activate any railroad train engine or locomotive horn or whistle within any designated quiet-zone in the village except as absolutely necessary to avoid or prevent personal injury or property damage or as may be required by state or federal law. 
(Code 1964, § 17-46(h); Ord. No. 2000-46, 7-24-2000)  
Secs. 36-713—36-737. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIII. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 36-738—36-757. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CITATIONS AND SETTLEMENTS 
 
Sec. 36-758. - Notice of violation; manner of proceeding. 
All persons accused of violating or failing to comply with any provisions of the this Code or any other ordinances of the village not included in this Code, including provisions adopted by reference herein and ordinances relating to traffic control, shall be notified of such violation or failure to comply in one of the following two ways: 
(1)  By arrest, or by the issuance of a formal complaint in the circuit court of the county, which complaint shall require the appearance of the defendant of the circuit court upon a noted day. A violation or a failure to comply commenced in this manner shall not be settled or compromised, but shall proceed to a hearing at which the defendant may plead "guilty" or "not guilty;" or 
(2)  By the issuance to the defendant of a "hang-on ticket." A violation or failure to comply commenced in this manner may be settled or compromised as provided in this article. 
(Code 1964, § 17-55; Ord. No. 1990-22, 4-9-1990)  
Sec. 36-759. - Hang-on tickets. 
(a)  A person receiving a hang-on ticket may settle or compromise the ticket by payment of the amount shown on the ticket or, if no amount is shown on the ticket, then the amount of the minimum fine provided in the minimum fine schedule adopted by the village board and available in the office of the village clerk. If no minimum fine is provided in the minimum fine schedule, then the fine shall be the minimum provided in section 1-13 or by state law if the state law minimum is less. The provisions of section 1-14 regarding the effect of the time of payment shall apply. 
(b)  Payment shall be made at the municipal building of the village within ten days after the issuance of such ticket. 
(c)  If the ticket is not settled or compromised within such ten-day period, it may be settled or compromised by the payment of twice the amount of such ticket, or if no amount is shown on the ticket, then twice the amount of the minimum fine provided in this article for the offense, for a period of 20 days after the lapse of the initial ten-day period. 
(d)  In the case of failure to make payment as herein provided, the person must appear at the circuit court of the county at the specific time and date. 
(e)  In the event that the person fails to appear in court on the date set forth in the notice to appear and complain, the matter shall be referred to the circuit court of the county for issuance of summons or an arrest warrant and the setting of a date for a hearing. 
(Code 1964, § 17-56; Ord. No. 1990-22, 4-9-1990)  
Sec. 36-760. - Method of payment of settlement; receipts. 
Payment of a settlement and compromise amount shall be made to the municipality in person or by mail, and a receipt shall be issued for all money so received. 
(Code 1964, § 17-57; Ord. No. 1990-22, 4-9-1990)  
Sec. 36-761. - Prosecutions. 
Officers of the village police department are authorized to refrain from initiating a prosecution for any alleged offense for which hang-on tickets are issued until the expiration of 11 days from the date of issuance of the ticket as provided in this article. 
(Code 1964, § 17-58; Ord. No. 1990-22, 4-9-1990)  
Secs. 36-762—36-790. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - CODE HEARING DEPARTMENT 
 
Sec. 36-791. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this division is to provide for fair and efficient enforcement and expeditious prosecution of municipal ordinance violations, as may be allowed by law and directed by this or any other ordinance, through an administrative adjudication of violations of village ordinances and by establishing a schedule of fines and penalties, and authority and procedures for collection of unpaid fines and penalties. 
(Ord. No. 2007-12, § 2(36-10), 2-12-2007)  
Sec. 36-792. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Building code means any municipal ordinance, law, housing, or building codes, property maintenance codes, including those codes adopted by reference, or zoning ordinances that establish construction, plumbing, heating, electrical, fire prevention, sanitation or other health and safety standards that are applicable to structures and property in the village or any village ordinance that requires, after notice, the cutting of weeds, the removal of garbage and debris, the removal of inoperable motor vehicles, or the abatement of nuisances from private property. 
Building inspector means any state, county or municipal employee whose duties include the inspection or examination of structures and properties in the village to determine if building code violations exist. 
Building owner or property owner means the legal, equitable, or beneficial owner of a building, structure or premises. 
Code violation. 
(1)  The term "code violation" means any infraction or violation of this Code, any other village ordinance, or any of codes adopted by the village by reference, except: 
a.  Building code violations; and 
b.  Any offense under the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq., or a similar offense that regulates traffic or otherwise governs the movement of vehicles. 
(2)  The term "code violation" does include the administrative adjudication of violations of traffic regulations concerning the standing, parking or condition of vehicles as provided in 625 ILCS 5/11-208.3. 
Defendant or respondent means any person, corporation, partnership, building or property owner, whether such ownership is legal or equitable, charged with a violation of this Code, any other village ordinance, or any of codes adopted by the village by reference. 
Hearing officer means an appointee of the village other than a law enforcement officer or building inspector whose duty it is to: 
(1)  Preside at an administrative hearing called to determine whether or not a building code violation or other code violation exists; 
(2)  Hear testimony and accept evidence from all interested parties relevant to the existence of a building code violation or other code violation; 
(3)  Preserve and authenticate the transcript and record of the hearing and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing; and 
(4)  Issue and sign a written finding, decision and order stating whether a code violation exists. 
(Ord. No. 2007-12, § 2(36-11), 2-12-2007)  
Sec. 36-793. - Creation of code hearing department; jurisdiction. 
(a)  There is hereby created within the village a code hearing department, which is authorized to provide for and operate a system of administrative adjudication, for the express purpose of adjudicating any code violation or any other municipal ordinance violation of the village, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Those actions brought pursuant to this Code, including the zoning chapter, and adopted codes such as the building code, fire code, plumbing code, electrical code, property maintenance code and health and sanitation codes of the village; 
(2)  Standing, stopping and parking violations brought pursuant to authority granted the village by section 11-208.3 of the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/11-208.3) and adopted in this Code. 
(b)  The standing, stopping and parking violations specified in subsection (a)(2) of this section shall be adjudicated pursuant to the procedures of division 2. All other violations shall be adjudicated pursuant to this division, excluding only those proceedings set forth in subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  Those proceedings not within the statutory authority granted to the village pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/11-3.1-1 et seq., and 65 ILCS 5/1-2.2-1 et seq., including, specifically, any offense under the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.) or similar offense that is a traffic regulation governing the movement of vehicles, and any reportable offense under Section 6-204 of the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/6-204), shall not be subject to administrative adjudication pursuant to the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2007-12, § 2(36-12), 2-12-2007)  
Sec. 36-794. - Hearing procedures nonexclusive. 
The provisions of this division shall not preclude the village from using other methods or proceedings to enforce the ordinances of the village, including the institution of any action in the county circuit court or any other court or other authorized administrative proceeding. 
(Ord. No. 2007-12, § 2(36-13), 2-12-2007)  
Sec. 36-795. - Qualifications of administrative hearing officers. 
Prior to conducting proceedings for administrative hearings, hearing officers shall successfully complete a formal training program that includes the following: 
(1)  Instruction on the rules of procedure of the hearing that they will conduct; 
(2)  Orientation in each subject area of code violations that they will administer; 
(3)  Observation of administrative hearing; 
(4)  Participation in hypothetical cases, including rules on evidence and issuing final orders; and 
(5)  All hearing officers must be attorneys licensed to practice in this state for a minimum period of three years. 
(Ord. No. 2007-12, § 2(36-24), 2-12-2007)  
Sec. 36-796. - Instituting and conducting code hearing proceedings. 
(a)  At such time as any building inspector, police officer, or other individual authorized to issue a code violation citation notice finds the existence of any code violation, he shall note the violation on a multiple copy violation notice and report form, indicating the name and address of the structure owner, or other respondent, in cases other than building code violations, the type and nature of the violation, the date and time the violation was observed, the name of the person witnessing the violation and the address of the structure or other location where the violation is observed. 
(b)  The violation notice form shall be forwarded by the building inspector, police officer or other authorized individual to the code hearing department where a citation or docket number shall be stamped on all copies of the notice and a hearing date noted in the blank spaces provided for that purpose on the violation notice form. Unless otherwise provided herein, the hearing date shall not be less than 30 days nor more than 40 days after the violation is reported to the code hearing department. 
(c)  One copy of the violation notice form shall be maintained in the files of the code hearing department and shall be part of the record of hearing, one copy of the notice form shall be returned to the inspector or officer so that he may prepare evidence of the code violation for presentation at the hearing on the date indicated, and one copy of the violation notice form shall be served, by first class mail, postage prepaid, to the respondent, along with a summons commanding the respondent to appear at the hearing. 
(d)  If, in the case of a building code violation, the name of the owner of the structure or premises cannot be ascertained or if service on the owner cannot be made by mail, service may be made on the owner of the structure or premises by posting or nailing a copy of the violation notice form and summons on the front door of the structure where the violation is found, not less than 20 days before the hearing is scheduled. 
(Ord. No. 2007-12, § 2(36-14), 2-12-2007)  
Sec. 36-797. - Subpoenas; defaults. 
(a)  At any time prior to the hearing date, the hearing officer assigned to hear the case may, at the request of an inspector, other authorized party on behalf of the village, or the village attorney, or the respondent or his attorney, issue subpoenas directing witnesses to produce records, appear and give testimony at the hearing. The party requesting a subpoena shall serve, via first class mail, copies of any and all subpoenas on all parties to the action. 
(b)  If, on the date set for hearing, the respondent, his attorney, or agent, fails to appear, the hearing officer may, after determining that proper notice of hearing has been given, find the respondent in default and shall proceed with the hearing and accept evidence relevant to the existence of a code violation. 
(Ord. No. 2007-12, § 2(36-15), 2-12-2007)  
Sec. 36-798. - Continuances; representation at code hearings. 
(a)  No continuances shall be authorized by the hearing officer except in such cases where a continuance is absolutely necessary to protect the rights of the respondent. Lack of preparation shall not be grounds for a continuance. Any continuance authorized by a hearing officer under this section shall not exceed 25 days or the next scheduled hearing, whichever is later. 
(b)  At the hearing, the case for the village may be presented by the building inspector in the case of a building code violation, by another village employee or by an attorney designated by the village board; provided, however that the case for the village may not be presented by a member of the code hearing department. The case for the respondent may be presented by the respondent, his attorney or other agent or representative designated by the respondent. 
(Ord. No. 2007-12, § 2(36-16), 2-12-2007)  
Sec. 36-799. - Hearing; evidence. 
At the hearing, the hearing officer shall preside and shall hear testimony and accept any evidence relevant to the existence or nonexistence of a code violation. The strict rules of evidence applicable to judicial proceedings shall not apply to a hearing herein. 
(Ord. No. 2007-12, § 2(36-17), 2-12-2007)  
Sec. 36-800. - Rights of the occupants. 
If the violation charged is a building code violation, it shall be unlawful for an action for eviction, abatement of a nuisance, forcible entry and detainer or other similar proceeding to be threatened or instituted against an occupant of a dwelling, by the respondent or anyone at his direction, solely because such occupant agrees to testify or testifies at a code violation hearing. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $750.00. 
(Ord. No. 2007-12, § 2(36-18), 2-12-2007)  
Sec. 36-801. - Defense to building code violations. 
It shall be a defense to a building code violation charged under this division if the owner, attorney on behalf of the owner, or any other agent or representative proves to the hearing officer's satisfaction that: 
(1)  The code violation alleged in the notice did not in fact exist, at the time the violation notice was issued or at the time of the hearing the violation has been remedied or removed. 
(2)  The code violation has been caused by the current property occupants and that despite reasonable attempts by the owner to maintain the dwelling free of such violations, the current occupants continue to cause the violations. 
(3)  That an occupant or resident of the dwelling has refused entry to the owner or his agent, to all or a part of the dwelling for the purpose of correcting the code violation. 
(Ord. No. 2007-12, § 2(36-19), 2-12-2007)  
Sec. 36-802. - Findings, decision, order. 
(a)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall make a determination on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing as to whether or not a violation existed on the date and time alleged. Except for violations related to the standing, stopping or parking of motor vehicles, registration of motor vehicles and motor vehicle equipment violations, the determination shall be in writing and shall be designated as findings, decision and order. 
(b)  The findings, decision and order shall include the hearing officer's findings of fact, a decision as to whether a code violation exists based upon the findings of fact, and an order, ordering correction of the violation in the case of a building code violation, stating the sanctions if applicable or dismissing the case, in the event a violation is not proved. 
(c)  If a violation is proved, the order may impose any and all sanctions that are provided by this Code for a violation proved not to exceed the sum of $750.00 per violation, except in the case of standing, stopping or parking regulations, the maximum fine for which shall not exceed $350.00 for a violation of parking spaces reserved for persons with disabilities and $250.00 for all other standing, stopping or parking regulations. 
(d)  A copy of the findings, decision and order shall be served on the respondent or his attorney within five days after it is issued. Service shall be in the same manner as the violation notice form and summons are served pursuant to this division. Payment of any penalty or fine imposed shall be to the village and shall be paid no later than 30 days of the date the order is issued. 
(Ord. No. 2007-12, § 2(36-20), 2-12-2007)  
Sec. 36-803. - Review under state law. 
The findings, decision and order of the hearing officer shall be subject to review in the circuit court of the county and the provisions of state law and shall apply to and govern every action for the judicial review of the final findings, decision and order of a hearing officer, for hearings conducted pursuant this division. 
(Ord. No. 2007-12, § 2(36-21), 2-12-2007)  
Sec. 36-804. - Judgment on findings, decision, order. 
(a)  Any fine, other sanction or costs imposed, or part of any fine, other sanction or costs imposed, remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust, judicial review procedures under state law shall be a debt due and owing the village and, as such, may be collected in accordance with applicable law. 
(b)  After expiration of the period within which judicial review under state law may be sought for a final determination of the violation, the village may commence a proceeding in the circuit court of the county for purposes of obtaining a judgment on the findings, decision and order. Nothing in this division shall prevent the village from consolidating multiple findings, decisions and orders against a person in such a proceeding. 
(c)  Upon commencement of the action, the village shall file a certified copy of the findings, decisions and order, which shall be accompanied by a certification that recites facts sufficient to show that the findings, decision and order was issued in accordance with the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1 et seq., or 65 ILCS 5/1-2.2-1 et seq., as the case may be and the applicable village ordinances. 
(d)  Service of the summons and a copy of the petition may be by any method provided by Section 2-203 of the Illinois Code of Civil Procedure or by certified mail, return receipt requested, provided that the total fines or other sanctions and costs imposed by the findings, decision and order do not exceed $2,500.00. If the court is satisfied that the findings, decision and order was entered in accordance with the requirements of 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1 et seq., or 65 ILCS 5/1-2.2-1 et seq., as the case may be, and the applicable village ordinances, and that the respondent had an opportunity for a hearing and for judicial review as provided: 
(1)  The court shall render judgment in favor of the village and against the property owner for the amount indicated in the findings, decision and order, plus costs. Such judgment shall have the same effect and may be enforced in the same manner as other judgments for the recovery of the money; and 
(2)  The court may also issue such other orders and injunctions as are requested by the village to enforce the order of the hearing officer to correct a code violation. 
(Ord. No. 2007-12, § 2(36-22), 2-12-2007)  
Sec. 36-805. - Sanctions applicable to owner. 
Any order to correct a building code violation and any sanctions imposed as a result of a finding of a building code violation under this division shall attach to the property as well as to the owner of the property, so that a finding of a violation against one owner cannot be avoided by conveying or transferring the property to another owner. Any subsequent transferee or owner of property takes subject to the findings, decision and order of the hearing officer. 
(Ord. No. 2007-12, § 2(36-23), 2-12-2007)  
Chapter 38 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to grant control of parks to local park boards, 70 ILCS 1245/5; maintenance of public streets by park commissions and boards, 65 ILCS 5/11-86-1; authority of municipalities with populations of 15,000 or less to acquire certain property for public parks, 65 ILCS 5/11-100-1; municipal authority to accept dedication of public lands, 65 ILCS 5/11-105-1; Swimming Facility Act, 210 ILCS 125/1 et seq.; Boat Registration and Safety Act, 625 ILCS 45/1-1 et seq.; municipal cultural centers, 65 ILCS 5/11-45.1-1; Campground Licensing and Recreational Area Act, 210 ILCS 95/1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 38-1. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than $25.00 or more than $500.00 for each offense upon conviction thereof. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(ee); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001)  
Secs. 38-2—38-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PLAYGROUND AND RECREATION BOARD 
 
Sec. 38-21. - Created; composition. 
The village board, in accordance with state law, has established a playground and recreation board for the village composed of five members to be appointed by the president of the village by and with the consent of the village board. 
(Code 1964, § 20-8; Ord. of 5-14-1951, § 1) 
Editor's note— The original playground and recreation board was approved by the electors at referendum held on April 17, 1951.  
Sec. 38-22. - Terms; vacancies; compensation. 
Member appointments shall be made for five-year terms. Members shall serve until their successors are appointed and qualified. In case of vacancy, the village president shall appoint a successor to service for the unexpired term. The members of the playground and recreation board shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1964, § 20-9; Ord. of 5-14-1951, § 1)  
Sec. 38-23. - Quorum. 
A majority of the members of the playground and recreation board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1964, § 20-10; Ord. of 5-14-1951, § 1)  
Sec. 38-24. - General powers. 
(a)  The playground and recreation board shall have and may exercise all powers conferred on it by state law and by this article. In the exercise of such powers, the board may cooperate or join with school, park and other governmental authorities and bodies and shall have power to use lands, buildings and equipment made available to it by other governmental bodies and authorities. 
(b)  In addition, the playground and recreation board shall advise the president, board of trustees and the village manager on matters concerning the liaison, monitoring, establishment and operations of fairs and similar special events sponsored or sanctioned by the village as well as recommendations governing the establishment of new events intended to promote the interests of the village. 
(c)  In the exercise of such powers, the board may cooperate or join with school, park and other governmental authorities and bodies and shall have the power to use lands, buildings and equipment made available to it by other governmental bodies and authorities. 
(d)  The playground and recreation board is authorized and empowered to make such rules and regulations as it deems necessary to implement the provisions of this chapter and to carry out the orderly operation of organized recreation facilities and programs. 
(e)  Nothing in this article shall authorize such board to make any expenditures of money or exercise any of its powers beyond the corporate limits of this village without first obtaining approval and consent by proper resolution of the president and village board. 
(Code 1964, §§ 20-4(a), 20-11; Ord. of 5-14-1951, § 1)  
Sec. 38-25. - Elections of officers and adoption of rules and regulations. 
The playground and recreation board shall elect necessary officers and adopt such rules, bylaws and regulations as it may deem proper for the conduct of its work. 
(Code 1964, § 20-12; Ord. of 5-14-1951, § 1)  
Sec. 38-26. - Acceptance of gifts, grants, etc. 
(a)  The playground and recreation board may accept any grant or devise of real estate of any gift or bequest of money or other personal property or any donation, the principal or income of which is to be applied for either temporary or permanent use for playground or recreation purposes, but, if the acceptance thereof for such purposes shall subject the village to expense for improvements, maintenance or renewal, the acceptance of any grant or devise of real estate shall be subject to the approval of the village board. 
(b)  Money received for such purpose, unless otherwise provided by the terms of the gift or bequest, shall be deposited with the treasurer of the village to the account of the playground and recreation board, and such money may be withdrawn and paid out upon warrants drawn upon the municipal treasury by such playground and recreation board. 
(Code 1964, § 20-13; Ord. of 5-14-1951, § 1)  
Sec. 38-27. - Payment of board's costs and expenses. 
The cost and expense incurred by the playground and recreation board shall be paid out of the taxes collected pursuant to this article or out of money received as, or realized from, gifts received for this purpose and shall be paid out upon the warrants drawn on the village treasury upon order of such board. 
(Code 1964, § 20-14; Ord. of 5-14-1951, § 1)  
Sec. 38-28. - Reports. 
(a)  Within 15 days after the expiration of the fiscal year of the village, the playground and recreation board shall make a report as of the last day of the fiscal year, to the village board. This report shall be in writing and shall be verified under oath by the secretary or some other responsible officer of the playground and recreation board. It shall contain: 
(1)  An itemized statement of the various sums of money received from the playground and recreation tax and from other sources; 
(2)  An itemized statement of the objects and purposes for which such sums of money have been expended; 
(3)  A statement of the real and personal property acquired by devise, bequest, purchase or otherwise; 
(4)  A statement of the character of any extensions of playground and recreation service that have been undertaken; 
(5)  A statement of the financial requirements of the playground and recreation board for the ensuing fiscal year, and its recommendations on the rate of tax which it will be necessary to levy for recreation and playground purposes; and 
(6)  Any other information and recommendations that may be of interest. 
(b)  Nothing herein contained shall be construed as any limitation on or waiver of the authority, right and power of the president and village board to, at any time, call for and demand a full and complete report of all the acts and doings of the playground and recreation board, nor shall anything herein contained be construed as any limitations on the power, right and authority of the president and village board to examine into the records and affairs of such board whenever, in the opinion of the president and village board, such examination may be necessary. 
(Code 1964, § 20-15; Ord. of 5-14-1951, § 1)  
Sec. 38-29. - Authority granted to village manager. 
The village recreation director and all other recreation employees shall be under the immediate and direct supervision, direction and control of the village manager. All other statutory authority vested in the village recreation board, not otherwise vested in the village manager pursuant to this article, shall be reserved by the village recreation board. 
(Code 1964, § 20-16; Ord. No. 93-49, 9-27-1993)  
Secs. 38-30—38-46. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PARK RULES AND REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 38-47. - Fees. 
The playground and recreation board is authorized to establish fees and deposits for the use of park lands and outdoor facilities, including those that constitute designated picnic areas and may, from time to time, amend the same. The fees established by the playground and recreation board under authority granted in this section shall be included in the village fee schedule. 
(Code 1964, § 20-5; Ord. No. 1981-1, 1-26-1981; Ord. 92-43, 11-23-1992)  
Sec. 38-48. - Picnic reservation permits. 
Whenever any group, association or organization desires to use the designated picnic areas in the parks, a representative of said group, association or organization shall first obtain a permit from the director of recreation. The director shall issue the permit if it appears that the group, association or organization will not interfere with the general use of the park by the individual members of the public and if said group, association or organization meets all the other conditions contained in the application. 
(Code 1964, § 20-5; Ord. No. 1981-1, 1-26-1981; Ord. 92-43, 11-23-1992)  
Sec. 38-49. - Park closed from sunset to sunrise; exceptions. 
No person shall remain in any park of the village between sunset and sunrise of any day, except as otherwise provided in this article. This provision shall not apply to officers or employees of the village while in discharge of their duties, nor to persons having a permit in writing to be or remain in any part of the park, issued by the director of playground and recreation, nor to any village-organized and sponsored recreation program. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(a); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-50. - Restricted portions of park. 
No person shall enter upon any portion of the park system where persons are prohibited by direction of the director of recreation, village manager, police officer or authorized person acting in the name of the director of recreation or village manager or an indicated by sign or notice. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(b); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-90; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-51. - Public assemblies require consent. 
No person shall call or hold any public meeting or give any concert or public entertainment of any kind in the park without the express written consent of the village manager. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(c); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-52. - Improper speech and conduct prohibited. 
No person shall use any abusive, threatening, insulting, indecent, profane or obscene language, or languages calculated to occasion a breach of the peace, nor be guilty of any indecent act or behavior in the park system. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(d); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-53. - Solicitations prohibited. 
No person shall beg or solicit donations in the park system. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(e); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-54. - Overnight camping or sleeping prohibited. 
No person shall sleep in the park system, on the ground or on any type structure, permanent or portable, between sunset and sunrise. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(f); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-55. - Fires prohibited; exceptions. 
No person shall light or make use of any fire in the park system, except such portion thereof as may be designated for such purpose and then only under such regulations as are prescribed by the director of recreation. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(g); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-56. - Firearms and fireworks prohibited; exceptions. 
No unauthorized person shall carry or discharge firearms, or set off any rocket, cracker, torpedo, squib or other fireworks or things containing any substance of an explosive nature in the park system unless authorized by the playground and recreation board. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(h); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-57. - Weapons prohibited; exceptions. 
No unauthorized person shall bring, attempt to bring, carry, have in his vehicle, or use in any way, any knife having a blade longer than three inches, or air gun, pellet gun or sling shot in the park. No person shall bring, attempt to bring, carry or use in any way, any bow or arrow in any park, unless in a directly supervised park program. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(i); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-58. - Throwing stones and other dangerous objects prohibited. 
No person shall throw or cast any stones or other dangerous objects within the park system. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(j); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-59. - Advertisements prohibited; exceptions. 
No person shall display any placard or advertisement of any kind in the park system, nor shall any person distribute, cast, throw or place any handbill, pamphlet, circular, advertisement or notice of any kind, nor post, stencil or otherwise affix any of the above upon any structure or thing within the park system except as authorized by the playground and recreation board, except as specifically allowed in chapter 42. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(k); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-60. - Gambling and certain amusements prohibited; exceptions. 
No person shall tell fortunes, play at games of chance or use any gambling device in the park system. Exceptions may be made for special events with playground and recreation board approval. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(l); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-61. - Improper dumping prohibited. 
No person shall deposit, dump, throw or place any coal, ashes, dust, manure or rubbish in or upon any part of the park system. Paper, garbage or refuse matter shall not be so deposited except in receptacles provided for that purpose. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(m); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-62. - Intoxication, alcoholic beverages and illegal drugs prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  No intoxicated person shall enter, be or remain in the park system, nor shall any person bring within, sell, give away, or drink any intoxicating liquors in the park system. Beer and wine may be provided for special events with village liquor commission approval. 
(b)  No person shall enter, be or remain in the park system under the influence of a controlled substance, nor shall any person bring within, sell, or give away any controlled substance within the park system. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(o); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-63. - Offering articles for sale prohibited; exceptions. 
No person shall offer for sale or exchange, any article or thing, or do any hawking, peddling or soliciting, or buy or offer to buy an article or thing, or take up any collection or solicit or receive contributions of money or anything of value in the park system, except when authorized to do so by permit from or contract with the playground and recreation board. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(p); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-64. - Dog regulations; other animals prohibited. 
(a)  No animals of any type except dogs are allowed in the park, either leashed or unleashed, except for special events where animals are part of the event with prior playground and recreation board approval and meeting all other ordinances of the village. 
(b)  No person owning or keeping a dog shall allow such dog to run freely in any park or playground in the village. 
(c)  No person owning or keeping a dog shall allow such dog to be in any park or playground in the village unless such dog remains under control, securely fastened and restrained by a leash not more than eight feet in length. Dog licenses and proof of vaccination must be displayed on the dog's collar. 
(d)  No person owning or keeping a dog shall allow such dog to enter upon or remain upon any area of a park utilized as an athletic field, court, children's play area or posted to prohibit dogs. 
(e)  Owners or keepers of dogs shall carry appropriate equipment to and shall immediately clean the dog's waste and deposit the waste in an appropriate waste receptacle. 
(f)  Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be fined not less than $25.00 or more than $200.00. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(r); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-65. - Misuse of playground equipment prohibited. 
No person shall in any manner use any of the playground apparatus or devices for other than their intended purpose or misuse any playground apparatus, which by its size and shape is meant exclusively for the use of children. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(s); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-66. - Games and sports activities restricted. 
No person shall engage in any sport, game or amusement in the park system except such portions as may be designated and then only under rules and regulations as may be prescribed by the playground and recreation board. Such activities prohibited include, but are not limited to, hitting of golf balls, for practice or otherwise, upon property under the jurisdiction of the playground and recreation board. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(t); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-67. - Use of ball fields and other outdoor facilities. 
(a)  No major league type baseball will be practiced or played on playgrounds except on designated fields. 
(b)  No baseball or softball playing is allowed after sunset and before sunrise, except scheduled league practice or play on lighted fields, and then only until 11:00 p.m., at which time the lights will be extinguished. 
(c)  No basketball or volleyball is allowed after sunset and before sunrise, except on those facilities specifically designated by the playground and recreation board to be lighted and then only until 9:00 p.m., at which time the lights will be extinguished. Said designation shall be approved only by an appropriate motion passed at a public meeting of the playground and recreation board. Any such designated volleyball or basketball facilities when so lighted shall only be used for its intended purposes, namely volleyball or basketball, from sunset to 9:00 p.m. and shall, at other times, fully comply with the uses permitted under this chapter or rules promulgated under authority granted in this chapter. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(u); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2004-47, 12-20-2004; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-68. - Construction prohibited; exceptions. 
No person shall construct any structure, or object, either permanent or temporary, or add to any current structure or object, permanent or temporary, regardless of material, in any park without written consent of the playground and recreation board. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(v); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-69. - Protection of wildlife. 
No person shall trap, catch, wound or kill, or treat cruelly, or attempt to trap, catch, wound or kill, any bird or animal or molest or rob any nest of any bird or animal in the park system. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(w); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-70. - Plants, shrubs or trees. 
No person shall bring into or remove from the park system any tree, shrub or plant or any newly plucked branch or portion of a tree, shrub or plant unless authorized by the board. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(x); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-71. - Unauthorized use of park equipment prohibited. 
No person shall operate any playground and recreation department equipment or vehicle unless they are a playground and recreation department employee or have secured permission from the playground and recreation board. Unauthorized rental or use of park equipment outside of the park limits is prohibited. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(y); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-72. - Interfering with department personnel prohibited. 
No person shall interfere with or in any manner hinder any employee of the playground and recreation department while engaged in constructing, repairing or caring for any park property. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(z); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-73. - Resisting or interfering with officers prohibited. 
No person shall resist any playground and recreation board member, police officer, or other lawfully authorized person, or park personnel of the playground and recreation department in the discharge of his duty or fail to refuse to obey any lawful command of any such board member, police officer or park personnel from discharging his duty or in any manner assist or give aid to any person in custody to escape or attempt to escape from custody or rescue. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(cc); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-74. - Damage to park property prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall cut, break, climb on or in any way injure or deface any tree, shrub, plant, turf, or any of the buildings, fences, lamps or posts or other structure or property within the park system. 
(b)  Special events approved by the playground and recreation board within the parks shall leave said property in the condition it was prior to the event. The recreation director will review park conditions before and after event. If damage has occurred, the sponsors of event will bear the cost of restoring the park. The board reserves the right to require adequate security to guarantee the restoration of the condition of the park. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(aa); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-75. - Disorderly conduct or other breach of peace prohibited. 
No person shall make, countenance or assist in making any improper noise, riot disturbance, breach of the peace or diversion tending to a breach of the peace in the park system, or be guilty of any disorderly conduct therein or collect with other persons, in bodies, or crowds for unlawful purposes or for any purpose to the annoyance or obstruction or disturbance of other persons. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(bb); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-76. - Obstruction of travel ways prohibited. 
No unauthorized person shall set or place, or cause to be set or placed, any goods, wares or merchandise or property of any kind so as to obstruct travel in the park. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(n); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-77. - Motor vehicle restrictions. 
(a)  No person shall operate any motor vehicle except upon the established roadways, drives, or parking lots, except upon a paved surface roadway intended to provide direct access to a designated parking lot, unless authorized by the playground and recreation board. No person shall operate any mini-bike, snow-mobile, unlicensed motor vehicle or vending vehicle anywhere in the park system, nor park any mini-bike, snow-mobile, unlicensed vehicle or vending vehicle anywhere in the park system. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful of any person to park or otherwise leave a motor vehicle of any description in Kiwanis Park or Ehlert Park. 
(c)  This provision shall not apply to officers or employees of the village while in discharge of their duties, nor to persons having a permit in writing to park in an area of the park not so designated for the purpose of parking motor vehicles, issued by the village manager or the director of playground and recreation, nor to parking as may be so directed by an officer of the village in the normal discharge of his duties. 
(Code 1964, §§ 18-96.04, 20-4(q), 20-21; Ord. No. 1969-2, § 2, 1-27-1969; Ord. No. 1973-25, § 2, 10-22-1973; Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 94-53, 12-12-1994; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Sec. 38-78. - Bicycles and other play devices and vehicles. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Bicycle means a device with one or more wheels having a seat designed to be ridden by one or more persons and propelled by the riders pedaling the device with their feet. 
Roller skate or skating means the act of a person propelled by the alternate action of their legs while wearing roller skates on their feet. 
Roller skates means a boot or shoe or a frame attached to the sole of a boot or shoe and to which is attached one or more sets of wheels used by a person for gliding over a surface, including, but not limited to, in-line skates and roller blades. 
Skateboard means a device containing a short board or platform on which a person rides and to which is attached one or more sets of wheels used by a person for coasting or performing jumps or athletic stunts, including, but not limited to, coasters and scooters, but not including wheelchairs or strollers or other similar devices used for transporting infants, toddlers, physically challenged or incapacitated persons. 
(b)  No person shall roller skate, ride a skateboard or ride a bicycle in a public park except in compliance with this section. 
(c)  No person shall roller skate, ride a skateboard or ride a bicycle in a public park in a reckless manner or without exercising due care for the safety of other persons using the park. 
(d)  Any person roller skating, riding a skateboard or riding a bicycle in a public park shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian. 
(e)  Persons shall roller skate, ride a skateboard or ride a bicycle in a public park in a manner so as to avoid colliding with pedestrians. 
(f)  Persons who shall roller skate, ride a skateboard or ride a bicycle upon the sidewalks, paved pathways and roadways within a park shall do so as far to the right of the walk or way as is safely possible. 
(g)  No person shall roller skate, ride a skateboard or ride a bicycle in a public park in a manner so as damage any tree, bush, bench, table, playground equipment, fence, structure, fountain, statue, athletic field or court or other park improvement. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4(dd); Ord. No. 1990-18, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 93-10, 3-8-1993; Ord. No. 00-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. No. 2001-14, 3-27-2001; Ord. No. 2012-32, § 2, 5-14-2012)  
Chapter 40 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal zoning, 65 ILCS 5/11-13-1 et seq.; Local Land Resource Management Planning Act, 50 ILCS 805/1 et seq.; local plan commissions, 65 ILCS 5/11-12-4 et seq.; fair housing ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/11.1-1; urban rehabilitation, 65 5/11-11-1 et seq.; setback lines, 65 ILCS 5/11-14-1; approval of maps and plats, 65 ILCS 5/11-15-1; community planning and development, 65 ILCS 5/11-39.1-1; flood control and drainage, 65 ILCS 5/11-110-1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 40-1. - Adoption of master plan. 
The 2020 master plan for the village is approved, adopted by reference and incorporated into this Code as though fully set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 2005-04, § 2, 2-14-2005)  
Secs. 40-2—40-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS 
 
Sec. 40-21. - Board of local improvements. 
There shall be and is hereby created the board of local improvements for the village. The board of local improvements shall be comprised of five members, appointed by the president with the consent of the village board, and shall serve without compensation. Such board shall have all the powers conferred and all the duties imposed by state law. 
(Code 1940, § 12.001; Code 1964, § 16-1; Ord. of 5-25-1953, § 1; Ord. 90-24, 4-23-1990)  
Sec. 40-22. - Origination of local improvements. 
All petitions for local improvements to be paid for, wholly or in part, by special assessment or special taxation shall originate with the board of local improvements and petitions for such improvements shall be addressed to said board and such board shall have the power to originate a local improvement to be paid for by special assessment or special tax, either with or without a petition, and in either case shall adopt a resolution describing the proposed improvement, which resolution shall be at once transcribed in the records of such board. 
(Code 1940, § 12.001; Code 1964, § 16-2; Ord. of 5-25-1953, § 1)  
Sec. 40-23. - Special assessments. 
(a)  In all cases of local improvements to be paid for by special assessment, the commissioner appointed for such assessment shall receive as and for his fees a first installment voucher in the sum of one per cent of the estimated cost of the improvement, payable solely out of the first installment of the special assessment for which he is appointed. Such vouchers shall be issued to the commissioner after a contract for the work has been entered into between the successful bidder and the village, and a bond has been furnished by the contractor and approved and accepted by the village. 
(b)  The village shall pay for the postage on all notices required for the special assessment, and the necessary printing of such notices, which amount shall be deducted from the sum to be paid to the commissioner. 
(c)  The cost of publication of the necessary legal notices in relation to a special assessment shall be payable by a first installment voucher payable solely out of the first installment of the special assessment. 
(d)  Should the petition for the levying of a special assessment to pay for the cost of construction of a local improvement be dismissed by resolution of the board of trustees, the commissioner shall have no claim against the village for any services rendered. 
(Code 1940, §§ 11.018—11.022; Code 1964, § 16-3)  
Secs. 40-24—40-39. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - REDEVELOPMENT PROJECT AREA MODERNIZATION PROGRAM 
 
Sec. 40-40. - Establishment. 
There is hereby created and established a redevelopment project area modernization program for the village. 
(Ord. No. 2017-10 , § 2, 1-23-2017)  
Sec. 40-41. - Purpose. 
The redevelopment project area modernization program is designed to promote the continued use and maintenance of commercial buildings in the redevelopment project areas of the village by assisting property owners and their tenants to rehabilitate and restore signage on eligible structures. Grants are made available to subsidize the interest rate on loans from participating financial institutions to finance the rehabilitation and restoration of signage on eligible structures by property owners or tenants in recognition of the positive impact that individual building improvements can have on overall appearance, quality, and vitality of the redevelopment project areas. The grant funds will be paid directly to the participating financial institutions to reduce the interest rate on qualifying loans to zero percent. 
(Ord. No. 2017-10 , § 2, 1-23-2017)  
Sec. 40-42. - Funding of program. 
The village will participate in funding for the redevelopment project area modernization program for rehabilitating and restoring signage on eligible structures by paying to participating financial institutions funds necessary to reduce the interest rate to zero percent on qualifying loans of the owner or tenant of the property to finance eligible signage improvements. A limited amount of village funds will be available to subsidize the interest on loans for eligible signage improvements on a "first come, first served" basis. 
(Ord. No. 2017-10 , § 2, 1-23-2017)  
Sec. 40-43. - Program administration. 
The village manager shall manage and administer the redevelopment project area modernization program on behalf of the village. The village manager shall develop, publish and, when necessary and prudent to the administration of the program, may amend program guidelines consistent with this article to administer the redevelopment project area modernization program on behalf of the village and to guide participants on the terms, conditions and requirements for participation in the program. The village manager is authorized and directed to enter into appropriate agreements with one or more financial institutions to participate in the redevelopment project area modernization program. 
(Ord. No. 2017-10 , § 2, 1-23-2017)  
Sec. 40-44. - Eligibility. 
To be eligible for the redevelopment project area modernization program, a building must be located within one of the designated redevelopment project areas in the village. The applicant must file an application with the village as provided in the program guidelines. The applicant must file a loan application with a participating financial institution as provided in the program guidelines. The applicant's loan application must be approved by a participating financial institution. The director of the community and economic development department will submit recommendations for approval of the applications to the village manager for review and final approval. The applicant must execute and the village manager must review and approve a redevelopment project area modernization program agreement to authorize the payment of the economic incentive provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2017-10 , § 2, 1-23-2017)  
Sec. 40-45. - Village financial participation. 
Costs will be shared for the program on the following basis: 
(1)  The property owner or tenant shall contract for the eligible signage improvements, pay or arrange the financing of the cost of the improvements with a participating financial institution. 
(2)  The village shall pay to the participating financial institution the funds necessary to subsidize the interest rate on the qualifying loan to finance the eligible signage improvement costs by the property owner or tenant of an eligible building up to a maximum loan amount of $10,000.00 amortized over a maximum loan period of four years and a maximum loan subsidy amount of $1,000.00. If the owner or tenant of an eligible building does not finance the costs of the improvements, the village shall reimburse the property owner or tenant of an eligible building for the eligible signage improvement costs based upon the formula contained in the village's program guidelines up to a maximum of $1,000.00. 
(3)  Eligible signage improvement costs include the following: professional and consultant fees, sign cleaning, painting, construction, reconstruction, rehabilitation and restoration of the signage. 
(4)  Eligible projects must follow the village's program guidelines. 
(5)  When a qualifying loan has been approved in compliance with the approved application, the village shall pay to the participating financial institution the funds necessary to subsidize the interest rate on the qualifying loan to finance the eligible signage improvement costs. 
(6)  The village manager is hereby authorized to waive the building permit fee for eligible signage improvement projects under the redevelopment project area modernization program. 
(Ord. No. 2017-10 , § 2, 1-23-2017)  
Chapter 42 - SIGNS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Highway Advertising Control Act, 225 ILCS 440/1 et seq.; municipal authority to regulate all street advertising and adult entertainment advertisements, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-15; authority for removal of unauthorized signs and billboards constituting obstructions, 605 ILCS 5/9-112. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 42-1. - Purpose. 
This chapter is adopted for the following purposes: 
(1)  To preserve and protect the public health, safety and welfare by regulating outdoor advertising and signs of all types. 
(2)  To maintain the inherent right of business to communicate reasonably, and identify their products and services by promoting the reasonable, orderly and effective display of signs and outdoor advertising. 
(3)  To enhance the physical appearance of the village, making it a more enjoyable and pleasing community. 
(4)  To reduce the sign or advertising distractions which may increase traffic accidents and result in visual congestion for pedestrians. 
(5)  To acknowledge the appropriate display of signs as necessary to public service and to the conduct of competitive commerce. 
(Code 1964, § 31-1; Ord. No. 1983-12, 6-27-1983)  
Sec. 42-2. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Ad bench sign means a bench sign used for advertising. 
Animated sign means a sign or part of a sign which changes physical position by any movement or rotation or any sign which presents the illusion of movement. 
Attention-getting device means any propeller, spinner, streamer, search light, balloon and similar device or ornamentation designed for purposes of promotion or advertising or attracting of promotion or advertising or attracting attention. 
Awning sign, marquee sign or canopy sign means any fixed, retractable or removable awning, marquee or canopy sign projected over, suspended above, or erected upon any public thoroughfare. 
Billboard or poster board means a single- or double-faced sign permanently erected on the premises, including changeable copy signs, used for the display of information not associated with the establishment located on the same premises as such sign. 
Business sign means a sign that directs attention to or advertises a business or profession conducted upon or to a commodity, service or entertainment sold or offered upon the zoning lot upon which such sign is erected. 
Changeable copy sign means a sign wherein provision is made for the manual or electronic change of letters or characters in the field in or upon the surface area of the sign. 
Commercial districts means those parcels, tracts or lots zoned as C-Business and D-Light Manufacturing according to the village zoning map. 
Erect means to build, construct, attach, hang, place, suspend, or affix and shall also include the painting of all signs. 
Externally illuminated sign means a sign illuminated by a source of sight which is cast upon, or falls upon, the surface or face of the sign to illuminate by reflection only. 
Festoon lighting means a group of two or more incandescent light bulbs hung or strung overhead, not on a building or structure, which are exposed to persons on a public right-of-way, or which are not shaded or hooded to prevent the direct rays of light from being visible from the property line. 
Flashing sign means any directly or indirectly illuminated sign, either stationary or animated, which exhibits changing natural or artificial light or color effects by any means whatsoever. 
Freestanding sign or ground sign means a sign completely or principally self-supported by posts or other supports independent of any building or other structure and anchored in or upon the ground. 
Identification sign means a sign which states the company name of any business including both national company and/or proprietor. 
Internally illuminated sign means a sign, all or any part of the letters or design of which is made of incandescent, neon, or other types of lamps; a sign with painted, flush or raised letters lighted by an electric lamp attached thereto; a sign having a border of incandescent or fluorescent lamps thereto attached and reflecting light thereon; or a translucent sign, whether lighted by electricity or other illuminant. 
Nameplate means a sign which displays only the name or address, or both, of the occupant, is nonelectrical, and does not exceed two square feet in area. 
Nonconforming sign means a sign, lawful at the time of the enactment of this chapter, which does not comply with all of the regulations of this chapter or any amendment hereto governing the use of signs. 
Obsolete sign means a sign which advertises a business which is not being presently conducted upon the premises or advertises a service, commodity or activity not sold or offered upon the premises on which the sign is located. 
Off-premises sign means a sign which directs attention to or advertises a use, business, commodity, service or activity not sold or offered upon the premises where the sign is located. (The term "off-premises sign" also includes those signs commonly known as business signs, billboards and poster panels.) 
Permittee means a person to whom a permit has been issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
Political sign means a sign announcing candidates seeking public political office or any sign concerning political issues and other issues pertinent thereto. 
Portable sign or sandwich sign means any sign that is not permanently affixed to a building structure, or the ground; a sign designed to be moved from place to place. Portable signs primarily include, but are not limited to, signs attached to wood or metal frames designed to be self-supporting and movable; and paper, cardboard, or canvas signs wrapped around supporting poles. Also included are those signs, commonly trailer mounted, which are designed to be moved from place to place. 
Projecting sign means a sign supported by a wall which projects more than 12 inches over any street, public sidewalk, alley or public way or public easement; or which projects more than 12 inches from the face of any building, structure or supporting wall. Any sign suspended under a marquee and in a place approximately perpendicular to the wall of the adjoining building shall not be deemed to be a projecting sign. 
Real estate sign means a sign located for purposes of advertising a parcel of land or a building as available for sale, rental or lease. 
Roof sign means a sign erected, constructed or maintained in whole or in part upon or over the roof of a building or structure. Roof signs shall not include those signs maintained upon the lower slope of a mansard roof which do not extend above the uppermost point of the lower slope. Such signs shall be classified as wall signs. 
Shopping center means any concentration of retail stores and service establishments in one or more buildings under single ownership or management with common parking facilities. 
Sign means any object, device, display, or structure or part thereof including any supports or appurtenant members which is used primarily to advertise, identify, display, direct or attract attention to an object, person, institution, organization, business, project, service, event or location by any means, including words, letters, figures, designs, symbols, fixtures, colors, motion illumination, or projected images. The term "sign" includes, but is not limited to, every projecting sign, wall sign, roof sign, billboard, poster board, free-standing sign, ground sign, window sign, vehicle sign, awning, canopy, marquee, changeable copy sign, illuminated sign, flashing sign, animated sign, temporary sign, portable sign, banner, pennant, valance, or other attention getting device, or other display whether affixed to a building or separate from any building. 
Sign surface area is the total exposed surface devoted to the sign's message, including all ornamentation, embellishment and symbols, but excluding the supporting structure which does not form part of the sign proper or of the display. The area of a sign composed of characters or words attached to a wall and/or window surface shall be the smallest rectangle which encloses the whole group. In the case of a ground sign designed with more than one exterior surface containing items of information, the sign surface area shall be computed as including only the maximum single display surface which is visible from any one ground position. 
Temperature signs are devices that periodically display the current temperature.
