State Law reference— Local Solid Waste Disposal Act, 415 ILCS 10/1 et seq.; Solid Waste Planning and Recycling Act, 415 ILCS 15/1 et seq.; Illinois Solid Waste Management Act, 415 ILCS 20/1 et seq.; disposal of refuse, garbage and ashes, 65 ILCS 5/11-19-1 et seq.; removal of garbage and debris, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-13; Environmental Protection Act, 415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.; "garbage" defined, 415 ILCS 5/3.200; "solid waste" defined, 415 ILCS 5/3.470; municipal solid waste landfill rules, 415 ILCS 5/22.40. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 44-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Bulk item means any discarded and unwanted large household appliances and furnishings that exceed 20 pounds in weight, including, but not limited to: refrigerators, freezers, stoves, trash compactors, washers, dryers, dishwashers, furnaces, hot water heaters, air conditioners, humidifiers, dehumidifiers, microwaves, water softeners, televisions, pianos, organs, tables, chairs, mattresses, box springs, bookcases, sofas, and similar furniture. 
Commercial collection means all refuse, household recyclables and yard waste, as well as both commercial and household construction and demolition debris, but not including commercial recyclables, collected from commercial, industrial and institutional facilities. 
Commercial construction and demolition debris means waste materials from contracted or commercial interior and exterior household construction, remodeling and repair projects, including, but not limited to, drywall, plywood, and paneling pieces, lumber, and other building materials; windows and doors; cabinets; carpeting; disassembled bathroom and kitchen fixtures, roofing and roofing materials, and sod, earth, clay, sand, concrete, rocks, and similar materials. Provided that such materials are not required by state or federal laws or regulations to be disposed of as hazardous materials, such as, but not limited to, asbestos or lead. 
Commercial recyclables are those items found as waste or byproduct in commercial, industrial and institutional facilities and for which special handling or disposal may be required. Such items and byproducts shall include, but not be limited to: used tires; used batteries; contaminated medical supplies; grease and food renderings; cleaning fluids used by commercial dry cleaners; bulk used motor oil; and surplus or defective metal extrusions, shavings or filings. 
Construction and demolition debris means waste materials from interior and exterior household construction, remodeling and repair projects, including, but not limited to, drywall, plywood, and paneling pieces, lumber and other building materials; windows and doors; cabinets; carpeting; disassembled bathroom and kitchen fixtures; roofing and roofing materials; and sod, earth, clay, sand, concrete, rocks, and similar materials, provided that such materials are not required by state or federal laws or regulations to be disposed of as hazardous materials, such as, but not limited to, asbestos or lead. 
Hazardous materials are those materials requiring special disposal methods by state or federal laws, regulations or agencies. 
Household construction and demolition debris means waste materials from "do-it-yourself" scale interior and exterior household construction, remodeling and repair projects, including, but not limited to, drywall, plywood, and paneling pieces, lumber and other building materials; windows and doors; cabinets; carpeting; disassembled bathroom and kitchen fixtures; and small amounts of sod, earth, clay, sand, concrete, rocks, and similar materials. 
Household recyclables or household recyclable materials means, at a minimum, newspapers and inserts; glass bottles and jars of all color; food and beverage cans (steel, aluminum and bi-metal); mixed paper which includes magazines, telephone books, chipboard (single-layer cardboard used for packaging cereal, crackers, tissue, food boxes and similar products), junk mail (brochures, advertisements, fliers, postcards, greeting cards, window envelopes, credit card bills and similar correspondence), writing paper, stationery, computer paper, note paper, letterhead and similar products, Kraft paper bags, corrugated cardboard, Type 1 PET and Type 2 HDPE plastics, empty open latex cans, empty aerosol paint and spray cans; and clean aluminum foil and aluminum containers. 
Premises means any residential dwelling, building, flat, commercial or industrial establishment, office building, hotel, motel, church, hospital, or any other structure in which people occupy or commerce is conducted, and including the entire parcels of real estate on which the building is located or which are used in conjunction with said building. 
Refuse means all discarded and unwanted putrescible and nonputrescible household and kitchen wastes, necessarily used for packaging, storing, preparing and consuming the same, usually defined as garbage; and all combustible and noncombustible waste materials resulting from the usual domestic housekeeping, including, but not limited to, containers; crockery and other containers; metal; paper of all types, including newspaper, books, magazines, and catalogues; boxes and cartons; cold ashes; furniture, furnishing fixtures; household appliances of all kinds; textiles and leather; dead animals and animal waste; "unacceptable refuse" as may hereafter be prescribed by the village. 
Residential collection means the collection of all refuse, recyclables and yard waste from all single-family, two-family and multifamily dwelling units. 
Roll-off container means any container specifically utilized for the temporary storage of refuse or construction and demolition debris commonly known as "dumpsters." 
Scavenger , for residential purposes, shall have the same definition as residential collection. For the purposes of nonresidential service, the term "scavenger" shall mean any of the collectors described in division 3 of article III of this chapter. 
Sharps container means any container specifically manufactured for the disposal of sharp medical waste. 
Sharps medical waste means any type of product capable of puncturing or lacerating the skin that is designed or used to treat, diagnose, or prevent a disease or medical condition, including, but not limited to, scalpels and hypodermic needles. 
Yard waste or landscape waste means grass clippings; leaves, branches and brush, other than yard and garden trimming; vines, garden plants and flowers; weeds, tree droppings (such as pine cones and crabapples); and other similar organic waste materials accumulated as the result of the cultivation and maintenance of lawns, shrubbery, vines, trees and gardens. Holiday trees and greens shall be treated as refuse and not as yard waste. Sod shall be treated as refuse and not as yard waste. 
(Code 1964, § 13-1; Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994; Ord. No. 2017-53 , § 2, 9-11-2017)  
Sec. 44-2. - Penalty. 
Any person that violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be fined no less than $25.00 or more than $500.00 for each offense. 
(Code 1964, § 13-14; Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-3. - Collection and disposal required; accumulation prohibited. 
(a)  General refuse, household recyclables and yard waste shall be collected and disposed of by the village or its agents or persons, firms or corporations with whom it may contract or license to perform such services from time to time and shall not be collected or disposed of in any other manner, except as provided in this chapter or as may be reflected in an existing contract or licensing agreement. 
(b)  No such general refuse, household recycling or yard waste, except controlled landscape composting, shall be allowed to accumulate on any property or premises within the village for a period longer than the time between scheduled collections by the village, its agents or contractors at said property or premises for the purpose of collecting the same. It shall be the duty of every owner, occupant or agent of any premises to comply with the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1964, § 13-6; Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-4. - Unlawful acts. 
It is unlawful: 
(1)  For any person to place any refuse, recyclable or yard waste for collection in the public streets or alleys in the village except in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  For any person, other than a law enforcement officer during a bona fide investigation or an employee of a contractor licensed under this chapter or with which the village has contracted, during the course of collection, to sort through, tamper or remove any contents deposited into any refuse, recyclable material or yard waste receptacle which is placed at a location for collection. Each sorting, tampering or removal from each separate receptacle shall constitute a separate and distinct violation. 
(3)  For any person to counterfeit any yard waste or extra refuse sticker. 
(4)  For any person other than an employee of a contractor licensed under this chapter or with which the village has contracted during the course of collection to remove any yard waste or extra refuse sticker from a refuse or yard waste receptacle. 
(5)  For any person to deposit any refuse or yard waste produced in or brought into or upon that person's premises into a refuse or yard waste receptacle of another person. 
(6)  For any person to pile or deposit garbage or refuse of any kind whatsoever or to accumulate any offensive or nauseous substance other than within a proper and authorized receptacle within the limits of the village, or for any person to unload, discharge or put upon or along the line of any railroad, sidewalk, street, park, private or public place within the village, or upon any vacant lot, garbage, refuse or other offensive, hazardous or nauseous substance or for any cars loaded with or having upon them any such substance to be allowed to remain or stand on or along any railroad or street within the village, within 300 yards of any inhabited dwelling. 
(7)  For any person to permit or suffer any garbage, offal, refuse or animal or vegetable matter, which is liable to become putrid or offensive or injurious to health, to remain on any premises used or occupied by him for a longer period than four hours at any one time. 
(8)  For any person to deposit or place in any manner whatsoever any refuse in or upon any sidewalk, street, alley, park, or public place in the village. This section shall not apply to: 
a.  The deposit of material under a permit issued by the village. 
b.  Goods, wares or merchandise deposited upon any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place temporarily in the necessary course of trade and removed therefrom within two hours after being so deposited. 
c.  Lawfully acceptable articles or things deposited in the village sewerage system through lawful drains and in accordance with the ordinances of the village. 
(9)  For any person to dispose of yard waste on any property, provided that compostable material such as grass trimmings, wood waste, leaves, weeds and other garden refuse may be placed in a compost pile provided it is placed in such a way so the material will not be windblown. The depositing of garbage, pet waste, meat scraps or other materials that may attract animals or vermin to the compost pile, or which may produce an obnoxious odor, shall be prohibited. A compost pile shall not be placed in any required front yard as defined by the village zoning code and shall not be closer than eight feet to any side yard lot line nor closer than eight feet to any rear property line where an alley does not exist and in no case shall a compost pile be located in any front yard or side or rear yard drainage or utility easement. A compost pile shall be no more than five feet in height and shall not have a maximum ground or base area of more than 50 square feet, shall be limited to the exclusive use of the occupant of the premises, and shall be limited to one such pile per zoning lot. 
(10)  For any person to burn general refuse, hazardous material, construction waste, recyclable material or yard waste within the village. 
(11)  For any person to bury general refuse, hazardous material, construction waste, recyclable material or yard waste within the village. 
(12)  For any owner of any commercial or industrial premises to contract for collection less than once per week. 
(13)  For any person other than the village, its agents, persons, firms or corporations that have contracted with the village for or are otherwise licensed or authorized to perform refuse removal, to remove, or dispose of any refuse in any manner except as otherwise provided by this chapter. 
(Code 1964, § 13-11; Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994; Ord. No. 95-19, 5-22-1995)  
Secs. 44-5—44-26. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - RESIDENTIAL FEES 
 
Sec. 44-27. - Residential collection contracts. 
The village board shall, from time to time, contract for the collection of residential refuse, recyclables and yard waste. Only such firm holding a valid contractual agreement with the village may hereafter be licensed to provide residential service for residential refuse within the village. 
(Code 1964, § 13-2; Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-28. - Rates for residential collection. 
(a)  The rates for collection of general refuse, yard waste and recyclable materials from residential units may be established at any given time by contract entered into by the village and any qualified contractor. These rates shall be construed as being adjusted pursuant to the terms of any such contract and shall be enforceable as if fully set forth herein. 
(b)  Each single-family and two-family dwelling unit located within the village shall pay a fee for garbage, refuse and recycling collection, and charges or costs incurred for services rendered such as administrative or special disposal costs regardless of whether that residential customer generates any garbage, refuse or recyclable material for collection during any billing cycle. 
(c)  The fee shall be included on the customer's water bill and shall be due and payable in advance at the same time the water bill is due and payable. If service is commenced after the 15th day of any month, there shall be no charge for that month. If service is commenced on or before the 15th day of any month, the full charge shall be collected. 
(d)  Any subsequent changes in the administrative or disposal fee shall be approved by the village board and shall be promulgated by the village staff prior to becoming effective. 
(e)  In the event the customer fails to pay any charge for garbage or refuse collection or administrative/disposal fees within 15 days after the date of billing, then that customer shall be subject to a late charge of ten percent of the amount of the bill. 
(f)  However, provided that when a customer shall have faithfully and timely paid such charges for the preceding 12-month period and said payment is not made more than ten calendar days after the due date; and, payment is made at the village hall during regular hours of operation, any late charge so due for late payment for that particular billing period shall be waived. 
(g)  For residential buildings containing three or more dwelling units, charges for garbage, refuse and recycling collection, and charges such as administrative and special disposal costs rendered shall be billed by the contractor directly to the owner or agent of such multifamily structure having the responsibility for management of said property. 
(h)  The contractor shall inform the village within 48 hours of the failure of any multifamily customer to make timely payment after proper billing. 
(Code 1964, §§ 13-3, 13-4; Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994; Ord. No. 95-19, 5-22-1995)  
Sec. 44-29. - Disposition of revenues. 
(a)  All of the revenues and monies received for the collection of refuse shall be kept and maintained in a separate fund and used only for the purpose of operating and maintaining refuse, yard waste and recyclable collection services, including, but not limited to, contracted obligations, disposal fees, refuse and recycling education and administrative costs such as billing and collection of payments. 
(b)  No monies shall be permanently transferred from such fund for any purpose except upon the vote of the majority members of the village board and then only in the event that such transfer is from funds declared to be surplus over and above any and all requirements of the operation of the services provided for in this section. 
(Code 1964, § 13-5; Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Secs. 44-30—44-46. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 44-47. - Title to refuse, recyclable material and yard waste. 
Title to all refuse and yard waste shall pass to the contractor when the material is placed into the collection vehicle. Title to all recyclable materials shall pass to the contractor when the material is placed upon a public right-of-way (alley, street or parkway, as applicable) on the day of collection. 
(Code 1964, § 13-13; Ord. No. 4-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-48. - Refuse containers. 
The owner, occupant or agent of any premises located within the village shall provide and keep on the lot on which the building, use or business is situated, suitable watertight and durable with close-fitting covers, receptacles of sufficient size to handle the accumulation of general refuse on the premises during the intervals between collections without being filled beyond their capacity, unless approved containers are provided by a waste contractor contracting with the village. 
(Code 1964, § 13-7; Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-49. - Recyclable containers. 
(a)  The contractor providing refuse service shall furnish for the collection of household recyclables a minimum of one suitable and durable container not less than 64 gallons in capacity for single-family and two-family dwellings, and one of sufficient size to handle the containment of recyclable materials for multifamily, commercial, industrial or institutional structures or facilities. 
(b)  Said containers for recyclable materials furnished by the contractor shall remain the property of the contractor and shall be supplied to the property being served at no separate charge. 
(c)  Individuals, persons, companies or firms shall not receive any billing or other credit for the failure to utilize recycling containers. 
(d)  Extra recycling containers purchased independently by property owners, occupants or tenants shall remain the property of the person or persons acquiring the same. 
(e)  Containers furnished by the contractor shall be clearly marked as to their intended use, such as refuse or recyclable materials. Containers furnished by other individuals shall also be clearly identified where their purpose is for a use other than for general refuse purposes. 
(Code 1964, § 13-7; Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-50. - Size of containers. 
(a)  In the case of single-family and two-family dwellings, the size of such receptacle shall: 
(1)  For general residential refuse, have a capacity not to exceed 64 gallons for any one container. 
(2)  For yard waste, a permanent receptacle shall not exceed 64 gallons in capacity or 50 pounds in weight nor shall a disposable receptacle be anything other than a biodegradable paper bag with a capacity not to exceed 64 gallons for any one container. 
(3)  For recyclable materials, have a capacity not less than 20 gallons nor more than 64 gallons for any one container. 
(b)  In the case of multifamily dwellings, the size of receptacles for general refuse, recyclable materials and yard waste shall be determined by agreement between the property owner or agent, provided that such receptacles be provided in sufficient size and quantity to take care of their respective contents for a period of at least seven days. 
(c)  In the case of commercial, industrial, institutional and all other nonresidential buildings and structures, the size of receptacles for general refuse, recyclable materials and yard waste shall be determined by agreement between the property owner or agent provided that such receptacles be provided in sufficient size and quantity to take care of their respective contents for the period between collections, further provided that such collection shall not exceed seven days in duration. 
(Code 1964, § 13-7; Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-51. - Yard waste. 
(a)  All yard waste shall be placed in readily identifiable approved containers identified for such purpose. A sticker approved by the village shall be affixed to the container for pickup. 
(b)  Twigs, brush and branches not exceeding four feet in length, nor more than three inches in diameter shall be bagged, placed in containers herein described or tied with biodegradable twine in bundles not to exceed 24 inches in diameter. Such bundles shall also have an approved sticker affixed to each bundle. 
(c)  Any yard waste in a container not bearing the approved sticker shall not be collected. 
(d)  All commercial landscape maintenance firms, tree contractors and similar services shall provide for their own disposal of yard waste, brush and logs and similar debris through legal and authorized means. 
(e)  No yard waste shall be placed in any general refuse or recyclable container nor be included with any other garbage or material identified in this chapter. 
(f)  The cost of the approved sticker which shall be sold by the village and at other locations within the village shall be used by the village in whole or part for the collection of yard waste. 
(Code 1964, § 13-8(B); Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-52. - Sharp medical waste. 
(a)  Sharp medical waste shall not be deposited in any other place or manner in the village than as herein provided. 
(b)  Acceptable means of disposing of sharp medical waste include disposal in an approved medical waste box, such as a sharps container, or disposal in a heavy plastic container, such as a laundry soap bottle, providing that the lid is permanently affixed thereto using tape or another means, and the container is marked "Medical Waste: Do Not Open." 
(c)  No container for sharp medical waste or loose sharp medical waste may be mixed with recyclables. 
(d)  Any licensed contractor may refuse to pick up any refuse or recyclable containing sharp medical waste not separately contained and prepared as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1964, § 13-12; Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Secs. 44-53—44-77. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - RESIDENTIAL 
 
Sec. 44-78. - Time and place of collection. 
(a)  The collection of residential refuse, household recyclables and yard waste shall not commence before 7:00 a.m. and the collection shall cease by 7:00 p.m. Residential collection will generally be limited to the Monday through Friday work week; however, when a holiday occurs during the week, the collection shall be rescheduled to the next working day, or on Saturday, as necessary, for that week only. 
(b)  Where curbside collection is made, no refuse, recyclables or yard waste may be placed out for pickup more than 24 hours in advance of the scheduled pickup. Emptied refuse, recyclable and reusable yard waste receptacles must be stored wholly upon the property being serviced no later than 9:00 p.m. on the day of the scheduled pickup. 
(Code 1964, § 13-8(F); Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-79. - Preparation of refuse for disposal. 
Each occupant, tenant or person in the possession of any premises shall cause all garbage and refuse produced in or brought into or upon such premises to be thoroughly drained of surplus liquid, securely wrapped and be deposited within a proper and authorized receptacle as soon as the same is produced or brought into or upon such premises. Combustible materials shall be securely wrapped in such manner as to prevent the blowing of the same by the wind and shall be deposited in the receptacle provided for such materials. 
(Code 1964, § 13-8(A); Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-80. - Number of refuse receptacles; excess refuse stickers. 
For single-family and two-family dwellings, the number of authorized general refuse receptacles allowed per dwelling per pickup shall be that number contained within the then-current contract in effect between the village and the residential waste hauler. For general refuse not being able to be contained wholly within the limit of the authorized receptacles and exceeding the number of receptacles allowed per dwelling per pickup, a sticker approved by the village shall be affixed to the excess container for pickup. Excess general refuse containers shall not exceed 64 gallons in capacity. 
(Code 1964, § 13-8(C); Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-81. - Recyclable preparation and disposal. 
Recyclable materials shall be placed in a container supplied by the contractor or approved by him from time to time. Preparation of recyclable materials for collection shall be under the direction of the contractor. There shall be no limit upon the number of receptacles allowed for pickup of recyclable materials which were generated by persons occupying or residing within the dwelling being served. 
(Code 1964, § 13-8(D); Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-82. - Alternative methods of recyclable disposal. 
Nothing in this division shall be construed to prevent residents from taking or giving recyclables generated from their own households to a recyclable drop-off center, buy-back center, or other recycling program of their choice independent of the residential refuse and recycling service provided hereby. 
(Code 1964, § 13-8(E); Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Secs. 44-83—44-107. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - NONRESIDENTIAL 
 
Sec. 44-108. - Classifications. 
Nonresidential collections of refuse, garbage and recyclable materials shall be classified into four categories as provided in this division. 
(Code 1964, § 13-9; Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-109. - Regular commercial, industrial and institutional service. 
The type of waste collected by these haulers would involve those materials normally found in residential households, but likely at a larger scale or in a substantially different mix. This type of service shall provide a recycling component, minimally to the level provided to all residential customers in the village. Such recycling element shall be included in the base price for commercial service, and no deduction for nonuse of such service shall be allowed. 
(Code 1964, § 13-9(A); Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-110. - Commercial recyclable service. 
This type of service provides specialized, but nonhazardous removal of waste and byproducts, generally of a manufacturing or assembly process. The types of materials which could be handled by this type of hauler could include, but is not limited to, restaurant grease and renderings, metal shavings and defective parts, wood chips and damaged automotive parts. 
(Code 1964, § 13-9(B); Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-111. - Commercial construction and demolition service. 
The services provided are generally related to one-time, or as-needed services. The services generally consist of the drop-off of a larger steel container to a specific project or work site. Common uses include, but are not limited to, roofing and reroofing debris collection, garage and other structural demolition, and remodeling. 
(Code 1964, § 13-9(C); Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-112. - Hazardous waste service. 
This type of waste, its collection, hauling and disposal are governed by state and federal statutes and regulations and are under the review and control of an appropriate state or federal agency. This type of waste includes, but is not limited to, radioactive materials, asbestos, lead, and medical waste. 
(Code 1964, § 13-9(D); Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Secs. 44-113—44-137. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - CONTAINER REGISTRATIONS AND PERMITS 
 
Sec. 44-138. - Applicability. 
The restrictions imposed herein shall apply to all roll-off containers, other containers in excess of one cubic yard for the collection and storage of construction and demolition debris, or any similar obstruction placed on private property, any public street, public sidewalk, or public alley at any time, or moved across public right-of-way for placement on private property. 
(Ord. No. 2007-73, § 1(6-81(1)), 8-13-2007; Ord. No. 2017-53 , § 3, 9-11-2017)  
Sec. 44-139. - Registration required. 
All persons, companies, corporations, or entities providing any roll-off container or other container for the collection and storage of construction and demolition debris in the village shall complete a registration form and pay a scavenger's license registration fee as required by this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2007-73, § 1(6-81(2)a), 8-13-2007; Ord. No. 2017-53 , § 4, 9-11-2017)  
Sec. 44-140. - Scavenger's license required. 
All persons, companies, corporations, or entities providing any roll-off container or other container for the collection and storage of construction and demolition debris in the village shall obtain a scavenger's license from the village prior to delivering any roll-off container or other container for the collection and storage of construction and demolition debris to a location within the village. All persons, companies, corporations, or entities providing any roll-off container or other container for the collection and storage of construction and demolition debris in the village shall renew its scavenger's license each year to continue to deliver roll-off containers or other containers for the collection and storage of construction and demolition debris to locations within the village. 
(Ord. No. 2017-53 , § 5, 9-11-2017) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2017-53 , § 5, adopted Sep. 11, 2017, amended § 44-140 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 44-140 pertained to contractor's license required and derived from Ord. No. 2007-73, § 1(6-81(2)b), adopted August 13, 2007.  
Sec. 44-141. - Permit required; fee. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, or cause to be placed, a roll-off container or other container for the collection and storage of construction and demolition debris on any public or private property within the village without having first obtained a roll-off container permit. 
(b)  An application for a roll-off container permit requesting the location of a roll-off container on private property or on a public street, along with the required permit fee, shall be filed with the zoning enforcement administrator by the owner or authorized agent of the owner of the property proposed to be serviced by the roll-off container. The zoning enforcement administrator shall review the permit application; and, if the application discloses that the roll-off container complies with the requirements of this chapter, the zoning enforcement administrator shall issue the permit to the applicant. 
(c)  A roll-off container permit is valid for the period that the roll-off container is located at the permitted location, not to exceed 30 days for projects: 
(1)  Having a building permit value of $100,000.00 or less; or 
(2)  Projects adding less than 50 percent to the interior space of an existing building; 
(d)  A roll-off container permit is valid for the period that the roll-off container is located at the permitted location, not to exceed 90 days for projects: 
(1)  Having a building permit value in excess of $100,000.00; 
(2)  Projects adding 50 percent or more to the interior space of an existing building; or 
(3)  Projects involving the demolition of an existing building and replacement of the demolished building with a new building. 
(e)  The roll-off container permit shall be obtained by the owner or authorized agent of the owner of the property where the roll-off container or other container for the collection and storage of construction and demolition debris will be placed or, if the roll-off container is to be located on a public street, the permit shall be obtained by the owner or authorized agent of the owner of the property from which the construction and demolition debris placed in the roll-off container originates. A roll-off container permit is renewable once for a like period of time as the original roll-off container permit upon payment of the renewal fee and the filing of a renewal application with the zoning enforcement officer. After the initial renewal period, a roll-off container permit may be renewed by the village manager for additional periods of up to 30 days upon the payment of a renewal fee and the filing of an application setting forth circumstances beyond the control of the owner or occupant of the property justifying the renewal. 
(f)  The permit fee and, if applicable, the permit renewal fee shall be paid in accordance with the village fee schedule. 
(g)  A hold harmless agreement signed by the owner of the property where the roll-off container or other container for the collection and storage of construction and demolition debris will be placed shall be submitted prior to the roll-off container permit's being issued. 
(h)  It shall be a condition to the issuance of a roll-off container permit that the service providing the roll-off container shall hold a current, valid scavenger's license with the village. 
(i)  A roll-off container permit shall not be required for any construction projects having roll-off container use approved by the village board of trustees as a part of final planned development approval. 
(Ord. No. 2007-73, § 1(6-81(3)), 8-13-2007; Ord. No. 2017-53 , § 6, 9-11-2017)  
Sec. 44-142. - Location and placement. 
(a)  All roll-off containers shall be located on private property, except when it is not possible to place a roll-off container on private property; a maximum 20-yard roll-off container may be placed in the street in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Roll-off containers exceeding 20 cubic yards are strictly prohibited from being located within the village. Freight containers are strictly prohibited from being located within the village. The placement of roll-off containers on public alleys or parkways is strictly prohibited. 
(c)  No roll-off container shall be allowed to be placed in any manner so as to block any public street, sidewalk, or alley for use by vehicles, pedestrians, or bicycles. No such roll-off container shall be allowed to be placed within 15 feet from the corner of any street or alley. 
(d)  When a roll-off container will be located on a street where there is parking on the opposite side of the street, the permit holder shall provide flashing barricades in the street parking areas on the side opposite from where the roll-off container will be placed, to ensure adequate space for vehicular passage. 
(e)  The permit holder shall ensure that the placement of the roll-off container does not interfere with snow removal, street cleaning, or public improvements. 
(f)  Roll-off containers shall have no signage other than the name, address and telephone number of the person or firm engaged in the business of renting or otherwise placing the roll-off container. 
(g)  Roll-off containers shall be maintained in a good state of repair, free from rust, peeling paint and other forms of visible deterioration. 
(Ord. No. 2007-73, § 1(6-81(4)), 8-13-2007; Ord. No. 2017-53 , § 7, 9-11-2017)  
Sec. 44-143. - Care of public right-of-way. 
(a)  The owner or authorized agent of any property with a roll-off container or other container located on a public street shall place or cause a flashing barricade to be placed on either side of the roll-off container. 
(b)  Any roll-off container or delivery truck delivering a roll-off container traversing the public parkway shall have padding, plywood, or a like material placed under the truck or roll-off container to prevent damage to or depressions in the public parkway. 
(c)  The roll-off container permit holder is responsible for any damage to the public right-of-way. In the event of damage to the public right-of-way, the department of public works shall estimate, or cause an estimate to be made of the cost to repair the damage; and the permit holder will be notified of the cost of repair. Failure of the permit holder to pay the cost to repair the damage within 30 days of receipt of the estimate of the cost of repair shall be punishable by a fine in the amount of $750.00. 
(Ord. No. 2007-73, § 1(6-81(5)), 8-13-2007; Ord. No. 2017-53 , § 8, 9-11-2017)  
Secs. 44-144—44-169. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - REFUSE COLLECTORS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 44-170—44-191. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - RESIDENTIAL 
 
Secs. 44-192—44-220. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - NONRESIDENTIAL 
 
Sec. 44-221. - Registration required; fees. 
(a)  All firms described as providing nonresidential refuse collection are required to be registered before operating within the corporate limits of the village. A registration form can be obtained from the village manager's office. 
(b)  Registration shall be valid for a period of 12 months and shall be renewed annually on or before June 1 of each year. Firms seeking a registration renewal shall file an application 45 days in advance of the June 1 renewal. Initial registration issued after June 1 shall be subject to a June 1 renewal. 
(c)  An initial nonrefundable, nonproratable application fee in the amount provided in the village fee schedule, separate and distinct from any other fee, bond or license charge, shall be required to accompany the completed application form prior to the village undertaking any review or approval of any registration or license request. 
(Code 1964, § 13-10(A); Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-222. - Business license required. 
(a)  No firm providing regular commercial, industrial and institutional service; commercial recyclable service; or commercial construction and demolition services shall provide such services within the corporate limits of the village without first filing for and receiving a business license. 
(b)  A business license form can be obtained from the village manager's office. 
(c)  All licenses shall be subject to approval by the village board and fees shall be as provided in the village fee schedule. 
(d)  Licenses shall be valid for a period of 12 months and shall be renewed annually on or before June 1. Firms seeking a license renewal shall file said application 45 days in advance of the June 1 renewal. Initial licenses issued after June 1 shall be subject to a June 1 renewal. 
(Code 1964, § 13-10(B); Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-223. - Licensing conditions. 
In issuing commercial collection licenses as required by this section, the village shall seek to maximize the quality of service provided. Therefore, all applicants shall meet and adhere to the following conditions: 
(1)  All firms applying for a commercial collection license shall be required to conform to all applicable local, county, state and federal regulations governing refuse, yard waste and recycling, their collection, transportation and processing or disposal. 
(2)  Application and annual fees paid for the right to collect refuse, yard waste and recyclable materials from commercial, industrial, and institutional establishments within the village shall be paid at the time a license application is filed and thereafter at the time of renewal pursuant to charges as provided in the village fee schedule. 
(3)  A complete listing of all customers served shall be submitted by all licensed contractors within 90 days of initial licensing, and amended as of the first of each month for additions and deletions thereafter. 
(4)  A license to provide for commercial collection shall not be reassigned and is not transferable. 
(5)  As part of the application process, the applicant shall supply information including, but not limited to, operation office location; equipment storage facilities and transfer stations; a listing of the vehicular equipment intended for utilization within the village; public customer telephone numbers; emergency telephone numbers; and the listing of owned or leased disposal or recycling sites intended for use during the licensing period, all of which must be properly approved by the state. 
(6)  The servicing location must be equipped with sufficient telephones and shall have a responsive person in charge during the times of collection and at least from 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., Monday through Friday, except during village-designated holidays. 
(7)  In the event a firm licensed for commercial collections in the village relocates any or all of its operations, written notice of such change shall be promptly submitted to the village. 
(Code 1964, § 13-10(C); Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-224. - Service procedure and requirements. 
(a)  Service provided Mondays through Saturdays shall not commence before 7:00 a.m. and shall cease by 7:00 p.m. While circumstances may require Sunday collection, on that day the contractor shall not commence work before 9:00 a.m. and shall cease collection by 7:00 p.m. 
(b)  All refuse, recyclables, and yard waste collected must be removed from the village as soon as the materials are collected, but in any event no later than 7:00 p.m. of the date of collection. 
(c)  Fees charged for the collection or processing of refuse and yard waste shall be negotiated directly between the contractor and the customer. 
(d)  Contractors licensed to provide regular commercial, industrial and institutional service shall provide recycling service of the materials collected in the village's regular residential recycling program at no additional fee to their commercial, industrial or institutional customers. Such listing of recyclable material may be obtained from the village manager's office. Such contractors shall be required to offer a minimum of a once-per-week pickup of refuse and recycling materials. 
(e)  Contractors licensed to provide regular commercial, industrial and institutional service shall provide for the collection of yard waste from their customers as required. 
(f)  The contractor shall collect and maintain accurate data and records of the refuse, recyclable material and any yard waste collection programs, including, but not limited to, a total weight or cubic yardage of general refuse, recyclables and yard waste on a monthly basis; recycling information per month by category, sales and weight; the names of all disposal facilities and transfer stations, composting sites, processing facilities for refuse, recyclables and yard waste, and other such information as may be required for the providing of accurate information to any local, country, state or federal agency requiring the reporting of such information. 
(g)  All contractors shall furnish competent employees in providing refuse collection services. Employees shall wear proper attire at all times while performing work within the village. 
(h)  All contractors shall be equipped and possess the competence necessary to develop and operate the level of services for which they seek to be licensed by the village. The village reserves the right to conduct such investigations as necessary to verify the contractor's ability to provide service, including, but not limited to, field inspection of operation sites, equipment and equipment yards. 
(i)  All vehicles used for the collection of refuse, recyclable materials and yard waste shall be maintained in good working order and appearance, free of rust, and shall be clean at the start of each collection day. No vehicle shall be operated on village streets or alleys which leaks any fluids from the engine or compacting mechanism. In the event that any vehicle is not properly operable, a suitable vehicle shall immediately be provided that complies with the terms herein. All vehicles shall display the name of the contractor, a local phone number, and a vehicle identification number that is clearly visible on both sides. 
(j)  All vehicles shall be fully enclosed, leak-proof and operated in such a way that no refuse, recyclables or yard waste leaks, spills or blows off the vehicles. Should any refuse, recyclable material or yard waste leak, spill or blow off a vehicle due to vehicle operator's failure to properly monitor the load or to close openings or due to failure of any mechanism, the contractor shall be responsible for collecting or cleaning up such litter or fluids. Drain plugs, if available, shall be kept closed except during collections made in rainy weather. All vehicles shall be made available for inspection during regular business hours at the request of the village, in addition to yearly inspection requirements of the contractor's annual business licenses. 
(k)  All spills of any refuse, recyclable materials or yard waste on any private property, parkways, streets, sidewalks, alleys or other public place shall be immediately cleaned up; and the area shall be left in a neat and cleanly manner. 
(Code 1964, § 13-10(D); Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-225. - Insurance required. 
(a)  All firms registered or licensed under the provisions of this article shall maintain the following insurance coverage limits: 
(1)  Workers' compensation and occupational diseases insurance in the amount required by state law. 
(2)  General liability insurance, as follows: 
a.  Bodily injury with limits of not less than $1,000,000.00 each occurrence and $2,000,000.00 aggregate. 
b.  Property damage with limits of not less than $1,000,000.00 each occurrence and $2,000,000.00 aggregate. 
c.  Contractual insurance, broad form, with limits of not less than $1,000,000.00 each occurrence and $2,000,000.00 aggregate. 
(3)  Motor vehicle liability insurance, as follows: 
a.  Bodily injury with limits of not less than $1,000,000.00 each occurrence and $2,000,000.00 aggregate. 
b.  Property damage with limits of not less than $1,000,000.00 each occurrence and $2,000,000.00 aggregate. 
c.  Umbrella or excess liability coverage $5,000,000.00 per occurrence and in the aggregate. 
(b)  Certificates of insurance to be supplied to the village prior to undertaking any work in the village. 
(c)  Notification of insurance cancellation must be made a minimum of 30 days prior to the effective date of such cancellation. 
(Code 1964, § 13-10(E); Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Sec. 44-226. - Denial of issuance and revocation. 
The village board reserves the right to deny a license application. In addition, an issued license shall be revoked for reasons including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Failure to pay the annual license fee, or any applicable individual fee. 
(2)  Failure to comply with any condition or term of this chapter or other applicable codes and ordinances of the village. 
(3)  Failure to comply with any applicable county, state or federal regulations regarding the operation of the types of services intended to be governed by this chapter. 
(4)  Unsatisfactory performance resulting in danger to public health, safety and general welfare. 
(5)  The misrepresentation of any material fact by the applicant or any person providing information on behalf of the applicant. 
(Code 1964, § 13-10(F); Ord. No. 94-20, 5-2-1994)  
Chapter 46 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND RIGHTS-OF-WAY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Parade Police Protection Charge Waiver Act, 50 ILCS 730/0.01 et seq.; municipal administration of streets, 605 ILCS 5/7-101 et seq.; general highway provisions, 605 ILCS 5/9-101 et seq.; municipal authority over streets and public ways, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-1 et seq.; municipal sidewalk construction and repair, 65 ILCS 5/11-84-1 et seq.; municipal street railways, 65 ILCS 5/11-90-1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 46-1—46-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - STREET AND SIDEWALK USE  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 46-19. - Obstructions and encroachments prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct or encroach upon any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place in the village, except as otherwise specifically provided in this article. 
(b)  It shall also be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, in person or by his agent, employee or servant, to place, cast, throw, sweep, sift or deposit in any manner in or upon any street, alley or other public place in the village any kind of dirt, rubbish, waste, tables, chairs, other articles, things or substance whatsoever, whether liquid or solid, including snow. 
(c)  No person, firm or corporation shall place, cast, throw, sweep, sift or deposit any of the aforementioned items anywhere within the jurisdiction of the village in such manner that it may be carried or deposited in whole or in part, by the action of the sun, wind, rain or snow, into or on any of the aforementioned places. 
(Code 1940, § 26.001(5); Code 1964, § 24-1; Ord. No. 1979-72, 10-22-1979; Ord. No. 2007-64, § 1, 7-9-2007) 
State Law reference— Municipal authority over streets and public ways, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-1 et seq.; authority of municipalities to prevent and remove encroachments or obstructions upon streets and other municipal property, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-3.  
Secs. 46-20—46-41. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - SIDEWALK CAFES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to construct, repair and regulate use of sidewalks, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-13. 
 
Sec. 46-42. - Permit required. 
(a)  No person shall operate or maintain a sidewalk cafe on property occupied, maintained or controlled by the village without first having obtained a permit from the village clerk upon approval of the village manager. 
(b)  Application for such permit shall be made on forms provided by the village by the owner of the property fronting the public property on which such sidewalk cafe is to be operated or maintained by the owner or lessee thereof. 
(c)  Such permit shall be issued in accordance with the standards established herein. 
(Code 1964, § 24-3; Ord. No. 99-35, 10-11-1999; Ord. No. 03-19, 6-9-2003)  
Sec. 46-43. - Additional and supporting documentation. 
(a)  The application for permit under this article shall be accompanied by the following: 
(1)  Evidence of a general liability insurance with limits of not less than $1,000,000.00 with coverage approved by the village attorney. Such insurance shall be issued by a company authorized to do business in this state and shall show the village as additional insured. The policy shall not be cancelled unless 30 days prior written notice is given to the village. 
(2)  An indemnification and hold harmless agreement in a form approved by the village attorney, in which the applicant agrees to indemnify and hold the village harmless against all lawsuits and related costs, fees and expenses, including attorney's fees, arising out of the use of the public sidewalks as authorized by this section or arising out of any acts or omission of the applicant. 
(3)  A drawing depicting the location of any and all proposed tables, chairs, waste receptacles and other fixtures to be located as part of the operations of the outdoor cafe. The drawing shall depict the relationship of outdoor cafe fixtures to existing features located within the public right-of-way between the applicant's business and the street curb nearest the property and shall show existing lighting fixtures, landscaping materials, as well as any other items located within the public area. Dimensions shall be shown between proposed outdoor cafe fixtures and any public features so as to clearly show conformity to setbacks and separations required by this section. 
(b)  In the event that an applicant for a sidewalk cafe permit under this article also is seeking a Class S1 subsidiary liquor license, then, in addition to any other information required under this article, the applicant shall include detailed information on removable perimeter barriers to enclose the proposed sidewalk cafe area, which barriers, at a minimum, shall be three feet tall, and designed to clearly delineate the sidewalk cafe area from the remainder of the public right-of-way. 
(Code 1964, § 24-3(D); Ord. No. 99-35, 10-11-1999; Ord. No. 03-19, 6-9-2003)  
Sec. 46-44. - Fees. 
The annual fee for any permit issued under this article shall be in the amount provided in the village fee schedule, and shall be used to cover the expense of permit reviews, inspections and related costs incurred by the village. Permit fees charged are applicable for operations of such an outdoor cafe only during the calendar year of issuance. 
(Code 1964, § 24-3(G); Ord. No. 99-35, 10-11-1999; Ord. No. 03-19, 6-9-2003)  
Sec. 46-45. - Review by code enforcement department and village board. 
Initial application shall be reviewed by the code enforcement department who shall make recommendation to the village board as to the application being complete and meeting all requirements herein contained. The village board shall then review the permit application for possible issuance, issuance with restrictions, or denial. 
(Code 1964, § 24-3(A); Ord. No. 99-35, 10-11-1999; Ord. No. 03-19, 6-9-2003)  
Sec. 46-46. - Expiration. 
All permits issued under this article shall be for a term beginning April 1 and ending December 31 of the same calendar year. 
(Code 1964, § 24-3(F); Ord. No. 99-35, 10-11-1999; Ord. No. 03-19, 6-9-2003)  
Sec. 46-47. - Renewal. 
A permit issued under this article may be renewed upon payment of the required annual fee and the completion and filing of a renewal form with the village manager, including a certification signed by the applicant that the proposed use complies with all of the conditions of this article and with every other condition imposed by the village board on the original permit. 
(Code 1964, § 24-3(A); Ord. No. 99-35, 10-11-1999; Ord. No. 03-19, 6-9-2003)  
Sec. 46-48. - Revocation. 
Permits issued under this article are licenses at will, revocable by the board of trustees with or without cause. In addition, the board of trustees shall revoke any permit if the applicant: 
(1)  Intentionally or carelessly misrepresented any material fact on a permit application or permit renewal form; 
(2)  Fails to continuously comply with all conditions of the permit; 
(3)  Violates any applicable regulation or provision of this Code; 
(4)  Conducts the permitted activity in such a manner as to constitute a threat to the public health, safety or general welfare; or 
(5)  Violates applicable federal, state or county law or regulation. 
(Code 1964, § 24-3(E); Ord. No. 99-35, 10-11-1999; Ord. No. 03-19, 6-9-2003)  
Sec. 46-49. - Minimum standards. 
Use of public sidewalks for outdoor cafe purposes shall be permitted only under the following conditions: 
(1)  The business being a conforming use for the zoning district in which it is located. 
(2)  The business being properly licensed by the village and maintaining said license through the duration of the life of the permit. 
(3)  The use of public sidewalks for tables and chairs shall be permitted as indicated to the operation of an establishment maintaining a current village business license for food service operations. 
(4)  The maintaining of a minimum width of five feet traversing the sidewalk containing the sidewalk cafe to allow clear and free passage of the public. The minimum width shall be measured between the outermost table, chair or fixture used in the operation of the outdoor cafe in its normal position and the nearest obstruction, including, but not limited to, the back of the street curb, or any traffic sign, tree well or planter, bicycle rack, street light or other natural or manmade object located on the sidewalk. 
(5)  The applicant shall be responsible for maintaining the sidewalk area in a clean, sanitary and safe condition. 
(6)  No permanent fixtures are to be installed on the public right-of-way. 
(7)  All fixtures are to be removed from the public right-of-way during nonbusiness hours. 
(8)  A minimum of ten feet of public right-of-way shall be provided between the sidewalk cafe and any street travel lane where the posted speed limit is 25 miles per hour, or greater; however, where the posted speed limit is less than 25 miles per hour the minimum shall be five feet. 
(9)  All outdoor furnishings shall be designed to withstand a wind pressure of not less than 30 pounds per square foot; tables shall not have a surface area greater than nine square feet and shall be easily removable; materials and finishes shall be selected for their durability and wear as well as for their appearance; and devices incorporated to separate eating areas from pedestrian pathways must conform to the above standards. 
(Code 1964, § 24-3(B); Ord. No. 99-35, 10-11-1999; Ord. No. 03-19, 6-9-2003)  
Sec. 46-50. - Use for planned public event takes precedence. 
If the outdoor cafe interferes with a public event planned on the public right-of-way, the public event shall take precedence. The village shall notify the permittee 30 days in advance of the scheduled event that will require the use of the public right-of-way being used by the permittee. 
(Code 1964, § 24-3(C); Ord. No. 99-35, 10-11-1999; Ord. No. 03-19, 6-9-2003)  
Secs. 46-51—46-73. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - OTHER PERMITTED ENCROACHMENTS IN COMMERCIALLY ZONED DISTRICTS 
 
Sec. 46-74. - Generally. 
No person shall place or maintain an encroachment or obstruction in the public right-of-way without compliance with this division. The village manager or his designee is hereby authorized to issue a license to the owner or occupant of nonresidential property located in commercially zoned districts for one or more encroachments into the village right-of-way that meet the standards and criteria set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2007-64, § 2, 7-9-2007; Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4), 5-10-2010)  
Sec. 46-75. - Allowable encroachments. 
Subject to permit approval and entering into a license agreement per the provisions of this article, the following privately owned encroachments may be permitted to encroach into the public right-of-way in the commercially zoned district and may not be placed in state department of transportation (IDOT) right-of-way: planters, awnings or canopies, decorative or dining tables and chairs, benches, or other decorative items relative to the adjacent business or special event. 
(Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4(A)(1)), 5-10-2010)  
Sec. 46-76. - Types of encroachments. 
(a)  Temporary encroachments are those that are placed in the public way seasonally. Such encroachments may not be permanently affixed to the building or public way and must be removed from November 1 through April 15 of each year. 
(b)  Permanent encroachments are those that are placed in the public way year-round. Only awnings or canopies may be permitted as permanent encroachments. Such encroachments must, in addition to a right-of-way encroachment license and agreement, obtain a building permit in accordance with this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4(C)(2)), 5-10-2010)  
Sec. 46-77. - License and agreement required. 
A right-of-way encroachment license and agreement is required for the placement of any allowable encroachments in the public way. Any owner or occupant of a nonresidential property located in the commercially zoned district may apply for a right-of-way encroachment license and agreement to request approval of an encroachment meeting the requirements of this division. Upon license approval, the owner or occupant must enter into a license agreement prior to placing the encroachment in the public way. 
(Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4(B)), 5-10-2010)  
Sec. 46-78. - Location. 
(a)  Proposed encroachments must be located on the public sidewalk adjacent to the licensee's property in the area bounded by the licensee's property line, the back edge of the curbline, and the licensee's property lines extended to the street and so located to maintain a minimum of five feet unobstructed sidewalk width and a minimum of five feet unobstructed access way from each entrance or exit of the building located on the property to the street. 
(b)  Allowable encroachments shall be located so that the encroachment does not obstruct any traffic control sign or device or street identification sign and does not impair the safe visibility of pedestrians and vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. No. 2007-64, §§ 2A1, 2A2, 7-9-2007; Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4(C)(1), (5)), 5-10-2010)  
Sec. 46-79. - Advertising prohibited; exceptions. 
With the exception of awnings and canopies, no allowable encroachment may be utilized for the purpose of displaying signage or advertisements. 
(Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4(C)(3)), 5-10-2010)  
Sec. 46-80. - Construction standards. 
All permitted encroachments must be constructed of weather resistant materials and maintained in good condition, clean and free of litter, by the property owner or occupant. Permits are subject to revocation in the event the encroachment is not maintained by the property owner or occupant. 
(Ord. No. 2007-64, § 2A3, 7-9-2007; Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4(C)(4)), 5-10-2010)  
Sec. 46-81. - Pre-existing nonconforming encroachments. 
Any existing permanent encroachments nonconforming to the provisions of this division must be maintained in good condition and be permitted and licensed per the provisions of this division. In the event an existing permanent encroachment is damaged by any means 50 percent or greater, removed, or replaced, the new encroachment must meet the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4(C)(6)), 5-10-2010)  
Sec. 46-82. - Conformity to zoning district standards. 
A right-of-way encroachment license and agreement may be denied in the event the proposed encroachment does not complement or substantially conform to the character of the zoning district and village-supplied streetscape accessories. 
(Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4(C)(7)), 5-10-2010)  
Sec. 46-83. - Sidewalk planter standards. 
(a)  The sidewalk planters shall be located on the public sidewalk adjacent to the licensee's property in the area bounded by the licensee's property line, the back edge of the curbline and the licensee's property lines extended to the street and so located to maintain a minimum five feet unobstructed sidewalk width and a minimum five feet unobstructed access way from each entrance or exit of the building located on the property to the street. 
(b)  The sidewalk planters shall be located so that the sidewalk planter and the vegetation growing from the sidewalk planter does not obstruct any traffic control sign or device or street identification sign and does not impair the safe visibility of pedestrians and vehicular traffic. 
(c)  The sidewalk planters shall be constructed from weather resistant materials approved by the village manager. 
(d)  The sidewalk planter shall not be affixed, attached or anchored to the public sidewalk or any building or wall, but shall be of sufficient size and weight to resist being easily tipped or toppled. 
(e)  The vegetation planted in the sidewalk planters shall be approved by the village forester, kept cultivated, trimmed of overgrowth and weed free. The licensee shall be responsible for planting all vegetation in the sidewalk planter, keeping the sidewalk planter planted with vegetation during all growing seasons, maintaining, weeding and watering the vegetation. The sidewalk planters shall be maintained in good repair, clean and free from litter. 
(Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4(D)(1)), 5-10-2010)  
Sec. 46-84. - Awning and canopy standards. 
Awnings or canopies must be permitted and constructed in accordance with village buildings, zoning and sign regulations. Awnings and canopies may project in to the public right-of-way if a right-of-way encroachment license and agreement are approved. Awnings and canopies projecting into the right-of-way may not be supported by poles or any similar structure support extending to the ground. 
(Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4(D)(2)), 5-10-2010)  
Sec. 46-85. - Table, chair and bench standards. 
Tables, chairs, and benches located in the public right-of-way must meet the zoning and liquor license requirements for outdoor dining or consumption of beverages. Previously approved outdoor dining facilities in the public right-of-way may continue to be used as such, but must obtain a right-of-way encroachment license and agreement in accordance with this division. Benches must match village-supplied benches in make, model, style, color, and finish. 
(Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4(D)(3)), 5-10-2010)  
Sec. 46-86. - Standards for other decorative items. 
Any proposal for decorative items in the public right-of-way must directly relate to the adjacent business or special event. The village may deny a right-of-way encroachment license and agreement if the proposal does not demonstrate a direct relationship with the adjacent business or special event, or if the decorative item does not substantially conform to the character of the zoning district or village-supplied streetscape accessories. 
(Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4(D)(4)), 5-10-2010)  
Sec. 46-87. - Licensee to indemnify village. 
(a)  The licensee shall agree to assume all liability and shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless the village, its officials, employees, agents, and volunteers, for any injury or damage to persons or property, including the village's property, officials, employees, agents, and volunteers, occasioned by or arising in connection with any part of the encroachment, the use or occupancy of the area occupied by the encroachment, or the existence or condition of the encroachment. 
(b)  The licensee shall further agree to indemnify, defend and hold harmless the village and its officials, employees, agents, and volunteers against: 
(1)  Any actions which may be brought against the village, its officials, employees, agents, and volunteers, arising out of the license issued, the installation and use of the encroachment, or any act or omission of the licensee, its agents or assigns, or any independent contractor on the licensee's behalf; and 
(2)  Any claim or expenses incurred by the village, its officials, employees, agents, and volunteers, in enforcing the terms and provisions of the license against the licensee. 
(Ord. No. 2007-64, § 2A7, 7-9-2007; Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4(E)(1)), 5-10-2010)  
Sec. 46-88. - Liability insurance required. 
(a)  The licensee shall obtain and keep in full force and effect throughout the term of the license insurance against claims for injuries to persons or damages to property, which may arise from or in connection with the placement of the sidewalk planter on the public sidewalk. The insurance policy shall contain liability limits not less than $1,000,000.00 combined single limit per occurrence for bodily injury, and property damage and $1,000,000.00 per occurrence for personal injury. 
(b)  The insurance policy shall name the village, its officers and employees, as additional insureds. The insurance policy shall be written on an occurrence basis and not on a claims made basis. The licensee's insurance coverage shall be primary with regards to the village, its officers and employees. The insurance policy shall be endorsed to state that coverage shall not be suspended, voided, cancelled, reduced in coverage or in limits except after 30 days prior written notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, has been given to the village. The insurance policy shall be issued by an insurer with a Best's rating of no less than A-, VII and licensed to do business in this state. 
(c)  Any insurance or self-insurance maintained by the village, its officers, and employees shall be excess of licensee's insurance and shall not contribute with it. Any failure to comply with reporting provisions of the insurance policy shall not affect coverage provided to the village, its officers and employees. 
(d)  The licensee shall submit to the village manager, prior to the installation of the sidewalk planter, a certificate of insurance, signed by a person authorized by that insurer to bind coverage on its behalf, evidencing the required coverage. The village shall also have the right to request, and the licensee shall promptly provide to the village, full certified copies of the insurance policy and its endorsements. 
(Ord. No. 2007-64, § 2A8, 7-9-2007; Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4(E)(2)), 5-10-2010)  
Sec. 46-89. - Term of license. 
All temporary right-of-way encroachment licenses and agreements shall be for a term of one calendar year from January 1 to December 31. Permits and licenses for permanent encroachments shall be valid until such encroachment is removed. 
(Ord. No. 2007-64, § 2B, 7-9-2007; Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4(F)), 5-10-2010)  
Sec. 46-90. - Fees. 
No annual fee shall be charged for a right-of-way encroachment license and agreement. Permit fees shall be charged in accordance with the village fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. 2007-64, § 2C, 7-9-2007; Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4(G)), 5-10-2010)  
Sec. 46-91. - Revocation. 
The village manager may revoke any license or permit issued pursuant to this division if the license agreement is terminated or the encroachment does not conform to the requirements of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2007-64, § 2D, 7-9-2007; Ord. No. 2010-41, § 2(24-4(H)), 5-10-2010)  
Secs. 46-92—46-107. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - TEMPORARY CLOSURE OF PUBLIC WAYS

The city may issue permits for the temporary closure of any street, sidewalk, alley or other public way, and any associated public property, for the conduct of any exhibition, block party, carnival, festival or other special event of limited duration. 
(Code 1964, § 02-33; Ord. of 1-14-1952, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1974-45, § 1, 12-9-1974; Ord. No. 1978-20, § A, 6-26-1978; Ord. No. 1978-31, § A, 8-14-1978; Ord. No. 98-10, 2-9-1998; Ord. No. 2001-34, 7-23-2001; Ord. No. 2003-21, 6-23-2003; Ord. No. 2006-59, § 1, 7-10-2006; Ord. No. 2007-37, § 1, 4-23-2007)  
Sec. 46-109. - Application. 
Requests for a temporary closure permit shall be made in writing to the village manager setting forth the nature of the event for which the permit is requested, the dates, times, and location of the event. 
(Code 1964, § 02-33; Ord. of 1-14-1952, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1974-45, § 1, 12-9-1974; Ord. No. 1978-20, § A, 6-26-1978; Ord. No. 1978-31, § A, 8-14-1978; Ord. No. 98-10, 2-9-1998; Ord.
