Sec. 46-110. - Information to be included on permit. 
Any such permit issued shall recite the dates, times and location of the temporary closure. 
(Code 1964, § 02-33; Ord. of 1-14-1952, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1974-45, § 1, 12-9-1974; Ord. No. 1978-20, § A, 6-26-1978; Ord. No. 1978-31, § A, 8-14-1978; Ord. No. 98-10, 2-9-1998; Ord. No. 2001-34, 7-23-2001; Ord. No. 2003-21, 6-23-2003; Ord. No. 2006-59, § 1, 7-10-2006; Ord. No. 2007-37, § 1, 4-23-2007)  
Sec. 46-111. - Permit copies to be provided to certain city officials. 
Copies of the permit issued shall be delivered, by the village manager or his designee, to the police chief, fire chief, and the department of public works and services. 
(Code 1964, § 02-33; Ord. of 1-14-1952, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1974-45, § 1, 12-9-1974; Ord. No. 1978-20, § A, 6-26-1978; Ord. No. 1978-31, § A, 8-14-1978; Ord. No. 98-10, 2-9-1998; Ord. No. 2001-34, 7-23-2001; Ord. No. 2003-21, 6-23-2003; Ord. No. 2006-59, § 1, 7-10-2006; Ord. No. 2007-37, § 1, 4-23-2007)  
Sec. 46-112. - Permittee responsible for restoration of event site. 
All persons, corporations, groups, or other entity requesting a temporary closure permit shall be responsible for returning street, sidewalk, alley or other public way or public place to its prior condition at the conclusion of the event, including, but not limited to, removal of all trash, debris and garbage. 
(Code 1964, § 02-33; Ord. of 1-14-1952, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1974-45, § 1, 12-9-1974; Ord. No. 1978-20, § A, 6-26-1978; Ord. No. 1978-31, § A, 8-14-1978; Ord. No. 98-10, 2-9-1998; Ord. No. 2001-34, 7-23-2001; Ord. No. 2003-21, 6-23-2003; Ord. No. 2006-59, § 1, 7-10-2006; Ord. No. 2007-37, § 1, 4-23-2007)  
Secs. 46-113—46-129. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PUBLICATION DISPENSING DEVICES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 46-130. - Findings and purpose. 
(a)  The village has a substantial interest in promoting the public health, safety, welfare and convenience of its citizens and visitors by ensuring that public streets, public sidewalks and public rights-of-way are not unreasonably obstructed by publication dispensing devices, and that publication dispensing devices are properly maintained. 
(b)  The public rights-of-way historically have been used to circulate publications. 
(c)  The substantial growth in the number of publications has produced a proliferation of freestanding publication dispensing devices located on public rights-of-way that have contributed to the congestion of public sidewalks, impeded the flow of pedestrian and vehicular traffic, interfered with the use of streets, public sidewalks and public rights-of-way; and poorly maintained or abandoned, freestanding publication dispensing devices have presented hazards to persons and property, contributed to the litter problems of public sidewalks and resulted in visual blight. 
(d)  The village has a substantial interest in preserving and protecting its unique visual and aesthetic qualities and, to that end, the village must take steps to reduce the visual blight, the inconvenience and the hazards associated with unlimited numbers and designs of publication dispensing devices, poorly maintained publication dispensing devices and the virtually unrestricted placement of publication dispensing devices on public streets, public sidewalks and public rights-of-way. 
(e)  The unregulated placement and maintenance of individual publication dispensing devices in the public rights-of-way interferes with the free and unimpeded use of such public rights-of-way, and threatens the health, safety and welfare of persons who use the public rights-of-way, including pedestrians, children, the aged, persons entering and leaving vehicles and buildings, drivers, persons performing essential utility, traffic control and emergency services, and persons with disabilities. 
(f)  The unregulated placement of multicolored, broken, rusted and abandoned individual publication dispensing devices of various shapes and sizes in the public right-of-ways significantly detracts from the aesthetic character of surrounding areas. Due to the limited space available and the congestion on certain public sidewalks, streets and public rights-of-way, the village has a substantial interest in devising an approach to placement of publication dispensing devices in those areas that promote public health, safety and welfare and the aesthetic quality of the village. 
(g)  An effective way to reduce the visual clutter and hazards associated with excessive numbers of publication dispensing devices is to prohibit freestanding publication dispensing devices in congested areas and to allow only modular publication dispensing devices in these areas. This objective may be achieved by creating a modular publication dispensing device district in congested areas or areas that have particular public safety, aesthetic, historical or economic concerns and the permitting of freestanding publication dispensing devices outside these districts. Allowing modular publication dispensing devices and prohibiting freestanding publication dispensing devices and unauthorized modular publication dispensing devices in modular publication dispensing device districts and regulating the location of publication dispensing devices on the public right-of-way and other public areas outside of the modular publication dispensing device districts will promote the village's interest in promoting public safety, reducing visual blight and clutter, protecting the unique aesthetic and historical attributes of the village, and advancing the economic interests of the village's businesses and residents by improving the appearance of the area and resulting in better use of space and reduced congestion, while respecting publication's interests in effective distribution. A reasonable accommodation of these competing interests can be achieved by adoption of this article, which regulates the placement, size, construction design, maintenance, and appearance of publication dispensing devices in specified areas. 
(h)  Based on the findings described above, it is further found that there is a need for reasonable time, place and manner restrictions regarding the installation, placement, size, appearance and maintenance of publication dispensing devices in the public rights-of-way. Consistent with these findings, it is the purpose of this article to promote the health, safety and welfare of users of the public rights-of-way and to enhance the aesthetic qualities of the village by controlling the placement, size, construction and appearance of publication dispensing devices and modular publication dispensing devices in a manner which may utilize publication dispensing devices as a method of distribution of publications, so as to accomplish the following, to the extent reasonably possible: 
(1)  Provide for pedestrian and driving safety and convenience. 
(2)  Restrict unreasonable interference with the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, including ingress and egress from any residence or place of business or from the street to the sidewalk by persons exiting or entering parked or standing vehicles. 
(3)  Provide for the safety of the public and property during windstorms and other inclement weather. 
(4)  Replace, remove, or relocate individual publication dispensing devices that have created visual blight on the public rights-of-way or unreasonably detracted from the aesthetics of adjacent businesses, landscaping and other improvements. 
(5)  Maintain and protect the values of surrounding properties. 
(6)  Reduce unnecessary exposure of the public to personal injury and property damage. 
(7)  Ensure compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act and improve passage for persons with disabilities by reducing impediments to passage caused by poorly located publication dispensing devices. 
(8)  Provide reasonable access for the safe and efficient use and maintenance of sidewalks, poles, posts, traffic signs or signals, hydrants, mailboxes, delivery areas, loading zones, transit shelters, curb ramps and locations used for public transportation services. 
(9)  Reduce visual blight and clutter and litter problems associated with poorly maintained, improperly located or abandoned publication dispensing devices. 
(10)  Protect the unique aesthetic and historical attributes of the village. 
(11)  Advance the economic interests of the village's businesses and residents, including the interests of those involved in the publication or distribution of publications through publication dispensing devices. 
(12)  Respect the publisher's interests in effective distribution, including: 
a.  Allowing publications currently distributed from freestanding publication dispensing devices to receive distribution space in modular publication dispensing devices located at, or as close as reasonably possible to, the locations of such freestanding publication dispensing devices; 
b.  Allowing publications not currently distributed from freestanding publication dispensing devices to receive distribution space in modular publication dispensing devices; 
c.  Allowing the number, locations, and usage of modular publication dispensing devices to change over time in response to changing market conditions; and 
d.  Providing for modular publication dispensing devices and prompt and effective maintenance, repair and replacement of freestanding publication dispensing devices, including providing for the maintenance, repair and replacement of parts of such publication dispensing devices which, if not thus maintained, repaired or replaced, could significantly impede the effective use of such publication dispensing device. 
(i)  This article is not intended to and does not ban freestanding publication dispensing devices on public sidewalks, streets and public rights-of-way throughout the village outside of modular publication dispensing device districts. Subject to the requirements of this article, freestanding publication dispensing devices may continue to be placed on public sidewalks, streets and public rights-of-way in areas of the village that are not within modular publication dispensing device districts created pursuant to this article. Publications also may continue to be distributed within modular publication dispensing device districts created pursuant to this article by all authorized means other than freestanding publication dispensing devices. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-50), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-131. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Abandoned publication dispensing device means any publication dispensing device or any compartment of a modular publication dispensing device that does not contain the publication specified therefor or contains outdated publications for more than seven consecutive days for a daily publication, 14 consecutive days for a weekly publication, 30 consecutive days for a biweekly publication, 60 days for a monthly publication, or 90 days for a bimonthly publication, except that a publication dispensing device or a compartment of a modular publication dispensing device remaining empty due to labor strike or any temporary and extraordinary interruption of the publication or distribution of the publication sold or distributed therein shall not be deemed abandoned. 
Compartment means the individual space within a modular publication dispensing device that dispenses a publication, including the door, coin return mechanism and associated hardware. 
District means a modular publication dispensing device district as defined in this article. 
Modular publication dispensing device means a publication dispensing device that is designed with multiple separate enclosed compartments to accommodate at any one time the display, sale or distribution of multiple, distinct and separate publications. 
Modular publication dispensing device district means that portion of the village within the Prairie Avenue Train Station and within 1,000 feet of the Prairie Avenue Train Station. 
Publication dispensing device means any unmanned, self service or coin operated box, container, storage unit or other dispenser located in or upon, or projecting onto, into, or over, any part of the public rights-of-way, and which is installed, used or maintained for the display, sale, or distribution of publications which is not a modular publication dispensing device. 
Publications means and includes newspapers, periodicals, advertising circulars, and all other printed materials that may be distributed through the use of publication dispensing devices. 
Publisher means the person or other legal entity selling, displaying or distributing publications in a publication dispensing device. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-51), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-132. - Administration. 
The village manager shall appoint an employee of the village as the publication dispensing device commissioner. The publication dispensing device commissioner shall serve without additional compensation other than the compensation normally otherwise paid to the employee. The publication dispensing device commissioner shall have the following powers and duties, which shall at all times be performed without consideration of the content or viewpoint of the material being distributed in a publication dispensing device: 
(1)  To administer and rule upon the applications for, and the issuance, renewal, suspension, denial and revocation of publication dispensing device permits as set forth in this article. 
(2)  To conduct or provide for such inspections of publication dispensing devices as shall be necessary to determine and ensure compliance with the provisions of this article and other applicable provisions of law. 
(3)  To collect an annual permit fee to be paid by each permit holder. The fees adopted pursuant to this article shall be uniformly imposed upon all permit holders based upon the type and number of permits issued to the holder. The anticipated annual revenue within any particular year from the permit fee, as initially established, is anticipated to be reasonably related to the actual costs incurred by the village for implementation, administration and enforcement of the program and not as a revenue-generating source for the village. 
(4)  To review annually the permit fees imposed by this article and to propose to the board of trustees any recommended adjustments, along with written justification for the adjustment. 
(5)  To take such further actions as the village manager shall deem necessary to carry out the purposes and intent of this article and to exercise such additional powers in furtherance thereof as are implied or incident to those powers and duties expressly set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-52), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-133. - Adjustment of permit fees. 
(a)  In any year where the publication dispensing device commissioner anticipates that the revenue from the permit fees during that year will exceed a reasonable relationship to the estimated administrative costs, the publication dispensing device commissioner shall recommend an adjustment reducing the permit fee. 
(b)  In any year where the publication dispensing device commissioner anticipates that the revenue from the permit fees during that year will exceed a reasonable relationship to the estimated administrative costs, the publication dispensing device commissioner may recommend an adjustment increasing the permit fee by an amount not in excess of the limitations imposed by 65 ILCS 5/11-55-2. The board of trustees shall not increase the permit fee without holding a public hearing thereon and providing notice thereof in compliance with 65 ILCS 5/11-55-2. 
(c)  In proposing adjustments, the publication dispensing device commissioner shall take into account the anticipated penalties and other charges to be collected from violators during the forthcoming year which are to be used to offset program administration and enforcement costs that would otherwise be defrayed by permit fees imposed during the forthcoming year so that the permit fees, including any surplus from the prior year, maintain a reasonable relationship to the projected costs of administering the program. 
(d)  For any year in which the permit fee proceeds exceed a reasonable relationship to the administration, inspection and abatement expenses, such surplus shall be taken into account in fixing the permit fee for the subsequent year. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-52), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-134. - Revocation of permits. 
The publication dispensing device commissioner shall revoke any permit issued under the provisions of this article after a finding that a publication dispensing device is an abandoned publication dispensing device or that any of the following causes exists: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or any false statement contained in the application for a permit. 
(2)  Failure to maintain the publication dispensing device in good repair and working order or in a safe and clean condition, after written notice to the permit holder specifying the condition to be remedied followed by the failure within ten business days from the date of the written notice to remedy the condition. 
(3)  Failure, following 30 days after the expiration of any appeal rights, to pay any penalty assessed under this article. 
(4)  Violation of any term of the permit granted to the holder of a permit. 
(5)  Violation of any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-59), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-135. - Appeal of decisions of the publication dispensing device commissioner. 
(a)  Any decision of the publication dispensing device commissioner under this article shall be appealable. Any person aggrieved by a decision of the publication dispensing device commissioner shall have the right to appeal the decision to the village manager, provided that the applicant files a written notice of appeal, including a statement of the grounds of appeal, with the village manager within 15 calendar days after notice of the decision of the publication dispensing device commissioner. 
(b)  The village manager shall set a hearing on the appeal within ten calendar days after receipt of the written notice of appeal and notice of the time and place shall be given to the aggrieved party. The village manager shall have the power to reverse, affirm or modify the decision of the publication dispensing device commissioner. In making his determination, the village manager shall only consider the standards set forth in this article. 
(c)  The village manager's decision shall be rendered the same day as the hearing. Failure of the village manager to set or conduct a hearing in accordance with the requirements of this section shall be considered a denial of the appeal. 
(d)  The decision of the village manager shall be a final administrative decision subject to judicial review under the administrative review law, 735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq., in the circuit court of the county. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-61), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-136. - Penalties. 
Any person or entity who shall be guilty of a violation of any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine of not less than $75.00 and not more than $750.00. A separate offense shall be deemed committed for every day a violation continues. The provisions of this section shall not limit any other remedies authorized by law. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-61), 10-12-2009)  
Secs. 46-137—46-151. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DEVICES INSIDE DISTRICT 
 
Sec. 46-152. - Provision of modular publication dispensing devices. 
(a)  The village shall provide for the placement of one or more modular publication dispensing devices on public right-of-way in the modular publication dispensing device districts. 
(b)  After the initial installation of the modular publication dispensing device, the total number of compartments in the modular publication dispensing device in the modular publication dispensing device district may be increased or decreased only consistent with the purposes of this division. 
(c)  Modular publication dispensing devices shall be placed at locations in the modular publication dispensing device district which afford easy, convenient service to pedestrians, but which do not obstruct or interfere with access to abutting properties, and which do not impede or endanger pedestrian, bicycle or vehicle traffic. 
(d)  Any publisher may petition the publication dispensing device commissioner for placement of a modular publication dispensing device at a specific location within the modular publication dispensing device district. The publication dispensing device commissioner shall review each petition and determine whether such location is warranted. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-56), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-153. - Compartment permits. 
The modular publication dispensing device compartment permit grants the holder thereof a license allowing for the placement of publications in an assigned compartment of a modular publication dispensing device within the public right-of-way, along the public streets, thoroughfares, parkways, and sidewalks within the modular publication dispensing device districts of the village. A village permit allowing the placement of publications within a modular publication dispensing device compartment shall be subject to, and granted upon, the conditions, restrictions and requirements provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-57(A)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-154. - Permit procedure. 
(a)  Applications for a modular publication dispensing device compartment permit shall be made on forms provided by the publication dispensing device commissioner. The applications shall be provided by the publication dispensing device commissioner immediately upon request. 
(b)  Within ten business days of receipt of an application for a modular publication dispensing device compartment permit, the publication dispensing device commissioner shall grant the application and issue the permit provided that the applicable requirements contained in this division are satisfied. 
(c)  If the requirements contained in this division are not satisfied, the publication dispensing device commissioner shall, within ten business days of receipt of the application for a permit, deny the application, and state the reasons in writing for such denial. 
(d)  If the publication dispensing device commissioner fails, within ten business days of receipt of the application for a permit, to act on the application, then, provided that the permit fee has been paid, the application shall be considered granted. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-57(B)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-155. - Location restrictions. 
A modular publication dispensing device compartment permit shall apply only to the compartment specified in the permit, and no publication permitted hereunder shall be relocated to another compartment without application for and issuance of a new permit. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-57(C)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-156. - Fees. 
The fee for each modular publication dispensing device compartment permit shall be in the amount provided in the village fee schedule. No permit shall be issued pursuant to this division unless and until the permit fee required by this section is paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-57(D)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-157. - Term; expiration; renewal. 
A modular publication dispensing device compartment permit shall expire on December 31 of the year of its issuance. A modular publication dispensing device compartment permit may be renewed by the payment of the permit fee provided that the applicable requirements contained in this division are satisfied. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, §§ 1(24-57(E), (F), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-158. - Publications to be placed only in authorized compartment. 
No publication shall be placed within a modular publication dispensing device compartment, other than the compartment for which a modular publication dispensing device compartment permit has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-58(A)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-159. - Insurance requirements. 
(a)  The applicant shall furnish to the village a certificate showing that such person has then in force a policy or policies of commercial liability and property damage insurance, naming the village as an additional insured, in an amount not less than $100,000.00 minimum liability combined single limit (bodily injury and property damage) per person and per occurrence. 
(b)  The permit holder shall provide and keep in force such policy or policies of liability insurance during such time as it continues to place or maintain any publication in a modular publication dispensing device compartment under the terms of this division. The evidence of insurance filed with the village shall include a statement by the insurance carrier that such carrier will give the village 30 days notice before cancelling such insurance. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-58(B)(1)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-160. - Indemnification agreement required. 
The applicant shall execute and deliver with its application an indemnification and hold harmless agreement indemnifying and holding the village, its officials, both elected and appointed, its employees and agents harmless against any loss or liability or damage, including expenses and costs for bodily or personal injury, and for property damaged sustained by any person as the result of the negligent use of the modular publication dispensing device compartment. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-58(B)(2)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-161. - Allocation of compartments. 
(a)  For initial assignment of modular publication dispensing device compartments, the publication dispensing device commissioner shall notify all publishers who currently distribute their publications by publication dispensing devices within the modular publication dispensing device district. The notification shall, at a minimum, notify the publisher that the village intends to discontinue permitting freestanding publication dispensing devices within the modular publication dispensing device district, advising the publisher that it may apply for a modular publication dispensing device compartment permit, consisting of a copy of the village's application for a modular publication dispensing device compartment permit and, that upon written request, the publisher may have a hearing on the proposed removal of its publication dispensing device from the modular publication dispensing device district. 
(b)  On the application for a modular publication dispensing device compartment permit, each publisher shall include the number of compartments and the locations it is seeking. All applications shall be returned to the publication dispensing device commissioner, who shall ensure that compartments are allocated in accordance with the procedure set forth in this division. 
(c)  The publication dispensing device commissioner shall ensure that there are sufficient compartments in each modular publication dispensing device to accommodate all publishers who initially wish to distribute their publications, up to a maximum of ten compartments per modular publication dispensing device, in the modular publication dispensing device district. If more than ten publishers wish to distribute publications at that location, then the compartments shall be allocated as follows: 
(1)  Priority shall be given to publishers who continuously have distributed publications in publication dispensing devices at that location for more than 12 months before the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, as indicated by the publisher's affidavit provided to the village; 
(2)  Among publishers who have priority under this subsection, compartments will be allocated first to publications issued at least five days per week, second to publications issued between two and four days per week, third to publications issued once a week, and fourth to publications issued less frequently; 
(3)  If there are more compartments than publishers with priority under this section, then the village shall allocate the remaining compartments among publishers who do not have priority, first to publications issued at least five days per week, second to publications issued between two and four days per week, third to publications issued once a week, and fourth to publications issued less frequently; 
(4)  Notwithstanding the requirements of this subsection, no publication may receive a second compartment in a modular publication dispensing device until all other interested publishers have had the opportunity to have their publication allocated to a compartment; 
(5)  Whenever additional compartments become available, they shall be allocated in the manner described in this subsection; and 
(6)  In the event two or more publishers have equal priority under this subsection, then allocation shall be determined by lottery conducted by the publication dispensing device commissioner. 
(d)  The opportunity of publishers to have their publications distributed from a modular publication dispensing device shall not be affected whatsoever by their content, consistent with the First Amendment to the United States Constitution. 
(e)  Following initial assignment of modular publication dispensing device compartments, no publication dispensing devices of any type shall be located within the modular publication dispensing device district except the village-installed modular publication dispensing devices. 
(f)  After the initial assignment of modular publication dispensing device compartments, any publisher seeking to place its publication within the modular publication dispensing device must fill out an application for a modular publication dispensing device compartment permit and submit it to the publication dispensing device commissioner, who shall ensure that compartments are allocated in accordance with the procedure set forth above. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-59(A)—(C), (E)—(G)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-162. - Compartments to contain one publication of appropriate size. 
Each compartment in a modular publication dispensing device shall contain copies of only one publication and have a door that is sized to fit and display such publication. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-59(D)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-163. - Pre-existing devices to be removed. 
All existing publication dispensing devices shall be removed from the modular publication dispensing device district within seven days after the installation of the modular publication dispensing device and the initial assignment of modular publication dispensing device compartments. Any publication dispensing device not so removed or otherwise placed in violation of this division shall be subject to removal by the village. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-59(H)), 10-12-2009)  
Secs. 46-164—46-186. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - DEVICES OUTSIDE DISTRICT 
 
Sec. 46-187. - Permit required; prohibited acts. 
(a)  Permit required. A publication dispensing device permit shall be required to establish, install, operate, or maintain a publication dispensing device on public property within the village. No publication dispensing devices, other than a modular publication dispensing device, shall be placed within the modular publication dispensing device district. 
(b)  Operation without permit prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person not having a current and valid publication dispensing device permit to establish, operate, or maintain a publication dispensing device on public property within the village at any time after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(c)  Operation in violation of permit prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any holder of a publication dispensing device permit to install, establish, operate, or maintain a publication dispensing device on public property within the village except in the manner authorized by, and in compliance with, the provisions of this division. 
(d)  Distribution without permit prohibited. No person may place any publication in: 
(1)  Any publication dispensing device for the purpose of sale or distribution without first having obtained a publication dispensing device permit authorizing placement of the publication in that publication dispensing device; or 
(2)  Any modular publication dispensing device compartment for the purpose of sale or distribution without first having obtained a modular publication dispensing device compartment permit authorizing placement of the publication in that modular publication dispensing device compartment. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-53), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-188. - Placement of devices outside district requires permit; compliance required. 
(a)  The publication dispensing device permit grants the holder thereof a license allowing for the installation and placement of publication dispensing devices within the public right-of-way, along the public streets, thoroughfares, parkways, and sidewalks outside of the modular publication dispensing device district within the village. 
(b)  A village permit allowing the placement of a freestanding publication dispensing devices outside the modular publication dispensing device district shall be subject to, and granted upon, the conditions, restrictions and requirements provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-54(A)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-189. - Application form and content. 
Applications for a publication dispensing device permit shall be made on forms provided by the publication dispensing device commissioner. The applications shall be provided by the publication dispensing device commissioner immediately upon request. The application must include a site plan that depicts the exact location where the applicant desires to install a publication dispensing device. The application must also include a description of and the specification for the intended publication dispensing device. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-54(A)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-190. - Issuance or denial; effect of failure to act on application. 
(a)  Within ten business days of receipt of an application for a publication dispensing device permit, the publication dispensing device commissioner shall grant the application and issue the permit, provided that the applicable requirements contained in this division are satisfied. 
(b)  If the requirements contained in this division are not satisfied, the publication dispensing device commissioner shall, within ten business days of receipt of the application for a permit, deny the application, and state the reasons in writing for such denial. 
(c)  If the publication dispensing device commissioner fails, within ten business days of receipt of the application for a permit, to act on the application, then, provided that the permit fee has been paid, the application shall be considered granted. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-54(B)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-191. - Permit application to single location; relocation prohibited. 
A publication dispensing device permit shall apply only to the location specified in the permit, and no publication dispensing device permitted hereunder shall be relocated without application for and issuance of a new permit. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-54(C)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-192. - Fee. 
The fee for each freestanding publication dispensing device permit shall be the amount specified in the village fee schedule. No permit shall be issued pursuant to this division unless and until the permit fee required by this section is paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-54(D)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-193. - Term; expiration; renewal. 
A publication dispensing device permit shall expire on December 31 of the year of its issuance. A publication dispensing device permit may be renewed by the payment of the permit fee provided that the applicable requirements contained in this division are satisfied. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-54(D)—(F)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-194. - Insurance requirements. 
(a)  The applicant for a permit under this division must furnish to the village a certificate showing that such person has then in force a policy of commercial liability and property damage insurance, naming the village as an additional insured, in an amount not less than $100,000.00 minimum liability combined single limit (bodily injury and property damage) per person and per occurrence. 
(b)  The permit holder shall provide and keep in force such policy of liability insurance during such time as it continues to place or maintain any publication dispensing device under the terms of this division. The evidence of insurance filed with the village shall include a statement by the insurance carrier that such carrier will give the village 30 days notice before cancelling such insurance. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-55(A)(1)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-195. - Indemnification agreement required. 
The applicant for a permit under this division must execute and deliver with his application an indemnification and hold harmless agreement indemnifying and holding the village, its officials, both elected and appointed, its employees and agents harmless against any loss or liability or damage, including expenses and costs for bodily or personal injury, and for property damage sustained by any person as the result of the negligent installation, use or maintenance of the publication dispensing device within the village. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-55(A)(2)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-196. - Location restrictions. 
(a)  A permit shall authorize the installation of a publication dispensing device only at the exact location described in the application for the permit. The permit shall contain a description of the authorized location. Permits shall not be transferable from one location to another. 
(b)  The publication dispensing device shall be located adjacent and parallel to building walls not more than six inches distant therefrom, or near and parallel to the street curb not less than 18 inches and not more than 24 inches distant from the street curb. No publication dispensing device shall be placed, installed, located, used or maintained: 
(1)  Within three feet of any fire hydrant or other emergency facility. 
(2)  Within 15 feet of any intersecting driveway, alley, or street. 
(3)  Within three feet of any marked crosswalk. 
(4)  At any location where the width of paved clear space in any direction for the passage of pedestrians is reduced to less than five feet. 
(5)  So as to be chained or otherwise secured to any tree, utility pole, light pole, parking meter, traffic control post, street signpost, or other public property. 
(6)  Which in whole or in part rests upon, in or over any portion of any street or other public right-of-way on which motor vehicles are lawfully permitted or on or within any median within any public right-of-way. 
(7)  So as to project into any part of the public right-of-way or along the street, thoroughfares, parkways and sidewalks within the village, unless authorized by a properly issued village permit. 
(8)  Within three feet ahead of and 15 feet to the rear of any sign marking a designated bus stop. 
(9)  Within three feet of any bus bench or bus shelter. 
(10)  Within three feet of any display window of any building abutting the sidewalk or parkway, or in such manner as to impede or interfere with the reasonable use of such window for display purposes. 
(11)  On any handicapped access ramp. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-55(A)(4)—(5)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-197. - Owner identification information to be posted on device. 
The publication dispensing device shall identify its owner and display a telephone number for refund in case of malfunctioning of the device. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-55(A)(6)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-198. - Size limitations. 
No publication dispensing device shall exceed five feet in height, two feet, six inches in width, or two feet in depth. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-55(A)(7)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-199. - Maintenance. 
The publication dispensing device shall be in and after installation shall be maintained in good repair and working order, in a safe and clean condition, in such a manner that: 
(1)  It is reasonably free of dirt and grease. 
(2)  It is reasonably free of chipped, faded, peeling and cracked paint in the visible painted areas thereof. 
(3)  It is reasonably free of rust and corrosion in the visible unpainted metal areas thereon. 
(4)  It is free of graffiti. 
(5)  The clear plastic or glass parts thereof, if any, through which the publications therein are viewed are unbroken and reasonably free of cracks, dents, blemishes and discoloration. 
(6)  The paper or cardboard parts or inserts thereof are reasonably free of tears, peeling or fading. 
(7)  The structural parts thereof are not broken or unduly disfigured. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-55(A)(8)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-200. - Replacement of damaged or stolen devices. 
Any publication dispensing device that has been damaged or stolen shall be replaced or repaired as soon as is practical, but not later than ten business days from the date of written notice to the permit holder from the publication dispensing device commissioner specifying the condition to be remedied unless the permit holder wishes to abandon the location, in which event the permit holder shall promptly remove the publication dispensing device. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-55(D)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-201. - Restoration of site upon removal of device. 
The permit holder, upon removal of the publication dispensing device, shall restore the property of the village to the same condition as when the publication dispensing device was initially installed, ordinary wear and tear excepted. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-55(D)), 10-12-2009)  
Sec. 46-202. - Removal of violating, abandoned or unclaimed devices. 
(a)  If any publication dispensing device is placed or remains within any public right-of-way, street, thoroughfare, parkway or sidewalk without a permit therefor being issued, or after the expiration or revocation of a previously issued permit, or is deemed abandoned or unclaimed, or in violation of any other provision of this division, the publication dispensing device commissioner shall send, by certified mail, with return receipt requested, a written notice to the address of the permit holder, or in the event of an unpermitted publication dispensing device, the owner, user of or publisher of the publication distributed by the publication dispensing device, if the owner, user or publisher can be ascertained. If the owner, user or publisher cannot be ascertained, the notice shall be affixed to the publication dispensing device. 
(b)  The notice shall state the address and telephone number of the publication dispensing device commissioner; a description of why the publication dispensing device is in violation of the requirements of this division; that the owner, user or publisher is ordered to cause immediate removal of the publication dispensing device from the public property; and that the publication dispensing device shall be removed by the village after a date designated by the notice. The date shall be no less than ten calendar days after the date the notice is mailed or first posted, as the case may be, unless the owner, user or publisher requests a hearing before the village manager by filing a written appeal with the publication dispensing device commissioner on or before the designated removal date. 
(c)  If any publication dispensing device remains on public property after an appeal is made and denied by the village manager or in the event no appeal is perfected, after the ten-day period described in this section, the publication dispensing device commissioner shall cause the publication dispensing device to be removed. 
(d)  The owner of any publication dispensing device removed in accordance with the terms of this section shall be responsible for all the expenses of the removal, storage and disposal of such publication dispensing device. 
(e)  Should the publication dispensing device or materials fail to be claimed or should the owner fail to pay any money due the village within a period of no less than 60 days after the removal of the publication dispensing device, such publication dispensing device or materials shall be unclaimed property and become property of the village. 
(f)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, however, the publication dispensing device commissioner may remove any publication dispensing device from public property which, because of its location or condition, poses an immediate threat to the health, safety and welfare to the public or a member thereof. Within five business days of the removal, the publication dispensing device commissioner shall send, by certified mail, with return receipt requested, a written notice to the address of the permit holder of the publication dispensing device. The notice shall state the address and telephone number of the publication dispensing device commissioner and a description of why the publication dispensing device was removed. The permit holder may request a hearing by filing a written appeal with the village manager as provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 2009-55, § 1(24-60), 10-12-2009)  
Secs. 46-203—46-227. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - STREET NAMES AND STRUCTURE NUMBERS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to name and rename streets, avenues, alleys and other public places, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-19; municipal authority to number and renumber of buildings and lots, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-18. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 46-228. - Names of streets. 
Street names are and shall be as they exist at the time of the adoption of this Code; provided, however, that the president and board of trustees may, by ordinance, change the name of any existing street or may, by ordinance, designate the name of any new street provided for in any plat approved by ordinance. 
(Code 1940, § 43.017; Code 1964, § 24-2) 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to name and rename streets, avenues, alleys and other public places, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-19.  
Secs. 46-229—46-249. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BUILDING NUMBERING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to number and renumber of buildings and lots, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-18. 
 
Sec. 46-250. - Duty to number buildings. 
It is hereby made the duty of the owner, agent or person in possession of every building in the village to number it in the manner provided for in this division. 
(Code 1940, § 43.009; Code 1964, § 24-26)  
Sec. 46-251. - Base lines—North and south. 
All lots or buildings located on north and south streets, or on streets running in a northerly or southerly direction, shall be numbered from 26th Street as a base line, beginning with No. 2601 at the south line of 26th Street and increasing toward the south. Grand Boulevard shall be considered for numbering purposes as a north and south street. 
(Code 1940, § 43.010; Code 1964, § 24-27)  
Sec. 46-252. - Same—East and west. 
All lots or buildings located on east and west streets, or on streets running in an easterly or westerly direction, shall, if such street lies north of 39th Street, be numbered from 84th Avenue as a base line, beginning with No. 8401 at the west line of 84th Avenue and increasing toward the west, and if such street lies north of 39th Street, numbered from 84th Avenue buildings located therein shall be numbered from 88th Avenue as a base line, beginning with No. 8801 at the west line of 88th Avenue and increasing toward the west. Broadway and Plainfield Road shall be considered as east and west streets for numbering purposes. 
(Code 1940, § 43.011; Code 1964, § 24-28)  
Sec. 46-253. - Assignment of numbers generally. 
The chief building inspector shall assign or cause to be assigned to each lot or building its proper number and inform the owner, agent or person in possession thereof as to the number of such lot or building at any time upon demand. 
(Code 1940, § 43.014; Code 1964, § 24-29)  
Sec. 46-254. - Rate of number assignments. 
There shall be assigned to each mile, 800 numbers, or 100 numbers to each one-eighth of a mile on all streets, and such numbers shall change from any 100 to the succeeding 100 at the intersecting street nearest such one-eight of a mile line; provided that, on all north and south streets between 26th Street on the north and 31st Street on the south, numbers shall be assigned at the rate of 900 numbers to a mile. 
(Code 1940, § 43.012; Code 1964, § 24-30)  
Sec. 46-255. - Odd and even numbers. 
The even numbers on north and south streets or streets running in a northerly or southerly direction shall be on the west side of such streets and the odd numbers shall be on the east side of such street. The even numbers on east and west streets, or streets running in an easterly or westerly direction, shall be on the north side of such streets and the odd numbers shall be on the south side of such streets. 
(Code 1940, § 43.013; Code 1964, § 24-31)  
Sec. 46-256. - Size and location of numerals. 
Numerals placed on buildings, including garages and accessory structures, shall be at least two inches high and so placed as to be easily read from the sidewalk in front of the building and the alley in the rear of the building. 
(Code 1964, § 24-32; Ord. No. 0-3, 1-24-2000)  
Sec. 46-257. - Plats to control in case of conflict with division. 
The series of plats on file in the office of the chief building inspector, which plats show the numbers assigned to various lots and buildings by the chief building inspector, shall control the language of this division in case of a conflict. 
(Code 1940, § 43.016; Code 1964, § 24-33)  
Secs. 46-258—46-277. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - PARKING LOTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Off-street parking generally, 65 ILCS 5/12-1-71-1 et seq.; municipal authority to license and regulate parking garages, lots and ramps, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-12. 
 
Sec. 46-278. - Definition. 
For the purposes of this article, the terms "parking lot" and "parking area" shall mean any lot, property or premises established, maintained or operated, in whole or in part, for the off-street parking of motor vehicles. 
(Code 1964, § 24-39; Ord. of 4-1-1963, § 1)  
Sec. 46-279. - Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, maintain or operate any parking lot, until a plan or other drawing is submitted to the supervisor of building and zoning showing that compliance will be had with the requirements, specifications and restrictions set forth in this article and articles IV (commercial and multifamily residential developments and improvements) and VII (stormwater management) of chapter 48, and a permit is issued by the supervisor of building and zoning. 
(Code 1964, § 24-40; Ord. of 4-1-1963, §§ 1, 9; Ord. of 8-10-1964, § 1; Ord. No. 2015-29, § 2 , 4-27-2015)  
Sec. 46-280. - Fees. 
Before obtaining such a permit, every applicant shall pay the permit fee in the amount set forth in the village fee schedule. 
(Code 1964, § 24-40; Ord. of 4-1-1963, §§ 1, 9; Ord. of 8-10-1964, § 1)  
Sec. 46-281. - Specifications. 
All off-street parking areas, except the two parking spaces required for each single-family detached dwelling, shall be paved and have a dust-free surface. The minimum requirement standards for an off-street parking area pavement shall be: 
Hot-Mix Asphalt (HMA) Pavement Section 
8? aggregate base 
2.25? HMA binder course 
1.5? HMA surface course 
Portland Cement Concrete (PCC) Pavement Section 
6? aggregate base 
6? PCC pavement (IDOT class PV concrete) 
(Code 1964, § 24-41; Ord. No. 1972-24, § 5, 7-24-1972; Ord. No. 90-25, 5-29-1990; Ord. No. 2015-29, § 3 , 4-27-2015)  
Sec. 46-282. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2015-29, § 4 , adopted April 27, 2015, repealed § 46-282, which pertained to surface drainage and derived from Code 1964, § 24-42; an ordinance adopted April 1, 1963, § 7; an ordinance adopted Aug. 10, 1964, § 2; Ord. No. 1972-24, § 4, adopted July 24, 1972; and Ord. No. 90-25, adopted May 29, 1990.  
Sec. 46-284. - Lights. 
Where night parking is permitted in a parking lot, lights shall be installed to prevent pilfering and shall be so focused as not to annoy adjoining property. 
(Code 1964, § 24-44; Ord. of 4-1-1963, § 5; Ord. No. 1972-24, § 4, 7-24-1972)  
Sec. 46-285. - Barriers and fencing. 
Every person owning or maintaining a parking lot shall maintain a substantial barrier on or adjacent to the property line and so located that no portion of any vehicle parked on the lot shall extend over the property lines. In addition, there shall be maintained around the perimeter of the lot fencing either constructed or grown vegetation. 
(Code 1964, § 24-45; Ord. of 4-1-1963, §§ 3, 8; Ord. No. 1972-24, § 4, 7-24-1972)  
Sec. 46-286. - Maintenance. 
Each parking area shall be kept free from dirt, ice, sleet and snow. 
(Code 1964, § 24-46; Ord. of 4-1-1963, § 4; Ord. No. 1972-24, § 4, 7-24-1972)

ARTICLE VI. - CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal sidewalk construction and repair, 65 ILCS 5/11-84-1 et seq.; municipal authority over streets and public ways, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-1 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 46-306—46-328. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS 
 
Sec. 46-329. - Permits. 
Any person desiring to build, remove, repair or disturb in any manner flatwork, including, but not limited to, sidewalks, driveways, patios and other such slabs, in the village shall first obtain a permit to perform such work from the chief building inspector and shall pay therefore fees as established under the provisions of chapter 12. 
(Code 1964, § 24-7; Ord. No. 98-23, 5-11-1998)  
Sec. 46-330. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2015-29, § 6 , adopted April 27, 2015, repealed § 46-330, which pertained to duty of engineer to furnish sidewalk lines and grades and derived from Code 1940, § 36.021; and Code 1964, § 24-8.  
Sec. 46-331. - Specifications for sidewalk construction. 
All sidewalks in the village shall be constructed in accordance with specifications on file in the office of the chief building inspector. 
(Code 1940, § 36.018; Code 1964, § 24-9)  
Sec. 46-332. - Supervision of construction. 
It shall be the duty of the supervisor of building and zoning to furnish an inspector to supervise the construction of any sidewalk or private driveway which requires the breaking of an existing curb. 
(Code 1940, § 36.021; Code 1964, § 24-11; Ord. No. 2015-29, § 7 , 4-27-2015)  
Sec. 46-333. - Duty to repair upon notice. 
Whenever any sidewalk or private driveway, or portion thereof, shall be required or directed to be relaid, raised, lowered or repaired, the supervisor of building and zoning shall give notice thereof to the owners or occupants of the property interested, and if the sidewalk or private driveway is not relaid, raised, lowered or repaired within 30 days from the receipt of such notice, the board of trustees may order such work to be done at the expense of the property owner. 
(Code 1940, § 36.022; Code 1964, § 24-12; Ord. No. 2015-29, § 8 , 4-27-2015)  
Sec. 46-334. - Applicability of division to construction of sidewalk by special assessment. 
This division shall apply to sidewalks constructed by special assessment or special tax in so far as it may be applicable. 
(Code 1940, § 36.026; Code 1964, § 24-13)  
Secs. 46-335—46-356. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - GRADES 
 
Sec. 46-357. - Grade and specifications for driveway construction. 
All private driveways shall be so constructed that the longitudinal grade thereof shall conform to the elevation of the gutter at its intersection with the driveway and shall rise at a uniform rate to the elevation of the edge of the sidewalk nearest the roadway. All private driveways shall be constructed in accord with specifications on file in the office of the supervisor of building and zoning. 
(Code 1940, § 36.019; Code 1964, § 24-10; Ord. No. 2015-29, § 9 , 4-27-2015)  
Sec. 46-358. - Grades for tracks of Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railway Company. 
(a)  The grade for the tracks lying in and along the right-of-way of the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railway Company in the village are hereby fixed at the following elevation above the village datum: 
At the east line of the village it shall be 41.6 feet above village datum; and at its crossing of Hollywood Avenue in the village, 41.9 feet above village datum; and at its crossing with Prairie Avenue in the village, 43.5 feet above village datum; and at its crossing at Maple Avenue in the village, 47.10 feet above village datum; and its intersection with Eberly Avenue at the west line of the village, 59.2 feet above village datum. 
(b)  All elevations of such tracks in and along the right-of-way of the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railway Company in the village shall comply with the profile of such company's right-of-way in the village, which profile of such company's right-of-way is on file with the village clerk and which is hereby adopted and made part of this section. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railway Company, or its agent, to raise or lower its railroad tracks running in and along its right-of-way within the limits of the village to any other grade, except that which is hereby established, without the written consent of the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1940, § 4.004; Code 1964, § 01-10; Ord. No. 2015-29, § 9 , 4-27-2015) 
State Law reference— Street Railroad Right of Way Act, 610 ILCS 115/0.01 et seq.; safety requirements for track, facilities and equipment, 625 ILCS 5/18c-7401.  
Secs. 46-359—46-389. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - EXCAVATIONS 
 
Sec. 46-390. - Permit required. 
No person shall excavate any portion of any public way without first obtaining a permit therefore as provided in this division.  
Sec. 46-391. - New curb cuts prohibited for residential uses or districts. 
(a)  For all properties improved with residential uses or located in residential zoning districts as defined by the zoning provisions of this Code, no new curb cut on a public street shall be permitted where an alley is available to be used for access. Where an alley is not available for access, a property owner may apply for a curb cut on a public street. 
(b)  The department of public works and safety shall review the application and make a recommendation to the division of building and zoning of the department of administration. The zoning enforcement administrator or, in the absence of a zoning enforcement administrator, the village manager shall review the application. 
(c)  Should the zoning enforcement administrator or, in the absence of a zoning enforcement administrator, the village manager find that the application complies with the requirements of this section, the application for a curb cut shall be approved and a curb cut permit shall be issued. 
(Code 1940, § 40.048; Code 1964, § 24-15; Ord. No. 2008-33, § 1(24-15), 4-14-2008)  
Sec. 46-392. - Permit fees. 
The fees to be paid for permits issued pursuant to this division shall be in the amount provided in the village fee schedule. 
(Code 1940, § 40.048; Code 1964, § 24-16; Ord. No. 1974-03, § 1, 5-13-1974; Ord. No. 99-11, 3-22-1999; Ord. No. 2005-08, 2-28-2005)  
Sec. 46-393. - Cash deposits. 
(a)  In addition to the permit fee, no permit shall be issued under this division unless the applicant makes a cash deposit with the chief building inspector in the amount provided in the village fee schedule. 
(b)  The deposit made pursuant to this section shall be refunded to the permittee upon return of the cash deposit receipt after the opening in the street or public ground has been restored to its original condition. The deposit shall be reduced by the amount of the cost of replacing the pavement or repairing the public ground. 
(c)  Any deposit not redeemed within two years after completion of the work shall be forfeited to the village. 
(Code 1940, §§ 40.049, 40.052; Code 1964, § 24-17; Ord. No. 1974-03, § 1, 5-13-1974)  
Sec. 46-394. - J.U.L.I.E. processing fees. 
(a)  If a resident or business requests a J.U.L.I.E. check to be conducted on private property, the resident or business shall reimburse the village for marking the J.U.L.I.E. location at the hourly rate a maintenance operator II is paid to mark the location, plus material costs. There will be a one hour minimum cost for marking a J.U.L.I.E. location. 
(b)  The village will issue an invoice to the resident or business owner within 30 days the J.U.L.I.E. location was made. Failure to pay the invoice within 60 days of the J.U.L.I.E. location will result in a denial of all subsequent village permit requests until said balance is paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 2005-07, 2-28-2005)  
Sec. 46-395. - Time limit on work permits; notice of completion. 
Openings or excavations authorized by a permit issued under this division shall be made within five days from the date of such permit, unless an extension is granted, and the work for which such opening or excavation was made shall be completed within three days thereafter. The village shall be immediately notified as to the completion of such work. 
(Code 1940, § 40.050; Code 1964, § 24-19)  
Sec. 46-396. - Backfilling and pavement replacement. 
Any person obtaining a permit under this division shall backfill all excavations in any pavement, street, alley or other public ground in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  Tunneling will not be allowed in excess of two feet under the pavement except in unusual circumstances as determined by the director of public works. 
(2)  All trench excavations shall be backfilled and the material compacted in accordance with Article 550.07 of the latest version of the Illinois Department of Transportation's Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction. Method 1 which consists of depositing the backfill material in uniform lifts not exceeding 12 inches in depth, and compacting by mechanical means shall be used to compact the trench backfill. 
(Code 1940, § 40.051; Code 1964, § 24-20; Ord. No. 2015-29, § 10 , 4-27-2015)  
Sec. 46-397. - Repaving standards. 
All pavement openings shall be repaired in a method approved by the village engineer or the supervisor of building and zoning. No pavement shall be removed until written approval of the method of repair has been received from the village. 
(Code 1940, § 40.051; Code 1964, § 24-20; Ord. No. 2015-29 , § 11, 4-27-2015)  
Secs. 46-398—46-422. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - UTILITY CONSTRUCTION IN RIGHTS-OF-WAY 
 
Sec. 46-423. - Purpose and scope. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this chapter is to establish policies and procedures for constructing facilities on rights-of-way within the village's jurisdiction, which will provide public benefit consistent with the preservation of the integrity, safe usage, and visual qualities of the village rights-of-way and the village as a whole. 
(b)  Intent. In enacting this article, the village intends to exercise its authority over the rights-of-way in the village and, in particular, the use of the public ways and property by utilities, by establishing uniform standards to address issues presented by utility facilities, including, without limitation: 
(1)  Prevent interference with the use of streets, sidewalks, alleys, parkways and other public ways and places; 
(2)  Prevent the creation of visual and physical obstructions and other conditions that are hazardous to vehicular and pedestrian traffic; 
(3)  Prevent interference with the facilities and operations of the village's utilities and of other utilities lawfully located in rights-of-way or public property; 
(4)  Protect against environmental damage, including damage to trees, from the installation of utility facilities; 
(5)  Protect against increased stormwater runoff due to structures and materials that increase impermeable surfaces; 
(6)  Preserve the character of the neighborhoods in which facilities are installed; 
(7)  Preserve open space, particularly the tree-lined parkways that characterize the village's residential neighborhoods; 
(8)  Prevent visual blight from the proliferation of facilities in the rights-of-way; and 
(9)  Ensure the continued safe use and enjoyment of private properties adjacent to utility facilities locations. 
(c)  Facilities subject to this article. This article applies to all facilities on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within the rights-of-way within the jurisdiction of the village. A facility lawfully established prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived may continue to be maintained, repaired and operated by the utility as presently constructed and located, except as may be otherwise provided in any applicable franchise, license or similar agreement. 
(d)  Franchises, licenses, or similar agreements. The village, in its discretion and as limited by law, may require utilities to enter into a franchise, license or similar agreement for the privilege of locating their facilities on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within the village rights-of-way. Utilities that are not required by law to enter into such an agreement may request that the village enter into such an agreement. In such an agreement, the village may provide for terms and conditions inconsistent with this article. 
(e)  Effect of franchises, licenses, or similar agreements. 
(1)  Utilities other than telecommunications providers. In the event that a utility other than a telecommunications provider has a franchise, license or similar agreement with the village, such franchise, license or similar agreement shall govern and control during the term of such agreement and any lawful renewal or extension thereof. 
(2)  Telecommunications providers. In the event of any conflict with, or inconsistency between, the provisions of this article and the provisions of any franchise, license or similar agreement between the village and any telecommunications provider, the provisions of such franchise, license or similar agreement shall govern and control during the term of such agreement and any lawful renewal or extension thereof. 
(f)  Conflicts with other articles. This article supersedes all chapters or parts of chapters adopted prior hereto that are in conflict herewith, to the extent of such conflict. 
(g)  Conflicts with state and federal laws. In the event that applicable federal or state laws or regulations conflict with the requirements of this article, the utility shall comply with the requirements of this article to the maximum extent possible without violating federal or state laws or regulations. 
(h)  Sound engineering judgment. The village shall use sound engineering judgment when administering this article and may vary the standards, conditions, and requirements expressed in this article when the village so determines. Nothing herein shall be construed to limit the ability of the village to regulate its rights-of-way for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 2007-99, § 2(37-1), 12-10-2007)  
Sec. 46-424. - Definitions. 
As used in this article and unless the context clearly requires otherwise, the words and terms listed shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section. Any term not defined in this section shall have the meaning ascribed to it in 92 Ill. Admin. Code § 530.30, unless the context clearly requires otherwise. 
AASHTO means the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials. 
ANSI means the American National Standards Institute. 
Applicant means a person applying for a permit under this article. 
ASTM means the American Society for Testing and Materials. 
Backfill means the methods or materials for replacing excavated material in a trench or pit. 
Bore or boring means to excavate an underground cylindrical cavity for the insertion of a pipe or electrical conductor. 
Cable operator means that term as defined in 47 USC 522(5). 
Cable service means that term as defined in 47 USC 522(6). 
Cable system means that term as defined in 47 USC 522(7). 
Carrier pipe means the pipe enclosing the liquid, gas or slurry to be transported. 
Casing means a structural protective enclosure for transmittal devices such as: carrier pipes, electrical conductors, and fiber optic devices. 
Clear zone means the total roadside border area, starting at the edge of the pavement, available for safe use by errant vehicles. This area may consist of a shoulder, a recoverable slope, a nonrecoverable slope, and a clear runout area. The desired width is dependent upon the traffic volumes and speeds, and on the roadside geometry. Distances are specified in the AASHTO Roadside Design Guide. 
Coating means protective wrapping or mastic cover applied to buried pipe for protection against external corrosion. 
Code means the Municipal Code of the Village of Brookfield. 
Conductor means wire carrying electrical current. 
Conduit means a casing or encasement for wires or cables. 
Construction or construct means the installation, repair, maintenance, placement, alteration, enlargement, demolition, modification or abandonment in place of facilities. 
Cover means the depth of earth or backfill over buried utility pipe or conductor. 
Crossing facility means a facility that crosses one or more right-of-way lines of a right-of-way. 
Director of public works means the village director of public works or his designee. 
Disrupt the right-of-way means, for the purposes of this article, any work that obstructs the right-of-way or causes a material adverse effect on the use of the right-of-way for its intended use. Such work may include, without limitation, the following: excavating or other cutting; placement (whether temporary or permanent) of materials, equipment, devices, or structures; damage to vegetation; and compaction or loosening of the soil, and shall not include the parking of vehicles or equipment in a manner that does not materially obstruct the flow of traffic on a highway. 
Emergency means any immediate maintenance to the facility required for the safety of the public using or in the vicinity of the right-of-way or immediate maintenance required for the health and safety of the general public served by the utility. 
Encasement means provision of a protective casing. 
Equipment means materials, tools, implements, supplies, and/or other items used to facilitate construction of facilities. 
Excavation means the making of a hole or cavity by removing material, or laying bare by digging. 
Extra heavy pipe means pipe meeting ASTM standards for this pipe designation. 
Facility means all structures, devices, objects, and materials (including, but not limited to, track and rails, wires, ducts, fiber optic cable, antennas, vaults, boxes, equipment enclosures, cabinets, pedestals, poles, conduits, grates, covers, pipes, cables, and appurtenances thereto) located on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within rights-of-way under this article. For purposes of this chapter, the term "facility" shall not include any facility owned or operated by the village. 
Freestanding facility means a facility that is not a crossing facility or a parallel facility, such as an antenna, transformer, pump, or meter station. 
Frontage road means roadway, usually parallel, providing access to land adjacent to the highway where it is precluded by control of access to a highway. 
Hazardous materials means any substance or material which, due to its quantity, form, concentration, location, or other characteristics, is determined by the director of public works to pose an unreasonable and imminent risk to the life, health or safety of persons or property or to the ecological balance of the environment, including, but not limited to, explosives, radioactive materials, petroleum or petroleum products or gases, poisons, etiology (biological) agents, flammables, corrosives or any substance determined to be hazardous or toxic under any federal or state law, statute or regulation. 
Highway means a specific type of right-of-way used for vehicular traffic, including rural or urban roads or streets. The term "highway" includes all highway land and improvements, including roadways, ditches and embankments, bridges, drainage structures, signs, guardrails, protective structures and appurtenances necessary or convenient for vehicle traffic. 
Highway Code means the Illinois Highway Code, 605 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq., as amended from time to time. 
Holder means a person or entity that has received authorization to offer or provide cable or video service from the ICC pursuant to the Illinois Cable and Video Competition Law, 220 ILCS 5/21-401. 
ICC means the Illinois Commerce Commission. 
IDOT means the Illinois Department of Transportation. 
Jacking means pushing a pipe horizontally under a roadway by mechanical means with or without boring. 
Jetting means pushing a pipe through the earth using water under pressure to create a cavity ahead of the pipe. 
Joint use means the use of pole lines, trenches or other facilities by two or more utilities. 
J.U.L.I.E. means the Joint Utility Locating Information for Excavators utility notification program. 
Major intersection means the intersection of two or more major arterial highways. 
Occupancy means the presence of facilities on, over or under right-of-way. 
Parallel facility means a facility that is generally parallel or longitudinal to the centerline of a right-of-way. 
Parkway means any portion of the right-of-way not improved by street or sidewalk. 
Pavement cut means the removal of an area of pavement for access to facility or for the construction of a facility. 
Permittee means that entity to which a permit has been issued pursuant to sections 46-74 and 46-75. 
Petroleum products pipelines means pipelines carrying crude or refined liquid petroleum products, including, but not limited to, gasoline, distillates, propane, butane, or coal-slurry. 
Practicable means that which is performable, feasible or possible, rather than that which is simply convenient. 
Pressure means the internal force acting radially against the walls of a carrier pipe expressed in pounds per square inch gauge (psig). 
Prompt means that which is done within a period of time specified by the village. If no time period is specified, the period shall be 30 days. 
Public entity means a legal entity that constitutes or is part of the government, whether at local, state or federal level. 
Restoration means the repair of a right-of-way, highway, roadway, or other area disrupted by the construction of a facility. 
Right-of-way or rights-of-way means any street, alley, other land or waterway, dedicated or commonly used for pedestrian or vehicular traffic or other similar purposes, including utility easements, in which the village has the right and authority to authorize, regulate or permit the location of facilities other than those of the village. The term "right-of-way" or "rights-of-way" shall not include any real or personal village property that is not specifically described in the previous two sentences and shall not include village buildings, fixtures and other structures or improvements, regardless of whether they are situated in the right-of-way. 
Roadway means that part of the highway that includes the pavement and shoulders. 
Sale of telecommunications at retail means the transmitting, supplying, or furnishing of telecommunications and all services rendered in connection therewith for a consideration, other than between a parent corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries or between wholly owned subsidiaries, when the gross charge made by one such corporation to another such corporation is not greater than the gross charge paid to the retailer for their use or consumption and not for sale. 
Security fund means that amount of security required pursuant to section 46-432. 
Shoulder means a width of roadway, adjacent to the pavement, providing lateral support to the pavement edge and providing an area for emergency vehicular stops and storage of snow removed from the pavement. 
Sound engineering judgment means a decision consistent with generally accepted engineering principles, practices and experience. 
Telecommunication includes, but is not limited to, messages or information transmitted through use of local, toll and wide area telephone service, channel services, telegraph services, teletypewriter service, computer exchange service, private line services, mobile radio services, cellular mobile telecommunications services, stationary two-way radio, paging service and any other form of mobile or portable one-way or two-way communications, and any other transmission of messages or information by electronic or similar means, between or among points by wire, cable, fiber optics, laser, microwave, radio, satellite, or similar facilities. The term "private line" means a dedicated nontraffic sensitive service for a single customer that entitles the customer to exclusive or priority use of a communications channel, or a group of such channels, from one or more specified locations to one or more other specified locations. The term "telecommunications" shall not include value added services in which computer processing applications are used to act on the form, content, code and protocol of the information for purposes other than transmission. The term "telecommunications" shall not include purchase of telecommunications by a telecommunications service provider for use as a component part of the service provided by such provider to the ultimate retail consumer who originates or terminates the end-to-end communications. The term "telecommunications" shall not include the provision of cable services through a cable system as defined in the Cable Communications Act of 1984 (47 USC 521 and following), as now or hereafter amended, or cable or other programming services subject to an open video system fee payable to the village through an open video system as defined in the Rules of the Federal Communications Commission (47 CFR 76.1500 and following), as now or hereafter amended. 
Telecommunications provider means any person that installs, owns, operates or controls facilities in the right-of-way used or designed to be used to transmit telecommunications in any form. 
Telecommunications retailer means and includes every person engaged in making sales of telecommunications at retail as defined herein. 
Trench means a relatively narrow open excavation for the installation of an underground facility. 
Utility means the individual or entity owning or operating any facility as defined in this article. 
Vent means a pipe to allow the dissipation into the atmosphere of gases or vapors from an underground casing. 
Video service means that term as defined in Section 21-201(v) of the Illinois Cable and Video Competition Law of 2007, 220 ILCS 21-201(v). 
Village means the Village of Brookfield. 
Water lines means pipelines carrying raw or potable water.
