Sec. 54-945. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Sec. 54-945 was repealed at the request of the village, per an e-mail dated June 2, 2014. The former § 54-945 pertained to installation, control and maintenance; manner of parking and derived from Code 1964, § 18-137.03; Ord. No. 1986-6, adopted Jan. 27, 1986; Ord. No. 95-46, adopted Oct. 9, 1995.  
Sec. 54-946. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Sec. 54-946 was repealed at the request of the village, per an e-mail dated June 2, 2014. The former § 54-946 pertained to meter to indicate legal parking period and expiration of time and derived from Code 1964, § 18-137.04; Ord. No. 1986-6, adopted Jan. 27, 1986; Ord. No. 95-46, adopted Oct. 9, 1995.  
Sec. 54-947. - Deposit of fee required; time allowed on deposit. 
The driver, operator, owner or other person controlling the operation or parking of any vehicle parked within any parking device fee zone of the village, immediately after such vehicle has been brought to a complete stop within a parking space adjacent to the parking fee device, or within a parking lot served by one singular parking fee device, shall immediately deposit a coin or paper currency of the United States in, and as appropriate to that particular parking fee device. 
(Code 1964, § 18-137.05; Ord. No. 1986-6, 1-27-1986; Ord. No. 95-46, 10-9-1995)  
Sec. 54-948. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Sec. 54-948 was repealed at the request of the village, per an e-mail dated June 2, 2014. The former § 54-948 pertained to overtime parking and derived from Code 1964, § 18-137.06(a); Ord. No. 1986-6, adopted Jan. 27, 1986; Ord. No. 95-46, adopted Oct. 9, 1995.  
Sec. 54-949. - Use of coin substitutes prohibited. 
No person shall deposit, or cause to be deposited, in any parking fee device any slug, device, paper, or metallic substitute for a coin or paper currency of the United States. 
(Code 1964, § 18-137.07; Ord. No. 1986-6, 1-27-1986; Ord. No. 1995-46, 10-9-1995)  
Sec. 54-950. - Tampering with or damaging devices prohibited. 
No person shall deface, injure, tamper with, open or willfully break, or destroy, any parking fee collection device, or impair the usefulness of any parking fee collection device, installed under this article. 
(Code 1964, § 18-137.07; Ord. No. 1986-6, 1-27-1986; Ord. No. 1995-46, 10-9-1995; E-mail of 6-2-2014)  
Sec. 54-951. - Prohibited parking practices. 
The following acts in respect to the driving, operation, control or parking of any vehicle within any parking device fee zone of the village are forbidden: 
(1)  The placement, parking or leaving of any vehicle in any parking space within the parking device fee zone beyond the lawful parking period as prescribed by this division or any other ordinance or police or engineer's regulation of the village is unlawful and a violation of this division. 
(Code 1964, § 18-137.08(a)—(c); Ord. No. 1986-6, 1-27-1986; Ord. No. 95-46, 10-9-1995; E-mail of 6-2-2014)  
Sec. 54-952. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Sec. 54-952 was repealed at the request of the village, per an e-mail dated June 2, 2014. The former § 54-952 pertained to method of parking and derived from Code 1964, § 18-137.08(4); Ord. No. 1986-6, adopted Jan. 27, 1986; Ord. No. 95-46, adopted Oct. 9, 1995.  
Sec. 54-953. - Daily fee parking device zones. 
(a)  Parking device fee zones include certain daily fee zones. The fee to park in a daily fee parking zone shall be the amount provided in the village fee schedule for each calendar day or portion thereof. 
(b)  The public parking lot located north of the village municipal building shall be a daily fee parking zone. 
(Code 1964, §§ 18-137.09, 18-137.10; Ord. No. 2006-60, 7-10-2006)  
Secs. 54-954—54-979. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 11. - COMMUTER PARKING PERMITS 
 
Sec. 54-980. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or to permit any of his agents or employees to park any motor vehicle within any lot or parking space within and under the control of the village where such lot or space is posted with notice indicating the requirement of a special parking permit or the payment of a daily parking fee for the use of such lot or space. 
(Code 1964, § 18-201; Ord. No. 1986-4, 1-13-1986)  
Sec. 54-981. - Application. 
Any person desiring a permit to allow for the use of any lot or parking space which is so restricted as to require a permit shall file a form provided therefor, which shall set forth the name, address and telephone number of the applicant, a description of the motor vehicle for which the permit is desired, and such other information as may be prescribed. 
(Code 1964, § 18-202; Ord. No. 1986-4, 1-13-1986)  
Sec. 54-982. - Permit term. 
(a)  Every parking permit shall be purchased prior to the occupancy of any parking lot or space so posted as to require a commuter parking permit. Permits shall be issued on a monthly basis and a quarterly basis. 
(b)  Monthly permits shall be valid beginning with the first day of the month indicated numerically on the permit and shall expire on the last day of the month indicated numerically on the permit. 
(c)  Quarterly permits shall be issued for four specific quarterly periods. The first quarter shall represent the period from January 1 through March 31, the second quarter shall represent the period from April 1 through June 30, the third quarter shall represent the period from July 1 through September 30, and the fourth quarter shall represent the period from October 1 through December 31. 
(Code 1964, § 18-203; Ord. No. 1986-4, 1-13-1986; Ord. No. 1986-10, 5-12-1986; Ord. No. 1990-4, 1-22-1990; Ord. No. 2005-70, 12-12-2005; Ord. No. 2006-60, 7-10-2006)  
Sec. 54-983. - Fees; proration. 
Fees for parking permits under this division shall be as provided in the village fee schedule and shall be subject to proration as set forth therein. 
(Code 1964, § 18-204; Ord. No. 1986-4, 1-13-1986; Ord. No. 1986-10, 05-12-1986; Ord. No. 1990-4, 1-22-1990; Ord. No. 2006-60, 7-10-2006)  
Sec. 54-984. - Issuance; placement on vehicle. 
(a)  Upon the payment by the applicant of the proper permit fee, the village manager shall issue, or cause to be issued, a permit applied for under this division authorizing the parking of such motor vehicle within those areas so designated. 
(b)  Upon the issuance of a commuter parking permit under this division for a motor vehicle, the village manager shall deliver to the applicant for such permit a transparent sticker permit emblem, which emblem shall bear the words "Commuter Parking Permit" and the expiration date through which such permit is valid. When such emblem is delivered to the applicant, it shall be his duty to affix the same in the lower left-hand corner of the rear windshield, behind the driver, approximately one-half inch from the lower section of the window frame. 
(Code 1964, §§ 18-206, 18-208(a); Ord. No. 1986-4, 1-13-1986; Ord. No. 1990-4, 1-22-1990)  
Sec. 54-985. - Tampering with permit prohibited. 
Any person who shall take, destroy, obliterate or remove any such permit emblem, without the consent of the owner of the vehicle, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and every such wrongful destruction, obliteration or removal of such permit emblem from any vehicle shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Code 1964, § 18-208; Ord. No. 1986-4, 1-13-1986; Ord. No. 1990-4, 1-22-1990)  
Sec. 54-986. - Use of spaces. 
Parking permits issued under the terms of this division do not represent a guarantee by the village of any specific assignment of a parking space. The permits so issued shall be valid at all commuter parking lots and parking spaces under the control of the village and as posted for this specific use. 
(Code 1964, § 18-207; Ord. No. 1986-4, 1-13-1986; Ord. No. 1990-4, 1-22-1990)  
Secs. 54-987—54-1015. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 12. - EMPLOYEE PARKING PERMITS 
 
Sec. 54-1016. - Issuance. 
Upon the completion of an appropriate form, certifying of the fact of employment of the applicant with an authorized business or industry having facilities located within the village and upon the payment of appropriate fees to the village as may be hereafter required and established by the village board, the village manager shall issue, or cause to be issued, a permit applied for under this division authorizing the parking of such motor vehicle displaying said permit within those areas designated for business employee parking. 
(Code 1964, § 18-209(a); Ord. No. 1990-4, 1-22-1990)  
Sec. 54-1017. - Term. 
Such permit shall be valid only for the term of employment or association of the individual with the authorized business or industry, or for such other period of duration as may be hereafter established by the village board. 
(Code 1964, § 18-209(b); Ord. No. 1990-4, 1-22-1990)  
Sec. 54-1018. - Transfer prohibited. 
In no case shall a permit be transferred to another vehicle or person without the expressed written consent of the village. If such unauthorized transfer occurs, said permit is immediately null and void and all benefits, rights and privileges associated therewith are immediately revoked. 
(Code 1964, § 18-209(c); Ord. No. 1990-4, 1-22-1990)  
Sec. 54-1019. - Form and contents. 
Upon the issuance of a business parking permit under the terms of this division for a motor vehicle, the village manager shall deliver to the applicant a permit emblem which shall bear the words "Business Parking Permit," a unique identifying number, and, as may be applicable, the expiration date through which the permit remains valid, unless otherwise rendered void. 
(Code 1964, § 18-210; Ord. No. 90-4, 1-22-1990)  
Sec. 54-1020. - Placement of permit emblem. 
When such emblem is delivered to the applicant, it shall be his duty to affix the same, in the lower left-hand corner of his rear windshield, behind the driver, approximately one-half inch from the lower section of the window frame. It shall also be the responsibility of the applicant to remove such emblem upon the sale or disposal of the vehicle. 
(Code 1964, § 18-210; Ord. No. 90-4, 1-22-1990)  
Sec. 54-1021. - Tampering with permit emblem prohibited. 
Further, any person who shall otherwise take, destroy, obliterate or remove any permit emblem, without the consent of the owner of the vehicle or of the village, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and every such wrongful destruction, obligation or removal of such permit emblem from any vehicle shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Code 1964, § 18-210; Ord. No. 90-4, 1-22-1990)  
Sec. 54-1022. - Unlawful parking prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle upon any street, parking lot, or other area under the jurisdiction of the village where such areas are marked for business employee parking purposes and where such person does not properly display a valid permit emblem during those time periods so requiring display. Said parking emblem does not relieve any responsibility for the conformance with all other parking restrictions and regulations established by this Code or state law. 
(Code 1964, § 18-211; Ord. No. 90-4, 1-22-1990)  
Sec. 54-1023. - Time and location of permissible parking. 
Locations of automobile business parking areas requiring the display of an employee permit emblem shall be as follows: 
(1)  Between 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m., Sunday through Saturday: 
a.  On the north side of Brookfield Avenue, beginning at its intersection with Sunnyside Avenue and continuing west to its intersection with Park Avenue. 
b.  On the north side of Brookfield Avenue, beginning at a point 50 feet east of its intersection with Sunnyside Avenue and continuing to a point 125 feet from the place of beginning. 
(2)  Between 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., Sunday through Saturday: Along the southerly lot line of Lot 14 in Block 30 of the original subdivision of Grossdale Avenue, commencing at the west point of said lot line and extending easterly for a distance of 125 feet. 
(3)  Between 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon, Sunday through Saturday: 
a.  Along the west side of Grand Boulevard, beginning at its intersection with Grant Avenue and extending southerly for a distance of 200 feet. 
b.  Along the southerly side of the median parking area located within Broadway Avenue, beginning at its intersection with Park Avenue and extending in a southwesterly direction for a distance of 250 feet. 
(Code 1964, § 18-211; Ord. No. 90-4, 1-22-1990)  
Secs. 54-1024—54-1044. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 13. - PUBLIC PARKING PERMITS 
 
Sec. 54-1045. - Unlawful parking prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park any motor vehicle not properly displaying in plain view a valid parking permit emblem upon any street, parking lot, or other area at any time when signs posted on such street, parking lot, or other area prohibit parking without a valid parking permit for such street, parking lot, or other area. 
(Code 1964, §§ 18-212(a); Ord. No. 99-52, 12-13-1999)  
Sec. 54-1046. - Hollywood Area permits. 
(a)  Upon the purchase of a village vehicle license, a registered owner of a motor vehicle residing on a street set forth below shall be issued a Hollywood Area ("H") parking permit emblem, entitling the owner to park between 2:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. Monday through Friday in the following areas: 
(1)  On the east and west sides of Hollywood Avenue between Washington Avenue and Parkview Avenue. 
(2)  On the north and south sides of Rockefeller Avenue between Hollywood Avenue and McCormick Avenue. 
(3)  On the north and south sides of Rockefeller Avenue between McCormick and Arden Avenue. 
(4)  On the west side of Hollywood Avenue between Rockefeller Avenue and Washington Avenue. 
(5)  On the east side of Woodside Avenue between Washington Avenue and Brookfield Avenue. 
(6)  On the east side of Rosemear Avenue between Washington Avenue and Parkview Avenue. 
(7)  On the east and west sides of McCormick Avenue between Rockefeller Avenue and Washington Avenue. 
(8)  On the east and west sides of McCormick Avenue between Washington Avenue and Parkview Avenue. 
(9)  On the south side of Parkview Avenue between Golf Road and Woodside Avenue. 
(10)  On the north and south sides of Parkview Avenue between Woodside Avenue and Hollywood Avenue. 
(11)  On the north and south sides of Parkview Avenue between Hollywood Avenue and Rosemear Avenue. 
(12)  On the east and the west sides of McCormick Avenue beginning at Rockefeller Avenue and continuing for a distance of 237 feet. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle between 2:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. Monday through Friday at any of the places specified in subsection (a) above without properly displaying a Hollywood Area ("H") parking permit emblem issued by the village. 
(c)  Hollywood Avenue guest permit. In addition, the owners of each residential dwelling located upon a street set forth in this subsection shall be issued two Hollywood Area ("H") parking emblems for use by their guests. 
(Code 1964, § 18-212(b), (c); Ord. No. 99-52, 12-13-1999; Ord. No. 2016-40 , § 4, 8-22-2016; Ord. No. 2019-24 , § 4, 5-28-2019)  
Sec. 54-1047. - Rockefeller Avenue permits. 
(a)  A fee per semiannual period, or any portion thereof, in the amount provided in the village fee schedule shall be charged for the issuance of a permit emblem authorizing parking on the north side of Rockefeller Avenue between a point 100 feet west of Golf Road to Hollywood Avenue during the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. 
(b)  The fee shall be due and payable on or before January 1 for the period January 1 through June 30, and on or before July 1 for the period July 1 through December 31. 
(c)  There shall be no refund or proration of the permit fee. 
(Code 1964, § 18-212(d); Ord. No. 99-52, 12-13-1999)  
Sec. 54-1048. - Transfer or other conveyance prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person after having acquired a parking permit emblem from the village to sell, convey or transfer a parking permit emblem to another person in exchange for anything of value. Parking permit emblems shall remain the property of the village. 
(Code 1964, §§ 18-212(e), (f); Ord. No. 99-52, 12-13-1999)  
Sec. 54-1049. - Other parking regulations applicable. 
The issuance or display of a parking permit emblem does not relieve the owner or operator of a motor vehicle from responsibility for complying with all other parking restrictions and regulations established within this Code or applicable state law. 
(Code 1964, § 18-212(g); Ord. No. 99-52, 12-13-1999)  
Secs. 54-1050—54-1066. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - BICYCLES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 54-1067. - Applicability. 
The provisions of this article shall apply whenever any bicycle is operated upon any street or public way or upon any path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, subject to those exceptions stated in this article. 
(Code 1940, § 35.072; Code 1964, § 05-2)  
Sec. 54-1068. - Penalties. 
Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-12 of this Code or by suspension or revocation of his bicycle license, or by the impounding of his bicycle for a period not exceeding 30 days, or by any combination of the penalties herein prescribed. 
(Code 1940, § 35.083; Code 1964, § 05-16; Ord. of 12-22-1958, § 1)  
Sec. 54-1069. - Parental responsibility. 
It shall be unlawful for the parent of any child and the guardian of any ward to authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1940, § 35.072; Code 1964, § 05-15)  
Sec. 54-1070. - Riders subject to traffic regulations. 
Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be subject to the provisions of this article and other traffic regulations of the village applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except as otherwise provided in this article and except those provisions that, by their nature, can have no application. 
(Code 1940, § 35.073; Code 1964, § 05-3)  
Sec. 54-1071. - Required equipment. 
(a)  Brakes. Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake adequate to control the movement of and to stop such bicycle whenever necessary. 
(b)  Lamps and reflectors. Every bicycle shall be equipped with a lamp on the front exhibiting a white light visible from a distance of at least 500 feet to the front and with a red reflector on the rear. Every such reflector shall be so designed and maintained as to be visible at night from all distances within 300 feet to 50 feet from such bicycle when directly in front of a motor vehicle displaying lawfully lighted headlamps. A lamp exhibiting a red light visible from a distance of 300 feet to the rear may be used in addition to the rear reflector. 
(c)  Warning device. No person shall ride a bicycle unless it is equipped with a bell or other device capable of giving a signal audible for a distance of at least 100 feet; except that no bicycle shall be equipped with, nor shall any person use upon a bicycle, any siren or whistle. 
(Code 1940, § 35.080; Code 1964, § 05-4)  
Sec. 54-1072. - Riders to use seats; excess riders prohibited. 
A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than upon or astride the permanent and regular seat attached thereto, nor carry any other person upon such bicycle other than upon a firmly attached and regular seat thereon, nor shall any person ride upon a bicycle other than as authorized in this article. No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed and equipped. 
(Code 1940, § 35.081; Code 1964, § 05-5)  
Sec. 54-1073. - Speed. 
No person riding a bicycle shall ride faster than is reasonable and proper in regard to the safety of the rider and others. 
(Code 1940, § 35.081; Code 1964, § 05-6)  
Sec. 54-1074. - Races and endurance contests. 
No person operating a bicycle upon a public street shall participate in any race for speed or an endurance contest with any other vehicle, except under a permit from and under the supervision of the police chief. 
(Code 1940, § 35.081; Code 1964, § 05-7)  
Sec. 54-1075. - Trick riding prohibited. 
No rider of a bicycle shall remove both hands from the handlebars, or feet from the pedals, or practice any acrobatic or fancy riding on any street. 
(Code 1940, § 35.081; Code 1964, § 05-8)  
Sec. 54-1076. - Restriction on riders carrying articles. 
No person riding a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle or article which prevents the rider from keeping both hands upon the handlebars. 
(Code 1940, § 35.081; Code 1964, § 05-9)  
Sec. 54-1077. - Riders not to cling to moving vehicles. 
No person riding upon any bicycle shall attach the same or himself to any moving vehicle upon a roadway. 
(Code 1940, § 35.081; Code 1964, § 05-10)  
Sec. 54-1078. - Riding more than two abreast. 
Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride more than two abreast, except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles. 
(Code 1940, § 35.081; Code 1964, § 05-11)  
Sec. 54-1079. - Operating in parks. 
It shall be unlawful to operate a bicycle in any park in the village, except on paths or trails posted for use by cyclists. 
(Code 1964, § 05-17; Ord. No. 1979-67, 10-8-1979)  
Sec. 54-1080. - Parking regulations. 
No person shall park a bicycle upon a roadway. Bicycles parked in an alley, in a public driveway, on a sidewalk, or on a public path must be in such a position as not to interfere with the safety or movement of the vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
(Code 1940, § 35.081; Code 1964, § 05-12)  
Secs. 54-1081—54-1098. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 54-1099. - Required. 
No resident owner of a bicycle shall ride or propel such bicycle or permit to be ridden by another any bicycle owned by him on any street or public way in the village, or upon any part thereof, unless such bicycle has been licensed by the village. 
(Code 1940, § 35.074; Code 1964, § 05-22)  
Sec. 54-1100. - Application. 
Application for a license to own and operate a bicycle shall be made to the police chief upon a form to be provided by the police chief. 
(Code 1940, § 35.075; Code 1964, § 05-23; Ord. of 12-22-1958, § 1)  
Sec. 54-1101. - Fees. 
The fee for a bicycle license required by this division shall be in the amount provided in the village fee schedule and shall be paid at the time the license is issued. 
(Code 1940, § 35.075; Code 1964, § 05-24; Ord. of 12-22-1958, § 1)  
Sec. 54-1102. - Inspection prerequisite to issuance. 
The police chief shall inspect each bicycle presented to him for licensing and shall have the authority to refuse a license for any such bicycle found to be unsafe because of its mechanical condition. 
(Code 1940, § 35.079; Code 1964, § 05-25)  
Sec. 54-1103. - Issuance. 
The police chief, upon proper application and payment of the prescribed fee, shall have authority to issue licenses required by this division. 
(Code 1940, § 35.076; Code 1964, § 05-26)  
Sec. 54-1104. - License plate. 
(a)  Upon the issuance of a license under this division, the police chief shall issue a proper plate for the bicycle; and he shall cause such plate to be firmly attached to the frame of the bicycle in such a position as to be plainly visible from the rear. The removal of any such plate, except by proper authority or upon transfer of ownership, shall be a violation of this division. 
(b)  Upon the sale or transfer of a licensed bicycle, the licensee thereof shall remove and surrender to the police chief the attached license plate, or may have such plate assigned gratis to another bicycle owned by him. 
(Code 1940, §§ 35.077, 35.078; Code 1964, § 05-27)  
Sec. 54-1105. - Records to be kept. 
The police chief shall register all licenses issued under this division and keep records of all fees collected for the issuance of such licenses. Such records shall be public records. 
(Code 1940, § 35.076; Code 1964, § 05-28)  
Secs. 54-1106—54-1133. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - BICYCLE SHOPS 
 
Sec. 54-1134. - Equipment required on bicycles offered for rent. 
Bicycles offered for rent by bicycle shops shall be equipped with lights and all safety equipment required and shall be kept in safe working order. 
(Code 1940, § 25.106; Code 1964, § 05-13)  
Sec. 54-1135. - Inspections. 
The police chief shall inspect all bicycle shops periodically and check all used bicycles and bicycles offered for rent to see that they meet all safety requirements in lights and equipment, and to see that such shops are complying with all applicable state laws and provisions of this Code and other village ordinances. 
(Code 1940, §§ 25.106, 25.107; Code 1964, § 05-14)  
Secs. 54-1136—54-1163. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XI. - VEHICLE EQUIPMENT  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 54-1164. - Use of horn in quiet zones. 
Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating a zone of quiet, as provided in section 54-358(5), no person operating a motor vehicle within such zone shall sound the horn or other warning device of such vehicle, except in an emergency. 
(Code 1940, § 35.040; Code 1964, § 18-86)  
Sec. 54-1165. - Brakes and warning devices. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in charge or control of any vehicle to use such vehicle on the streets, alleys, or public places of the village unless such vehicle is provided with good and sufficient brakes and with a suitable bell, horn or other sounding device. All such equipment shall be in conformity with the requirements of state law. 
(Code 1940, § 35.071; Code 1964, § 18-53)  
Sec. 54-1166. - Mufflers. 
Every motor vehicle operated within the village shall be equipped with a good and sufficient muffler and the muffler of any vehicle shall not be open or "cut out" while the vehicle is in use upon the streets, alleys, or public places of the village. 
(Code 1940, § 35.051; Code 1964, § 18-54)  
Sec. 54-1167. - Maximum length of tow bars. 
It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to tow any motor vehicle upon any street if the drawbar or connection exceeds eight feet from one vehicle to the other. 
(Code 1940, § 35.055; Code 1964, § 18-48)  
Secs. 54-1168—54-1197. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LIGHTS 
 
Sec. 54-1198. - Generally. 
(a)  When upon any street during the period from sunset to sunrise, every motorcycle shall carry one lighted lamp and every motor vehicle two lighted lamps showing white lights, or lights of a yellow or amber tint, visible at least 500 feet in the direction toward which each motorcycle or motor vehicle is proceeding, and each motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer shall also exhibit at least one lighted lamp which shall be so situated as to throw a red light visible for at least 500 feet in the reverse direction, provided, that every trailer having a gross weight of 3,000 pounds or less, including the weight of the trailer and maximum load, shall be equipped with two lighted lamps, one on each side of the rear of such trailer, which shall be so situated as to throw a red light visible for at least 500 feet in the reverse direction. 
(b)  All vehicles, including animal-drawn vehicles, not specifically required to be equipped with lamps by other provisions of this division, shall, during the period from sunset to sunrise, be equipped with at least one lighted lamp or lantern exhibiting a white light visible from a distance of 500 feet to the front of such vehicle and with a lamp or lantern exhibiting a red light visible a distance of 500 feet to rear. 
(Code 1940, §§ 35.063, 35.066; Code 1964, § 18-44)  
Sec. 54-1199. - Number of driving lights required or permitted. 
(a)  At all times during the period from sunset to sunrise, at least two lighted lamps shall be displayed, one on each side at the front of every motor vehicle, except when such vehicle is parked subject to regulations governing lights on parked vehicles. 
(b)  Whenever a motor vehicle equipped with head lamps as herein required is also equipped with any auxiliary lamps or a spot lamp or any other lamp on the front thereof projecting a beam of an intensity greater than 300 candlepower, not more than a total of four of any such lamps on the front of a vehicle shall be lighted at any one time when upon a highway. 
(Code 1940, § 35.069; Code 1964, § 18-45)  
Sec. 54-1200. - Spot lights and auxiliary driving lights. 
(a)  Any motor vehicle may be equipped with not to exceed one spotlight or lamp and every lighted spotlight or lamp shall be so aimed and used upon approaching another vehicle that no part of the high intensity portion of the beam will be directed to the left of the prolongation of the extreme left side of the vehicle nor more than 100 feet ahead of the vehicle. 
(b)  Any motor vehicle may be equipped with not to exceed three auxiliary driving lights or lamps mounted on the front at a height not less than 12 inches nor more than 42 inches above the level upon which the vehicle stands. 
(Code 1940, § 35.067; Code 1964, § 18-46)  
Sec. 54-1201. - Lights for towed vehicles. 
Any vehicle being towed upon any street during a period between sunset and sunrise shall maintain lights on both sides and the rear thereof, visible to the rear and on both sides for a distance of not less than 200 feet. 
(Code 1940, § 35.055; Code 1964, § 18-47)  
Sec. 54-1202. - Dimming of headlights. 
On approaching another vehicle proceeding in an opposite direction and when within not less than 350 feet of the same, any person in charge of a motorcycle or motor vehicle equipped with electric headlights shall dim or drop such headlights. 
(Code 1940, § 35.068; Code 1964, § 18-49)  
Sec. 54-1203. - State license plate to be firmly attached and lighted. 
The state license number plate at the back of a motor vehicle shall be firmly attached to the vehicle so that it will not swing loosely, and shall be so lighted that the numbers on such plate shall be plainly legible and intelligible at a distance of 50 feet. 
(Code 1940, § 35.064; Code 1964, § 18-50)  
Sec. 54-1204. - Light or flag on projecting loads. 
Whenever the load upon any vehicle extends to the rear four feet or more beyond the bed or body of such vehicle, there shall be displayed at the extreme rear end of the load, during the period from sunset to sunrise, a red light or lantern plainly visible from a distance of at least 500 feet to the sides and rear. The red light or lantern required under this section shall be in addition to the red rear light required upon every vehicle. At any other time there shall be displayed at the extreme rear end of such load a red flag or cloth not less than 16 inches square. 
(Code 1940, § 35.065; Code 1964, § 18-51)  
Sec. 54-1205. - Prohibited lights. 
(a)  Red lights. No person shall drive or move any vehicle or equipment upon any street with any lamp or device thereon displaying a red light visible from directly in front thereof. 
(b)  Flashing lights. Flashing lights are prohibited on motor vehicles, except as a means for indicating a right or left turn or the presence of a vehicular traffic hazard requiring unusual care in approaching, overtaking or passing. 
(c)  Exceptions. Subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles or to vehicles of the second division designed for towing or hoisting disabled vehicles while actually being used for such purposes, or to motor vehicles or equipment of the state, the village, contractors or public utilities while engaged in maintenance or construction operations within the limits of construction projects. In addition, subsection (b) of this section shall not apply to mail delivery vehicles when actually used for such purpose. 
(Code 1940, § 35.070; Code 1964, § 18-52)  
Secs. 54-1206—54-1228. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XII. - TRUCK AND WEIGHT RESTRICTIONS 
 
Sec. 54-1229. - Gross weight limit; exceptions. 
It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle on any street in the village when the weight of the vehicle is in excess of the weight shown by signs which indicate gross weight limit except for the purpose of making a delivery or picking up a load, in which case such vehicle may be driven on such street for not more than the minimum distance necessary for the purpose of making a delivery or picking up a load. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Authorized emergency vehicles. 
(2)  Vehicles equipped with self-compactors for hauling garbage or refuse. 
(3)  Vehicles operated by a public utility when transporting equipment required for emergency repair of public utility facilities. 
(4)  A combination of vehicles consisting of a two-truck and a disabled vehicle or vehicles when engaged in towing such disabled vehicles from the roadway to the nearest qualified repair station, provided that neither the disabled vehicle, nor any vehicle being towed, nor the towtruck itself, exceeds the weight limitations permitted under this section. 
(5)  School buses and buses operated by a public transportation system. 
(Code 1940, §§ 35.032, 35.033; Code 1964, § 18-73; Ord. of 5-13-1963, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 11-25-1963, § 1; Ord. of 6-26-1967, § 1; Ord. No. 1968-33, § 1, 11-25-1968; Ord. No. 1977-32, § 1, 8-22-1977; Ord. No. 1978-52, § 1, 12-11-1978)  
Sec. 54-1230. - Truck traffic prohibited on certain streets. 
The following streets are designated as no through truck traffic streets: 
(1)  On Sahler Avenue between Sunnyside and Maple Avenues. 
(2)  On Maple Avenue between 31st Street and 47th Street. 
(3)  On the 4500 and 4600 blocks of Forest Avenue and Grove Avenue, in those portions zoned for single-family and multifamily purposes. 
(Code 1964, § 18-96.03; Ord. No. 1984-8, 2-13-1984; Ord. No. 1987-2, 1-12-1987; Ord. No. 1990-19, 3-26-1990)  
Secs. 54-1231—54-1248. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIII. - PEDESTRIANS 
 
Sec. 54-1249. - Obedience to traffic-control signals. 
Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic-control signals at intersections as provided in 625 ILCS 5/11-1001, and in this article, but at all other places pedestrians shall be accorded the privileges and shall be subject to the restrictions as stated in this article. 
(Code 1940, § 35.084; Code 1964, § 18-148) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, 625 ILCS 5/11-1001.  
Sec. 54-1250. - Right-of-way at crosswalks. 
(a)  Where traffic-control signals are not in place or not in operation, the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be to so yield, to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within any marked crosswalk or within any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection, except as otherwise provided in this article. 
(b)  Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass such stopped vehicle. 
(c)  Where stop signs or flashing red signals are in place at an intersection or at plainly marked crosswalk between intersections, drivers of vehicles shall stop before entering the nearest crosswalk and pedestrians within or entering the crosswalk at either edge of the roadway shall have the right-of-way over vehicles so stopped. Drivers of vehicles having so yielded the right-of-way to pedestrians within or entering the nearest crosswalk at an intersection shall also yield the right-of-way to pedestrians within any other crosswalk at the intersection. 
(Code 1940, § 35.085; Code 1964, § 18-149)  
Sec. 54-1251. - Use of right half of crosswalks. 
Pedestrians shall move, whenever practicable, upon the right half of crosswalks. 
(Code 1940, § 35.087; Code 1964, § 18-150)  
Sec. 54-1252. - Crossing roadway at other than crosswalk. 
(a)  Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(b)  Any pedestrian crossing a roadway at a point where a pedestrian tunnel or overhead pedestrian crossing has been provided shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(c)  Between adjacent intersections at which traffic-control signals are in operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a marked crosswalk. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, every driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any roadway and shall give warning by sounding the horn, when necessary, and shall exercise proper precaution upon observing any child or any confused or incapacitated person upon a roadway. 
(Code 1940, § 35.086; Code 1964, § 18-151)  
Sec. 54-1253. - Duty to walk on left of pavement, etc. 
It shall be the duty of any person walking along and upon improved streets or highways in the village to keep on the left of the paved portion, or on the left shoulder thereof, and, upon meeting a vehicle when walking on such paved portion, to step off to the left. 
(Code 1940, § 35.089; Code 1964, § 18-152)  
Sec. 54-1254. - Walking on roadway prohibited where sidewalks provided. 
Where sidewalks are provided, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway. 
(Code 1964, § 18-153)  
Sec. 54-1255. - Soliciting rides. 
No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride from the driver of any private vehicle. 
(Code 1940, § 35.088; Code 1964, § 18-154)  
Secs. 54-1256—54-1283. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIV. - ABANDONED AND INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Abandonment of vehicle prohibited, 625 ILCS 5/4-201. 
 
Sec. 54-1284. - Abandonment prohibited. 
No person shall abandon any vehicle, or any part thereof, on any public or private property within the village. A person commits abandonment when he is the owner of the vehicle within the village limits and that vehicle is: 
(1)  Left unattended and is creating a traffic hazard or nuisance because of its position in relation to the roadway. 
(2)  Left unattended and its physical appearance is causing traffic to be impeded. 
(3)  Left unattended upon any public way and is parked illegally and in violation of the law. 
(4)  Has not been moved or used for seven consecutive days or more and is apparently deserted. 
(5)  Is in a state of disrepair, rendering the vehicle incapable of being driven in its present condition. 
(6)  Left on private property without the property owner's consent. 
(Code 1964, § 18-161; Ord. No. 1968-4, § 1, 2-12-1968; Ord. No. 1990-33, 7-9-1990)  
Sec. 54-1285. - Inoperable vehicles declared a nuisance. 
(a)  The presence of an abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, inoperable, junked, partially dismantled, vehicle, or parts thereof, on any public or private property within the village is hereby declared a public nuisance which may be abated in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to any vehicle enclosed within a building on private property or any vehicle held in connection with a business enterprise, properly operated in a commercial zoned area, having an enclosed storage area for such vehicles. 
(Code 1964, § 18-162; Ord. No. 1968-4, § 1, 2-12-1968; Ord. No. 1990-33, 7-9-1990)  
Sec. 54-1286. - Right of entry for inspection. 
The police chief or his delegated representative may enter upon private property at all reasonable hours for the purpose of inspecting such vehicles, posting notices on such vehicles, or removing and impounding such vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person to impede or prevent the police chief or his representative from entering upon private property for the purposes of carrying out his duties hereunder. 
(Code 1964, § 18-163; Ord. No. 1968-4, § 1, 2-12-1968; Ord. No. 1990-33, 7-9-1990)  
Sec. 54-1287. - Improperly parked vehicles on public property. 
Any vehicle parked in violation of traffic regulations or parked so as to obstruct the free flow of traffic or to cause a traffic hazard may be immediately removed by order of the police department. Any such vehicle removed under this section shall be held until the owner or authorized agent pays the reasonable costs of removal or storage. 
(Code 1964, § 18-164; Ord. No. 1968-4, § 1, 2-12-1968; Ord. No. 1990-33, 7-9-1990)  
Sec. 54-1288. - Improperly parked vehicles on private property. 
If a vehicle is parked on private property without the consent of the owner, the vehicle is deemed abandoned and the police department is authorized to remove said vehicle and cause the same to be impounded until lawfully claimed or disposed of, provided the owner of such private property has first signed a complaint against the owner or operator of the vehicle. Any such vehicle removed under this section shall be held until the owner or authorized agent pays the reasonable costs of removal and storage. 
(Code 1964, § 18-165; Ord. No. 1968-4, § 1, 2-12-1968; Ord. No. 1990-33, 7-9-1990)  
Sec. 54-1289. - Abandonment on private property. 
It is unlawful for any person to park, store, or leave any vehicle which is abandoned, dismantled, wrecked, inoperable, or junked upon private property in the village for a period in excess of seven days. 
(Code 1964, § 18-175; Ord. No. 1990-33, 7-9-1990)  
Sec. 54-1290. - Notice of intent to remove vehicle abandoned on private property. 
(a)  Any vehicle left in violation of section 54-1289, shall be removed and impounded as provided herein, after notice has been given by the police department. Such notice shall be given by affixing notice on such vehicles, sending notice by mail to the owner of such vehicle at his last known address if the owner is reasonably ascertainable, and sending notice by mail to the person owning or controlling the property on which such vehicle is located. 
(b)  If none of the above notice methods are possible, then notice shall be given by posting in a conspicuous place upon the private property on which the vehicle is located. 
(c)  The notice shall contain the notice for removal, the date specified for removal and advise that failure to remove the vehicle will result in the vehicle being removed by the police department. 
(Code 1964, § 18-176; Ord. No. 1990-33, 7-9-1990)  
Sec. 54-1291. - Abandonment on public property. 
It is unlawful for any person to park, store, or leave any abandoned, dismantled, wrecked, inoperable, or junked vehicle on any street or other public property in the village for a period in excess of 72 hours. 
(Code 1964, § 18-170; Ord. No. 1990-33, 7-9-1990)  
Sec. 54-1292. - Notice of intent to remove vehicle abandoned on public property. 
Any vehicle left in violation of section 54-1289 shall be removed and impounded as provided herein, after notice has been given by the police department. Such notice shall be given by affixing notice on such vehicles and sending notice by mail to the owner of such vehicle at his last known address if the owner is reasonably ascertainable. The notice shall contain the notice for removal, the time specified for removal and advise that failure to remove the vehicle will result in the vehicle being removed by the police department. 
(Code 1964, § 18-171; Ord. No. 1990-33, 7-9-1990)  
Sec. 54-1293. - Disposition of vehicle by responsible person or possessor. 
All persons are required to dispose of abandoned or inoperable vehicles within seven days after receiving written notification from the police department. In the event of removal and disposition of the vehicle, the owner or occupant of the property where the vehicle has been removed from shall be liable for expenses incurred. 
(Code 1964, § 18-1770; Ord. No. 1990-33, 7-9-1990)  
Sec. 54-1294. - Failure to responsible person to remove; notice of removal by village. 
The police department shall give notice to the registered owner of the vehicle if known, and also to the owner of the property from which the vehicle was removed, that said vehicle has been impounded and stored for violation of this article within 48 hours. Such notice shall contain location of the stored vehicle and the costs incurred for removal and storage. 
(Code 1964, § 18-178; Ord. No. 1990-33, 7-9-1990)  
Secs. 54-1295—54-1316. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XV. - PARADES AND PROCESSIONS 
 
Sec. 54-1317. - Driving in processions. 
Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right edge of the roadway as practical and follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practical and safe. 
(Code 1940, § 35.050; Code 1964, § 18-87)  
Sec. 54-1318. - Driving through processions. 
No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicle comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion and when such vehicles are conspicuously designated. This provision shall not apply at intersections where traffic is controlled by traffic-control signals or police officers. 
(Code 1940, § 35.048; Code 1964, § 18-88)  
Sec. 54-1319. - Permit for funeral processions and parades. 
No funeral procession or parade, except the military forces of the United States, the military forces of this state, and the forces of the police and fire departments, shall occupy, march or proceed along any street or public place, without first having obtained a permit from the police chief. Such permit must be obtained not less than 24 hours prior to the commencement of such funeral procession or parade and such procession or parade must comply with such other applicable regulations as are set forth in this article. 
(Code 1940, § 35.049; Code 1964, § 18-10; Ord. of 6-24-1963, § 1)  
Chapter 56 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Public Utilities Act, 220 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.; Illinois Underground Utility Facilities Damage Prevention Act, 220 ILCS 50/1 et seq.; municipal utilities, 65 ILCS 5/11-117-1 et seq.; Municipal Wastewater Disposal Zones Act, 65 ILCS 90/0.01. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 56-1. - Water and sewer systems combined. 
The water system and sewer system of the village shall be and are hereby combined as one system to be operated as a single unit under the water division. 
(Code 1940, § 37-003(28-1); Code 1964, § 28-1; Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 1, 2, 12-23-1968)  
Sec. 56-2. - Damaging pipe and other property of water and sewer system. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, mark, deface or damage any water or sewer pipe or other property of the village used in connection with its water and sewer system. 
(Code 1940, § 27.016(28-9); Code 1964, § 28-11; Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 3, 4, 12-23-1968)  
Sec. 56-3. - Access to any customer's premises. 
Employees of the combined water and sewer division shall have the right at all reasonable times to access any customer's premises for the purpose of ascertaining the number and type of water and sewer connections to the water and sewer service lines of the village. 
(Code 1964, § 28-42; Ord. No. 1969-8, § 2, 6-23-1969)  
Secs. 56-4—56-24. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - WATER SERVICE  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 56-25. - Use of groundwater as a potable water supply prohibited. 
(a)  As used in this section, potable water is any water used for human or domestic consumption, including, but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming, washing dishes, or preparing foods. 
(b)  Except for such uses or methods in existence before the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, the use of, or attempted use of, groundwater from within the corporate limits of the village, as a potable water supply, by the installation or drilling of wells or by any other method, is hereby prohibited. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of up to $750.00 for each violation. Each day that a violation continues shall be considered a separate violation. 
(Code 1964, § 28-3; Ord. No. 2006-57, 7-10-2006)  
Sec. 56-26. - Water pollution prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to corrupt or render unwholesome or impure the water of any drinking hydrant, spring, stream, pond or reservoir. 
(Code 1940, § 26.001(4)(28-11); Code 1964, § 28-13; Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 3, 4, 12-23-1968)  
Sec. 56-27. - Electrical connections to water system prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to connect any device that transmits electrical current, including, but not limited to, an arc welder, generator, transformer, or rectifier to any water pipe, valve, fire hydrant or other part of the village's water distribution system. This section shall not apply to the village, its employees or agents or any independent contractors hired by the village. 
(Code 1964, § 28-5; Ord. No. 94-12, 2-14-1994)  
Sec. 56-28. - Discontinuance of water service for misrepresentation, unauthorized use or waste. 
The water supply may be cut off from any premises if such water service was obtained through misrepresentation or if any unauthorized use or willful waste of water is found. 
(Code 1940, § 40.044(28-10); Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 3, 4, 12-23-1968)  
Secs. 56-29—56-59. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTIONS AND TAPS 
 
Sec. 56-60. - Persons authorized to tap or connect to water system. 
No person except an authorized agent of the department of public works and services or a licensed plumber acting under the supervision of such department shall tap or make any connection with the water mains in the village. 
(Code 1940, §§ 40.042, 40.045(28-3); Code 1964, § 28-6; Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 3, 4, 12-23-1968)  
Sec. 56-61. - Connections required. 
(a)  Each premises in the village using village water services shall be independently and separately connected by a separate water service pipe with a public water main if a village water main is located not less than 200 feet from the nearest lot line of said property. 
(b)  No permit shall be issued for the construction of any building in the village unless the plans and specifications show connections to a public water main. 
(c)  Every premises in existence prior to the construction of a public water main located not more than 200 feet from the nearest lot line of the property on which the premises stands shall, upon the construction of the public water main, and after written notice, be connected to the water main within one year of the time the water main is so constructed and made available for use, provided that if the premises is serviced by a well which ceases to function properly so that its continued operation constitutes a nuisance or menace to health, the building shall be connected to the adjoining public water main immediately. 
(Code 1964, § 28-7; Ord. No. 1968-35, § 1(28-14), 11-25-1968; Ord. No. 1968-43, § 4, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 95-48, 11-13-1995; Ord. No. 2006-57, 7-10-2006)  
Sec. 56-62. - Tap in and connection permits required; fee. 
No person shall tap in or connect to any water main in the village without first obtaining a permit as required by this section. Application for permit shall be made to the building and planning department on a form provided by the clerk and shall be accompanied by a permit fee in the amount specified in the village fee schedule. 
(Code 1964, § 28-9; Ord. of 11-17-1947, § 1(28-4); Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 3, 4, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1977-20, § 2, 6-27-1977; Ord. No. 98-30, 6-1-1998)  
Sec. 56-63. - Maximum tap size. 
Water main taps shall not exceed one inch unless authority is granted by the director of public works or his designee. 
(Code 1964, § 28-9; Ord. of 11-17-1947, § 1(28-4); Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 3, 4, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1977-20, § 2, 6-27-1977; Ord. No. 98-30, 6-1-1998)  
Sec. 56-64. - Supervision of installation. 
Every water main tap shall be made under the supervision of the director of public works or his designee. 
(Code 1964, § 28-9; Ord. of 11-17-1947, § 1(28-4); Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 3, 4, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1977-20, § 2, 6-27-1977; Ord. No. 98-30, 6-1-1998)  
Sec. 56-65. - Service cock installation standards. 
All service cocks must be inserted at or near the top of the street main, and in no case nearer than one foot to the bell of the pipe, except that when the street main is less than five feet, six inches below the curb grade, such tap shall be made in a manner to least expose the service pipe to damage by frost. 
(Code 1940, §§ 40.042, 40.045(28-3); Code 1964, § 28-6; Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 3, 4, 12-23-1968)  
Sec. 56-66. - Sprinkler system connections; maintenance fee. 
The owner or user of any property utilizing utility lines shall be responsible for maintaining the fire line connections and sprinkler system, and shall avoid the use of said connection except for fire protection purposes. A monthly fee in the amount provided in the village fee schedule shall be paid by the consumer for each sprinkler connection made to the public water system. 
(Code 1964, § 28-15; Ord. No. 1977-20, § 3, 6-27-1977)  
Sec. 56-67. - Maintenance and repair of the water service pipe and meter. 
It shall be the responsibility of the property owner to maintain and repair the water service pipe from the curb stop (round way) to the farthest fixture in the building. The water meter is the responsibility of the village except as otherwise provided by the village board. 
(Code 1964, § 28-8; Ord. of 8-31-1964, § 1(28-3.1); Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 3, 4, 12-23-1968)  
Sec. 56-68. - Deposit required before connection installation. 
Service connections will not be made until the water deposit required by this article has been made. 
(Code 1964, § 28-27; Ord. of 6-12-1967, § 2(28-28); Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 5, 6, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1977-20, § 10, 6-27-1977)  
Secs. 56-69—56-94. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - METERS 
 
Sec. 56-95. - Meters. 
(a)  All buildings shall be equipped with meters and meter reading devices at the owner's expense. The meters and meter reading devices shall be furnished by the village and shall remain the property of the village. The meters will be read and repaired by the water division of the village as often as may be necessary and no additional charge will be made for such services unless otherwise specifically provided in this chapter. 
(b)  Customers or property owners where meters are located within the building must not cover the meters or place obstructions that may prevent convenient access to the meters at any time by the employees of the water division for the purpose of reading or making repairs. 
(c)  The village shall determine the size and number of meters required for any service. 
(Code 1964, § 28-14; Ord. of 12-14-1964, § 1(28-12); Ord. No. 1968-43, § 3, 4, 12-23-1968)  
Sec. 56-96. - Care and protection of water meter and other equipment on consumer's premises. 
Upon the installation of a water meter or any other equipment upon the premises of any water consumer, the consumer shall be held responsible for the care and protection of the same and shall be charged any costs for repair or replacement of the same resulting from his failure to properly protect or care for such meter or equipment. 
(Code 1964, § 28-10; Ord. of 11-17-1947, § 1(28-8); Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 3, 4, 12-23-1968)  
Sec. 56-97. - Meter test fees. 
(a)  In the event a water meter is tested by personnel of the village upon the request of any consumer, a deposit in the amount provided in the village fee schedule shall be made. If, following the test, the tested meter proves to record an amount not in excess of the standards of the American Water Works Association, the deposit shall be refunded in its entirety. 
(b)  In the event a consumer requests a water meter be tested by a certified testing facility, a deposit in the amount provided in the village fee schedule shall be paid to the cashier's office in advance of the testing. If the test reveals that the tested meter proves to record an amount not in excess of the standards of the American Water Works Association, the deposit shall be refunded in its entirety. 
(Code 1964, § 28-26; Ord. of 11-17-1947, § 1(28-26); Ord. of 4-11-1966, § 3; Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 5, 6, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1977-20, § 9, 6-27-1977; Ord. No. 98-30, 6-1-1998)  
Sec. 56-98. - Failure of meter. 
Whenever, for any reason, a water meter fails to operate, a reasonable estimate shall be made by the water and sewer division for billing purposes of the amount of water supplied during the period the meter failed to operate. 
(Code 1964, § 28-43; Ord. No. 1969-8, § 2, 6-23-1969)  
Secs. 56-99—56-124. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - DEPOSITS AND SERVICE CHARGES 
 
Sec. 56-125. - Deposit to secure payment. 
No water shall be supplied to any consumer unless he first makes a deposit with the village manager as security for the payment of water service charges. The amount of the deposit shall be as provided in the village fee schedule. 
(Code 1964, § 28-20; Ord. of 11-17-1947, § 1(28-20); Ord. of 4-11-1966, § 2; Ord. of 6-12-1967, § 1; Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 5, 6, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1977-20, § 6, 6-27-1977)  
Sec. 56-126. - Method of assigning service classes. 
(a)  The village has designated certain water service classes. The service class designation is largely dependent upon the assigned billing period. 
(b)  Water service customers are assigned a monthly or quarterly billing period based on the size of the water meter required and the volume of water use measured. Customers with water meter sized greater than one inch are generally assigned a monthly billing period. Customers with volumes of water use less than 1,200 cubic feet per month are considered for quarterly billing periods. Uncertainties over assignment will be resolved by the water department with an evaluation of the specific service needs of the customer. 
(Code 1940, § 37-010(28-18); Code 1964, § 28-18(b); Ord. of 5-12-1947; Ord. of 11-17-1947, § 1; Ord. of 10-25-1948, § 1; Ord. of 5-10-1957, § 1; Ord. of 4-14-1958, § 1; Ord. of 5-29-1961, § 1; Ord. of 4-11-1966, § 1; Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 5, 6, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1970-1, § 1, 1-26-1970; Ord. No. 1973-27, § 1, 11-26-1973; Ord. No. 1977-20, § 5, 6-27-1977; Ord. No. 1979-11, § A, 3-26-1979; Ord. No. 1980-1, 1-28-1980; Ord. No. 99-41, 11-22-1999; Ord. No. 2001-05, 1-8-2001; Ord. 2002-01, 1-28-2002; Ord. No. 04-16, 2-3-2004; Ord. No. 2012-49, § 2, 8-7-2012)  
Sec. 56-127. - Water classes enumerated. 
(a)  Class WA (general water service). There are three types of Class WA water service: 
(1)  WA1 includes those single-family residential, commercial, industrial or municipal users of the water service with a quarterly water billing period. 
(2)  WA2 includes those water service accounts with multiple residential or commercial subunits serviced through a single water meter with a quarterly water billing period. This class of service includes apartment buildings, mobile home parks, and other commercial or residential uses with multiple subunits located within the same structure, with the exception of hotels or motels. 
(3)  WA3 includes those residential, commercial or industrial customers with quarterly water billing periods located outside of the corporate limits of the village. 
(b)  Class WB (business service). There are three types of Class WB water service: 
(1)  WB1 includes those commercial, industrial or municipal users of the water service with monthly water billing periods. 
(2)  WB2 includes those water service accounts with multiple residential or commercial subunits served through a single water meter with a monthly water billing period. This class includes apartment buildings, mobile home parks, and other commercial or residential uses with multiple subunits located within the same structure with the exception of hotels and motels. 
(3)  WB3 includes those residential, commercial, or industrial customers with monthly water billing periods located outside of the corporate limits of the village. 
(c)  Class WC (special service). There are three types of Class WC water service: 
(1)  WC1 includes the Chicago Zoological Society (Brookfield Zoo) water service account with a monthly water billing period. 
(2)  WC2 includes temporary accounts created for construction operations or other special uses where water service cannot practically be metered. 
(3)  WC3 includes a municipal wholesale account for providing water service to an adjacent community when required during emergency periods. 
(Code 1940, § 37-010(28-18); Code 1964, § 28-18(b); Ord. of 5-12-1947; Ord. of 11-17-1947, § 1; Ord. of 10-25-1948, § 1; Ord. of 5-10-1957, § 1; Ord. of 4-14-1958, § 1; Ord. of 5-29-1961, § 1; Ord. of 4-11-1966, § 1; Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 5, 6, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1970-1, § 1, 1-26-1970; Ord. No. 1973-27, § 1, 11-26-1973; Ord. No. 1977-20, § 5, 6-27-1977; Ord. No. 1979-11, § A, 3-26-1979; Ord. No. 1980-1, 1-28-1980; Ord. No. 99-41, 11-22-1999; Ord. No. 2001-05, 1-8-2001; Ord. 2002-01, 1-28-2002; Ord. No. 04-16, 2-3-2004; Ord. No. 2010-008, § 2, 1-25-2010; Ord. No. 2010-57, § 2, 8-9-2010)  
Sec. 56-128. - Water service charges. 
(a)  Water service charges are as set forth in the village fee schedule, subject to and as supplemented by the provisions of this section. 
(b)  WA2. All charges shall be the same as Class WA1, except that the minimum charge shall apply to each sub-unit of the account served by the single water meter. The sum of the minimum charges assigned to each subunit shall be the minimum charge for the total account, except hotels and motels whose minimum shall be billed as a single unit for that portion of the establishment providing individual accommodations and not by subunits metering individual accommodation units. 
(c)  WB2. All charges shall be the same as Class WB1, except the minimum charge shall apply to each subunit of the account served by single water meter. The sum of the minimum charges assigned to each subunit shall be the minimum charge for the total account, except hotels and motels whose minimum shall be billed as a single unit for that portion of the establishment providing individual accommodations and not by subunits metering individual accommodation units. 
(d)  WB3. All charges shall be the same as Class WB1, except that a 25 percent surcharge shall be added to the billed amount. 
(e)  Class WC1. The charges for service to this account shall be based on the current rate that the village pays for water from the Brookfield/North Riverside Water Commission plus five percent and an annual fee set by agreement between the village and the water customer. 
(f)  Class WC2. The charge for non-metered customer accounts shall be based upon the Class WB1 rates, with estimated water volumes provided by the water department. 
(g)  WC3. The charge for water in this category shall be equal to water commission rate for the volume used plus five percent. 
(Code 1940, § 37-010(28-18); Code 1964, § 28-18(b); Ord. of 5-12-1947; Ord. of 11-17-1947, § 1; Ord. of 10-25-1948, § 1; Ord. of 5-10-1957, § 1; Ord. of 4-14-1958, § 1; Ord. of 5-29-1961, § 1; Ord. of 4-11-1966, § 1; Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 5, 6, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1970-1, § 1, 1-26-1970; Ord. No. 1973-27, § 1, 11-26-1973; Ord. No. 1977-20, § 5, 6-27-1977; Ord. No. 1979-11, § A, 3-26-1979; Ord. No. 1980-1, 1-28-1980; Ord. No. 99-41, 11-22-1999; Ord. No. 2001-05, 1-8-2001; Ord. 2002-01, 1-28-2002; Ord. No. 04-16, 2-3-2004; Ord. No. 2009-006, § 2(28-18), 1-26-2009; Ord. No. 2012-49, § 2, 8-7-2012; Ord. No. 2012-64, 9-10-2012; Ord. No. 2013-05, § 2, 1-28-2013; Ord. No. 2015-05 , § 2, 1-26-2015)  
Sec. 56-129. - Deductions or rebates not allowed for leakage. 
No deductions shall be made nor rebates allowed to any consumer of water on charges accrued as a result of any leakage in any water pipe, tank or other apparatus or device. The amount of water registered by any meter measuring water supply to any building, structure or premises shall be charged and paid for in full, regardless of whether such water was lost by leakage, accident or otherwise. 
(Code 1964, § 28-21; Ord. of 11-17-1947, § 1(28-21); Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 5, 6, 12-23-1968)  
Sec. 56-130. - Billing procedure 
Consumers of water supplied by the village shall be billed every two months, provided, however, that bills will be rendered more frequently upon the request of the consumer and approved by the village manager, or upon direction of the village manager without such request. All bills shall be for the minimum charge, and, in addition thereto, for the amount of water used in excess of the minimum during the previous billing period. 
(Code 1940, § 37.001(28-22); Ord. of 11-17-1947, § 1; Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 5, 6, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1977-20, § 7, 6-27-1977; Ord. No. 2012-49, § 2, 8-7-2012; Ord. No. 2012-64, 9-10-2012; Ord. No. 2018-55 , § 2, 6-25-2018)  
Sec. 56-131. - When and where payable; penalty for delinquency. 
All water bills shall be payable at the office of the village manager on or before the 21st day following the date of billing and all bills paid after the expiration of such 21 days shall be subject to a penalty of ten percent of the amount of the bill. There will be no waiver of late payment penalties, except the Village Manager shall have the discretion to waive late payment penalties when: 
(1)  a customer has faithfully and timely paid his or her water service charges during the preceding twelve-month period; 
(2)  payment is made not more than ten calendar days after the payment due date, and 
(3)  payment is made in person at the village hall during regular business hours. 
(Code 1964, § 28-23; Ord. of 11-17-1947, § 1(28-23); Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 5, 6, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1989-57, 12-11-1989; Ord. No. 2012-49, § 2, 8-7-2012; Ord. No. 2012-64, 9-10-2012; Ord. No. 2018-55 , § 3, 6-25-2018)  
Sec. 56-132. - Discontinuance of service for failure to pay. 
Water service shall be terminated when any bill for metered water service is 35 days past due. The water division shall notify such consumer of the past due billing nine days after the due date of the bill. Five days after such notification, if payment in full is not received, service shall be terminated. Where service is terminated, the consumer may obtain water service by the payment of the past due bill plus a charge in the amount provided in the village fee schedule for the shutting off and opening such service. 
(Code 1964, § 28-24; Ord. of 11-17-1947, § 1(28-24); Ord. of 6-12-1967, § 1; Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 5, 6, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1977-20, § 8, 6-27-1977; Ord. No. 2012-49, § 2, 8-7-2012; Ord. No. 2012-64, 9-10-2012)  
Sec. 56-133. - Liens. 
(a)  Whenever a bill for water service remains unpaid 90 days after it has been rendered, the village manager will file with the recorder of deeds of the county a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the village claims a lien for this amount as well as for all charges for water served subsequent to the period covered by the bill. 
(b)  If the consumer of water whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises, and the village has notice of this, notice shall be mailed to the owner of the premises, or his agent, if his address is known to the village, whenever such bill remains unpaid for a period of 90 days after it has been rendered. 
(c)  The failure of the village to record such lien claim or to mail such notice, or the failure of the owner to receive such notice, shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien. 
(d)  Property subject to a lien for unpaid water charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by bill in equity, in the name of the village. 
(e)  The village attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute such proceedings, in the name of the village, in any court having jurisdiction over such matters, against any property for which the water bill remains unpaid 90 days after it has been rendered. 
(Code 1940, §§ 37.013, 37.014(28-25); Code 1964, § 28-25; Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 5, 6, 12-23-1968)  
Sec. 56-134. - Disposition of revenue. 
All of the revenues and monies derived from the operation of the water division shall be kept and maintained in a separate fund and used only for the purpose of operating and maintaining such system. No monies shall be transferred from water division funds for any purpose except upon vote of the majority members of the board of trustees and then only in the event that such transfer is from funds declared to be surplus over and above any and all requirements of the water division. 
(Code 1940, § 37.012(28-27); Code 1964, § 28-28; Ord. of 11-17-1947, § 1; Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 5, 6, 12-23-1968)  
Secs. 56-135—56-151. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - WATER CONSERVATION 
 
Sec. 56-152. - Water conservation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to occupy or use any newly constructed or remodeled building or premises or to use the equipment hereinafter set forth unless the following requirements have been met that: 
(1)  All new water services shall be metered. 
(2)  All existing unmetered services shall be metered as part of any major remodeling. 
(3)  In all new construction and in all repair or replacement of fixtures based upon a pressure at the fixture of 40 to 50 psi, the following water efficient plumbing fixtures shall be installed: 
Fixtures 	Maximum Flow 
Water closets, tank type 	3.5 gal/flush 
Water closets, flushometer type 	3.0 gal/flush 
Urinals, tank type 	3.0 gal/flush 
Urinals, flushometer type 	3.0 gal/flush 
Shower heads 	3.0 gal/minute 
Lavatory, sink faucets 	3.0 gal/minute 
 
(4)  In all new construction and in all new remodeling, a closed system air conditioning shall be required. 
(5)  All lavatories for public use in new construction, closing faucets. 
(6)  All newly constructed or remodeled carwash installations shall be equipped with a water recycling system. 
(Code 1964, § 28-16; Ord. No. 1977-20, § 4, 6-27-1977; Ord. No. 1981-14, 04-13-1981)  
Sec. 56-153. - Nonessential water uses; lawn watering restricted; authority for additional restrictions. 
(a)  The use of water from the village water system for purposes of sprinkling or watering lawns, or filling swimming pools, or the noncommercial washing of cars is, in emergency situations, adverse to the health, safety, and welfare of the residents of the village. For the purpose of this section, the term "lawn" shall be that portion of any land under cultivation with grass, trees, shrubs, bushes or types of vegetation not occupied by the principal building or accessory building. The village manager is empowered to determine if other uses not specified herein are nonessential. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful, during the period beginning May 15, to and including September 15, of each year, for any person to use water from the village water system to water lawns on any day between the hours of noon and 6:00 p.m. or at any time on consecutive days. 
(c)  The village manager is hereby authorized and empowered to further restrict the nonessential use of water from the village water system in order to conserve the supply of water in the village. The village manager shall publish said restrictions and the restrictions are effective upon publication. 
(Code 1964, § 28-17; Ord. No. 1978-38-1, § A, 10-8-1978; Ord. No. 1988-14, 6-13-1988; Ord. No. 1989-13, 5-8-1989; Ord. No. 95-38, 9-25-1995; Ord. No. 2015-63, § 2 , 9-28-2015)  
Sec. 56-154. - Notice to village board and board action. 
Following publication of the emergency restrictions, the village manager shall advise the village board of the restrictions implemented and the reason for their implementation. The village board, at the earliest opportunity thereafter, shall enact such ordinances deemed necessary to conserve the village's supply of water, at which time the emergency restrictions shall be deemed to have expired. 
(Code 1964, § 28-17; Ord. No. 1978-38-1, § A, 10-8-1978; Ord. No. 1988-14, 6-13-1988; Ord. No. 1989-13, 5-8-1989; Ord. No. 95-38, 9-25-1995)  
Sec. 56-155. - Penalties. 
Any person who uses water in violation of this division or in violation of the emergency water conservation ordinances hereafter enacted by the village board shall be fined not less than $25.00 or more than $100.00 for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1964, § 28-17; Ord. No. 1978-38-1, § A, 10-8-1978; Ord. No. 1988-14, 6-13-1988; Ord. No. 1989-13, 5-8-1989; Ord. No. 95-38, 9-25-1995)  
Secs. 56-156—56-178. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - WATER COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 56-179. - Established by legislative act; purpose. 
The Brookfield-North Riverside Water Commission is establishing a common source of supply of water for the village and the village of North Riverside from Chicago, and to service other areas by contract, such commission being established under an Act entitled, "An Act to provide for the joint acquisition and operation of a waterworks system or common source of supply of water, or both, by certain cities, villages or incorporated towns, and authorizing the issuance of bonds for such acquisition, and for improvements, and extensions thereto, secured only by the revenues derived from the operation thereof," approved July 6, 1935." 
(Code 1940, §§ 37.007, 37.008(28-2); Code 1964, § 28-2; Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 1, 2, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1977-20, § 1, 6-27-1977)  
Sec. 56-180. - Appointment of local commissioner. 
(a)  The president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint a commissioner to such water commission, such commissioner so appointed to serve for a term of six years or until his successor has been duly appointed and qualified. 
(b)  Any commissioner so appointed by the president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall be eligible for reappointment upon the expiration of his term, but any person who shall have held any elective office in the village shall not be eligible for an appointment as such commissioner until one year from the expiration of his term for which he was last elected. 
(Code 1940, §§ 37.007, 37.008(28-2); Code 1964, § 28-2; Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 1, 2, 12-23-1968; Ord. No. 1977-20, § 1, 6-27-1977)  
Secs. 56-181—56-198. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - SEWER  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 56-199. - Adoption of manual of procedures for processing sewer permits. 
The Manual of Procedures for the Administration of the Sewer Permit Ordinance (revised May 27, 1970) and adopted by the trustees of the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater Chicago on September 3, 1970, and the whole thereof of which not less than three copies have been and now are on file in the office of the clerk, is and the same is adopted as an integral part of the procedures of the administration for sanitary sewer permits. 
(Code 1964, § 28-37.01; Ord. No. 1971-5, § 1, 4-12-1971)  
Sec. 56-200. - Outhouses, thunderboxes privies, and vault connections to sewer prohibited; privies near streets, dwellings, shops or wells. 
(a)  Outhouses, thunderboxes or privies shall not be constructed in the village nor shall any old vault be connected to a village sewer. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any outhouse, thunderbox or privy within the village 
(Code 1940, §§ 26.001(15)(28-6), 40.031(28-5); Code 1964, §§ 28-35, 28-36; Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 7, 8, 12-23-1968)  
Sec. 56-201. - Certain connections to storm drains or sewers prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to connect or cause to be connected any drain carrying or to carry any toilet, sink, basement, septic tank, cesspool or industrial waste, or any fixture or device discharging polluting substance, to any stormwater drain or storm sewer in the village. 
(Code 1964, § 28-37; Ord. of 3-26-1956, § 1(28-7); Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 7, 8, 12-23-1968)  
Sec. 56-202. - Building wall openings; overhead sewers. 
(a)  The elevation of sewers, door sills, window sills, well openings in the village shall be in accordance with the requirements of the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater Chicago and the flood control regulations of the village. 
(b)  When the building wall encloses open space that is below the floodplain elevation, low level gravity building drain connections are prohibited and overhead sewers are required. 
(c)  All new buildings with basements, floors, rooms or occupancy areas below ground level at the building site and served by a public or private sewer system shall have overhead plumbing. 
(d)  No building permit application will be accepted nor any permits issued for construction of any structure unless plans and specifications therefor provide for such overhead plumbing. 
(Code 1964, § 28-37.2; Ord. No. 1971-5, § 1, 4-12-1971; Ord. No. 1977-20, § 11, 6-27-1977)  
Sec. 56-203. - Certain drains prohibited. 
Roof drains, foundation footing drains, paring and paved lot or area drains, groundwater drains or surface water connections to the sanitary sewer system are strictly forbidden in all areas. 
(Code 1964, § 28-37.03; Ord. No. 1971-5, § 1, 4-12-1971)  
Sec. 56-204. - Foot drain specifications. 
Footing drains shall be connected to sump pumps for further discharge into storm sewer or drainage ditches. 
(Code 1964, § 28-37.03; Ord. No. 1971-5, § 1, 4-12-1971)  
Sec. 56-205. - Maintenance and repair of sewer service pipe. 
It shall be the responsibility of the property owner to maintain and repair the sewer service pipe, servicing the building of the property owner, including the junction with the village main sewer. 
(Code 1964, § 28-38; Ord. of 8-31-1964, § 2(28-7.1); Ord. No. 1968-43, §§ 7, 8, 12-23-1968)  
Secs. 56-206—56-233. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - SEWER CONNECTIONS 
 
Sec. 56-234. - Persons authorized to tap or connect to water system. 
No person, except an authorized agent of the department of public works and services or a licensed plumber or drain layer, acting under the supervision of such department, shall tap or make any connections with the sewer mains in the village. 
(Code 1964, § 28-39; Ord. No. 1968-43, § 9, 12-23-1968)  
Sec. 56-235. - Connections required. 
(a)  Each premises in the village creating sewage waste shall be independently and separately connected by a separate sewer service pipe with a public sanitary sewer if such sanitary sewer adjoins the lot or parcel of land on which the premises stands or where such sanitary sewer is located not less than 200 feet from the nearest lot line of said property. 
(b)  No permit shall be issued for the construction of any building in the village where there is a public sanitary sewer adjoining such lot or parcel, unless the plans and specifications show connections in compliance with this article. 
(c)  Every premises in existence prior to the construction of a public sanitary sewer and located not more than 200 feet from the nearest lot line of said property on which the premises stands shall, upon the construction of such public sanitary sewer, and after written notice, be connected to said sanitary sewer within one year of notice, provided that if said premises is serviced by a septic tank system which ceases to function properly so that its continued operation constitutes a nuisance or menace to health, said building shall be connected to the adjoining public sanitary sewer immediately. 
(Code 1964, § 28-40; Ord. of 12-23-1958, § 8; Ord. No. 95-48, 11-14-1995)
